The economic merger takes place July 1, when the West German mark becomes East Germany's currency and East Germany abandons its communist economics for Western capitalism. ``All in all, it's a good chance for the west part of Germany to continue its performance,'' said Ulrich Hombrecher, an economist at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale in Duesseldorf. A report by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research in Britain said the merger is ``likely to provide a renewed stimulus to the West German economy.'' The union will enlarge West Germany's economy by an estimated 5 to 10 percent, but few statistics are available on the East German economy. ``We have so little information about the East German businesses and economy,'' Hombrecher. ``It really is a problem.'' West Germany already benefits from East German demand for its cars and consumer electronics, and consumer spending is likely to increase after East German savings are converted into West German marks. Experts say unification could help Germany sustain growth at the current West German level of above 3 percent, but no one has any real idea how much the East Germans will buy. ``That is one of the great unknowns at the moment,'' said Mark Houghton-Berry, executive director of foreign exchange trading at Goldman Sachs and Co. in London. Business investment should rise and West Germany will gain cheaper East German labor, which should slow wage increases and boost corporate profits, the experts predict. Inflation is the big fear. The rate in West Germany is an enviable 2.3 percent, but printing new deutsche marks to convert East German marks will swell the West Germany money supply by 10 percent. A larger money supply does not disturb Stephen King, international economist with the London investment firm James Capel and Co.. ``You need the 10 percent ... to cope with the 10 percent added in GNP,'' he said. Another risk for West Germany is higher interest rates, now at 8 to 9 percent. Its central bank, the Bundesbank, is expected to continue a tight monetary policy, but rates could be pushed higher by large demands for credit to rebuild the East. Hombrecher predicts monetary unification will add 1 percent to West German economic growth, inflation will move up to 3.5 percent and interest rates will rise to just over 9 percent. He sees the $80 billion trade surplus shrinking by 7 percent and the $50 billion budget deficit soaring by 30 percent. Higher taxes might be necessary to finance East Germany's reconstruction and povide help for the unemployed, whose ranks are sure to swell. Estimates of how many East German jobs will be lost range from 300,000 to 3 million. The actual number has risen so far this year from 20,000 to 130,000. Hombrecher predicts unemployment will reach 11 percent. West Germany's rate is a low 6.3 percent. Direct West German aid to the East is expected to be about $20 billion a year in the near future. East Germans can expect cheaper durable goods; construction, retail and wholesale sectors and tourism could flourish; factories will get the newest technology, and roads will be rebuilt. In the beginning, East German prices for housing, food and public transport are expected to rise because state subsidies have kept them artificially low. Some East Germans worry about Westerners snapping up state-owned businesses, property and workers cheaply. East Germans earn one-third to half the average West German monthly wage of $2,020, but West German productivity is three times as high.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a thumbnail of the economic sanctions imposed on South Africa by legislation passed in 1986 and still in effect.

FINANCIAL A ban on all new public and private loans and investments in South Africa, except for reinvesting profits from South African enterprises, short-term credits and rescheduling of existing debt. The ban exempts loans and credits for education, housing or humanitarian projects and investments in firms owned by black South Africans. Disinvestment, or withdrawal of existing loans or investments, was not required.
IMPORTS U.S. imports of South African iron, steel, arms, ammunition, military vehicles and farm products are prohibited. There also is a ban on uranium, coal and textiles.

EXPORTS Exports of petroleum products, crude oil, munitions or nuclear technology or materials to South Africa are prohibited as are exports of computers, software and services to the South African military, police or others involved in administering the apartheid system of racial separation.
AIRLINES South Africa Airways is not allowed to land in the United States and no U.S. air carriers are allowed to serve South Africa.

OTHER PROVISIONS U.S. government agencies are prohibited from buying goods and services from South Africa, promoting tourism to South Africa, promoting or subsidizing trade with South Africa or cooperating with the South African military except for intelligence-gathering activities.
PENALTIES Corporations are subject to maximum $1 million fines for each violation of the sanctions legislation. Individuals can be fined up to $50,000 and imprisoned up to five years.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Halts Nationwide Raids To Hit Public-Housing Drug Dealers
DOC.TEXT: A ruling by a federal judge is leaving in limbo a plan to crack down on accused drug dealers nationwide by throwing them out of public housing they rent. Federal marshals had been poised in 22 cities today to raid apartments in housing projects where the lessor is a suspected drug dealer who faces possible prosecution for at least two felonies. But in a ruling issued late Friday, U.S. District Judge Richard L. Williams ordered the federal government to give tenants ``proper notice and an opportunity to be heard in court'' before seizing their leases. His initial order, earlier in the week, had applied only to the Richmond area. The judge's expanded order left the plan in limbo. The New York Times quoted Frank Keating, general counsel for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, as saying agency officials had yet to discuss what to do in light of the order. He said they considered filing an emergency appeal today. ``Even if officials did not immediately evict the targeted tenants, they could be arrested and put on notice they were in peril of losing their housing,'' Keating was quoted as saying in the Times' Monday editions. ``If it was up to me, I think we should go in and make these arrests and crack in there.'' Under the program first announced last month by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, the tenant and his or her family could be kicked out of the apartment even if the person has not yet been convicted of a drug crime. The government calls the actions ``leasehold forfeitures'' _ not evictions. The plan already has stirred up a legal challenge in one city. The forfeiture of public-housing leases by such accused drug dealers is specifically authorized by asset-forfeiture provisions of the 1988 Anti-Drug Abuse Act, government officials say. The same provisions enable federal prosecutors to seize boats, cars and cash of drug dealers awaiting trial. In this case, the lease is the asset to be seized. The raids were scheduled to be conducted in cities where authorities have identified drug dealing in housing projects as a significant problem. The targeted housing projects were in some of the nation's largest cities _ New York, Los Angeles, Chicago _ as well as smaller municipalities such as Chandler, Ariz., Tacoma, Wash., and Frederick, Md., according to a list obtained by The Associated Press. Bob Nipp, a spokesman for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, declined to comment on the planned raids. When Kemp first announced the plan, he declined to identify the cities where housing projects would be raided. Civil libertarians have criticized the planned raids, saying they would violate the principle that a person is innocent of criminal wrongdoing until proven guilty. Under guidelines adopted by HUD and the Justice Department, only apartments that are notorious and open sites of drug distribution and leased by known drug dealers would have been raided, officials said. The guidelines also state that authorities should have ``proof beyond a reasonable doubt'' that the leaseholder committed at least two felony drug crimes and will face prosecution, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It was not known whether authorities also planned to serve search warrants to seek possible evidence of drug activity. The plan called for using local social service agencies to relocate children and elderly people who would have be displaced from their homes by the raids, officials said. Among the other cities in which public housing was targeted were: Washington; Atlanta; Dallas; Baltimore; Hartford, Conn.; Newark, N.J.; Indianapolis; Flint, Mich.; Charleston, S.C.; Macon, Ga.; El Paso, Texas; Omaha; Portland, Ore.; and St. Louis, Mo.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela Wows Church Crowd
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Winnie Mandela's first event in the nation's capital was at a church that greatly influenced her grandmother's views on apartheid. Mrs. Mandela told a wildly cheering crowd in the historic Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church on Sunday that the AME denomination was ``one of the first churches in our country.'' ``My grandmother was a worshipper in the AME church. She told me it was the only church that did not practice apartheid,'' she said, noting that the AME continues to be involved in blacks' struggle for freedom in South Africa. Mrs. Mandela accompanied her husband, Nelson, to Washington as part of his eight-city U.S. tour. She had struggled to keep alive the anti-apartheid movement during the 27 years he was imprisoned in South Africa. ``I look forward to the day when we can hoist the flag'' of the African National Congress, she said, standing next to an ANC flag of green, black and gold. The Metropolitan AME church was used by black leaders such as Frederick Douglass and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to sway support for the U.S. civil rights struggle. When Mrs. Mandela arrived at the church, the crowd roared and began chanting ``Man-del-a.'' They shouted support when she implored them, ``We need your prayers'' for the struggle for freedom by black South Africans. They burst into wild laughter, applause and cheers when she said, ``We need you to help us, teach us how you tolerated racism.'' She said the ANC was peaceful until forced to violence by the South African government and that its leaders are ``speaking a peace language'' again. But she stressed that ``it is not easy to walk that path of peace'' because many of the younger people are ready for immediate change. With her remarks constantly interrupted by applause, Mrs. Mandela said the ANC wants to negotiate with President F.W. de Klerk from a ``position of strength. We want him to know that we got your footsteps behind us.'' The occasion was women's day at the church, and a number of women addressed the crowd during the more than three hours they waited for Mrs. Mandela to arrive. The program also included Jacqueline L. Jackson, wife of civil rights activist Jesse Jackson; Effi Barry, wife of Washington Mayor Marion Barry, and Sister Bernard Ncube, president of Federation of Transvaal Women, who herself was imprisoned for one year in solitary confinement in 1986. ``We were just honoring women and clearly she (Mrs. Mandela) was one we wanted to honor,'' said the Rev. William P. DeVeaux, the pastor at Metropolitan. Methodist AME Church is popularly called The National Church or the Cathedral of African Methodism. Its leaders headed the anti-slavery campaigns in the 19th century and the church was a stop on the underground railroad. Recently, it has hosted ANC news conferences.

DOC.HEAD: Police Commissioner Warns More Arabs Could Be Killed
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Israel-Soviet Jews, Bjt ^By ALLYN FISHER
DOC.TEXT: The national police commander says ``Israel will respond with severity'' and more Palestinians could be killed if stone-throwing riots persist in Arab areas of Jerusalem. Late Sunday, police lifted a three-day curfew on three Arab sections of the city after an appeal from Mayor Teddy Kollek, a political moderate. The 20,000 Palestinian residents of the Jerusalem neighborhoods of Silwan, Abu Tor and Ras el-Amud were placed under curfew after rioting last week in which two Palestinians were shot to death by police. Also Sunday, Defense Minister Moshe Arens approved the formation of civil guard units made up of Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank, a move condemned by some as certain to fuel violence between settlers and Arabs. The moves came amid increasing friction between Jews and Arabs in Jerusalem and in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Police spokesman Uzi Sandouri said about 45 suspected rioters were detained during the curfew. Police commissioner Yaacov Turner said Sunday that if rioting persists, ``We will respond with severity. ... There are limits to a capability to exercise restraint. ``If those who live in Abu Tor, Ras el-Amud and Silwan don't catch the idea that there is a limit and ... if they don't absorb this, then the significance will be that there will be more killed,'' Turner said. Incidents of violence have increased between Jews and Arabs in east Jerusalem, annexed by Israel after its capture along with the West Bank and Gaza in the 1967 Middle East war. On Sunday, 200 Israelis hurled stones at homes in the Arab village of Dahyat Al-Barid and at cars driven by Arabs after Palestinians stoned an Israeli bus on its way to the nearby Jewish suburb of Neve Yaacov. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd, police reports and Israel radio said. The radio said at least 10 protesters were detained. The intensity of violence has been unusual for Jerusalem, which has been calmer than the West Bank and Gaza during the 30-month Palestinian uprising. Of the 719 Palestinians killed by Israelis during the revolt, eight have been from Jerusalem. At least six of the 45 Israeli victims have been killed in Jerusalem. Jerusalem is home to about 300,000 Jews and 140,000 Arabs. There are 1.7 million Palestinians and 70,000 Jewish settlers in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Drown Out Sullivan Speech at AIDS Conference
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: After a week of protests on the streets outside a world conference on AIDS, activists took their complaints indoors and drowned out the closing speech by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. Sullivan delivered his 20-minute address at the Sixth International AIDS Conference as several hundred protesters Sunday pelted him with wads of paper, blew whistles and air horns and shouted, ``No more words! We want action!'' ``It's too bad his speech wasn't heard, but it was important that he was here,'' said Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the government's top AIDS researcher. Rose Okello, a health educator from Uganda who attended the conference, said, ``The secretary did what he had to do and the activists did well in expressing their concerns. It was a form of dialogue.'' Sullivan's speech at the Moscone Center closed the five-day conference attended by more than 10,000 scientists and public officials from around the world. Thousands of activists had also converged on San Francisco for demonstrations against government policies on AIDS. Nearly 300 were arrested in protests outside the convention hall. Activists have accused the government of dragging out efforts to find new treatments and offer them to people infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Demonstrators didn't disrupt conference sessions until Sunday, the same day as San Francisco's annual Gay-Lesbian Freedom Day, celebrated by thousands of marchers. It was one of many gay-pride observances around the country Sunday. With a line of police standing between the podium and fist-shaking protesters, Sullivan asked for ``cooperation, tolerance, understanding and caring.'' ``We must find the ways and means to work together for the benefit of people with AIDS and HIV infection throughout the world,'' he said. Demonstrators stood on chairs at the front of the big conference hall, chanting, ``Get off the stage!'' Todd Weisse, a member of the New York Chapter of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, was in the front row of the protesters. ``Our purpose was to stop the administration's empty rhetoric,'' he said. ``Louis Sullivan has the power to do something much more than is being done,'' he said. One item in Sullivan's speech might have won applause from protesters had they heard it: Sullivan's opposition to legislation that would let employers fire workers in the food service industry who are infected with the AIDS virus. Many attending the final meeting were upset by the disruption. ``Thank you for supporting free speech!'' one delegate shouted at protesters as they left the hall. ``It's sad,'' said Dr. James Curran, head of the AIDS program at the Centers for Disease Control. ``It's an example of the fragmentation of the efforts that I most fear in the 1990s, sick versus well, gay versus straight.'' But Fauci said the demonstration would not interfere with growing cooperation between scientists and activists. ``There has been a movement of people who realize both sides have a lot to contribute,'' he said. Activists have persuaded federal regulators to let infected people take experimental AIDS drugs even before they are approved for routine use. Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and head of the federal Office of AIDS Research, was warmly received in his closing speech before the same audience. ``Activists are mistaken when they assume, or at least publicly state, that scientists do not care about them,'' he told the gathering. ``Most scientists care deeply and are employing all of their energies and talents to accomplish the same goals as the activists are trying to accomplish.'' Fauci outlined research objectives for the decade and noted that several promising new drugs are being tested. In another closing speech, Dr. Lars O. Kallings of Stockholm, president of the International AIDS Society, attacked laws restricting travel by people infected with the AIDS virus as ``shameful.'' He blamed ``political bigotry.'' Kallings did not specifically mention the United States, which has restrictions on AIDS-infected visitors. Because of those rules, the international society has threatened to cancel the next international AIDS conference planned in this country, the 1992 meeting in Boston. Sullivan did not mention the immigration policy.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Rally at White House for Child Care Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred adults and children rallied in a park across the street from the White House on Sunday to protest the slow progress in getting federal child care assistance legislation enacted. ``Working families are weary of campaign promises that vow to help America's families only to see those promises go unfulfilled,'' Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, told the gathering. The rally took on a festive atmosphere as red, green and yellow balloons were distributed to youngsters, many of whom munched on ice cream bars donated for the event. Several clowns and a juggler performed for the youngsters, along with volunteer who told children's stories and sang children's songs. Ms. Edelman said the rally was intended for families to ``have some fun together on a Sunday afternoon,'' but she also focused on the more serious concerns many parents have about inadequate child care. More than half the mothers of children under 2 work outside the home and millions of parents have a hard time getting proper day care for their children ``yet the men in Congress and in the White House are still dickering about technicalities'' on a child care assistance bill, she said. The House and Senate have agreed on parts of a $1.75 billion child care assistance bill, but differences remain on some elements dealing with tax credits.
DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Defends Administration's Attack on S&L Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Sunday fired back at critics who say the Bush administration is not moving aggressively to ferret out savings and loan fraud. ``We're going after savings and loans crooks, whether they're Republicans or Democrats, North, South, East and West. And we've compiled ... a very impressive record on that score,'' Thornburgh said during an appearance on the CBS-TV program ``Face the Nation.'' His comments came as Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said it was time for Democrats and Republicans to stop trying to affix blame for the S&L scandal and concentrate on catching culprits. Brady, appearing on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program, agreed with members of Congress who have said the focus should shift from finger pointing to prosecuting S&L industry officials who violated the laws. ``What the American people want is a dedicated, organized, calm approach to cleaning up the problem (and) ... make sure to prosecute the criminals involved,'' Brady said. Brady recently revised the Bush administration's estimate on the cost of the savings and loan bailout to as high as $130 billion. Members of Congress have criticized the slow pace of prosecutions in the saving and loans scandal. But administration officials have said the investigations of financial mismanagement and fraud are extremely complicated and will take time to resolve.
DOC.HEAD: Fletcher Says He Can't Persuade Bush To Accept Civil Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission says he had been unable to persuade President Bush that a proposed civil rights bill would not lead to racial hiring quotas. But Arthur Fletcher said he hoped Bush would back away from a threat to veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990 unless it is modified. Fletcher, who appeared on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program with Jesse Jackson, was asked whether he believed Bush would veto the legislation, Fletcher responded, ``I hope not.'' But he added ``I can't tell you what the president is going to do.'' The bill is designed to overcome a series of Supreme Court decisions last year that made it more difficult for workers to sue employers for alleged job discrimination. But the Bush administration has sought changes in the measure. The bill may be brought up for Senate consideration this week. A similar version still awaits Judiciary Committee approval before being cleared for debate in the House. The administration has claimed that the bill, as drafted, would in effect force businesses to resort to hiring quotas to reduce their exposure to lawsuits. Backers deny that the bill requires quotas, either directly or indirectly. The White House has said it is willing to compromise, although some Republican leaders have expressed doubts that an accord can be reached. But Fletcher, appointed by Bush in February, said the commission voted 7-1 last week to support the legislation. However, the commission wants included a statement that there is no intention to force quotas. Fletcher said he had tried to convince administration officials that the bill as drafted would not do so. ``I obviously haven't convinced them yet, but ... we don't know the language in the bill yet. When we finally see what that says, we'll know whether there is a propensity for quotas or not,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Troop Withdrawal From Eastern Europe Causes Housing Crunch
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The withdrawal of thousands of Soviet troops from Eastern Europe has exacerbated a housing crunch back home, further lowering morale in a demoralized officer corps and causing friction with local authorities. Soviet authorities had planned to relocate many of the troops in the Byelorussian republic, which borders Poland. But that plan has upset local authorities who already face problems housing families evacuated from their homes after the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear accident. ``It is astonishing ... that the decision to relocate troops to Byelorussia was made without an agreement with the leadership of Byelorussia,'' the Soviet army newspaper Red Star said in its Saturday editions under the headline: ``Where will the officers live?'' The eventual withdrawal of more than 500,000 Soviet troops from Eastern Europe, initiated by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's two years ago and accelerated by the collapse of Communist regimes in the region, has created a housing crunch that worries top generals. The sudden need to house more returning troops has run smack into a national shortage of civilian apartments and homes, retired Maj. Gen. Ivan Lebedev said in an interview. ``It is one of the most complicated questions'' facing the military, Lebedev said, and is making it harder to attract young men into the officer corps. The corps already faces a shrinking budget, weapons cuts, pacifist movements in the Baltic and Caucasian republics, and criticism in the press. Defense Minister Marshal Dmitri T. Yazov, in a June 3 article on military reform published in the Communist Party daily Pravda, cited housing of relocated troops as one of the major tasks in wider military reforms. The families of about 173,000 Soviet officers lack adequate housing, and the withdrawal of more troops from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland will create problems for 25,000 more families, Pravda quoted Col. N. Karasyev as saying. It identified him as director of social sciences for the main political directorate of the Soviet army and navy. ``This figure helps explain the following fact: in the current year, 17,500 officers applied to resign from the Armed Services, and analysis has shown that they were far from the worst officers,'' deputy director of military cadres Col. Gen. V.F. Arapov was quoted as saying in the June 13 edition of Red Star. The Red Star report did not suggest that housing problems will interfere with the military pullout that began with Gorbachev's announcement in December 1988 that he planned to withdraw 10 percent of the estimated 565,000 Soviet troops stationed in other Warsaw Pact countries. In the last six months, the pace of the pullout has quickened as both Hungary and Czechoslovakia have demanded the withdrawal of all 120,000 Soviet troops from their territory by mid-1991 _ and have indicated they might pull out of the Kremlin-led Warsaw Pact. Of 50,000 troops stationed in Hungary at the beginning of the year, more than 20,000 have been withdrawn, with the last to be pulled out over the next 12 months, the state news agency Tass quoted the commander of the forces, Col. Gen. Matveei Burlakov as saying in a dispatch Sunday. An even bigger crunch is expected after German unification with the anticipated gradual pullout of the 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany. Poland is also expected to demand the withdrawal of the 40,000 Soviet troops from its territory once its fears about German unification are put to rest. The returning troops are not exactly being welcomed with open arms. On Thursday, the commander of the Byelorussian military district, Col. Gen. A. Kostenko, met with local deputies to the national legislature and members of the parliamentary commission on defense and national security. He was told that regional authorities could not find room for the dislocated soldiers, Red Star reported. The Byelorussian leaders told Soviet lawmakers ``that there was a complicated housing situation in the republic. Thousands of families suffering from the tragedy at the Chernobyl Atomic Energy Station are awaiting relocation from the disaster zone.'' One of four reactors at Chernobyl, in the northern Ukraine, suffered a partial meltdown in late April 1986 and winds carried the radiation across Byelorussia, forcing the evacuation of thousands of residents. Many still await permanent housing.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,124.19, down 570.38 points, or 1.80 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Poised to Take Over Game Management in Much of State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Legislature convenes at 2 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Rural Alaskans' cherished right to live off the land is at the center of a dispute that has the federal government ready to take over game management in most of the state. Because of an Alaska Supreme Court ruling that put state and federal laws at odds, the government plans to assume responsibility for game management July 1 in the two-thirds of the state it owns. In hopes of regaining control, the Legislature was to convene in special session today to consider an amendment to the constitution that would ensure rural Alaskans continue to have first crack at fish and game for subsistence. An amendment must pass both houses of the Legislature by a two-thirds margin and be put to the voters, a process that could take months or years. Gov. Steve Cowper, a Democrat, and U.S. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, met with lawmakers Sunday to seek support for the amendment. An estimated 110,000 Alaskans venture into the wild to hunt, fish and gather plants for food. For less than half of them _ Indians, Aleuts and Eskimos _ it's ``the core of their existence,'' said Julie Kitka, president of the Alaska Federation of Natives. The dispute began in December when the Alaska Supreme Court ruled that part of a state law that limits subsistence activities to rural residents discriminates against urbanites. But a federal law, passed in 1980, requires a rural preference. Five federal land agencies plan to assume game management of Alaska's federal land to protect the rural subsistence right. The takeover is expected to lead to confusion among hunters faced with differing regulations on Alaska's patchwork of public lands. ``It's the worst jigsaw you can imagine,'' said Bruce Batten, spokesman for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with closing Nikkei, dollar, bonds. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed sharply lower Monday, reflecting higher prices for the dollar against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average plunged 570.38 points, or 1.80 percent, to 31,124.19 points, following Friday's loss of 392.70 points. Volume on the first section was estimated at 300 million shares. ``(The fall) is mainly because of the yen's weakness and a loss last Friday on the New York market,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. Although participants have few buying incentives, the market is gradually calming down, he said. The dollar closed at 155.62 yen, up from Friday's finish of 154.75 yen. It started the day trading higher at 155.53 yen, and saw a high of 155.75 and low of 155.42 during the day. ``We saw selling even to the 150 level, so the customers are interested to sell dollars. There was also some profit-taking,'' said Masato Hayashi, chief customer dealer at the Bank of Tokyo. Account settlements also contributed to dollar demand. But trading in dollars was ``flat'' compared to trading in European currencies, pending more news about the yen, he added. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell slightly to 86.92 points by mid-afternoon from its 87.18-point finish last Friday. The yield was higher at 7.20 percent, from 7.145 percent.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
BEIJING: American Embassy.
DOC.TEXT: The official Xinhua News Agency said Fang, an astrophysicist, and his wife Li Shuxian had been ``given lenient treatment'' by the government and allowed to leave the country for medical treatment. The report did not say where the couple had gone or when they left China. The U.S. Embassy had no immediate comment.

DOC.HEAD: Tons of Relief Supplies Arriving, But Distribution Difficult
With PM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Planes loaded with food, medicine and tents are converging on earthquake-stricken Iran from around the world, among them the first private American relief mission to the country in more than a decade. Authorities now are faced with the difficult task of getting supplies into the affected areas. More than 60 aftershocks jolted the quake zone in northwestern Iran on Sunday, triggering landslides along one key relief route. Tehran radio said Sunday that 68 relief aircraft had landed at Tehran's Mehrabad airport during a 24-hour period. Among them was a plane carrying medicine and other supplies from the United States. Another plane carrying U.S. government aid was due today. The shipment that arrived Sunday was the first of its kind to be accepted by Iran since the hostage crisis of 1979-80, when 52 Americans were held at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Two countries that also have suffered devastating earthquakes in recent years, the Soviet Union and Mexico, were among those sending assistance to help victims of Thursday's quake. Leaders of Iran's Arab neighbors, including Iraq, which waged an eight-year war with Iran, issued statements of sympathy and support. Pope John Paul II called on the international community to help earthquake victims, asking for ``a real and generous demonstration of solidarity with our brothers. Let us pray that their suffering is alleviated.'' The Vatican was among the many international donors. Eleven planes from West Germany ferried in 145 tons of supplies plus a field hospital with two medical teams. Nine flights arrived from Turkey. The Spanish Red Cross sent medicines and food; India sent medicine. The Austrian Red Cross shipped tents, blankets and medicine. Bernard Kouchner, the French secretary of state for humanitarian action, arrived in Iran on Sunday to coordinate French assistance and evaluate future needs, Radio France Inter said. The French government has sent a civil defense team of 195 people and 18 search dogs along with at least 24 tons of equipment. The Saudi-based 46-member Organization of the Islamic Conference, an umbrella organization for the world's estimated one billion Moslems, issued an ``urgent appeal to the international community and especially Islamic countries and organizations to hasten with emergency aid for the Iranians ...'' AmeriCares, a private U.S. relief organization based in New Canaan, Conn., flew in the 42 tons pounds of supplies that arrived Sunday. ``To be on the ground here in Tehran is a very special feeeling for us,'' said Stephen M. Johnson, president of AmeriCares. A spokeswoman for the U.S. Agency for International Development said a Red Cross charter flight carrying $225,000 worth of supplies donated by the U.S. government would arrive in Tehran this morning. Iran is believed to have influence with the Shiite Moslem extremists holding 16 Western hostages, including six Americans, in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The Soviet Union sent in medical teams and supplies from Soviet republics bordering Iran. More than 200 medical personnel arrived from the Soviet Union, which also sent medical supplies, trucks, trailers, ambulances, cranes, buses and water tankers. The December 1988 earthquake in Soviet Armenia left at least 25,000 people dead. Mexico, which lost at least 10,000 people in a 1985 earthquake, is sending food, medical supplies and blankets, officials said Sunday. In Lebanon, the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, said its members were donating 10 percent of their salaries to help the victims. That would amount to about $500,000, according to Hezbollah sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Alabama Democrats Wage Caustic Campaign for Nomination
DOC.TEXT: Closing out a short and caustic campaign, teacher-lobbyist Paul Hubbert and Attorney General Don Siegelman meet on Tuesday in a Democratic runoff for the right to challenge Republican Gov. Guy Hunt. Hubbert led a six-candidate field in the June 5 primary with 32 percent of the vote. Siegelman, who got 25 percent as the runner-up, has sought to close the gap with negative ads. ``If there was a law that guaranteed truth in advertising in a political campaign, then Don Siegelman would be on his way to jail,'' said Hubbert. The candidates have accused each other of racist tactics. Siegelman has depicted his opponent as a man opening classroom doors to child molesters, while Hubbert has exploited Siegelman's admission he smoked marijuana in college. Whoever wins the Democratic nomination, once tantamount to winning the governor's office in a state long dominated by the Democratic Party, will merely earn a long-shot chance against Hunt. Hunt, a preacher-farmer who in 1986 became Alabama's first GOP governor in 112 years thanks to a split in Democratic ranks, is favored in the polls over either Hubbert or Siegelman. A poll commissioned by The Anniston Star and published Friday had Hubbert leading Siegelman 46 percent to 41 percent, with 13 percent undecided. The poll had a margin of error of 4.6 points. Hubbert, 54, has been executive secretary of the Alabama Education Association for 21 years. He has built the teacher organization into one of the most influential forces at the Statehouse. Siegelman, 44, a former executive director of the Alabama Democratic Party, was state manager of George McGovern's 1972 presidential campaign. He won two terms as secretary of state and then the attorney general's office in 1986. Hubbert has come under fire because the teachers union offered representation to a teacher charged with molesting boys in Tennessee. The teacher later was convicted. It is union policy to offer legal help to members. Both candidates have strong support from black voters and are considered racial progressives. Blacks make up about 25 percent of the voters. Siegelman, however, said Hubbert used ``racist code words'' in calling for a workfare program to replace welfare, while Hubbert's camp said a Siegelman ad warning about a black leader's influence amounted to ``racist tactics.'' The black leader is Joe Reed, head of the state's oldest black caucus and the No. 2 man behind Hubbert at the teachers union. Reed's group endorsed Hubbert. During the three-week runoff, Siegelman accused Hubbert of making promises that would require the doubling of Alabama's $3.5 billion budget and the raising of $10 billion in new taxes over four years. Hubbert, alluding to Siegelman's use of marijuana, said the $10 billion claim makes one ``wonder what he was smoking'' to come up with such ``funny numbers.'' Siegelman supports a lottery and a timber tax to raise revenue. Hubbert said the state's problems can be solved with existing revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Scouts to Help Patrol Berkshires Town
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four young scouts with portable radios will help lay down the law here this summer by patrolling parks and checking on vacation homes. The Police Explorers, a program for law-minded Boy Scouts, have had a post in this Berkshires town since 1981, but questions over the community's liability kept the scouts off patrol except for a brief period in 1986. Last week, town selectmen agreed to reinstate the patrols after the post's adviser, police officer Richard Nicholas Jr., assured them the troop is now covered under the local scout council's $500,000 insurance policy. The 16 boys and eight girls ranging in age from 14 to 21 will keep an eye on vacation homes, patrol Main Street, parks and cemeteries and help out at special events. ``The idea is to give these young people, many of whom are planning careers in law enforcement or plan to attend law school, a chance to have some hands-on experience,'' said Lee Sneath, spokesman for the Boy Scouts of America, based in Irving, Texas. The scouts have more than 2,000 Police Explorer posts with 36,000 members nationwide, he said. Each post devises its own program. Some patrol and others are used for crowd and traffic control and police paperwork. Sneath said he knew of no other post whose activities were affected by liability problems. The scouts in Dalton, a town of about 8,000, won't replace police on their evening foot patrols, Nicholas said. ``They are to serve more as another set of eyes and ears,'' he said. ``Their main purpose is to curb vandalism and help out with such things as parking cars for events as long as they are off the road.'' The scouts will be issued radios so they can call police cruisers, Nicholas said. ``They have a very, very strict set of rules set up by me,'' he said. ``They are to avoid any confrontations and to use the radio and not get involved if they come upon something.''

DOC.HEAD: China's Best-Known Dissident Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to ADD U.S. Embassy comment, background on Fang. Picks up 9th pvs, `Xinhua said ...' ^By JIM ABRAMS
DOC.TEXT: China has allowed Fang Lizhi, its best-known dissident, to leave his year-long refuge in the U.S. Embassy and go to a foreign country, the official Xinhua news agency said Monday. The agency said Fang, a 53-year-old astrophysicist, and his wife Li Shuxian had been ``given lenient treatment'' by the government and allowed to leave the country for medical treatment. Fang was China's most outspoken and eloquent proponent of democratic reform. He and his wife fled into the U.S. Embassy shortly after the June 4, 1989 military attack that crushed the seven-week pro-democracy movement. Xinhua report did not say where the couple had gone or when they left China. The U.S. Embassy said it would have no comment until White House Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater made a formal announcement early Monday in Washington. ``But we're very happy,'' one diplomat said. Fang, 53, and Li had both been named in Chinese warrants that could have carried death sentences upon conviction. Fang's release removes a major thorn in U.S.-China relations, which have deteriorated badly since the military crackdown. Hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed in the assault on central Beijing and thousands of activists arrested in the months that followed. Fang and Li sought U.S. protection after being accused by the Communist government of inciting the student-led protests, in which they never played an active role. American diplomats refused to turn them over to Chinese authorities, exacerbating tensions between Beijing and Washington. To protest the crackdown, the United States imposed limited sanctions focusing on military and aviation equipment. However, U.S.-Chinese relations recently improved with the Bush administration decision last month to extend most-favored-nation trade status for another month. The U.S. Congress is now debating the issue. The Xinhua report said Fang and Li, a physicist, had met two conditions mentioned by Chinese leaders as conditions for their release _ that they admit in writing their anti-government activities and promise not to engage in anti-government activities after leaving China. Fang and Li well known for their advocacy of democracy and human rights in China well before last year's crackdown. Fang had led Chinese intellectuals in calling for release of political prisoners and asserting that economic and scientific progress is impossible without protections for free thought and expression. He also angered Chinese authorities by saying Marxism is dead. Xinhua said Fang and Li had recently written to the government admitting that they had opposed socialist principles, thus violating the country's constitution. ``In view of the signs of repentance by Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian and their illness and out of humanitarian considerations, the Beijing Public Security Bureau has decided to allow them to go abroad for medical treatment in line with China's polity of leniency towards those who participated in the disturbances.'' The report did not elaborate on their ``illness.'' Their son Fang Ke, a student at Wayne State University in Detroit, said earlier this month that his parents were in good spirits and continued their work within the U.S. Embassy. While at the embassy, Fang and Li declined to talk with reporters and the embassy refused to answer nearly all questions about them.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Other Daughter Watches Visit Unfold From TV Set
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's oldest daughter says she wasn't invited to share her father's triumphant visit to Boston, and she doesn't know why. Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah said her husband, Isaac, received a call Friday saying only he and the couple's three children were welcome at the festivities in honor of South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. ``So we decided not to go,'' Mandela-Amuah said in a telephone interview Sunday from her apartment in Amherst. She is a Fulbright scholar in anthropology at the University of Massachusetts. The 36-year-old daughter of Mandela's first marriage said she watched her father's entire visit on her living room TV set. She would not say who made the call. She said she was upset at not being able to see her father. ``Why can't my dad speak to me?'' she said. ``This is a whole strange story.'' ``If he's mad, he has never conveyed that to me,'' said Mandela-Amuah, who last saw her father in a prison visit last summer. Asked earlier whether Mandela had met or would meet with Mandela-Amuah, Colette Philips, a spokeswoman for one of the groups that coordinated Mandela's Boston visit, would not comment on what she said was a ``family matter.'' Mandela on Sunday left Boston for Washington. Those representing him and his wife, Winnie, did not return telephone calls Sunday night. Mandela's daughter from his current marriage, Zenani Dlamini, who lives in Boston, traveled with her father since his arrival in New York and saw him off at Boston's Logan International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Judaism Ready to Accept Gay Rabbis
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two decades after Reform Jews began accepting women as rabbis, they are being asked to extend the same welcome to homosexuals. A resolution in support of homosexual rabbis was scheduled for a vote today at the Central Conference of American Rabbis, and it was expected to pass. The Reform movement has more than 1.5 million Jews in the United States, led by about 1,560 Reform rabbis. It is the largest of the three main branches of Judaism in this country. The movement accepted women as rabbis beginning in 1972. The acceptance of homosexuals would be a major break from 4,000 years of Jewish tradition. A 17-member committee has prepared and recommended for approval a resolution that says homosexuals are as qualified as heterosexuals to lead congregations. Jewish law, embodied in the Torah and other texts, condemns homosexuality as an abomination. But ``out of concern for human dignity one is permitted to violate the prohibitions of Torah,'' said Rabbi Samuel Karff of Houston, conference president and a member of the committee. About 500 rabbis are attending the four-day conference, which ends Wednesday. The Conservative Jewish movement has had women rabbis since 1985, but it does not openly accept homosexual rabbis. Orthodox Jews, the third major branch, oppose ordination of women or homosexuals as forbidden by Jewish law. Judaism's smaller Reconstructionist movement and the Unitarian Universalist church openly accept homosexual clergy, and some other Christian denominations approve ordination of homosexuals if they remain celibate. The committee, headed by Rabbi Selig Salkowitz of Union Temple in New York City, arrived at its conclusion after a four-year study. ``The committee urges that all rabbis, regardless of sexual orientation, be accorded the opportunity to fulfill the sacred vocation which they have chosen,'' reads a draft of the resolution. ``Sexual orientation is irrelevant to the human worth of a person.'' At the same time, a majority of the committee affirmed that heterosexual marriage remains the ideal. The Central Conference of American Rabbis said there are probably dozens of gay and lesbian rabbis who already have been ordained. Several rabbis warned that even if the resolution passed, many congregations still would not accept homosexual leaders. ``To say that `I'm gay' before a congregation and expect that to be accepted is erroneous thinking. ... We're not saying this is a norm in our religion because it is not,'' Rabbi Gary Zola, national dean of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in Cincinnati, said in an interview. Zola said the college, which ordains about 40 rabbis a year from campuses in New York, Los Angeles, Cincinnati and Jerusalem, has ordained homosexuals unofficially. The college's admissions policy has been to ignore the issue unless a candidate brings it up, and even then it is considered among the candidate's other qualifications, he said. But he knew of only one rabbi who has openly admitted to being homosexual. He was dismissed by his congregation and went on to form another, Zola said. The Central Conference of American Rabbis can refuse to place and congregations can dismiss a rabbi. But a homosexual rabbi cannot lose his or her ordination, which represents an attainment of learning, not a sanctification by God, as in the priesthood. ``This resolution is hardly going to guarantee an end to social learning and prejudice. However, it's a critical beginning,'' said Rabbi Yoel Kahn of Sha'ar Zahav, a primarily homosexual congregation, in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Surpasses U.S. As World's Biggest Aid Donor
DOC.TEXT: Japan has overtaken the United States to become the biggest donor of government aid to the Third World, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The Paris-based group said Japan's total aid effort in 1989 was $9 billion, compared with $7.7 billion for the United States. The U.S. figure represented a decline of 27 percent from 1988, after adjusting for inflation. The third-biggest donor in dollars, after Japan and the U.S., was France with $5.14 billion, followed by West Germany with $4.95 billion. The report could soften criticism that Japan, with its immense financial strength, has not done its share to help developing countries. The decline meant that U.S. aid as a share of gross national product declined from 0.21 percent in 1988 to 0.15 percent last year _ the worst performance among the industrial democracies that are the organization's main aid donor countries. Joseph Wheeler, chairman of the group's Development Assistance Committee, told a news conference Sunday that U.S. aid to the Third World has fallen steadily in recent years. But Wheeler said he expects the United States will lift its aid effort to at least $9 billion this year. He said U.S. contributions to multilateral aid institutions should return to normal levels in 1990, and substantial new aid programs in Central America are likely. But this probably won't be enough to enable the United States to regain its status as the No. 1 aid provider, Wheeler said, since Japan plans to spend at least $31 billion on aid over the next three years. Wheeler said government assistance to developing countries from all sources in 1989 totalled $51.3 billion, scarecely changed from the year-earlier figure of $51.7 billion. The total flow, including private funds and export credits, to these countries is estimated at $109 billion, up 4.5 percent from 1988. Wheeler said the aid effort of the international group's 18 richest countries has increased in real terms at an average rate of 2.9 percent a year, or a total of about 33 percent in the past decade. Wheeler said the aid effort of Western industrialized nations in 1989 wasn't affected by assistance to Eastern Europe. Most donor countries have indicated future aid to Eastern Europe will not be diverted from traditional aid recipients, he said. The group said Scandinavian countries continued to provide the most official aid last year as a percentage of GNP, led by Norway with 1.02 percent. The organization's member nations are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Signed to Move U.S. Military Command out of Seoul
DOC.TEXT: South Korea and the United States, concluding more than a year of negotiations, signed a memorandum today to move the U.S. military command in Korea out of Seoul by 1996. ``The agreement is an important milestone and demonstrates the excellent coordinating and consultation process of our two countries,'' said Gen. Louis C. Menetrey, commander of U.S. Forces in South Korea. He and South Korean Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon signed the memorandum. The agreement calls for South Korea to pay the entire cost of the move, including the purchase of land and construction of base facilities, while the United States bears only maintenance costs. The total cost of the move was not yet known but Menetrey said construction of base facilities alone would cost at least $1 billion. The site also has not been settled, but some South Korean newspapers, quoting informed government sources, said Pyongtaek, 50 miles south of Seoul, is a top candidate. Officials of both countries said the agreement would help blunt a tenacious anti-U.S. campaign by Korean radical students. It would remove a highly visible target for attacks by the radicals, who claim the U.S. military presence in their country blocks Seoul's unification with Communist North Korea. South Korean radicals, a small but vocal minority, have frequently attacked U.S. military facilities with firebombs, demanding the withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in the country under a mutual defense treaty.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Marks National Day Amid Bitterness Over Failed Accord
DOC.TEXT: Celebrations on Quebec's national holiday were dampened by rain _ and by bitterness over the failure of an accord aimed at keeping the French-speaking province in the Canadian federation. ``There are a lot of people for whom today is a day of mourning,'' Michel Rivard, a popular Quebec singer, said Sunday on St. John the Baptist Day. The holiday came a day after the deadline for ratification of the so-called Meech Lake accord, which would have provided constitutional guarantees recognizing French-speaking Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' The Meech Lake accord was effectively torpedoed Friday by Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells, who suspended debate on the amendment in his legislature and thus denied the required unanimous ratification by all 10 provinces. Many in English Canada feared the accord would have given Quebec extra powers. But constitutional experts said the ``distinct society'' clause would have had few practical effects. The clause, however, had strong symbolic significance in Quebec _ Canada's largest province with one-fourth of the country's 26 million people. A parade and gala evening concert marking Sunday's holiday _ Quebec's equivalent of the Fourth of July _ were postponed until today because of wet weather. But Sunday was still a day for displays of nationalist sentiment. Blue and white Quebec flags sprouted in windows and on balconies throughout the city. Some cars flying enormous Quebec flags drove up and down the streets, winning scattered cheers. Nationalist T-shirts sold briskly along the rue St. Denis. There have been concerns that the failure of Meech Lake might lead to a renewed push by Quebec's citizens for independence. Headlines in provincial newspapers focused on Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa's comments that he would boycott future constitutional talks as the province decides on a new course for the future. But the prevailing opinion was that there would be no precipitous move toward independence, or toward some sort of sovereignty-association relationship with the rest of Canada. ``We won't be in a hurry,'' said Paul-Andre Comeau, editor of the Montreal newspaper Le Devoir. ``Everybody will go on summer vacation, then we'll make up our minds.'' Newfoundland and Manitoba were the only holdout provinces against Meech Lake, named after the government retreat near Ottawa where it was originally worked out in 1987. Manitoba leaders tried to bring the accord to a vote, but were blocked by a lone Indian legislator who promised to kill the accord because he wanted similar recognition as distinct for native people. The five-point Meech Lake accord was aimed at winning Quebec's signature on the 1982 constitution, which applies to the province even without its signature. Francine Pelletier, a columnist for the newspaper La Presse, wrote that the real reason for the failure of Meech Lake was ``the inability of English Canada to allow Quebec to be different.'' Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who had made ratification of Meech Lake a personal crusade, may have suffered the biggest setback. Even before the ratification deadline expired, his approval rating only stood at 15 to 17 percent in the polls. The prime minister, himself a bilingual Quebecois, spent St. John the Baptist Day in the Quebec town of Baie St. Paul. ``I have no doubt that justice eventually will be done to Quebec,'' he said in a brief speech. Mulroney ignored opposition calls that he resign and said he would search for a new way to bring the French-speaking province into the constitutional family. Bob Keaton, president of Alliance Quebec, representing the province's English-speaking minority, warned that the nationalists would be quick to try to fill the political vacuum left by Meech Lake's failure. ``Unless federal leaders come forward with an alternative immediately to fill in that vacuum, I think we're in very deep trouble,'' Keaton said.

DOC.HEAD: Parents of Test-Tube Quints in Financial Straits
DOC.TEXT: The parents of the nation's first test-tube quintuplets say they can barely afford diapers anymore and are selling their belongings to make ends meet. ``We don't have anything left,'' Michele L'Esperance told The Oakland Press in an interview Friday at her home in Springfield Township. ``We're selling everything, the horses, my fur coat, everything.'' The quintuplets _ Alexandria, Danielle, Erica, Veronica and Raymond Jr. _ were born Jan. 11, 1988 to Mrs. L'Esperance and her husband, Raymond. People magazine paid for an exclusive cover story in 1988, and corporate sponsors lined up to supply diapers and baby food. But the babies' fame hasn't even covered basic costs, their parents said. Mrs. L'Esperance said the family pays $350 a week to feed the four girls and one boy along with the babies' two older brothers, a half-brother and three nieces they took in last year. The L'Esperances said their phone has been cut off, they have received a shutoff notice from the electric company, and their limousine _ the only car big enough to hold the family _ has been repossessed. ``It's gotten so I don't know if we'll have enough money for diapers,'' L'Esperance said. The family receives $295 a month in welfare for the nieces, but Mrs. L'Esperance planned to ask a court today to place the nieces in foster homes. ``She has a big heart and she's trying to keep the family together,'' said Frank Millard, an attorney for the nieces. ``But they can't go on like this.'' L'Esperance is a corrections officer earning about $26,000 a year and has taken a second full-time job. His wife works for a shelter for battered women.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Apartheid is still there in spite of the fact that the discussions between the ANC (African National Congress) and the government are going on.'' _ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela, pressing for continued sanctions against the white-ruled South African government.

``The secretary did what he had to do and the activists did well in expressing their concerns. It was a form of dialogue.'' _ Rose Okello, a health educator from Uganda attending a world conference on AIDS in San Francisco at which activists drowned out the closing speech by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan.

``Don't ask me how many are dead. Ask how many survived. Only me, my son and a woman from my village.'' _ An unidentified man from Kopteh in the quake-devastated Caspian Sea region of northern Iran, quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Days of Mourning Declared for Second Victim in Council Attack
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The government designated today and Tuesday as days of mourning for a lawmaker who was fatally wounded in a gun attack last week on the governing Council of State. Serge Villard, a council member and an author of Haiti's 1987 constitution, died Sunday while being flown by air ambulance to Miami for emergency treatment, said Commerce Minister Maurice Lafortune. Villard, 66, was shot three times in Thursday's attack in the courtyard of a hotel where the 19-member council had gathered for a meeting with political and union leaders. Four gunmen, including two in army uniform, sprayed the group with gunfire shortly before the meeting was to begin. Union militant Jean-Marie Montes was killed in the attack, and Villard and political activist Emmanuel Mani were wounded. President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot was to meet with the council today. The independent Radio Antilles said the council held an emergency meeting with army officials Sunday in the National Palace. Today and Tuesday, flags were flying at half-staff and cinemas and other places of amusement were asked to close. State offices and commercial businesses were to be open, however. Villard, a prominent businessman, was a leading opponent of the 29-year dictatorship of the Duvalier family, which ended in 1986. Villard authored Article 291 of the constitution, which banned known supporters of the Duvaliers from running for public office for 10 years after the adoption of the constitution in 1987. His death heightened concern over possible violence in reaction to the attack. On Saturday, thousands of factories workers stayed home and most stores and gas stations closed for the day to mourn the victims of the attack. Thursday's attack was seen as an attempt to increase tensions and block the government from holding presidential balloting this fall. Haiti's attempt to hold free and fair elections, on Nov. 29, 1987, resulted in the massacre of at least 34 voters at polling stations. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said in a speech late Saturday on television and radio that the government was determined to hold the elections. She said the army had been ordered to crack down on violent street crime, which has created a climate of insecurity in the country. The civilian caretaker government Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot leads was appointed in March to replace military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, who fled into exile after a weeklong popular uprising.

DOC.HEAD: Showers in Northeast, Searing Heat in Southwest and Plains
DOC.TEXT: Showers were scattered over northern New England today, and searing heat was expected to spread from the Southwest into the Plains. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms over Minnesota, the central Gulf states and southern Florida, and scattered showers over Illinois, New England, Idaho and Montana. Areas from west Texas and eastern California that had 100-degree heat on Sunday were expected to have near-record temperatures. The mercury also was expected to rise above 100 degrees from the Dakotas to Kansas. Record temperatures were broken or tied across the Southwest on Sunday. Lubbock, Texas, reached 110 degrees, up from the previous high of 108 in 1980. Other highs included 98 degrees in Corpus Christi, Texas (97 in 1964) and 108 in Midland and Odessa, Texas (104 in 1980). Austin, Texas, tied its 1984 record of 100 degrees. The nation's high temperature was 118 degrees at Yuma, Ariz. Tornadoes touched down Sunday afternoon near the Miami airport and at Cape Canaveral, Fla. There were no reports of injuries or major damage.
