DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Rock Quake Zone, Hampering Rescue Efforts
LaserPhotos NY7, NY8
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs on new aftershocks, quotes from Iranian rescue officials, other details. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Four days...' EDITS thereafter to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Fresh aftershocks hit earthquake-devastated northern Iran early today, sending dazed survivors fleeing in panic for open ground and setting off landslides that snarled rescue efforts. Thursday's earthquake killed at least 50,000 people, and more than half a million are homeless, authorities say. Eight-two aftershocks, some as strong as 5.5 on the Richter scale, rattled the quake zone today and Sunday, Tehran University's geophysics center said. One landslide blocked a 35-mile stretch of road between Rasht and Rudbar, a critical supply route in the quake zone, about 125 miles northwest of Tehran. Relief convoys were caught in traffic jams on other boulder-covered roads. The official Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) reported non-stop rescue efforts, with army helicopters flying relief missions around the clock. ``The tragedy is so grave it cannot be described. I've never seen such a catastrophe before,'' it quoted the helicopter force's commander as saying. The commander said one pilot who lost his mother, sister and brother in the quake returned to duty to fly relief missions as soon as he had buried them. In Rudbar, an agricultural city of 100,000 people, thousands of tents have been set up by the Red Crescent _ the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross _ to house people. About 95 percent of the city's buildings were destroyed or damaged in the quake. The stench of decomposing bodies hung over the city as rescuers aided by police dogs pulled bodies from the rubble. Officials were worried about contamination of water supplies and the spread of infectious diseases as they struggled to bury the overwhelming numbers of dead. ``Don't ask me how many are dead. Ask how many survived,'' IRNA quoted a man from Kopteh as saying. ``Only me, my son and a woman from my village.'' ``My survival was a miracle, because tons and tons of rocks slid from mountain peaks and buried the village and all the villagers, livestock and orchards are under mountains of rock and rubble,'' he said. Four days after the quake, there were still conflicting death tolls. The Tehran Times, considered close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, quoted an unidentified senior relief official as saying 50,000 people died and 200,000 were injured in the quake. He said even that was a conservative estimate because ``the figures are quoted taking account only of those who have been registered officially as dead or wounded.'' Many victims were not counted, he said. In Geneva, senior U.N. relief official M'hamed Essaafi also estimated the toll would reach 50,000 dead and 200,000 injured. Tehran radio put the toll late Sunday at 48,000 killed and 100,000 injured. Accounting for the dead, injured and homeless was difficult because whole towns and villages remained isolated. Army mountaineers climbed peaks in the rugged region in an effort to rescue villagers trapped in remote hamlets, the news agency said. In Manjil, a farming and fishing community of 2,000 people about 125 miles northwest of Tehran, only a few telephone poles and parts of some buildings were left standing. In a nearby field, army bulldozers dug communal graves, which soldiers filled with hundreds of bodies. A large mural portrait of late revolutionary patriarch Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, half his face reduced to rubble, loomed above the remains of a house. For the first time since Khomeini's 1979 Islamic revolution, Iran is accepting overt U.S. aid. A cargo jet carrying 42 tons of U.S. aid _ including bandages, antiseptic burn cream, tents and orange slices in syrup _ arrived in Tehran on Sunday. ``To be on the ground here in Tehran is a very special feeling for us,'' said Stephen M. Johnson, president of AmeriCares, a private U.S. relief organization based in New Canaan, Conn. In addition to the aid collected by AmeriCares, a Red Cross charter flight left Washington carrying supplies donated by the U.S. government. Iran and the United States have had no diplomatic ties since the takeover of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran by Islamic militants, who held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days in 1979 and 1980. The U.S. supplies were among tons of relief equipment arriving in the Iranian capital over the weekend. Tehran radio said Sunday that 68 relief aircraft had landed at the capital's Mehrabad airport during a 24-hour period. The radical newspaper Jomhuri Islami had urged that no help be accepted from the United States and other countries whose hands ``are stained with the blood of the Iranian people.'' ``Our people, even under the rubble, chant `Death to America' and pray to God to cut off the hands of the United States ... even those hands stretched out to help,'' it said in an editorial. The Foreign Ministry, however, said that ``due to the magnitude of the disaster'' Iran would accept all such aid, except from Israel and South Africa. The quake's toll was the highest anywhere since July 28, 1976, when an estimated 200,000 people were killed in China by a quake. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage, while one of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage. Thursday's quake registered between 7.3 and 7.7 on the scale.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Fang's Release `Significant' for U.S.-China Relations
With PM-Fang
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today China's decision to allow dissident Fang Lizhi to leave his country is a ``farsighted significant step'' for U.S.-China relations. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, left China for Britain late Sunday after Communist authorities allowed them to end their yearlong refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. ``The United States government welcomes the People's Republic of China's decision to facilitate the departure of Dr. Fang and his wife,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement read to reporters. ``This humanitarian action is a farsighted significant step that will improve the atmosphere for progress in our bilateral relations,'' he said. Fitzwater said Fang had accepted a job teaching at England's Cambridge University where he will ``pursue his important research in astrophysics.'' Fang is scheduled to arrive in London at 9 p.m. EDT tonight. The official Xinhua news agency said Fang and his wife were allowed to leave the country for medical reasons after showing ``signs of repentance.'' But Fitzwater, noting he had not yet seen Fang's statement, said he believed it ``paralleled many of his public statements in the past.'' He added Fang and the Chinese government had ``been working out (the statement) over a longer period of time.'' China had said that to be released, Fang and Li would have to confess ``guilt,'' and promise not to carry out any anti-government activities. Fitzwater the United States made no commitments to China, but added, ``We do believe that this was an important contribution toward improving our relations.'' Congress, which has been critical of Bush for keeping communications with China open despite its crackdown on dissidents after last year's pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, is debating Bush's decision to extend most-favored-nation trading status to China for another year. Fitzwater said Bush was informed late last night by National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft of the release of Fang and Li, who took refuge in the U.S. Embassy June 4 after the killing of Tiananmen Square demonstrators.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Patient Returns to Hospital for Tests
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the longest surviving heart-liver transplant patient, is back in the hospital for tests to see whether her body is rejecting her second transplanted liver. The 13-year-old arrived Saturday night in Pittsburgh from her home in White Settlement, Texas. She was in fair condition at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, a hospital statement said Sunday. Stormie suffered a mild episode of liver rejection one month ago. Doctors increased her use of an experimental anti-rejection medicine. Episodes of rejection in transplant patients are fairly common. Stormie received the double transplant in 1984 because of a congenital condition that gave her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. She received a second liver transplant early this year after hepatitis damaged her first donor liver.

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Promises Not to Settle Soviet Jews in Occupied Lands
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with government launching diplomatic offensive, saying Sharon statement not a policy change. Pick up 10th pvs, `Palestinians in ...' ^By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY
DOC.TEXT: The new right-wing government launched a diplomatic offensive today to reassure international critics that it will not settle Soviet immigrants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. On Sunday, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, who is chiefly responsible for absorbing the Soviet immigration wave, gave the first specific pledge that Israel would not settle Soviet immigrants beyond Israel's 1967 borders. He stressed, however, that the government would continue efforts to increase Israeli settlement _ and thus influence _ in the territories. Today, Yitzhak Shamir's spokesman announced that the prime minister sent Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a telegram last month saying Israel is not settling Soviet Jews in the occupied territories. The spokesman, Avi Pazner, said Shamir also sent a letter to European Community leaders last week saying his two-week-old government wants to pursue the Middle East peace process. Israel has become increasingly isolated over its refusal to accept U.S. proposals for peace talks or to give solid guarantees on the settlement of immigrants. When it took office, the new government said that although it had no policy of directing Soviet Jews to the territories, it would refuse to discourage such settlement. Sharon, a hawkish former general and champion of Jewish settlement in the occupied lands, had been as steadfast as any member of the new government in defending the right of Israelis to settle where they choose. The United States has joined the Soviet Union, Arab and European states in opposing the settlement of Soviet Jews in the West Bank and Gaza. And both superpowers have threatened to penalize Israel unless such settlement stops. ``Our efforts in resettling immigrants are directed at this side of the Green Line,'' Sharon said Sunday, referring to Israel's pre-1967 borders. ``As far as the immigrants are concerned, they will not be settled _ because of the problems we have _ beyond the Green Line.'' He did not say what, if anything, the Israeli government would do to try to prevent new arrivals from the Soviet Union from moving to the occupied lands. A Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said today that Sharon's statement did not apply to east Jerusalem, the predominantly Arab sector seized from Jordan in 1967 and annexed to Israel. ``East Jerusalem is in Israel,'' the official told reporters, distinguishing it from the occupied territories. The Foreign Ministry official said Shamir told the leaders of the 12 European Community states that his government would absorb Soviet Jewish immigrants in ways that ``will not prejudice the position of any other inhabitants.'' ``They will not take the place of others and will not uproot them. This is our conviction, our policy and our commitment,'' the official quoted the Shamir's letter as saying. Pazner insisted neither Sharon's remarks nor Shamir's telegram to Gorbachev signaled a policy change. He said Shamir sent the telegram to the Soviet leader soon after Gorbachev threatened to reverse the Soviet policy of allowing Jews to freely emigrate. The United States also considers all new Israeli settlement in the occupied territories an obstacle to peace. It has sought guarantees that the Soviet immigrants are not settled in the occupied territories before approving a $400 million housing loan Israel has asked for to use for immigrant resettlement. Palestinians in the occupied territories have joined Arab nations in protesting the wave of Soviet Jewish immigration, fearing that immigrants settling on occupied lands could push Palestinians out. At least 56,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel since the beginning of 1989, and the figure is expected to reach 150,000 this year. About 320 have settled in the occupied lands, home to 1.7 million Palestinians and some 70,000 Jewish settlers. An additional 3,400 to 4,500 have moved into Jewish suburbs of annexed east Jerusalem, which was seized along with the West Bank and Gaza in the 1967 Middle East war. Sharon made the announcement in a speech to the Board of Governors of the Jewish Agency, which helps resettle immigrants. But he also pledged that Israel would not stop its settlement drive in the occupied territories. ``It does not mean that other people cannot settle in any place. Construction will be continued, in accordance with government policy, in all parts of the land of Israel,'' Sharon said in the speech, which was broadcast on Israel radio. He said Israel wanted the immigrants to settle in the central part of the country, the southern Negev desert and the northern Galilee area. Sharon, who as defense minister led Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, was appointed housing minister and head of the ministerial committee on immigrant absorption earlier this month, just after Shamir formed his new right-wing coalition. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek, speaking to the Jewish Agency forum, praised Sharon's statement. ``To put ideology above immigration is a capital mistake,'' Kollek said.

DOC.HEAD: Snake in the Glass Startles Texas Woman
DOC.TEXT: A woman says the stranger at her door Sunday night was stranger than anything she had seen there before. It was a 10-foot python. Jana Klarich said her 4-year-old daughter spotted the snake first. Ms. Klarich said she was cooking sausage about 7 p.m. when the girl came out of the bedroom and looked out the glass front door and said, ``Mama, what's that?'' ``I said, `I don't know,' '' Ms. Klarich recounted. ``Then I got closer, and I know.'' The snake was stretched out almost to the top of the door. Ms. Klarich called the police in this Fort Worth suburb for help. ``I envisioned a grass snake or a chicken snake or something like that,'' said police Sgt. Mike Davis. `When I got up there, there's this 10-foot python laying on her porch. It ruined my day.'' But officer Kathi Perkins decided the snake was friendly and squeezed it into a 55-gallon plastic garbage can. The reptile has been placed in custody of the Humane Society of North Texas. Police are trying to find its owner.

DOC.HEAD: Serial Gunman Now Killer, Stalking City's Defenseless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st two grafs to recast. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The city's...'.
DOC.TEXT: The letter-writing gunman threatening to shoot 12 people _ one for each sign of the zodiac _ is now a killer. A 78-year-old man who was shot in the back and beaten May 31 died Sunday at Jamaica Hospital. He was one of four men who have been shot by the so-called ``Zodiac'' gunman since March. The city's chief of detectives, Joseph Borrelli, said it was only luck that the three other victims were still alive. ``I think he is intending to shoot them and kill them,'' Borrelli said. The Zodiac shot his latest victim Thursday, a homeless man sleeping on a Central Park bench. All four victims were vulnerable, including a 50-year-old man who used a cane to steady a limp and a 33-year-old man who was tipsy. At least one of the victims _ the latest one _ was stalked because of his astrological sign, police said. Larry Parnham, the wounded homeless man, told detectives he was befriended days before the shooting by a stranger who asked him his birth date, Borrelli said. The day after the shooting, a note taking responsibility and introducing the writer as the ``Zodiac'' was received by the New York Post. The birth dates of all four victims correspond to astrological signs scrawled in notes written by the killer, Borrelli said. ``We were concerned and we were confused as to the manner in which these shootings were happening under the sign of the individual victim,'' he said. ``When you get four out of four, I think it goes beyond luck.'' Police believe the gunman has copied the methods of California's Zodiac killer, a man who claimed responsibility for as many as 40 killings in a series of notes sent to San Francisco-area newspapers from 1968 to 1987. In the most recent letter to the Post, the gunman claimed to be the same man who terrorized California. But police said they don't believe that. Astrologers had warned police that the first day of summer, when the Central Park shooting occurred, was considered a significant day, because the zodiac changed from the sign of Gemini to the sign of Cancer. After the Central Park shooting, Borrelli said: ``This opens up a whole new Pandora's box. We've got the whole city now to be looking at.'' Police have a Zodiac Task Force of about 50 officers on the case, Borrelli said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Both Firmer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0502 to fix header coding.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed in quiet trading in Europe this morning. Gold was steady with little action in the market. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 155.62 yen, up 0.87 yen from Friday's closing price. Market players were actively buying dollars in the morning to cover short positions and stop losses, said Junichi Kodama, head of corporate traders at Chemical Bank. Purchases by insurance companies sent the dollar up to 155.70 by midmorning. ``There was a rumor that the Bank of Japan might have intervened. The rumor came from Singapore. I don't know if the rumor was true, but it was true that there was strong selling at the 155.70 level,'' he added. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 155.62 yen. DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Stalwarts Break Ranks with Walesa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with commentator saying Solidarity finished, Solidarity newspaper criticizing Walesa supporters. Pickup 8th pvs, `The men...' Minor editing to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leaders have issued a death certificate for the movement that one year ago toppled Communist rule, a leading political commentator said today. Sixty-three leading members of Solidarity broke ranks with movement leader Lech Walesa Sunday over his criticism of the Solidarity-led government of Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former Walesa adviser. They said Walesa should disband Solidarity's Citizens Committee, which since 1988 has functioned as the movement's political arm, leading the successful campaign that ended four decades of Communist rule. The suggestion came in a letter read during a heated daylong meeting of the 200-member Citizens Committee at which Walesa and his opponents traded barbs. The tone of Walesa's supporters, many recently appointed to the committee, was ``threatening, brutal,'' Poland's largest newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, said today. In the end, the committee postponed considering the letter for one month. Walesa had asked that emotions be allowed to cool. ``Let's think it over. Maybe there are solutions for our further joint path,'' the Solidarity chairman said. The signatories of the letter agreed to remain on the committee in the meantime. ``What has ended is not only the time of heroic Solidarity,'' Konstantin Gebert, one of the best-known Solidarity journalists, wrote in today's Zycie Warszawy daily. ``What has ended, simply put, is the idea of Solidarity as a united community fighting against evil. ``In the auditorium they only issued the death certificate.'' The signatories include major figures of the Solidarity movement: Zbigniew Bujak and Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, former leaders of the Solidarity underground; Jacek Kuron, a veteran dissident who is now the minister of labor; Adam Michnik, a member of parliament and leading newspaper editor; and Bronislaw Geremek, one of Walesa's first advisers. The men were once Walesa's closest allies in his struggle to make the Communists share power with opposition forces. But now they differ with Walesa over his criticisms of the Mazowiecki government for what Walesa considers the slow pace of political and economic change. Poland is dismantling a centrally planned economy and building a free market system in its place. The former allies also disagree with Walesa's drive to become president of Poland and his opening the Citizens Committee to politicians from groups that were outside the old Solidarity movement. Mazowiecki stayed away from the meeting. But in a speech in Szczecin, he appealed for unity until the country completes painful economic reforms. The emotional debate among Citizens Committee members was tinged with sadness and anger. ``I have a feeling that I have lost something,'' said Geremek, leader of the Solidarity caucus in parliament, taking the floor near the end of the day. ``In our movement, there used to be no leader, there were no servants. There were citizens. There were friends. ... What happened?'' he asked, addressing Walesa. Michnik told Walesa he had no right to say who could use the name of Solidarity. Michnik edits Gazeta Wyborcza, whose use of the Solidarity logo Walesa is disputing. ``Nobody can take away our struggle, not even you, Lech,'' he said. The veteran Solidarity activists want the Citizens Committee, recently packed with new members beholden to Walesa, to be dissolved so that they can create a movement that would support Mazowiecki and remain true to what they consider to be Solidarity's historic ideals. Walesa said his recent criticisms of the government, including a vow to create a ``war at the top,'' have been intended to help Mazowiecki by conveying the frustrations of workers and farmers eager for a better standard of living. Walesa has criticized the government for moving too slowly to oust former Communists from positions of authority, and he says he fears his former allies in Solidarity might create a new political monopoly. Walesa aides recently formed a political group, the Center Alliance, to promote his election to the presidency of Poland, still held by former Communist leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Walesa critics charge that he is becoming a danger to democracy because he stirs emotions against the government at a time when it faces populist attacks for carrying out painful economic reforms. They say that as president of Poland he would rule by decree, undermining Poland's parliament and government.

DOC.HEAD: Release of Chinese Dissident May Clear Way for Huge Japanese Loan
With PM-China-Fang, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: China's release of dissident Fang Lizhi today appeared likely to clear the way for Japan to resume a huge loan program and reclaim its role as the biggest source of credit to Beijing. The vice foreign minister, Takakazu Kuriyama, welcomed the news that Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, had been permitted to leave their refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing and fly to Britain. China's move created a ``favorable environment'' for reopening talks on the loan program but there would not be any such talks before the Houston summit of the seven industrialized democracies in early July, Kuriyama was quoted as telling Japanese reporters. Fang's release was expected to put relations with China high on the agenda of Western leaders at the Houston summit. Sanctions against Beijing were solidified at last year's economic summit in France. Kyodo News Service said Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu described China's move as signaling ``good directions in an overall trend.'' But it said he told Japanese reporters asking about unfreezing the loans: ``We won't necessarily do so just because of this action.'' Japan had pledged $5.2 billion in a five-year program of loans to China but the plan was frozen after the suppression of pro-democracy protesters in June 1989. Tokyo also joined other big Western countries in banning high-level contacts with Chinese officials and repeatedly called on Beijing to release political prisoners and take other steps to show respect for human rights. Japan, however, has argued that for the sake of stability in the Far East, China should not be isolated in the international community. Last week, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama told Parliament that Japan eventually would move ahead with its loan program ``in order not to have China isolated.'' Foreign Ministry officials quoted Kuriyama, the vice minister, as saying the release of Fang and Li showed that China was trying to improve relations with the West, and he hoped Western countries would take a positive view of such a conciliatory move. Kyodo News Service quoted an unidentified high Finance Ministry official as saying Fang's release ``is expected to cause a change in attitude'' toward China at the Houston summit. Japan had contributed $6.1 billion in loans and grants to China before Beijing's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last year. The frozen loan program was to have financed projects to develop China's backward infrastructure. The loans were crucial to China's 1991-1995 economic plan, but when they were supposed to have started in April, negotiations had not even begun.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Family Prayed, Sat Still in 5-Day Vigil
DOC.TEXT: A longtime cave enthusiast who was trapped in a cave for five days with his two sons says he's had enough of exploring. ``Right now, I think I'm going to pack up the stuff (gear) and keep it as memories of my past,'' Gary Lutes said. ``I'm not sure I'll go back underground again. That was enough to show that just one momentary error could have cost the life of three of us. ``Once you go underground, the cave is unforgiving. You don't get second chances like this. We were just very fortunate,'' he told The Associated Press in a telephone interview from his hospital bed Sunday. Lutes, 37, a Tampa, Fla., land surveyor, and sons Gary Jr., 13, and Timothy, 9, were rescued from a Pendleton County, W.Va., cave on Saturday. They had been lost since the previous Monday, state police said. The three were taken to Rockingham Memorial Hospital in Harrisonburg, where they were in stable condition Sunday. The three endured dehydration, hallucinations and bats during the vigil, which began when their lamps went out while they explored a side trail, Lutes said. Lutes, a member of the National Speleological Society, a cave-study group, said he never had been lost in 20 years of cave adventuring. But on Monday, he put down his pack to squeeze through a small opening a half-mile into New Trout Cave in eastern West Virginia, about 200 miles west of Washington, D.C. He intended to retrieve the pack on his way out. But when their lamps went out, the three couldn't find the opening or the pack, which held food, water and extra lights, Lutes said. ``I knew if there was panic or terror we'd be nowhere,'' he said. ``We wouldn't have made it unless we were sitting and being calm.'' They took turns keeping watch. They recited Bible scriptures and prayed they would be rescued, Lutes said. ``Toward the end, we figured we were going to die,'' Lutes said. ``We were happy it would be all three of us together and not just one. We figured that was better than continuing on like that.'' The search didn't start until Thursday, when relatives in Powhatan, Va., contacted police after the Luteses missed a meeting, police said. About 25 experienced cave rescuers from Virginia, West Virginia and Maryland joined more than 50 police, fire and emergency squads in the search. Using Lutes' parked car as a starting point, they began combing three sets of caves about 10:30 p.m. Friday. They found the pack about 12:30 a.m. Saturday, and reached the Luteses 90 minutes later, said state police Trooper R.D. Gillespie. The three were caked in dirt and parched, but in remarkably good condition when they emerged. ``The first thing they said was `Thank God you came,''' said rescuer John Hempel. ``The second thing they said was `Do you have any water?''' Barry Chute, a National Speleological Society member from Maryland who led the rescue effort, said that Lutes did the right thing by staying put. ``If you get lost and lose your light sources, you can't go anywhere in a cave,'' he said. ``You can't grope your way out. You'd just go in circles.'' Lutes said both he and the boys came to appreciate life a little more when they faced death. ``I thought to myself if I ever get out of this, what do those things mean? Job, pressure, whether I get the lawn mowed ... things like that. ``I prayed so hard I'd be given a second chance, and it came through.''

DOC.HEAD: Western European Leaders Set Up Conference on Political Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with conference on political union, new comment on Soviet aid. Pickup 9th pvs, `The matter...'
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the European Community today agreed to meet in December to work out details on achieving political union by 1993. The agreement came despite reservations by Britain and Portugal. Also today, Britain told its European partners that is premature to heed West German and French calls for immediate large-scale aid to the Soviet Union. France's foreign minister, Roland Dumas, announced the agreement on a special Dec. 14 conference soon after the 12 Western European leaders opened a two-day summit. Dumas told reporters that Britain and Portugal raised concerns that the still undefined form of political union should not rob states of national sovereignty. The agreement had been widely expected after Britain said it would not try to block the conference on political union, which it envisages as amounting only to closer cooperation among the members of the wealthy trading bloc. On Soviet aid, a British government spokesman said some type of support was in order. The question, he said, was ``not whether we assist the Soviet Union ... it is how.'' ``We have to ask ourselves whether it makes sense to throw large amounts of money at the Soviet Union,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It is not exactly a deprived society.'' West Germany argued for the aid. Government spokesman Hans Klein told reporters it is ``in the interests of the entire free world'' to support the reform movements set in motion by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Klein acknowledged that the European leaders probably would not reach any conclusions at the Dublin meeting, but would instead lay the groundwork for more talks about the issue at the seven-nation summit of leading industrialized nations next month in Houston. Britain, backed by Portugal and Italy, was also pressing for the community to ease sanctions against South Africa in a firm signal of support for President F.W. de Klerk's reform moves. But British officials acknowledged the timing was probably bad. Black leader Nelson Mandela is on a 14-country tour and has been urging no letup in sanctions against South Africa until apartheid is irrevocably dismantled. The call for the aid package to support Gorbachev's reform efforts came from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand. ``The matter is really urgent,'' Mitterrand said after meeting Friday with Kohl in the Rhine River town of Ruedesheim. By providing large-scale aid, the Western nations hope Gorbachev would be encouraged to end his opposition to immediate membership for a united Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The West German magazine Der Spiegel reported Saturday that Kohl plans to travel to Moscow in late July with a package of Western loans worth $15 billion to $19 billion. The Bonn government denied the report. The European Community is coordinating the work of 24 Western countries to funnel economic aid into Poland and Hungary. The program will be extended early next month to other emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. Romania will be excluded because of the violent repression of anti-government protests. It was considered unlikely the aid program would be widenend to include the populous Soviet Union, with its daunting economic problems. In a sign of the changing times, East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere was invited to attend today's formal luncheon, hosted by Irish President Patrick J. Hillery. East Germany will become part of the community as it joins with its western neighbor. The questions of how far to push an economic and monetary union and a political merger have sparked controversy. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has strongly opposed plans to set up a common currency and European-wide system of central banks. ``If you lose sovereignty over monetary and budgetary policy, you haven't got much sovereignty left,'' Mrs. Thatcher said over the weekend. She also has urged a cautious approach in creating a political union of the dozen nations. The European Community nations are: Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, West Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today struck down a Minnesota law that banned abortions for unmarried young girls unless both parents first were notified. But the court upheld a less stringent Ohio law requiring parental notification.

DOC.HEAD: Visit By Heads Of German Parliaments Seen As Goodwill Gesture
DOC.TEXT: The president of East Germany's Parliament, visiting Israel along with her West German counterpart, said today she would seek speedy establishment of relations with the Jewish state. Israeli officials hailed the visit of Sabine Bergmann-Pohl of East Germany and Rita Suessmuth of West Germany as a special goodwill gesture. The visit is the first joint trip abroad by the leaders of the two parliaments and seemed designed to allay Israeli concerns about German unification. ``Israelis and not only Israelis are worried about the possible re-emergence of German military might,'' said legislator Zalman Shoval, head of the Israeli-German Friendship Association in Israel's Knesset, or parliament. ``On the other hand, it would be a mistake to put a unified Germany in the dock from the outset,'' Shoval said in a telephone interview before greeting the two visitors at Ben-Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv. Knesset Speaker Dov Shilansky, a Nazi death camp survivor who has vowed never to receive German delegations officially, took a vacation today to avoid attending ceremonies for the visitors. But a Foreign Ministry schedule listed a private meeting between the parliament presidents and Shilansky at his Jerusalem home on Tuesday. Shilansky could not be reached for comment, but the daily Maariv said he would tell the visitors about his suffering at the hands of the Germans during World War II. Ms. Bergmann-Pohl, 43, told reporters she would seek friendly relations beteween her country and Israel. ``I hope I will be able to assist in speeding up the creation of diplomatic relations between the two countries,'' said Ms. Bergmann-Pohl, a physician and newcomer to politics who became head of East Germany's first freely elected Parliament on April 5. East Germany's hard-line Communist regime, toppled by a popular revolt last fall, was hostile toward Israel. It refused to accept moral responsibility for the Holocaust or pay any reparations to the Jews. In April, the East German Parliament issued a resolution apologizing to Jews around the world for the atrocities of the Holocaust and pledging to pay reparations. Preliminary talks on diplomatic relations have been held between East Germany and Israel this year, and Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman Motti Amihai said today efforts will continue even though both Germanys may be united by the end of the year. Amihai said the visit, the first joint trip abroad by the two parliament presidents, was a continuation of confidence-building measures begun with the East German Parliament resolution. ``The central message is the continuation of the historic committment toward Israel and the Jewish people from a united Germany,'' Amihai said. Both Ms. Suessmuth and Ms. Bergmann-Pohl are Christian Democrats. On Tuesday, they were to tour the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial and attend a discussion on ``The Future of the Germans in Europe.'' They will meet with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Foreign Minister David Levy, President Chaim Herzog and Shimon Peres, leader of the opposition Labor Party, before returning home on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Gabriel Mace, Editor Of Satirical Weekly, Dies At 72
DOC.TEXT: Gabriel Mace, editor in chief of the satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaine, has died of heart disease, the newspaper announced today. He was 72. Mace, who died at a Paris hospital Saturday, joined the newspaper's staff in 1947 and had been editor in chief since 1969. He wrote a weekly commentary on French politics or international affairs. His most recent column, on May 30, pondered whether other ruling couples might be wise to emulate the conjugal dramas of Argentine President Carlos Menem and his wife, Zulema. Le Canard Enchaine, known for its investigative reporting as well as its humor, aims its satire at virtually every sector of the French establishment, including the church, the military and politicians from the far right to the far left. The announcement did not give funeral arrangements or say whether there were any survivors.

DOC.HEAD: WASH: parental notification
DOC.TEXT: The Ohio law requires that one parent be notified. The court, by a 5-4 vote, said the Minnesota law interferes too much with minors' constituional right to abortion. The ruling marked the first time Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who joined the court as its only woman in 1981, voted to invalidate a state-imposed restriction on abortion. The court voted 6-3 to uphold Ohio's law, with O'Connor joining the majority. Neither decision appeared to carry major impact for the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. O'Connor is viewed as a pivotal vote on the future of the 1973 ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Allows Visits by Chinese Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The government announced today that Chinese journalists will be allowed to visit Taiwan for the first time in four decades. Rules approved by the Cabinet's Mainland Affairs Committee also permit visits by Chinese scholars, artists, athletes and entertainers for up to two months, government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming said. But Chinese who belong to the Communist Party will have to renounce their membership in a written statement before they can come to Taiwan, he said. The new regulations go into effect July 1, the spokesman said. Although the Nationalist Chinese government of Taiwan is the archrival of the Chinese Communists, hostility between the two sides has eased in recent years. The Nationalist government fled to the island of Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces on the Chinese mainland. Taiwan already allows substantial unofficial contacts with China. About 1 million Taiwan residents have visited the mainland since the Nationalists dropped a travel ban in 1987. Only a small number of Chinese dissidents and Chinese with ailing relatives living in Taiwan have been allowed to visit the island, however.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers Return to U.S. After Delivering Relief Supplies to Iran
With PM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
LaserPhoto HF1
DOC.TEXT: A group of American relief workers returned to the United States this morning from Iran, saying they were received warmly after dropping off the first largescale U.S. aid since the hostage crisis a decade ago. ``One guy gave me a big bear hug and said, `Thank you for coming,''' said Dr. David Reed, a volunteer physician with the relief organization AmeriCares. ``I said, `I bet it's been a long time since you hugged an American,' and he just smiled.'' The earthquake that devastated parts of northern Iran on Thursday killed an estimated 50,000 people. The Boeing 707 jetliner carrying eight volunteers from AmeriCares landed at about 6:30 a.m. after a 14-hour flight from Tehran. On Sunday, the volunteers delivered an estimated $1 million worth of supplies for earthquake victims, including blankets, shovels, bandages and antiseptic burn cream, tents with built-in fiberglass frames and orange slices in syrup. The eight volunteers had hoped to remain in Iran to help with the relief effort. There were conflicting reports about why they didn't stay longer than the four hours it took to unload the 40 tons of supplies in Tehran. Reed said the group was told that the Bush administration wouldn't let volunteers travel beyond the airport because of concerns about security. But Stephen Norman, vice president of the relief group, said earlier the group had been unable to get visas from Iranian authorities. Reed said the Iranians seemed disappointed that the Americans had to leave and gave them a hot meal of lamb, rice and broiled tomatoes before they took off. ``I saw a bunch of dumbfounded but grateful people,'' said Stephen Johnson, president of AmeriCares. ``Virtually everyone we talked to said to tell the American people, `We're grateful.''' Aftershocks continued to rock northern Iran on Sunday and landslides blocked roads, hampering recovery efforts after Thursday's earthquake, which some officials estimate killed 50,000 people. The cargo pallets heaped with supplies, mostly from American pharmaceutical companies and private individuals, each bore an American flag and a hand-lettered sign in Farsi reading: ``From the American people to the Iranian people with very great affection and love, we offer you these things.'' It was the first overt U.S. shipment of its kind to be accepted by Iran since the hostage crisis of 1979-81, when 52 American hostages were held at the U.S. embassy in Tehran for 444 days. The two nations have no diplomatic ties. Johnson said AmeriCares, which is based in New Canaan, Conn., hopes to have another shipment of supplies ready soon. AmeriCares officials said they received scores of telephone calls both opposing and supporting the relief effort even before the shipment left Connecticut on Saturday. Reed said he told one critic of relief to Iran that ``these are people, not a political institution. They've been devastated by an earthquake.'' The U.S. relief shipment also had some critics in Iran. A radical newspaper considered a mouthpiece of hard-line opponents of President Hashemi Rafsansjani urged Sunday that no help be accepted from the United States and other countries whose hands ``are stained with the blood of the Iranian people.'' But the Foreign Ministry said Sunday that Iran would accept all aid ``due to the magnitude of the disaster.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Seek Final Agreement on Structural Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the United States began a final round of talks today on extensive structural reforms aimed at improving trade, investment and the quality of life in both nations. Officials are trying to finish a final report on the talks, dubbed the Structural Impediments Initiative, before the Houston summit of seven major industrialized nations begins July 9. The talks began in July 1989 as an effort to help cut Japan's massive trade imbalance with the United States by reforming business practices and policies that are believed to act as structural trade and investment barriers. Last year, Japan had a $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Washington has committed itself to cutting the federal budget deficit, encouraging savings, curbing excessive consumption and improving worker training and education. Japan has pledged to ease rules on opening retail stores, speed processing of patent applications, crack down on unfair business practices and increase public works spending. Talks began today with a discussion of Japan's land-use policies, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. U.S. officials say reforms are needed to deflate excessively high real estate prices that prevent foreign firms from setting up business here. The issue of Japan's public works spending was expected to be a subject of debate during this week's talks. Both nations agree that Japan should spend more on parks, roads and sewers to stimulate more imports and to reduce the imbalance between savings and investment in this thrifty nation. But they disagree over exactly how much more should be spent. U.S. officials appear to have given up a demand they voiced last week that Japan pledge a specific percentage of its annual gross national product to public works. The gross national product is the total value of a nation's goods and services. Japanese officials rejected committing such a percentage to such projects because it would limit the government's flexibility. Economists say Japan's booming economy has a limited capacity to absorb an increase in public spending without stimulating inflation. A senior U.S. official rejected that argument Sunday. It ``suggests that the Japanese people should be eternally resigned to having inadequate infrastructure,'' said Charles Dallara, assistant treasury secretary. Less than half of Japanese homes are connected to sewers, and development of other public facilities in this overcrowded nation lags behind other industrialized countries.

DOC.HEAD: Government Frees Without Trial Leaders of Aborted Coup
DOC.TEXT: The military government has released four leaders of an alleged coup attempt foiled on March 15, a newspaper reported today. The state-owned al-Inkaz al-Watani said in an unattributed story that the freed men included three former senior officials. They were not put on trial, the newspaper said. It gave no explanation for the release, and there was no comment from the government. Several dozen Sudanese were arrested following the alleged coup attempt in March but were not prosecuted. In April, the government claimed it had foiled a second coup related to the March attempt. The alleged perpetrators of the second attempt were dealt with immediately and severely. Military authorities executed by firing squad 28 active or retired army officers after a summary court-martial. Sixteen army officers received prison terms up to life and another 13 senior officers were cashiered. The newspaper identified the released men as retired Gen. Mahdi Babo Nimir, a former chief of staff; retired Maj. Gen. Fadlalla Burma Nasser, a former minister of state for defense; and Abdul-Rasoul Nour, governor of the western Kordofan region. The fourth was identified as Tayeb Mohammad Tayeb but his occupation was not given. The four are members of the now-dissolved Umma Party, whose leader is former Prime Minister Sadek Mahdi. Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan Bashir overthrew Mahdi last June 30 in a military coup. The newspaper did not say whether others remained in custody in connection with the March coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: `New Kids' Member Hospitalized After Fall on Stage
DOC.TEXT: A member of the New Kids on the Block singing group was hospitalized today after suffering injuries during a performance, apparently after falling through a trap door on the stage floor, officials said. Donnie Wahlberg, 20, suffered bruises to his chest and cuts to his arms and mouth when he crashed through an unsealed trap door late in Sunday night's concert at the Saratoga Raceway, said Skip Carlson, director of publicity for the raceway. ``I was told the door just gave way and he went down through it,'' Carlson said, adding he wasn't sure exactly what happened. Wahlberg was admitted at Saratoga Hospital at about midnight for treatment, said Helen Edelman, director of community relations for the hospital. ``He's sound asleep in stable condition with his bodyguard,'' Edelman said this morning. Edelman said fans had been appearing at the hospital all morning and that ``balloons and flowers from hundreds of well-wishers are on the way.'' She did not know when Wahberg would be released. Wahlberg, of Beech Tree, Mass., is one of five New Kids, a group known for its tightly choreographed shows and rabid teen-age following. Among its hits is the record ``Step by Step.'' More than 30,000 screaming fans turned out for the outdoor concert at the harness horse track. Emergency medical workers treated 18 people for heat exhaustion and four of them were taken to Saratoga Hospital. Concert promoters could not immediately be reached to say whether the injury would curtail the New Kids' tour schedule. Sunday's show was the second on the tour.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch, West German Soccer Fans Stage Cross-Border Battle
DOC.TEXT: Dutch and West German police early today dispersed hundreds of brick-hurling soccer fans in a cross-border riot following West Germany's 2-1 World Cup win over the Netherlands, police said. At least four people were injured during the riot, which lasted more than three hours, said a Kerkrade police spokesman, Hein Quaedvlieg. Hundreds of Dutch and West German soccer fans threw bricks and beer bottles at each other in a street that marks the frontier between the two countries, he said. Police from both sides of the border made baton charges to disperse the crowd, he said. Dutch TV put the number of rioters at 1,000. There were nine arrests in the Netherlands and an unknown number in West Germany, Quaedflieg said. There were no reports of riots in Milan, where tens of thousands of fans from both nations saw West Germany advance to the World Cup quarterfinals.

DOC.HEAD: Homosexuals Take to Streets in Gay-Pride Celebrations
With PM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8-9th grafs, `There also...', with 4 grafs to add detail on marches in Seattle, Toronto. Picks up 10th graf, `In San...'. Note contents 2nd graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos FX2, NY5
DOC.TEXT: More than 500,000 people took to the streets from California to New York in gay pride celebrations that mixed solemn protests over AIDS with cavorting by lesbian bikers and men in mermaid costumes. ``Some people say, `My God, it's faggots and queers,''' Debbie Holmes, a parade coordinator in Houston, said Sunday. ``What they don't see is we are mothers and brothers and their next-door neighbors. We're not monsters.'' Marches, rallies and parades were held in 25 cities nationwide. The largest crowds gathered for parades in New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles. ``It's the one time of the year that we really show our strength and our unity and our solidarity. We celebrate our pride. We let the world know that we're not going to go back in the closet,'' said Bill Anderson, a spokesman for the 21st annual parade in New York that drew about 200,000 people. In Chicago, where Mayor Richard M. Daley led the city's 21st annual parade, police said about 100,000 people marched or lined the two-mile route to Lincoln Park. A rally drew thousands of people in Miami. ``I think it's very important that the gay community stick together and recognize they are 10 percent of the vote and we exercise our political clout,'' participant John O'Rielly said. About 20,000 people marched through downtown Toronto to mark Gay Pride Day. Floats included an all-male wedding party with bridesmaids dressed in pink. In West Hollywood, Calif., dancing men in mermaid outfits marched with AIDS activists before a crowd of about 250,000. Some marchers lay on the pavement while people outlined their bodies in chalk to symbolize the death toll from AIDS. Some marchers in Seattle dropped to the ground every few blocks to dramatize AIDS deaths. An organizer estimated turnout at 25,000. There also were marches or rallies Saturday and Sunday in Hartford, Conn.; Honolulu; Kansas City; Montpelier, Vt.; Denver; Lansing, Mich.; Atlanta; and Tampa, Fla. In San Francisco, where protesters shouted down U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan at the international AIDS conference, the Dykes on Bikes motorcyclists led a 20th annual parade. ``Dykes on Bikes is a holdover from the gay parade of 10 years ago, when it was more of a drag-queen-disco type of parade. But times change and other things become important,'' said Kurt Fletcher of San Francisco. Since AIDS surfaced in the early 1980s, the parade's nudity and erotic romping have been toned down. This year, more than 40 AIDS organizations marched. One group carried a 20-foot banner that read: ``Not Sponsored by Sen. Jesse Helms.'' In front of it, a drag queen in high heels and pink body paint bore a big pink cross with the message: ``Martyrs for Art.'' Mayor Art Agnos, the first San Francisco mayor to participate in the gay parade in 1988, led other politicians and civic leaders in the march. New York's Mayor David Dinkins marched in his city's parade, which was led by lesbian bikers. At St. Patrick's Cathedral, counter-demonstrators heckled marchers beneath a banner that read ``Excommunicate Now.'' The marchers halted and kept silent for a few minutes in memory of those who have died from AIDS. They held up small magenta satin ribbons, each bearing the name of someone lost to AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Fundmanentalist Afghan Clerics Condemn Education For Women
DOC.TEXT: Moslem clerics claiming to represent the Afghan guerrilla movement condemned education for women and warned of a ``greater catastrophe than communism'' unless schools for women were closed. But a spokesman for a self-declared guerrilla ``government-in-exile'' said today the view was not the policy of his coalition of U.S.-backed guerrillas fighting the Afghan government. In a poster-sized edict 80 mullahs, or Islamic clerics, said ``women attending schools where subjects like English, history and geography are being taught instead of Islamic texts and roles are disgraceful.'' The lengthy edict, written in Afghanistan's native Pushto language, also said women must not go out without their husband's permission, laugh when speaking, wear perfume, speak to strangers, look at a man with ``a sexual sense'' or wear clothing that rustles. Under the edict, woman must only wear a traditional head-to-toe blanket-like covering. In the past several months fundamentalist rebels have threatened ``revolutionary action'' against Afghan women working with foreign aid groups or teaching at Afghan-run schools. Many women say they fear retribution if they talk to Western journalists. Najibullah Lefray, spokesman for the rebel government, based in Pakistan's frontier city of Peshawar, said today that the edict was written by a ``section of the ulema,'' or council of clerics. ``It is not the policy of the (guerrilla) government. ... In Islam seeking knowledge is a religious obligation for men and women and it does not differentiate between religious and other learning,'' said Lefray. ``The first thing will be to invite the ulema who have signed this and make them understand that this is not the view of all the ulema and then we should try to convince them to change their minds,'' he said. When about 115,000 Soviet soldiers left Afghanistan in February 1989 after nine years of military intervention, the rebel government-in-exile was touted by its Western backers as a likely replacement to the communist-style government Moscow left behind in Kabul. But the government has degenerated into a chaotic collection of bickering rebel warlords, say many Afghan and Western analysts. More than 3 million Afghan war refugees fled to Pakistan after the 1979 military intervention of Soviet troops in Afghanistan. Another 2 million live in Iran. Rebel fighters have refused to lay down their weapons until Kabul's Soviet-style government has been toppled.

DOC.HEAD: Dissidents' Son Concerned About Those Still Jailed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of Britain.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Fang, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The college student son of Chinese dissidents says he's happy his parents were allowed to leave China today, but he expressed concern for those still jailed in his homeland for pro-democracy actions. Fang Lizhi, and his wife, Li Shuxian, left China for Britain today. They had sought refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Bejing after the June 4, 1989, military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. ``I feel happy for my family and for their release ... but we don't know the exact number of people still in jail,'' said their son, Fang Ke, a student at Wayne State University in Detroit. Fang Ke said he doubted the Chinese government's explanation that his parents were allowed to leave because they had repudiated their role in the democracy movement and needed medical care. Neither was particularly ill, said Fang Ke, who said he kept in touch with his parents by letter during their year at the embassy. They have another son in China. Fang Ke said he hoped to visit them soon in Britain. ``I am happy to see the very real possibility for me in the near future to see them,'' Fang Ke said.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Agrees to Decide Case on Job Safety
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide who _ the secretary of labor or a safety and health review board _ has the last word on what federal regulations require for on-the-job safety. The court's decision, expected sometime next year, will determine whether CF&I Steel Corp. of Pueblo, Colo., must pay a $10,000 fine for not making sure the respirators given to coke oven workers fit them properly. CF&I was fined in 1979 by the secretary of labor, but the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission set aside the fine in 1986. The secretary of labor had interpreted a regulation governing employee exposure to coke oven emissions as a ``testing standard'' that imposes an obligation by employers to make sure respirators fit. But the commission interpreted the regulation as a ``training standard'' not requiring such employer assurances of proper fits. CF&I produces coke, a coal derivative, to fuel the blast furnaces of its steel plant in Pueblo. The Labor Department in 1976 determined that coke oven emissions are cancer-causing, and issued safety standards limiting exposure to them. The standard permits the use of respirators as one method of compliance. CF&I was cited in 1977 for several coke emission violations, and again in 1979. One of the Labor Department citations issued in 1979 imposed the $10,000 fine for ``willful'' violation of the respirator regulation. An administrative law judge for the review commission upheld the citation, but the commission reversed that judgment. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last December ruled against the secretary of labor. ``In the face of conflicting regulatory interpretations, deference is properly accorded to the interpretation of the commission,'' the appeals court said. Other appeals courts have reached the opposite conclusion. The commission, created under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, hears disputes over safety citations and penalties. It does not have the power to review safety and health standards issued by the federal government. That reviewing authority is held by federal appeals courts. The case is Dole vs. Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission, 89-1541.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Nancy Cruzan Right-To-Die Case
With PM-Scotus-Right-To-Die
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major events in the Nancy Cruzan right-to-die case: _ Jan. 11, 1983: Nancy Cruzan, then 25, has a car wreck on a country road southeast of Carthage, Mo., in the Ozarks of southwest Missouri. Thrown from the car, she is first thought to be dead. Paramedics restart her breathing, but her brain is without oxygen for so long that she never regains consciousness. _ Feb. 5, 1983: Doctors surgically implant a feeding tube in Ms. Cruzan's stomach, at a time when her prognosis is uncertain. Through it, she receives food and water to keep her alive. She isn't on any life support system, such as a respirator. _ Oct. 19, 1983: Ms. Cruzan is moved to the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon, where she remains. Her parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan of Carterville, Mo., visit her on a regular basis. _ Oct. 23, 1987: The Cruzans ask Jasper County Circuit Court for a judgment on their request that they be allowed to have Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube removed, so their daughter can die, as they believe she would want. _ March 9, 1988: A three-day hearing begins on the family's request. The Cruzans say their daughter has a common-law right to be free from unwanted medical treatment, and state and federal constitutional rights to privacy that protects her right to refuse unwanted medical treatment. _ July 27, 1988: Jasper County Circuit Judge Charles Teel Jr. issues a judgment authorizing the Cruzans, acting as Nancy's legal guardians, to request the withholding of food and water from their daughter. _ Aug. 3, 1988: Missouri Attorney General William Webster files notice to the circuit court that the state will appeal the ruling to the Missouri Supreme Court. _ Sept. 29, 1988: The Missouri Supreme Court hears arguments in the case, with Ms. Cruzan's family watching in the courtroom. _ Nov. 16, 1988: In a 4-3 decision, the Missouri Supreme Court overturns the lower court, holding there is no legal authority to grant the Cruzans' request. The family then appeals to the U.S. Supreme Court. _ Dec. 6, 1989: The nation's highest court hears arguments in the Cruzan case. It's the first right-to-die case that the court has considered. _ June 25, 1990: The U.S. Supreme Court bars the removal of a life-sustaining tube from Ms. Cruzan.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Exempt Mining Industry from Hazardous Waste Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to exempt the mining industry from some federal environmental rules for treating, storing and disposing of hazardous waste. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the American Mining Congress and a mining company, Solite Corp. The two challenged a 1987 decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to apply the hazardous waste regulations to the mining industry. The industry said it should be exempt under a 1980 law called the Bevill Amendment, which temporarily excluded some solid wastes from EPA rules until the agency could complete a study. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last year the EPA did not exceed its power in enforcing the regulations for the mining industry. The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court to reject the industry appeal. Justice Department lawyers noted that waste generated from mining, including ash and sludge, was believed to pose less of a hazard to the environment than other forms of toxic waste. But, the government said, chemicals and compounds are released from the mining wastes ``that are known to have adverse effects on humans or other life forms.'' The government said it therefore was appropriate for the EPA to apply stringent rules to the mining wastes. The case is American Mining Congress vs. Environmental Protection Agency, 89-1511.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Batters Eastern China, Another Gains Strength in Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Ofelia battered China's eastern coast, killing 10 people, capsizing more than 1,600 boats and destroying thousands of homes, the official Xinhua News Agency said today. At least 47 people were killed when the typhoon earlier ripped through the Philippines and Taiwan. Ofelia was the worst storm to hit eastern Taiwan in 30 years. Another storm, Typhoon Percy, gained strength today as it headed toward the Philippines. Typhoon Ofelia battered eight cities in China's Zhejiang province on Sunday, killing 10 people and destroying 3,700 homes, Xinhua said. The report said 1,696 boats were capsized and 50 miles of levees were breached in the storm. Ofelia first struck the eastern coast of Luzon, the main Philippine island, on Friday. Philippine officials said at least 30 residents were killed, and more than 84,000 were forced to flee their homes because of flooding and landslides. The typhoon hit Taiwan later Friday, triggering mudslides and leveling 200 homes in the eastern Taiwan province of Hualien. Police said the death toll rose to 17 today, and 23 people were reported missing. In Manila, forecasters said Typhoon Percy, packing 115 mph winds, was centered 335 miles east of the Philippine island of Catanduanes. Percy was moving west-northwest at about 14 mph toward Catanduanes and southeastern Luzon island, which were expected to feel the effects of the storm late today, the weather bureau said. One child was killed when Percy swept by the Pacific island cluster of Palau on Sunday, the Pacific Daily News of Guam reported. Earlier Sunday, the typhoon's winds battered Yap Island in the neighboring Federated States of Micronesia, knocking down about 30 houses and damaging banana and coconut plantations, police said. There were no reports of injuries on Yap.

DOC.HEAD: Court Fails to Revive Racial Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a 14-year-old lawsuit by a Texas oil refinery's black employees who say they are victims of racial discrimination. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that dismissed the suit against a union and Gulf Oil Corp. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in December threw out the 1976 suit by employees at a Gulf Oil refinery in Port Arthur. The appeals court said a federal judge who ruled against the workers ``was not clearly erroneous'' in deciding that revised seniority and promotion rules at the refinery did not discriminate intentionally against blacks. The appeals court also upheld the judge's findings that the seniority rules and promotion tests had legitimate business purposes even if, unintentionally, they disproportionately favored white workers. The plant maintained a strictly segregated work force until the mid-1950s, with blacks in unskilled jobs and whites in skilled craft positions. As that began to change, the company in 1967 changed job-classification rules in an agreement with the Oil Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union. Gulf Oil said the new rules were designed to streamline operations and promote efficiency. Blacks said the rules locked them into lower-ranking jobs by promoting craft helpers, most of them white, into trainee positions ahead of blacks with more seniority. The black workers also challenged the use of written tests, revised in 1971, that had the effect of promoting whites disproportionately. For example, nearly every white worker who took the tests between 1971 and 1980 passed, while only two-thirds of the blacks passed. The black employees said the tests were unrelated to job performance. But Gulf said statistics showed that those who did well on the tests also did well in their new jobs. The 5th Circuit Court, in dismissing the suit, relied in part on a key Supreme Court ruling last year that makes it harder for workers to prove bias. The appeals court said the high court ruling means that employers accused of bias can prevail merely by producing evidence, not proof, that the challenged practice ``serves in a significant way the legitimate employment goals of the employer.'' The black workers also questioned whether the appeals court gave too broad an interpretation to another 1989 high court decision that limits the time frame for some bias suits. In that ruling, the justices said the deadline for filing a suit is determined by the date an allegedly biased seniority plan is adopted, not when an individual worker is affected by the plan. Congress is seeking to overturn or modify both 1989 high court rulings as part of a legislative civil rights package. The legislation is the subject of negotiations in the House and Senate and with the Bush administration. The case is Bernard vs. Gulf Oil, 89-1617.

DOC.HEAD: Comsat Has to Refund $38.8 Million Under High Court Decision
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to free Communications Satellite Corp. from having to refund $38.8 million to its customers. The court, without comment, rejected arguments by Comsat that the Federal Communications Commission exceeded its authority in ordering the refunds. The commission said the refunds represent revenue Comsat received in excess of its allowed profit margin of 12.48 percent between Aug. 1, 1984, and Dec. 31, 1986. Comsat is a publicly owned company created by Congress to act as the U.S. member of Intelsat, a consortium of 119 countries and territories that operate a network of satellites for international communications. Comsat, a monopoly regulated by the FCC, channels U.S. traffic to and from the satellites. Its main customer is American Telephone & Telegraph Co. The FCC initially said Comsat's revenues exceeded its permitted rate of return by nearly $62 million. The agency reduced the amount of the refunds in 1987. Comsat said the commission, in effect, illegally ordered the satellite corporation to reduce its rates retroactively. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rejected Comsat's arguments in a two-page order last year. The case is Communications Satellite Corp. vs. FCC, 89-1687.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Death Row Inmate Loses High Court Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A Virginia death row inmate who killed a deputy sheriff in an escape attempt lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court left intact a ruling that Wilbert Lee Evans' rights were not violated when he was resentenced to death after his original death sentence was overturned. Evans was convicted of fatally shooting William Truesdale on Jan. 27, 1981, while the deputy was escorting him from a North Carolina prison to testify in Alexandria, Va. Evans said he didn't intend to kill Truesdale but that the gun went off accidentally in their struggle. Prosecutors said Evans deliberately killed the deputy in a planned escape. Evans was sentenced to death in 1981 but nearly two years later prosecutors admitted that, although unknown to them at the time, the sentence was based on erroneous evidence of his prior convictions. A judge threw out the death sentence, but Evans again received the sentence in March 1984 after a jury recommended capital punishment because of Evans' ``future dangerousness.'' Virginia enacted a law in March 1983 to permit a second death sentence when a death penalty is overturned because of sentencing errors. Evans contended that the law unconstitutionally was applied retroactively to him. Without the law, his sentence automatically would have been reduced to life in prison. But the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said applying the new law to Evans was fair because at the time he killed Truesdale he knew he could be sentenced to die. ``Fair warning of punishment was thus afforded'' to Evans, the appeals court said. He ``was on notice when he murdered deputy sheriff Truesdale that the imposition of death was a possible penalty.'' Evans also said the jury that sentenced him to death the second time was misled by the trial judge. The jury asked the judge what would happen if it split over the punishment for Evans. Rather than tell the jurors a split decision automatically would mean a life prison sentence, the judge said their ``verdict must be unanimous as to either life imprisonment or death.'' The 4th Circuit court said the judge had no obligation ``to inform the jury of the ultimate result should they fail to reach a verdict.'' The appeals court also rejected Evans' argument that prosecutors violated his rights by failing to disclose for two years after his first sentencing that the sentence was based on erroneous evidence. The appeals court said prosecutors acted in good faith and were not aware until then of the errors. Evans also disputed the jury's finding that he is a danger to society. He said that shortly after he was resentenced he helped head off violence when other prisoners at Mecklenburg, N.C., Correctional Center seized 14 guards as hostages. Evans said the hostages credited him with saving their lives. The case is Evans vs. Thompson, 89-516

DOC.HEAD: As Temperatures Soar, Wildfire Burns 6,000 Acres On Island In Great Salt Lake
DOC.TEXT: A wildfire caused by dry lightning has scorched thousands of acres of grassland on this island in the Great Salt Lake as 100-plus temperatures in the region made firefighting difficult. Mitch Larson, state park superintendent, said a team from the Utah State Prison was put on the out-of-control blaze this morning and hoped to make headway against the fire before this afternoon, when temperatures were expected to top 100 again. He estimated that the fire has scorched about 6,000 acres of grassland, but said a plane would fly over the fire later today to get a better estimate. ``We're really concerned about it,'' Larson said. ``It's going through a lot of good grass that has just made a comeback in the last four years.'' The island, 7 miles long, 1 mile wide and covering 28,000 acres, is mainly a state park, although there are small parcels in private ownership. The rising waters of the Great Salt Lake inundated a causeway leading to the island several years ago, forcing officials to close the park. State wildlife biologists estimate that 600 buffalo live on the island along with mule deer, bobcats and several species of migratory birds. The fire was sparked by a series of dry-lightning storms that passed over northern Utah on Sunday. Temperatures in the Salt Lake City area reached 100 degrees on Saturday and Sunday, and were expected to reach triple figures again today. National Weather Service Meteorologist Bill Alder said the broiling temperatures caused a series of ``micro bursts,'' which are dry storms accompanied by lightning. Alder said wind speeds topped 60 mph in several locations on Sunday, and emergency lines were flooded with calls of power lines knocked down and power polls on fire. There's no end in sight for the severe heat wave, he said. Pete Hansen, an Interagency Fire Center spokesman, said lightning also set fire to a tree in the Lone Peak Wilderness Area on the southern end of the Salt Lake Valley. Because the fire was in a wilderness area and naturally caused, it would be allowed to burn, although it would be monitored closely, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede PHILADELPHIA
Bankers Want to Put Trump on an Allowance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details of spending restrictions and bridge loan being prepared. No pickup. A NEW YORK-dated version moved on financial wires. ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump would be put on a $450,000-a-month budget to get the $65 million bank loan he needs to see his way through a cash crunch, newspapers reported today. Under the tentative deal, the syndicate of banks would lend Trump $65 million on the condition they be allowed to name two executives to run the Trump empire. The deal would prohibit Trump from moving money among his companies without permission and put him on a personal budget of $450,000 a month this year, less in subsequent years, according to reports in The New York Times and The Philadelphia Inquirer. On June 15, Trump missed a $43 million payment on bonds issued to finance the Trump Castle casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Under a grace period, he has until midnight Tuesday before he can be declared in default. A default on the Castle bonds could trigger defaults on bank loans secured by other properties, which could then be seized, and it could affect his gaming license in New Jersey. A banker who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press on Sunday that a West German bank and a French bank hold the key to Trump's hopes of raising the $65 million in the next two days. Trump's main banks _ Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover _ have agreed to the restructuring. But Dresdner Bank AG and Societe Generale are balking at terms of the deal, said the banker. ``If they don't agree, there won't be any deal,'' said the source. ``If there's no deal, then either he comes up with the cash from some other source ... or he defaults and perhaps declares bankruptcy on the casino and related properties.'' A $20 million bridge loan is being prepared to tide Trump over while the paperwork for the larger loan is completed, the Times reported today. The newspaper, quoting unidentified bankers involved in the negotiations, said before the 30-day financing can be extended, an agreement on the bigger loan must be obtained. Terms of the broad loan agreement include stringent restrictions on Trump's personal and business finances, the newspapers reported. An allowance is certain to put a damper on the lifestyle Trump enjoyed during the 1980s. His playthings include a 284-foot yacht, a 118-room Florida mansion and a helicopter and a jet for his personal use. The restrictions limit Trump's monthly charitable contributions to $100,000 and stipulate that his household and personal expenses not exceed $450,000 a month for the rest of this year, $375,000 a month in 1991 and $300,000 a month in 1992. Trump has been negotiating with the banks in recent weeks to restructure his debts and avert what could be a string of defaults in his real estate and casino empire. Under the proposed plan, the banks would extend Trump money to make overdue payments on the bond issue and suspend some payments on his $2 billion in bank loans in exchange for equity in some of his properties.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says `Nyet' to Soviet Suggestion
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney today rejected a Soviet suggestion for withdrawing foreign troops from Berlin. ``The problem, of course, is once you take troops out of Berlin you've still got Berlin inside what is currently East Germany surrounded by some 380,000 Soviet troops that are not leaving immediately,'' Cheney said in an interview on Fox-TV. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's suggested Friday that 15,000 British, American, French and Soviet troops leave Berlin six months after the Germanys unite. Cheney said the United States was likely to follow instead the proposal of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and others that U.S. forces remain in Berlin until Soviet forces are out of eastern Germany. Cheney also said the administration was prepared to reduce the defense budget ``in a cautious, orderly fashion.'' ``It ought to be done in connection with events as they develop in the outside world and shouldn't be done based upon wishful thinking,'' he said. Shevardnadze's proposal, which he outlined at a foreign ministers' meeting in Berlin, also drew strong objections from Secretary of States James A. Baker III. Cheney said it was his job to ``remind people that we have to deal with the real world as we find it, not as we hope it will change.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Open Fire On Food Rioters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with police blocking main routes, president reported out of capital; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire today on hundreds of stone-throwing university students who were protesting a doubling of the price of corn meal, Zambia's staple. No details were immediately available on casualties. But residents of Lusaka's suburb of Kalingalinga said they saw at least two people fall when police fired their rifles at demonstrators. They told reporters that police fired tear-gas canisters as well as live ammunition and charged, beat and seized protesters. It was unclear how many protesters were arrested. Police sealed the main routes to the city center as scores of ordinary residents and schoolchildren joined the student protesters. Looters reportedly smashed display windows and ran off with television sets, video cassette recorders, radios, liquor and food, witnesses said. Police barred everyone including journalists from entering the city center. By nightfall, military helicopters hovered overhead as security force units scattered the rioters. The protests began when about 2,000 students marched through suburbs near the main Zambia university campus in eastern Lusaka.
