As the protests spread to six residential suburbs known as townships, students burned ruling party flags. They chanted slogans against the United National Indpendence Party, the only legal political party in this southern African nation of 7.5 million people. ``We wanted to ignite the spark to set the fire alight in the townships. Now that fire is raging,'' said one student leader on condition of anonymity. Witnesses said several groups of students were beaten with truncheons and rifle butts before being forced onto police trucks at gunpoint. A witness who asked not to be identified said many residents fled to open fields. The windows of several police vehicles were smashed, and rocks and broken glass littered the roads. Last Tuesday, the government more than doubled the price of corn meal. The increase, in line with the recommendations of international financial institutions and donor nations, sparked protest marches, panic buying and a threat of labor unrest. Student protesters held a meeting Sunday and condemned the price increase. They also called for the resignation of Prime Minister Malimba Masheke, who announced it on Tuesday. The students also called for an end to the one-party political system that has been headed by President Kenneth Kaunda for nearly two decades. Kaunda was reported to have left Lusaka today for a vacation at his country home in eastern Zambia. Zambia is one of Africa's poorest and most indebted nations. Comparable food price increases in December 1986 led to violent clashes between troops and protesters that left 15 people dead.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Meets With Ukrainian Bishops, Urges Reconcilation With Orthodox
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II met for the first time today with the bishops of the Ukrainian Catholic Church and hailed their emergence from more than four decades of Soviet repression. But he also urged them to make peace with the Russian Orthodox, antagonists since the Ukrainian church was suppressed by dictator Josef Stalin in 1946, to strengthen the role of Christianity in a Europe emerging from Communist rule. The Ukrainians, the pope said, must be ``a bridge and in no way an obstacle'' to better relations among Christians. Other hurdles to improved Vatican-Kremlin ties have fallen under the leadership of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Ukrainian issue, however, has remained a stumbling block and differences between the Ukrainians and the Vatican have come to the surface. In his speech to the bishops, the pope appeared to be balancing his concern for the suffering of the Ukrainian faithful ``on the cross of Christ'' with the goals of the entire church. Stalin had forcibly merged the church with government-controlled Orthodox Church. Bishops and priests who resisted were shot or imprisoned and its churches were taken over by the Orthodox. According to Western estimates, there are at least 4 million Catholics in the Ukraine. Until the Kremlin recently softened its stance on religion, they practiced their faith secretly. Bishops were named in secret and held regular jobs, ranging from a worker on a collective farm to a university professor.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: you wanted to.''
DOC.TEXT: Almost as revealing as what some lobbyists report is what they don't. Last year, California had an estimated $90 million reported spent by lobbyists. Yet in a loophole-ridden state like Pennsylvania, lobbyists as a group reported spending $362,000. That's a fraction of what was reported in smaller states like Connecticut, Montana, Mississippi, Hawaii, Nebraska, New Hampshire, South Carolina, Kentucky and Kansas. The top lobbyist in at least five states reported spending more than was reported by Pennsylvania's 799 lobbyists combined. Many former elected officials have found second careers as lobbyists; among ex-governors representing special interest groups are Marvin Mandel of Maryland and Anthony Earl and Martin Schreiber of Wisconsin. Some of the best paid lobbyists make six-figure incomes that are several times greater than even the highest paid legislators. In Maryland, for instance, lobbyist Bruce Bereano got more than $1 million in fees from 53 clients in 1989. The persuaders, not surprisingly, aren't in favor of more reporting. ``Requiring a lobbyist to report doesn't make them honest or dishonest. No lobbyist is going to report doing something illegal,'' said Hobson Waits, a lobbyist for the Electric Power Associations of Mississippi Inc. Watchdogs agree, but they say the point is the public interest would be best served if special interests reported in detail what they do to influence legislators. ``We've cut the average citizen out of the process,'' said Barry Kauffman of Pennsylvania Common Cause. ``It's the contemporary golden rule: Those with the gold make the rules,'' Kauffman said. ``People are turned off. They've passed apathy and gone to alienation. It's not their system anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Kurdish Guerrillas Killed in Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Security forces killed six suspected Kurdish guerrillas in three clashes in southeastern and eastern Turkey, the regional governor's office announced Monday. A soldier, three village security officials and two children were slain by the guerrillas, the announcement said. The statement said one guerrilla was killed in southeastern Sirnak province and four others in eastern Van province in clashes with the security forces Sunday. A soldier died in the fighting in Van, it added. It said a group of Kurdish guerrillas raided a village in eastern Bingol province Sunday, killed two children and three local security officials. A guerrilla was killed when the security officials opened fire, it said. About 2,500 people have been killed in southeastern Turkey since the guerrillas of the Kurdish Labor Party, an outlawed Marxist group, started fighting for an independent Kurdish state in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Diplomat Named Ambassador to India for Second Time
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday named its ambassador to the Soviet Union to head its embassy in India at a time when Pakistan and India are trying to ease tensions in a disputed northern region. Abdul Sattar will serve as Pakistan's high commissioner in India, or ambassador, for a second time. He first held the post from 1978 to 1982. Besides New Delhi and Moscow, Sattar, 59, has had diplomatic assignments in the United States, Sudan and Saudi Arabia. His appointment comes as India and Pakistan are preparing for high-level talks to try to ease diplomatic tensions and massive military buildups on their border, particularly in the disputed Kashmir region. A date and venue for the talks have yet to be announced but are expected early next month.

DOC.HEAD: Three Deaths Reported as Fundamentalists Clash With Police
DOC.TEXT: At least three people were killed and several injured in a desert town where Islamic fundamentalists turned to violence after losing a local election, state radio said Monday. Fundamentalists and security forces clashed Sunday in Berriane, in the southern region of M'Zab. The fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front, which won a majority of votes nationwide in June 12 local elections, lost to independent candidates in Berriane. The front's headquarters confirmed the clashes and said it knew of two deaths. The fundamentalists had filed a legal challenge against the independents' victory in Berriane, and violence broke out after the challenge was rejected by a regional judicial commission. There were reports of beatings, pillaging of stores, and arson attacks, including one on the home of the newly elected mayor. Security forces reportedly used tear gas grenades in an effort to restore order. The elections were the first contested by more than one party since Algeria's independence from France in 1962. The Islamic Salvation Front received roughly twice as many votes as the ruling National Liberation Front, which holds every seat in the National Assembly. On Saturday, Prime Minister Mouloud Hamrouche rejected the fundamentalists' demands for the dissolution of the assembly so that early national elections could be held. Such elections are not scheduled until early 1992.

DOC.HEAD: French Arms Manufacturers Seek to Combat Sales Losses
LaserPhoto PAR5
DOC.TEXT: A state-of-the-art tank was the star exhibit Monday as French weapons manufacturers opened a major show, hoping to reverse last year's sharp drop in foreign sales. More than 300 companies are displaying 3,000 types of weaponry, vehicles and equipment at the week-long arms exhibition at Satory, outside Paris. Attendance is by invitation only, and the 30,000-name guest list includes representatives of 60 foreign governments. According to press reports, proceeds from French arms exports dropped from $3.2 billion in 1988 to $300 million last year. One factor was the end of the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, which had provided France with a steady flow of orders. Both state-subsidized and private arms manufacturers in France have received moral support from the Socialist government, which has not made any proposals to reduce its military budget despite the thaw in the Cold War. The Leclerc tank unveiled at this week's show is a product of GIAT, which the government is molding into a major state-controlled armaments maker comparable to the Aerospatiale aircraft manufacturer. The 54-ton Leclerc is armed with a standard NATO 120mm cannon and will come into use in the beginning of 1992. It has been described in the French press as a prototype of the next generation of tanks _ 60 percent of its cost reportedly relates to its sophisticated electronics systems. Another major display item is the PR4G radio unit, designed by Thomson-CSF to resist enemy attempts to intercept or interfere with its operations.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Kill Four of Family in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of four Moslems were found in a Kashmir town Monday, five days after they were kidnapped by Moslem militants agitating for secession from India. The bodies, which had bullet wounds, were found in the town of Sopore about 35 miles northwest of the Kashmir capital of Srinagar, said police officials speaking on condition of anonymity. Anonymous callers to local newspapers and news agency offices said the four were killed by the Hezbul Mujahedeen because they were police informers. The Hezbul Mujahedeen is one of more than a dozen Moslem organizations fighting for independence of the Kashmir valley from India. Police officials also reported the death of one soldier in a militant ambush of an army convoy in the district of Baramulla, northwest of Srinagar. At least three soldiers were injured, they said. The deaths raise to 630 the number of people killed since security forces began a crackdown on the Moslem movement on Jan. 20. The Kashmir valley, most of which falls in the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir, is predominantly Moslem. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Moslem militants earlier had demanded union with Pakistan, the Islamic nation on India's western border. But, of late, they have been demanding independence and the status of a neutral nation.

DOC.HEAD: One Civil Guard Killed, Second Wounded In Shootout
DOC.TEXT: One policeman was killed and a second seriously wounded Monday in a shootout near this northern city, a government official said. Although police announced few details about the incident, they have not ruled out the possibility that it was a terrorist attack, said the spokesman, who was not identified by custom. The armed Basque-separatist group ETA, which seeks independence for the three-province northern Basque region, also demands the annexation of the neighboring Navarre region, of which Pamplona is the capital. The shooting occurred when two policemen on patrol in the town of Lumbier stopped to investigate when they saw three individuals they considered suspicious. The three suspects opened fire, and Sgt. Jose Luis Hervas Manas, 34, was killed in the ensuing shootout. A second policeman, Jose Dominguez Piris, was injured. Since it began its insurgency in 1968, the group has claimed responsibility for more than 600 killings and has also carried out numerous bombings of government and administrative offices.

DOC.HEAD: George Benson Headlines JVC Jazz Concert
DOC.TEXT: Guitarist-singer George Benson returned to his musical roots at the JVC Jazz Festival in a concert that emphasized jazz and not the fusion that's made him so popular in recent years. The concert Sunday night at Carnegie Hall also featured pianists Michel Camilo and McCoy Tyner. Benson, who has had big pop hits, also knows how to turn on the jazz guitar, displaying a virtuosity and freshness. Camilo, from the Dominican Republic, is a percussive pianist, who plays with excitement and joy. His new record album, ``On Fire,'' is well-named. He announced his first tune, which he composed, as ``based on a sugarcane field in the Caribbean; the joys and happiness of the people.'' With Camilo were bassist Michael Bowie and drummer Cliff Almond. They were so tight that when a song changed mood or tempo, they all shifted at exactly the same instant. Tyner, with bassist Avery Sharpe and drummer Aaron Scott, played the second set. Tyner, who was in John Coltrane's group early in his career, also plays powerhouse, chordal piano. He has a rich, full sound. ``Will You Still Be Mine?'' went on for 10 inventive minutes, all of them interesting. Benson and Tyner made an album a year ago and Benson joined Tyner's trio for its last two numbers before his own set. Benson used a cordless electric guitar and cordless microphone. He played and scatted ``Breezin'.'' The first song he sang was the bebop era's ``Moody's Mood for Love,'' which he did beautifully. Benson radiates charisma. His singing is velvety and he projects an individual personality. He, of course, sang the expected ``Everything Must Change,'' ``On Broadway'' and ``This Masquerade.'' The audience enjoyed his guitar playing on the instrumentals just as much. But the musician who took the greatest risk was Camilo, who played a tribute to Art Tatum in Tatum's style and surprising his audience by doing it so well. The JVC Jazz Festival opened Friday night and continues through June 30. Originally the Newport Jazz Festival, it is now named after its sponsor, a Japanese electronics firm.

DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales Continue to Fall
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes continued to drop in May, but falling mortgage rates helped limit the decrease, a real estate trade group said Monday. The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.29 million, down 1.2 percent from April's rate of 3.33 million. Sales in April dropped 2.1 percent. Existing home sales have dropped each month since the first of the year, except during March when they were unchanged. They totaled 3.44 million in 1989. Mortgage rates, on the other hand, have generally declined since hitting double-digit figures in January. They dropped from 10.67 percent at the beginning of May to 10.33 percent at month's end, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Rates slipped to 10.16 percent last Friday. Mortgage rates also have crimped sales of new homes, which dropped 1.6 percent in April, the fifth straight monthly decline. April's seasonally adjusted annual rate of 546,000 was the lowest level of sales since the recession year of 1982. New home sales in May will post an increase when they are announced Friday by the Commerce Department, but ``growth is certain to be held back by May's unusually rainy, chilly weather,'' according to Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist with Fuji Securities Inc. ``Nevertheless, home sales may stabilize around their year-to-date pace in coming months, as the market begins to digest the decline in mortgage lending rates,'' he wrote in the government securities dealer's current issue of Perspectives. John A. Tuccillo, Realtors chief economist, has said mortgage rates will continue drifting downward through the summer, although no sharp drops are expected. Norman A. Flynn, Realtors president, said the credit crunch found in some sectors of the real estate industry mainly affects builders rather than home buyers. The Realtors said the median price of an existing home in May was $94,800, down from $95,600 the previous month. The median price of a new home in April was $135,900, according to the Commerce Department. Existing home sales rose 1.7 percent to an annual rate of 590,000 in the West where the median price was $135,300. Sales inched up 0.8 percent to 1.31 million units in the South, which posted an $85,200 median price. Sales in the recently sluggish Northeast were unchanged at 520,000 although the median price was $141,300, up from $140,700 the previous month. Sales had peaked at 610,000 units in October. ``Overall, the Northeast market appears to be stabilizing,'' Tuccillo said. In the Midwest, where the median price was $73,100, sales of existing homes fell 4.4 percent to 880,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: Long Court Battle in Cruzan Case Over for Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 9th graf pvs, `Webster reserved...', to UPDATE with comment from governor. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Dick Kurtenbach...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Scotus-Right-to-Die
DOC.TEXT: For Joe Cruzan and his family, the legal fight to let their comatose daughter die is over. Now come the years of waiting while she lies attached to a hospital feeding tube. The U.S. Supreme Court barred the removal of her life-sustaining tube today in its first ruling in a ``right-to-die'' case. The court in a 5-4 decision said a state's interest in preserving life may overcome the wishes of family members seeking to end the life of a patient in an irreversible coma-like condition. To the family, the facts were painfully simple: They wanted death to become a reality for 32-year-old Nancy, who has been in a persistent vegetative state since a January 1983 car crash. She's kept alive by a surgically implanted feeding tube at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon. Doctors say she has no hope of recovery, but could remain alive for many years. A voice on the telephone answering machine at the home of Joe and Joyce Cruzan in Carterville, Mo., said the family will have no response to the high court's decision until they have had time to analyze the ruling. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing the majority opinion, said Missouri may require ``clear and convincing'' proof that Ms. Cruzan wants to die before allowing the withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment. Such evidence is lacking in Ms. Cruzan's case, he said. ``That's one of the arguments the state made, which apparently the majority agrees with,'' Missouri Attorney General William Webster said. Webster reserved additional comment until he could review the ruling. In a statement, Gov. John Ashcroft said he was grateful the court backed the state's position. He also said that ``our thoughts and prayers remain with the Cruzan family.'' Dick Kurtenbach, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Kansas City, which had helped Cruzans throughout their seven-year court battle, said the ruling is not a surprise given the court's recent decisions. ``We were I guess, hopeful, mainly because the decision was obviously so important to the family. It's hard not to be hopeful under those circumstances,'' he said. ``But when we looked at it realistically, and with the recent history of the court, this is not that surprising,'' he said. For Joe Cruzan, a sheet metal worker from Carterville, there's no doubt about what his daughter would have wanted. ``She would say `Pull the plug, stop it. I don't want to live like this. I have no dignity,''' Cruzan said in an interview last year. ``If she had her way, she'd like to come back like she was. That's what I wish, but it's not going to happen.'' The legal fight began when the parents realized their daughter's condition would not change, and they asked doctors to remove the feeding tube so Nancy could die. The physicians refused, and in October 1987, the family asked the Jasper County Circuit Court for permission to carry out their wishes. Nancy had left no written instructions about what she would want done under such circumstances. Circuit Judge Charles Teel ruled in July 1988 that the family could have the feeding tube removed. Webster appealed. The case went to the Missouri Supreme Court, which overturned Teel's ruling in November 1988. The family then took its case to the U.S. Supreme Court. Meanwhile, Missouri lawmakers this year tried to change the law so the feeding tube could be removed from someone like Nancy. The Missouri Catholic Conference and others lobbied hard against it and the efforts failed. M. Rose Gasner, director of legal services for New York-based Society for the Right to Die, said ``Although we're sorry for the Cruzans, in terms of the decision's effect on the law, we'll just have to keep doing what we've been doing, which is working state by state to get laws passed.''

DOC.HEAD: The Case of the Missing Milk Crates
DOC.TEXT: Perrier water is back on grocery store shelves after the recent contamination scare, but a new problem has come bubbling to the surface. A New Jersey dairy has complained that retailers used milk crates to get rid of their Perrier when it was recalled in February. Now, Farmland Dairy wants its crates back _ and it has gone to court to get them. Marc Goldman, president of Farmland, said more than 50,000 of his milk crates, worth about $3 each, were not returned by a warehouse that Perrier had contracted to dispose of the water and recycle the bottles. ``I can understand the scramble on the first day of the recall, but it's not like they called us and said, `We have your cases.' We had to catch them,'' Goldman said. A spokesman for the warehouse said it has agreed to return the Farmland crates in its possession, and that Goldman was overreacting. A spokeswoman for the Perrier Group in Greenwich, Conn., said it was doing everything possible to have the crates returned. Farmland filed a criminal complaint against Distribution Warehouse & Service Corp. after finding crates at the company's storage center in Elizabeth. The warehouse was hired by the Perrier Group to store Perrier bottles collected throughout the New York metropolitan area, spokeswoman Jane Lazgin said. Charges also were lodged against REI Recycling of Newark, which also had Farmland milk crates. REI officials could not be reached for comment because there was no telephone listing for the company. Goldman said he was preparing to file additional complaints because he suspected some of the plastic milk crates were shredded and recycled. Distribution Warehouse vice president Robert Kortenhaus said that claim was ``ridiculous.'' Perrier recalled all its water worldwide Feb. 9 after traces of the chemical benzene were found in some bottles. It returned to the U.S. market in April.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Disease Epidemics Unlikely Following Earthquakes
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fears that an epidemic of contagious disease will sweep through the bodies that remain unburied after Iran's earthquake are unfounded, health officials say. At least 50,000 people were reported killed in the earthquake that struck Thursday. Iranian officials said they are worried about the danger of infectious diseases and contamination of the water supply in part because of unburied bodies. Officials of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta say that diseases such as typhoid and cholera simply do not occur after disasters, even in the absence of vaccinations. Typhoid vaccine, for example, which was given to rescue workers after the Mexico City earthquake in 1985, does no good, officials said. The reasons are that it offers only partial protection in some people, and the partial protection begins only after several weeks. Typhoid vaccine also can cause fever, pain and headaches and vaccination diverts humans resources from the work of caring for earthquake victims, officials said. The only health threat that decomposing bodies might present is possible contamination of drinking water if the bodies are in contact with the water, doctors said. Such contamination of the water supply is considered highly unlikely, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Patient Exposed to Solution Dies
DOC.TEXT: Four patients have died after being exposed to a tainted solution used in open heart surgery at a hospital, authorities said. The latest was a 59-year-old man who died Sunday at Bryan Memorial Hospital. Chief Deputy Lancaster County Attorney Gary Lacey said the man was one of 24 people who had open heart surgery at the hospital between May 22 and June 1, when a contaminated batch of solution is known to have been used. Eight of the 24 people exposed to the solution developed infections. Two of those eight died June 5 and 6. A third person died shortly after surgery. Lacey said he did not know whether the man who died Sunday was one of the six remaining people who had developed infections. The hospital is withholding the names of all the victims. The tainted solution was mixed at the hospital pharmacy, authorities said. The solution is used to reduce damage to cells when the heart is inactive during open heart surgery. Pharmacy employees found bacterial contamination in a batch of the solution and removed the tainted samples, but failed to discard the entire batch, authorities said. The cause of the contamination is being studied by two outside consultants and the national Centers for Disease Control.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Fang Lizhi and Wife Allowed To Leave China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 7th pvs, `The White...' to UPDATE with brief stopover in Anchorage. Pickup 8th pvs, `This humanitarian...' Fang Lizhi is pronounced Fuhng Lee'-Juhr. Li Shuxian is pronounced Lee Shroo'-Shyan.
DOC.TEXT: China's best-known dissidents, physicists Fang Lizhi and his wife, Li Shuxian, left the country for Britain today after Communist authorities allowed them to end their yearlong refuge in the U.S. Embassy. The White House immediately hailed Beijing's move as a ``humanitarian action'' that will better U.S.-Chinese ties. The 54-year-old astrophysicist and his wife had sought refuge in the embassy after the June 4, 1989 military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. The official Xinhua news agency said they were given permission to leave the country for medical reasons after showing ``signs of repentance.'' It said the move was ``in line with China's policy of leniency towards those who participated in the disturbances'' of last June. Since late last year, China has announced the release of more than 800 people jailed for their participation in the democracy movement, but it is believed that thousands more remain in jail. Fang and Li were bound for Britain aboard a U.S. C-135 air transport. The plane stopped briefly at Elmendorf Air Force Base in Anchorage, Alaska early today and transferred to another military plane with a fresh crew. The couple waved to onlookers but made no comments as they transferred planes, said Maj. Doug McCoy, an Air Force spokesman. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Fang and Li would arrive in London early Tuesday. He said Fang had accepted a job at Cambridge University. ``This humanitarian action is a far-sighted, significant step that will improve the atmosphere for progress in our bilateral relations,'' he said in a statement, adding that President Bush was informed of the development late Sunday. He did not disclose when or how the agreement to allow the couple free passage had been reached. Fang has been China's most outspoken and eloquent proponent of democratic reform. He and Li were well known for their advocacy of democracy and human rights in China well before the seven-week pro-democracy movement gelled. Hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed in the military assault on central Beijing and thousands of activists were subsequently arrested. Fang and Li did not play an active role in the student-led protests, but after the crackdown the the Communist government accused them of inciting the unrest. They took refuge in the U.S. Embassy in the days following the crackdown, and American diplomats refused to turn them over to Chinese authorities. Washington also imposed sanctions that cut shipments of military hardware and U.S.-Chinese relations deteriorated. Their release appeared timed by the Chinese for maximum political results. The seven leading industrialized nations are to hold their annual meeting July 9-11 in Houston, and policy toward China is to be a major subject. Congress is also debating Bush's decision last month to extend most-favored-nation trading status to China for another year. The Fang case has been cited by some members of Congress demanding revocation of the status, which reduces tariffs on Chinese goods sold in the United States. Chinese authorities had said that in order to be released, Fang and Li would have to confess ``guilt'' and promise not to carry out any anti-government activities. Xinhua said the two had recently admitted in writing that they have opposed socialist principles and the leadership of the Communist Party, thus violating the country's constitution. It also said the two had agreed not to engage in ``activities directed against China.'' The report did not say what their medical problems were. Their son Fang Ke, a student at Wayne State University in Detroit, said earlier this month that his parents were in good spirits and continued their scientific work in the embassy. ``I am happy to see the very real possibility for me in the near future to see them,'' he said today. Fang Ke said he doubted the Chinese government's explanation that his parents were allowed to leave because they had repudiated their role in the democracy movement and needed medical care. He said he had kept in touch with them by letter and that they were not particularly ill. Fang has another son in Beijing, Fang Zhe, a student at Beijing University. In Britain, a Foreign Office spokesman said Fang had received an invitation from the Royal Society, Britain's oldest and most prestigious scientific organization. However, Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, would enter the country on a six-month visa, the standard time granted any tourist, the Foreign Office said. Fang was expelled from the Communist Party and fired from his post as vice chairman of the Chinese Science and Technology University in Hefei in 1987 for allegedly fomenting pro-democracy unrest among the nation's students. He also angered authorities when he told reporters that Marxism had failed in China and that the Communist Party must make way for democratic reform. In January 1989, Fang called for the release of all political prisoners, and urged intellectuals to join together to work for human rights. The following month, when Bush was visiting Beijing, Fang was barred from attending a U.S.-staged banquet. China said that inviting him was an insult. While being sheltered at the embassy, Fang and Li declined to talk with reporters and the embassy refused to answer nearly all questions about them. In November, however, Fang wrote a letter accepting a human rights award. ``Remember that in the current climate of terror, it may well be that those who are most terrified are those who have just finished the killing,'' he wrote. ``We may be forced to live under a terror today, but we have no fear of tomorrow. The murderers are not only fearful today, they are even more terrified of tomorrow.'' The release of another dissident, teacher Wang Xuezhi, was also announced today. Wang is the husband of a French citizen.

DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Limited Parental Notification of Minor's Abortion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, ``The court xxx'' and inserts new 14th graf to show parental consent not required, ``While both xxx''
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may require notification of one parent when unmarried girls seek an abortion. But it said mandating notification of both parents may interfere with the constitutional right to abortion. The justices voted 6-3 to uphold an Ohio law requiring that one parent be notified. ``We discern no constitutional defect in the statute,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote. The court, by a 5-4 vote, struck down one version of a Minnesota law requiring notification of both parents. By another 5-4 vote, with Justice Sandra Day O'Connor changing sides, the court ruled constitutional a version that allows a minor to notify either both her parents or get a judge's permission. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the opinion for the court striking down the two-parent notification law. ``This requirement, ostensibly designed for the benefit of the minor, resulted in major trauma to the child, and often to a parent as well,'' Stevens said. ``In some cases, the parents were divorced and the second parent did not have custody or otherwise participate in the child's upbringing.'' Dissenting, Kennedy, wrote that ``to deny parents this knowledge is to risk, or perpetuate, estrangement or alienation from the child when she is in the greatest need of parental guidance and support.'' But in upholding the two-parent notification rule only if a judicial bypass option is included, O'Connor said ``the interference with the internal operation of the family'' no longer exists. Kennedy, writing for the court in the Ohio case, noted that the state law allows a minor to notify a judge rather than her parents if she wants an abortion. This, he said, shows ``an abundance of caution and concern for the minor's interets.'' He noted that today's decisions leave unanswered a key question: whether a state law that requires notification of one parent can be constitutional if it does not include a judicial bypass option. Today's action did not appear to carry major impact for the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. O'Connor is viewed as a pivotal vote on the future of that decision. Today marked the first time since joining the court in 1981 that she voted to strike down a state-imposed restriction on abortion. Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, said the court ``has thrown down the gauntlet before the young women and girls of America. State legislators have been given the green light to restrict the choices of pregnant teens whose desperation the politicians can never comprehend.'' Gary Bauer, an anti-abortion leader and former Reagan administration official who is president of the Family Research Council, said, ``In our view, these two cases represent further evidence that Roe v. Wade will sometime soon slip into the history books as an ill-fated Supreme Court decision.'' While both the Ohio and Minnesota laws require parental notification of a minor's plan to get an abortion, neither mandates parental consent. Thus, a girl could get an abortion over her parents' objections provided that notification was made. The court's decisions in the Ohio and Minnesota cases yielded nine separate opinions. They offered a patchwork of rationale for upholding the Ohio law in its entirety but striking down the Minnesota law unless a judicial bypass is included. The decisions hold these nationwide guidelines on the regulation of abortions for unmarried minor girls still dependent on one or both parents: _A law requiring that only one parent be notified is constitutional. _States may not require that, in all cases, both natural parents be notified before an abortion is performed. _A law requiring that both parents be notified can be constitutional if it also allows a girl to bypass parental notification by getting a judge's permission for an abortion. _A requirement, in the Minnesota law, that parents be notified at least 48 hours before an abortion is performed is constitutionally valid. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices O'Connor, Stevens, Antonin Scalia, Kennedy and Byron R. White voted to uphold the Ohio law requiring notification of one parent. A provision in the Minnesota law that would have required two-parent notification in all cases was struck down by O'Connor, Stevens, Justices William J. Brennan, Harry A. Blackmun and Thurgood Marshall. But O'Connor left those four in providing the fifth vote for saying that Minnesota's two-parent requirement is valid if accompanied by the judical bypass option. Of the 1.5 million legal abortions performed annually since 1973, about 12 percent _ some 180,000 a year _ have been for minors. Twenty-two states have enacted laws that require a minor to seek the consent of one or both parents before obtaining an abortion, and 10 states have enacted laws that require a minor to notify one or both parents before obtaining an abortion. Not all of the laws are in force, however. The Minnesota law, enacted in 1981, required that the minor's two biological parents be notified. There was no exception for ``mature minors'' or for those whose parents are divorced or were never married. The Minnesota law was in effect for five years before being ruled unconstitutional by a federal judge. A federal appeals court later ruled that the law is valid, but blocked its enforcement pending Supreme Court review. The judicial bypass procedure was added to the Minnesota law in an attempt to fend off a finding that the statute was unconstitutional. The Ohio law requires that one of a minor's parents be notified by a doctor at least 24 hours before an abortion is performed. The girl can avoid telling her parent if she persuades a judge she is mature enough to make the decision on her own, or that telling her parents is not in her best interest. The Ohio law, enacted in 1985, never took effect due to a successful legal challenge by an Akron abortion clinic and one of its doctors. The justices previously have allowed limits on the availability of abortions for minors. The court, in upholding key portions of a Missouri abortion law, gave states last July greater power to regulate abortions. Rehnquist, White, Scalia and Kennedy appeared ready then to reverse Roe vs. Wade and allow states to ban virtually all abortions. But O'Connor, who joined those four to uphold the Missouri law, refused to reverse the 1973 ruling. Today Kennedy led four of the court's members _ Rehnquist, Scalia and White joined him _ in saying states should be allowed to ban abortions for all minors unless both parents are notified, if such notification is possible. Kennedy said the court's striking down of the Minnesota provision ``no doubt will come as a surprise to most parents.'' He added, ``Minnesota has done no more than act upon the common sense proposition that, in assisting their daughter in deciding whether to have an abortion, parents can best fulfill their roles if they have the same information about their own children's medical condition and medical choices as the child's doctor does.'' Blackmun, Brennan and Marshall dissented from the decision upholding Ohio's law. Blackmun wrote for the three, ``Ohio has acted with particular insensitivity in enacting the statute the court today upholds. Rather than create a judicial-bypass system that reflects the sensitivity necessary when dealing with a minor making this deeply initimate decision, Ohio has created a tortuous maze.'' He added, ``The state has failed utterly to show that it has any significant state interest in deliberately placing its pattern of obstacles in the path of the pregnant minor seeking to exercise her constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy.'' The cases are Ohio vs. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, 88-805, and Hodgson vs. Minnesota, 88-1125.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Audited, Found Owing
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is being audited and may owe $2 million or more. The tax agency underpaid its postage bill, apparently due to a misunderstanding about the fees due for certified mail, according to the U.S. Postal Service. Postal inspectors discovered the discrepancy in checks of IRS mail in Covington, Ky., and Ogden, Utah. Underpayments were found totaling $827,100 in Covington and $570,000 Ogden. The audit was later expanded to Dallas, Memphis, Atlanta, Andover, Mass., Fresno, Calif., Kansas City and Austin, Texas, and officials say the total deficiency has reached $2 million. Paul Griffo of the Postal Inspection Service said the audit, which began in 1989, should be completed within a few weeks. IRS officials confirmed they are cooperating with the postal audit.

DOC.HEAD: Court Decisions Made Available Via Computer
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court has begun testing a system by which it distributes electronic copies of its decisions. The Associated Press used the system Monday to prepare excerpts of several major decisions. The court began its two-year Project Hermes last week. Under the test, court decisions are being made available by computer link to participating organizations just minutes after they are released.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Share Sense of Optimism in AIDS Fight
DOC.TEXT: A new word has quietly slipped into the vocabulary of doctors and scientists who are on the battle lines against AIDS: optimism. With 130,000 already sick or dead and at least 1 million infected, AIDS is a huge health problem in the United States. But for the first time since the epidemic emerged almost a decade ago, experts seem uniformly convinced that AIDS will someday _ and perhaps soon _ be brought under medical control. Researchers at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, which concluded Sunday, pointed to these hopeful signs: _The epidemic in the United States appears to be leveling off. The number of new AIDS deaths is sharply lower than what researchers a few years ago had projected it would be by now. _Many new drugs are in the works that will attack the AIDS virus at every stage of its life cycle. Combinations of medicines may be powerful tools for postponing or halting the development of AIDS in people infected with the virus, HIV. _Creating an AIDS vaccine to stop infections _ until recently considered a questionable prospect _ appears to be much more likely during the 1990s. ``There is a fair amount of optimism with the current drugs, and this will be added to when we have other drugs to combine with them,'' said the conference chairman, Dr. Paul Volberding of the University of California, San Francisco. Despite the positive developments during the past year, no one is talking seriously about curing AIDS. Instead, the goal is to turn HIV infection into a manageable chronic condition, like diabetes or high blood pressure. Awesome obstacles remain. The virus continues to move beyond its initial victims _ homosexual men and intravenous drug abusers. In the United States, women and children are increasingly becoming targets as HIV spreads through sex from men to women and in the womb from mothers to fetuses. Around the world, perhaps 8 million people are already infected, and the epidemic still seems to be gaining momentum. ``HIV is now part of the global environment, and the global potential for HIV spread remains vast,'' cautioned Jonathan Mann, former head of the World Health Association's Global Program on AIDS. The present is indeed gloomy. But at this gathering, more than any previous international AIDS meeting, the researchers spoke of their successes and the chance that they will ultimately stop the epidemic. One crucial weapon is a vaccine that will keep people who are still virus free from becoming infected. More than 30 approaches to vaccine development are being studied. Half a dozen potential vaccines already are being tested on people or nearing that stage. Dr. Wayne Koff, head of vaccine development at the National Institute on Allergy and Infectious Diseases, predicted that a vaccine should be ready for widespread use by the mid- to late 1990s. ``In the past year, we have cracked open the door of optimism,'' he said. ``In the next two to three years, we will knock it down.'' Now, only one drug, AZT, is available for routine use. While it does not cure AIDS, it can prolong patients' lives by a few months. Perhaps even more useful is its ability to forestall the start of AIDS in outwardly healthy people who are infected with HIV. Two similar drugs, DDI and DDC, are in the final stages of testing. New research suggests that combinations of these drugs will be far more powerful inhibitors of the virus than any single medicine. And dozens of new drugs are being tested. Researchers once predicted that the number of AIDS deaths would continue to grow sharply for years. But to their surprise, the epidemic began to flatten in 1986 and perhaps earlier. No one knows precisely why it happened or whether the epidemic will pick up speed again. However, the introduction of AZT and avoidance of risky habits that spread the disease probably contributed to the change. Doctors hope that all of these developments mean that the epidemic, while far from over, will soon lose some of its fierce power. As Dr. Jay Levy of the University of California, San Francisco, told the convention: ``We have begun to see the horizon, and we will get there.''

Here are excerpts from the Supreme Court decisions issued Monday striking down a Minnesota law requiring unmarried girls to notify both parents before getting an abortion, and upholding an Ohio law requiring notification of one parent:
DOC.HEAD: Ohio Main Opinion by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy:
DOC.TEXT: ... The Ohio statute, in sum, does not impose an undue, or otherwise unconstitutional, burden on a minor seeking an abortion. We believe, in addition, that the legislature acted in a rational manner in enacting (the law) ... A free and enlightened society may decide that each of its members should attain a clearer, more tolerant understanding of the profound philosophic choices confronted by a woman who is considering whether to seek an abortion. Her decision will embrace her own destiny and personal dignity, and the origins of the other human life that lie within the embryo. The State is entitled to assume that, for most of its people, the beginnings of that understanding will be within the family, society's most intimate association. It is both rational and fair for the State to conclude that, in most instances, the family will strive to give a lonely or even terrified minor advice that is both compassionate and mature. The statute in issue here is a rational way to further those ends. It would deny all dignity to the family to say that the State cannot take this reasonable step in regulating its health professions to ensure that, in most cases, a young woman will receive guidance and understanding from a parent. We uphold (the law).
DOC.HEAD: Ohio Dissenting Opinion by Justice Harry A. Blackmun:
DOC.TEXT: ... The State of Ohio has acted with particular insensitivity in enacting the statute the Court today upholds. Rather than create a judicial-bypass system that reflects the sensitivity necessary when dealing with a minor making this deeply intimate decision, Ohio has created a tortuous maze. ... Moreover, the State has failed utterly to show that it has any significant state interest in deliberately placing its pattern of obstacles in the path of the pregnant minor seeking to exercise her constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy. ... The challenged provisions of the Ohio statute are merely ``poorly disguised elements of discouragement for the abortion decision.''...
DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Main Opinion by Justice John P. Stevens:
DOC.TEXT: ...It is equally clear that the requirement that both parents be notified, whether or not both wish to be notified or have assumed responsibility for the upbringing of the child, does not reasonably further any legitimate state interest. ... In the ideal family setting, of course, notice to either parent would normally constitute notice to both. ... In many families, however, the parent notified by the child would not notify the other parent. In those cases the State has no legitimate interest in questioning one parent's judgment that notice to the other parent would not assist the minor or in presuming that the parent who has assumed parental duties is incompetent to make decisions regarding the health and welfare of the child. ... Not only does two-parent notification fail to serve any state interest with respect to functioning families, it disserves the state interest in protecting and assisting the minor with respect to dysfunctional families. ... The record reveals that in the thousands of dysfunctional families affected by this statute, the two-parent notice requirement proved positively harmful to the minor and her family. ... The testimony at trial established that this requirement, ostensibly designed for the benefit of the minor, resulted in major trauma to the child, and often to a parent as well. In some cases, the parents were divorced and the second parent did not have custody or otherwise participate in the child's upbringing. ... In these circumstances, the privacy of the parent and child was violated, even when they suffered no other physical or psychological harm. In other instances, however, the second parent had either deserted or abused the child, ... had died under tragic circumstances, ... or was not notified because of the considered judgment that notification would inflict unnecessary stress on a parent who was ill. ... In these circumstances, the statute was not merely ineffectual in achieving the State's goals but actually counterproductive. The focus on notifying the second parent distracted both the parent and minor from the minor's imminent abortion decision. ... In virtually every State, the consent of one parent is enough to obtain a driver's license or operator's permit. The same may be said with respect to the decision to submit to any medical or surgical procedure other than an abortion. ... Indeed, the only other Minnesota statute that the State has identified which requires two-parent consent is that authorizing the minor to change his name. ... ... These statutes provide testimony to the unreasonableness of the Minnesota two-parent notification requirement and to the ease with which the State can adopt less burdensome means to protect the minor's welfare. ... We therefore hold that this requirement violates the Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: State Police Sent in to Quell Prison Disturbance
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred inmates staged an angry uprising this morning at the state's minimum security prison, setting two buildings ablaze and injuring at least one guard who was hit by a rock, authorities said. The disturbance at the Carl Robinson Correctional Institution started about 7:15 a.m. when protesting inmates refused to return to their dormitories after breakfast. The disturbance was mostly quelled by early afternoon, said Correction Department spokesman William Wheeler. An estimated 400 inmates took part in the protest, throwing rocks, breaking windows, wrenching doors off their hinges and breaking into the prison's main mess hall and a second building housing a mess hall and gymnasium, Wheeler said. The two buildings were set ablaze and sustained heavy damage, Wheeler said. The inmates also looted the prison commissary, housed in the same building as the main mess hall, he said. The inmates have been complaining the food and the wages paid at their prison jobs, Wheeler said. Prison officials also have been struggling to accommodate an inmate population that has ballooned in the past year from 750 to the current 1,350. Most of the inmates were returned to their dormitories by 12:30 p.m., but a handful remained in the yard, and authorities were awaiting word from Warden George Bronson before taking the prison off alert status, Wheeler said. ``I can't say that it's totally under control, but the overwhelming majority returned to their housing units and a count is going on,'' Wheeler said. A guard suffered a broken ankle when he was struck by a rock thrown by an inmate, Wheeler said. A number of inmates complained of miscellaneous injuries, including smoke inhalation, cuts and bruises, he said. There were no escapes, Wheeler said. ``The perimeter security was maintained throughout the entire incident,'' Wheeler said. ``The correction officers were in control. The inmates were in the yard.'' About 100 state troopers equipped with riot gear and 15 state police dogs were dispatched to help quell the disturbance. They were kept on standby at a staging area about a quarter mile from the prison and never entered the prison grounds, Wheeler said. Firefighters from the towns of Enfield and nearby East Longmeadow, Mass., along with the prison's own fire department quickly put out the fires, Wheeler said. Guards from nearby Somers State Prison and from the Connecticut Correctional Institution, a medium security facility, were brought in to help put down the disturbance, Wheeler said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Bars Removal of Life-Sustaining Equipment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf to CORRECT that parental notification not consent needed, ``The court xxx''
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, in its first ruling in a ``right-to-die'' case, said today states may bar the removal of life-sustaining treatment from comatose patients who have not made or cannot make their desires known. In other decisions, the court ruled that states may require notification of one parent when unmarried girls seek an abortion. But it said mandating notification of both parents interferes with the constitutional right to abortion. By a 5-4 vote, the justices blocked the parents of a permanently unconscious Missouri woman, Nancy Cruzan, from ordering the removal of tubes that provide her with food and water. The court said Ms. Cruzan's rights were not violated by allowing the state's interest in preserving life to outweigh her parents' wishes. But the court, indirectly supporting so-called ``living will'' laws, said the Constitution guarantees a competent person a right to refuse medical treatment. That issue was not presented squarely in the Cruzan case since she is incompetent to decide her future, the court said. In the abortion decisions, the justices voted 6-3 to uphold an Ohio law requiring that one parent be notified. ``We discern no constitutional defect in the statute,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote. The court, by a 5-4 vote, struck down one version of a Minnesota law requiring notification of both parents. By another 5-4 vote, with Justice Sandra Day O'Connor changing sides, the court ruled constitutional a version that allows a minor to either notify both her parents or get the approval of a judge. The parents of Ms. Cruzan, Joe and Joyce Cruzan, left a message on the answering machine at their Carterville, Mo., home that the family will have no reaction until they have had time to analyze the ruling. But Dick Kurtenbach, who has worked with the Cruzans as head of the Kansas City, Mo., office of the American Civil Liberties Union, commented: ``When we looked at it realistically, and with the recent history of the court, this is not that surprising. ``I'm sure the family is going to be extremely disappointed.'' Speaking for the American Medical Association, Dr. Nancy Dickey, a Richmond, Texas, family physician and a trustee of the AMA, said of the decision: ``We feel it is an intrusion into the doctor-patient relationship and a step toward taking that decision away from the bedside. ... ``We should not deliver unnecessary care and pay for unnecessary care.'' Dickey spoke with reporters at an AMA policymaking conference in Chicago. Doctors have said Ms. Cruzan, 32, could live for 30 more years in her current ``persistent vegetative'' condition. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said Missouri may require ``clear and convincing'' proof that Ms. Cruzan wants to die before allowing the withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment. Such evidence is lacking in Ms. Cruzan's case, he said. The chief justice also said that ``not all incompetent patients will have loved ones available to serve as surrogate decisionmakers. A state is entitled to guard against potential abuses in such situations.'' ``In sum, we conclude that a state may apply a clear and convincing evidence standard in proceedings where a guardian seeks to discontinue nutrition and hydration of a person diagnosed to be in a persistent vegetative state,'' Rehnquist said. He was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin J. Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Dissenting were Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Brennan, in an opinion joined by Marshall and Blackmun, said, ``Nancy Cruzan is entitled to choose to die with dignity.'' Missouri and the Supreme Court ``have displaced Nancy's own assessment of the processes associated with dying,'' Brennan said. ``They have discarded evidence of her will, ignored her values, and deprived her of the right to a decision as closely approximating her own choice as humanly possible.'' But Brennan said he is heartened that the court tentatively concluded that in some cases a competent person must be allowed to choose death. State courts generally have permitted removal of life-sustaining treatment for patients like Ms. Cruzan. Until today, the Supreme Court had declined to step in. Today's ruling does not bar state courts, or state legislatures, from continuing to allow the removal of life-sustaining treatment even for incompetent persons. Most states, including Missouri, have so-called living will laws that allow people to authorize the termination of life-sustaining treatment before they undergo such treatment. Missouri's living-will law, which does not allow removal of feeding tubes, was not in effect when Ms. Cruzan was injured in a 1983 car crash. The American Medical Association estimates 70 percent of Americans at some time will be involved in a decision about whether to provide life-sustaining medical care for themselves or family members. Ms. Cruzan suffered severe brain damage. Her parents authorized the use of a feeding tube in hopes her condition would improve. But for seven years she has remained in a coma-like condition _ her body rigid, her hands and feet constricted and bent into claw shapes. She can breathe on her own, and at times her eyes are open and move randomly. Doctors say she is incapable of reacting or relating to her environment and can experience no thoughts or emotions. Nurses at the rehabilitation center where Ms. Cruzan is being cared for dispute that. They said she responds by turning toward those who speak to her and has cried on occasion. The cost to Missouri taxpayers of keeping Ms. Cruzan alive is about $130,000 a year. The Bush administration sided with Missouri officials in urging she be kept alive. Permitting the removal of a feeding tube is a step toward sanctioning mercy killing or suicide, Justice Department lawyers said. Debate over the case also has spilled over into the abortion controversy. Anti-abortion activists had said a court determination that life-sustaining treatment may be withdrawn based on a constitutional right of privacy would jeopardize efforts to curtail abortions. The Missouri Supreme Court in 1988, bucking a trend among courts nationwide, refused to let doctors remove Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube. The state court rejected a plea by Ms. Cruzan's parents, who said their daughter once had said she would not want to remain alive as ``an unconscious shell.'' The right-to-die issue captured national attention in 1976, when the New Jersey Supreme Court allowed the family of Karen Ann Quinlan to order the removal of a respirator helping her breathe. Ms. Quinlan, in a similar coma-like condition to that of Ms. Cruzan, continued to be fed through a tube and lived nine more years. The right-to-die case is Cruzan vs. Missouri Department of Health, 88-1503.

DOC.HEAD: Cacti Part of Life on Wagon Train
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old boy riding with the Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train fell face down in a cactus patch, one of the hazards facing the modern-day pioneers on their month-long trek. It took a nurse roughly two hours Sunday to pluck most of the cactus needles from the boy, said B.J. Wertz, a spokeswoman for the wagon train. ``He was running and he fell into cactus,'' she said Monday. ``His whole upper body was covered.'' Despite the painful experience, the boy ``was a little trooper. Not one tear,'' Wertz said. Cacti are a common hazard on the Jim Bridger Trail, which the wagon train is traversing. The travelers have been using shovels to clear away the plants from sleeping areas each night. The wagon train left Casper on June 2 to celebrate Wyoming's centennial by covering 260 miles of the trail. By Sunday, it had covered about 215 miles. On July 2, the 78 wagons and 364 riders are scheduled to conclude the trek by rolling into Cody.

DOC.HEAD: New Gun Lock to Be Provided At Cost to Groups
DOC.TEXT: Many of last year's accidental shooting deaths of children could have been prevented by use of a new gun lock that will be provided at cost to non-profit groups, a shotgun manufacturer said Monday. The deaths of 247 children aged 14 and under last year from accidents with firearms left around the house is ``a tough statistic,'' said Alan I. Mossberg, president of O.F. Mossberg & Sons Inc., the nation's largest producer of pump-action shotguns. Cablelock, which is threaded through a gun's action to make it inoperable, is produced by Mossberg and has been included at no extra charge with the estimated 250,000 Mossberg shotguns sold since last October, he said. The lock can be used on about 80 percent of the estimated 200 million handguns, rifles and shotguns owned by Americans, Mossberg said. Some 15,000 locks have been sold separately since December, said Richard M. Pelton, executive vice president of the company. Although the recommended retail price is $6.95, the locks will be available this year to non-profit groups at the company's cost of $2.46 apiece to boost their use, Mossberg said. He suggested that the groups could use them as a fund-raising tool. Mossberg said his company, based in North Haven, Conn., is not trying to make a profit on the lock, which has not been patented. He said the company also is developing model federal and state legislation that would make it a crime not to lock up a firearm. Specific penalties have not yet been determined, Mossberg said. ``People aren't doing it, otherwise those 247 children last year wouldn't have met with the tragic end that they did,'' he said. ``We think it's got to be a subject of mandatory activity.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: the Constitution.
sion requiring parental consent or
DOC.TEXT: consultation in most cases but providing for prompt (i) judicial resolution of any disagreement between the parent and the minor, or (ii) judicial determination that the minor is mature enough to give an informed consent without parental concurrence or that abortion in any event is in the minor's best interest. Such a provision would not impose parental approval as an absolute condition upon the minor's right but would assure in most instances consultation between the parent and child.''
DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Dissenting Opinion by Justice Thurgood Marshall:
DOC.TEXT: ... I dissent from the judgment of the court ... that the judicial bypass option renders the parental notification and 48-hour delay requirements constitutional. The bypass procedure cannot sae those requirements because the bypass itself is unconstitutional both on its face and as applied. ... At the very least, this scheme substantially burdens a woman's right to privacy without advancing a compelling state interest. More significantly, in some instances it usurps a young woman's control over her own body by giving either a parent or a court the power effectively to veto her decision to have an abortion. ...I strongly disagree with the Court's conclusion that the State may constitutionally force a minor woman either to notify both parents (or in some cases only one parent) and then wait 48 hours before proceeding with an abortion, or disclose her intimate affairs to a judge and ask that he grant her permission to have an abortion. Neither the scope of a woman's privacy right nor the magnitude of a law's burden is diminished because a woman is a minor. ... Rather, a woman's minority status affects only the nature of the State's interests. Although the court considers the burdens that the two-parent notification requirement imposes on a minor woman's exercise of her right to privacy, ... it fails to recognize that forced notification of only one parent also significantly burdens a young woman's right to have an abortion ...

DOC.HEAD: Lizhi One of Many to Seek Refuge in Embassy
With AM-Fang, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi spent more than a year inside the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, protected by international law that declares an embassy sacrosanct property belonging to the country of representation. According to the law, forces from the outside cannot legally enter an embassy to seize a person. However, an embassy's right to grant sanctuary to someone does not mean that person has a right to free passage out of the country. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega took refuge in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City last December after U.S. troops invaded the country in an effort to bring him to the United States to face drug charges. Noriega left the embassy Jan. 3 and surrendered to U.S. authorities. He is in Miami awaiting trial. Fang sought refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing after China's Communist government targeted him during its June 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protesters. Lizhi and his wife, Li Shuxian, were allowed to leave the embassy Monday and flew to Britain. Perhaps the longest instance of political refuge in an embassy involved Hungarian Cardinal Josef Mindszenty, who hid for 15 years at the U.S. Embassy in Budapest. He was arrested by Hungary's Communist rulers in 1948 as an enemy of communism and sentenced to life in prison. Hungarian revolutionaries freed him during the 1956 uprising, but Mindszenty took refuge in the U.S. mission in Budapest after Warsaw Pact forces crushed the revolt. He lived there until the Vatican arranged for his release to the West in 1971. Elsewhere in the East bloc, seven Pentecostalists claiming religious persecution lived for five years in a cramped room at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow, leaving in 1983.
Thousands of East Germans seeking to go West took refuge in various West German embassies in September, leading to a pro-democracy campaign that forced the lifting of travel restrictions, toppled the Communist government, and ultimately spread across the East bloc. The largest number of people to seek refuge at a foreign embassy at once may have been in Cuba in April 1980, when 10,000 Cubans entered the grounds of the Peruvian Embassy seeking to emigrate. Cuban authorities finally persuaded the crowd to go home, and eventually almost all of them received exit visas. In 1973, after Salvador Allende was overthrown as president of Chile and died in a battle in the presidential palace, his widow and her children received refuge in the Mexican Embassy in Santiago. The Mexican government then flew them out of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Activists Voice Alarm at Court Decision
With AM-Scotus-Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Abortion-rights activists voiced alarm Monday at the Supreme Court decision upholding a parental-notification law and called the vote a threat to abortion rights in general. ``This was too close for comfort,'' said Kate Michelman, executive director of National Abortion Rights Action League. ``The threat to overturning this right is as close as the next Supreme Court vacancy.'' Anti-abortion leaders, however, said they were pleased with the rulings involving Ohio and Minnesota laws. Gary Bauer, president of the anti-abortion Family Research Council, said the 17-year-old Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortions was in jeopardy. ``We're very gratified,'' Bauer said. The court voted 6-3 to uphold an Ohio law requiring that one parent be notified before a minor girl obtains an abortion. However, a Minnesota law requiring notification of both parents was struck down on a 5-4 vote. By another 5-4 vote, with Justice Sandra Day O'Connor changing sides, the court ruled constitutional a version that allows a minor to notify either both her parents or get a judge's permission. ``In our view,'' Bauer said, ``these two cases represent further evidence that Roe vs. Wade will sometime soon slip into the history books as an ill-fated Supreme Court decision.'' James Bopp Jr., general counsel for the National Right to Life Committee, said the rulings were in line with the court's decision last year in the Webster case permitting some state restrictions on abortion. ``The court is prepared to further restrict abortion,'' he said. ``As far as I can see, the state legislatures have basically carte blanche to regulate abortion as long as there is a rational reason or legitimate issue advanced in doing so.'' Michelman, head of the national abortion-rights group, called the decisions ``extremely alarming'' and pointed to O'Connor's switch in the two Minnesota votes as well as the wording of her written opinion. ``As if allowing states to treat teens like criminals were not enough, Justice O'Connor in her concurring opinion once again signaled her willingness to overturn Roe vs. Wade by joining ... the others to undermine the right for all women,'' she said. Michelman said she was concerned that O'Connor's opinion suggested any restriction on abortion ``which does not in her view pose an undue burden'' would be constitutional, and that there ``is no fundamental right'' to an abortion. ``The implication of this decision goes well beyond the narrow issue of parental notification and consent,'' she said. ``They failed completely to reaffirm Roe vs. Wade.'' At least 22 states have laws that require a minor to have the consent of one or both parents before having an abortion, and 10 states have enacted laws that require a minor to notify one or both parents before obtaining an abortion. Many were not in force because of court challenges, however. According to the National Abortion Rights Action League, parental consent laws were being enforced in Alabama, Indiana, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Missouri, North Dakota, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Utah and Wyoming. Notification laws were enforced in Arkansas and West Virginia, the group said. Legislatures in at least 22 states considered bills requiring parental consent or notification of their parents during the 1990 legislative sessions. A bill requiring a parent's consent was passed in South Carolina and signed into law, while a bill passed in Michigan was vetoed by Gov. Jim Blanchard. Michelman said those favoring abortion rights should be concerned by the narrowness of the 5-4 ruling against Minnesota's law requiring both parents be notified. She said that requirement was ``the most extreme, burdensome and onerous requirement on a teen-ager in trouble.'' The result, she said, amounted to an invitation to state legislatures to ``intrude in the most personal and private decisions individuals will make.'' ``I think Roe is seriously weakened,'' she said. ``We can't even call this a hollow victory.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Irrational Fears Could Drive Up Food Prices
DOC.TEXT: Irrational fears about chemicals and food safety could drive up the costs of farm production and lead to higher prices at the grocery store, a senior Agriculture Department official said Monday. ``If we react carelessly, without science, in response to imagined risks, and thereby needlessly increase food costs, the poor will be the first to notice reduced buying power and higher nutrition costs,'' said Deputy Secretary Jack C. Parnell. The efficiency of farmers _ productivity _ has more than doubled in the last 40 years, he said. And chemicals have played a role in ``this American victory over hunger.'' Parnell's remarks were prepared for a conference on food safety and nutrition sponsored by a number of governmment agencies, including USDA and the Food and Drug Administration. The conferences, primarily for journalists, have been held periodically over the years. In 1988, for example, three were held in Washington, Chicago and San Francisco to help spread the latest word on food and nutrition. Parnell, who was director of the California Department of Food and Agriculture before becoming the department's No. 2 official last year, said it has been ``American agriculture through inexpensive food that has helped enormously to raise our standard of living'' and that of many others around the world. On the whole, Americans spend about 12 percent of their disposable income for food, of which nearly 5 percent is for food eaten in restaurants and other places away from home. By comparison, he said, Japan spends almost 20 percent of its take-home pay for food, the Soviet Union more than 25 percent, and China and India over half of their income. But Parnell said he has noticed there is ``a group of Americans who are not always remembered in the debate'' about the safety of the nation's food supply. ``Those (are) poorer Americans who spend a much larger share of their budgets on food,'' he said. ``There are millions of Americans, perhaps over 30 million Americans, who spend over 50 percent of their income on food.'' Foreign countries, including poor Third World nations, also would feel the pinch, Parnell said. ``These are more good reasons to act as quickly as the threat demands, to the extent the danger requires _ but avoid alarmist calls for excessive or self-defeating policies,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, Meeting Bush at White House, Won't Rule Out Violence
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, On the... with Cohen remarks; picks up 7th graf pvs, Earlier, Bush...
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said today that South African blacks may have ``no alternative'' but to resort to violence to achieve racial equality as President Bush urged the black leader to pursue his goals through peaceful means. Mandela praised U.S. support for the fight against apartheid, describing its value as ``beyond words,'' and said he would press his case for continued economic sanctions against South Africa during his official talks with Bush. The deputy president of the African National Congress said his group is committed to achieving its ends peacefully, but he indicated its patience was not without limits. ``If we are forced to resort to violence, it is because we have no other alternative,'' he said. ``The methods of political action ... were determined by the South African government.'' Leaving the White House after three hours, Mandela told reporters he was ``very much encouraged'' by the response and support Bush gave him during their talks. He said the two discussed a wide variety of issues, and, ``We reached broad agreement on almost all of them.'' On the issues over which they disagreed, Mandela said he and the president ``narrowed the gaps.'' But the African leader refused to provide any detail about the differences, saying he would take questions later at a press conference. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen, briefing on Mandela's discussions with Bush, said U.S. officials were pleased that Mandela has said violence will be suspended so long as negotiations continue with the white government. But he said U.S. officials pressed Mandela to ``go all the way and renounce the armed struggle.'' Mandela said he would consider that option, Cohen said. ``Everything he has said is fine,'' Cohen said. Earlier, Bush pledged continued support for the black majority in South Africa and called for all parties to work through negotiations _ not armed struggle _ to achieve a democractic society. ``Sir, we here in America walk in solidarity with all the South Africans who seek through non-violent means democracy, human rights and freedom,'' Bush said. Bush also said the United States will maintain sanctions until the white government of President F.W. de Klerk meets all conditions spelled out in an anti-apartheid law. Those conditions have yet to be met. Earlier, U.S. officials said $10 million that Congress has allocated for South African groups cannot go to the ANC until it renounces violence. While his previous stops in New York and Boston were largely celebratory _ with hundreds of thousands of supporters attending enthusiastic rallies _ Mandela got down to business during his three-day visit to Washington. On Sunday, Mandela told black reporters that economic sanctions were vital in softening the South African government's hard line on apartheid. ``It is therefore necessary for you to continue to put on the pressure on your government and on Congress,'' said Mandela, who was freed in February after being imprisoned for 27 years by the South African government. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said the main U.S. emphasis was to find out Mandela's views on how to proceed with negotiations between the ANC and the South African government. The U.S. sanctions, which have had a harsh impact on the South African economy, include a ban on all new U.S. investment and trade embargoes on items such as oil and agricultural products. Mandela arrived at National Airport in mid-afternoon Sunday, greeted by Randall Robinson, a leader in the U.S. anti-apartheid movement, officials of the District of Columbia government and Effi Barry, the wife of Mayor Marion Barry. Barry, who is on trial on drug and perjury charges, did not attend. At a brief airport arrival ceremony, Mandela had said he was ``greatly encouraged'' by his rousing reception in the United States. Mandela's motorcade passed some of the country's most famous landmarks, such as the Lincoln Memorial, before arriving at the Madison Hotel. At the hotel, hundreds of people lined up behind ropes on the sidewalk across the street in hopes of catching a glimpse of Mandela. Some danced and waved banners as police watched. Mandela'sonly other appearances Sunday included brief remarks to South African exiles and a visit to a cocktail reception for African diplomats. Both events were closed to the media. In other remarks at the session with journalists, Mandela criticized the United States for aiding non-communists rebels in Angola. ``The United States and South Africa are the main countries that support Savimbi,'' he said, referring to Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi. ``We strongly condemn that,'' he said, adding that the nations should ``respect the political sovereignty and territorial integrity of Angola.'' Angola's central government has received help from the Soviets and the Cubans. When several journalists asked what could be done to help the anti-apartheid struggle in South Africa, Mandela said the ANC, with 20,000 exiles and enormous needs for new programs, must have money. ``Take part in the campaign to raise funds for the ANC,'' he said. Mandela also stuck to his support for Cuban leader Fidel Castro, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and Plestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in Train Collision
DOC.TEXT: A speeding freight train crashed into a stationary passenger train at a railroad station in eastern India on Monday, killing eight people and injuring 50, news reports said. United News of India said the accident occurred at the Mangra railway station, 510 miles southeast of New Delhi. Many cars of the passenger train were thrown off the track by the impact of the crash, it said.
