Several passengers jumped off the passenger train when railway staff shouted that the freight train was headed toward it, UNI said.

DOC.HEAD: Muscle-Bound Mannequins Represent `Man of '90s'
DOC.TEXT: He's the man of the '90s: Tall. Strong. Plastic. He's also pretty quiet, which isn't surprising for a mannequin. But this isn't just any mannequin. This is the new, improved mannequin that Dayton Hudson department stores has chosen to represent the new decade. While the store's standard mannequins took a 38 regular suit, these bulging hulks fill the seams of a 42. They're 6-feet-2, a good 2 inches over the old breed. Andrew Markopoulos, senior vice president for visual merchandising and store design at Dayton Hudson, said a statue in Paris inspired him to ask New York City mannequin maker Ralph Pucci to create the new models. ``I asked him to develop a collection of men, appropriate for Dayton's and our image of (the) man of the '90s,'' Markopoulos said. Pucci, owner of Pucci Manikins, took it from there. Dayton's commissioned 20 of his finished product _ at $865 each _ for a new store in Edina. ``This particular ideal is a young man very much aware of physical fitness, one who epitomizes all the other good qualities,'' Markopoulos said. ``A man who is cultured, aware of the very best that life has to offer. Could be young business man, young student. But a young guy very much aware of what's going on the world today.''

DOC.HEAD: Governors Call on Bush to Act Against Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: A task force of the nation's governors urged President Bush on Monday to act on a consensus report calling for speedy domestic and international action to fight global warming. The bipartisan group of politicians, led by Gov. James Thompson, R-Ill., said Bush appeared more receptive than in the past to the idea of taking action. The report, issued on behalf of the National Governors' Association, said action is needed to stabilize emissions of gases said to contribute to global warming, to develop an international agreement to protect the atmosphere and to use extensive reforestation programs to reduce the effects of climate change. The White House position has been that global warming is an unproven theory and that further study should precede action. Thompson and the other governors said that although considerable scientific uncertainty remains about the so-called greenhouse effect and other components of climatic change, enough evidence is in hand to justify action now. Democratic Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana said Bush must elude ``two traps'' if he is to deal with the problem successfully. In the first place, if Bush were to wait for 100 percent scientific certainty, ``you are paralyzed'' and nothing will be done ``because not all of the facts are on one side of the question,'' Roemer said. ``But I think the president will come to the conclusion that the evidence is clear enough to justify action now,'' Roemer said. The other ``trap,'' he said, is the fact that the issue transcends the next election and extends well into the next century. ``It is important to act now,'' Roemer said. `` I think he will.'' Task force recommendations include: _Cost-effective energy conservation and efficiency measures to stabilize U.S. emissions of carbon dioxide. _Halting the production of chlorofluorocarbons and using ``cost-effective strategies'' to stabilize or reduce other greenhouse gases. _Beginning extensive forestry programs to reduce the effect of climatic change. _Developing and commercializing alternative-energy systems, including clean fossil fuel, renewable energy sources and safe nuclear power. _Planing and acting now to adapt to a changing climate. Thompson said the report is important because ``it is probably the first and only consensus document that exists anywhere on the issue of global climate change and the greenhouse effect.'' ``It's an incredible consensus,'' he said,'' noting that the governors who produced the report come from urban and rural areas, from regions that produce coal and natural gas and from farm states. ``We tried to see beyond the excessive rhetoric that sometimes surrounds this issue,'' Thompson said. ``Those of us who must make policy in the face of scientific uncertainty must be careful to avoid over-reaction. But given the potential significance of global climate change, some immediate steps are justified.'' Because of that uncertainty, Thompson said, ``the policies we recommend have multiple benefits, including cleaner air and energy security. ``Regardless of how much or how little our climate changes, the result of these actions will be a cleaner environment,'' he said. ``I think the president's reaction to the whole report and the consensus that has been reached was a very strong one,'' Thompson said. ``I think we did get from the president a pledge for international leadership.'' The possibility of global warming and destructive climatic change is based on the fact that earth's atmosphere acts like a greenhouse around the globe. Certain gases generated on the surface rise into the atmosphere, trap the sun's heat and warm the planet. Although the greenhouse effect warms the planet to the extent needed to make it habitable, the governors noted the concern in recent years that the atmosphere may be being warmed at an excessive rate. The report was presented to Bush by Thompson, Roemer and governors Madeline Kunin, D-Vt., and Terry E. Branstad, R-Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident's Break With Marxism Began With Discussion of the Universe
With AM-Fang, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fang Lizhi has said he is happiest pondering the mysteries of the universe. It is this fascination with the unknown that led to his break with Marxism and emergence as one of China's most outspoken critics. Fang's research in cosmology _ the study of the universe _ and black hole physics won him international attention. But a debate in that field several years ago forced the 54-year-old astrophysicist to question his Communist leaders. Former Politburo member Hu Qiaomu had questioned the need to study cosmology, since Marxism already maintained the universe was infinite. ``This is an open question right now,'' Fang replied. ``In cosmology, Marxism is not right.'' It was the first step in a process that led to the leadership's enmity and to Fang's eventual flight to the U.S. Embassy to seek shelter from prosecution. He was allowed to leave the embassy on Monday after more than a year, and he flew to Britain. Fang became best-known for his fearless advocacy of transforming the one- party Communist state into a freer society. He was one of only a few Chinese who dared to campaign publicly for democratic change before the popular uprising for freedom rocked Beijing in the spring of 1989. ``I like to speak freely,'' Fang said in an interview in 1988. ``I think I just show ... we have the right of speech.'' Fang not only spoke with students and foreign reporters but also tried to reach a broader, tougher audience of Chinese. ``Some people think China doesn't need democracy, but I think human rights are basic,'' Fang told actors, scientists and business leaders at a gathering in February 1989. ``For (human rights) to be realized, first of all famous people must take a stand.'' Fang, the son of a postal clerk in Hangzhou, was admitted to Beijing University in 1952, at age 16, to study theoretical physics and nuclear physics. After studying nuclear reactor theory, he became one of China's pioneer researchers in laser theory. He burst into political prominence during pro-democracy student demonstrations of 1986-87. Authorities alleged his speeches to students at the University of Science and Technology, where he was vice president, incited unrest. China's leaders kicked him out of the Communist Party and fired him from his university post. Although the demonstrations died down, Fang refused to be silenced and he received letters of support from across the country almost daily. In January 1989, Fang called for the release of all political prisoners and urged intellectuals to join together to work for human rights. The following month, when President Bush was visiting Beijing, Fang was barred from attending a banquet held by the United States. China said that inviting him was an insult. China had accused Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, of leading the huge pro-democracy protests last spring, although the two did not take an active role. After the June 4, 1989, military crackdown on the demonstrations, in which hundreds and perhaps thousands of people died, Fang and Li sought refuge in the U.S. Embassy. American diplomats refused to turn them over to Chinese authorities. While being sheltered at the embassy, Fang and Li declined to talk with reporters and the embassy refused to answer nearly all questions about them. In November, however, Fang wrote a letter accepting a human rights award. ``Remember that in the current climate of terror, it may well be that those who are most terrified are those who have just finished the killing,'' he wrote. ``We may be forced to live under a terror today, but we have no fear of tomorrow. The murderers are not only fearful today, they are even more terrified of tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Tram Accident Injures Four People, One Critically
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT spelling of victim's name to Welsh sted Walsh, update condition from critical to serious.
DOC.TEXT: A lakeside tram plunged out of control 120 feet down a hillside, hurling four passengers into the Lake of the Ozarks and breaking the neck of one of them, authorities said. The cause of the Sunday evening accident was still under investigation, the Missouri State Water Patrol said today. All four Osage Beach residents aboard, ranging in age from 63 to 80, were injured. The tram, which has operated less than six weeks, hoists passengers up and down a 45-degree incline from the lakeside to the Swiss Village Restaurant, near Osage Beach. It is operated by the restaurant, the patrol said. Lake of the Ozarks is a popular tourist attraction. One of the injured, Marge Welsh, 76, had a broken neck and was listed in serious condition today at the University of Missouri-Columbia Hospital. Two of the other three were hospitalized in stable condition today, while the third was treated and released.

DOC.HEAD: East, West German Lawmakers Visit, Pledge United Germany's Support
DOC.TEXT: Parliament presidents from East and West Germany, on a historic joint visit to Israel, pledged Monday that a united Germany would be a strong supporter of the Jewish state. Deputy Knesset Speaker Dan Tichon hailed the visit as a goodwill gesture and said it was an ``important and unparalleled milestone in all connected between Israel and the two Germanys.'' The welcome was not unanimous. Knesset Speaker Dov Shilansky, a survivor of the Dachau death camp who has vowed never to receive German delegations, took a one-day vacation Monday to avoid meeting Rita Suessmuth of West Germany and Sabine Bergmann-Pohl of East Germany. Shilansky was scheduled to receive the two women in his Jerusalem home Tuesday, and the Maariv daily reported he would tell them about his suffering at the hands of the Nazis. The visit is the first joint trip abroad by the leaders of the two parliaments, and they said it was designed to allay Israeli concerns about German unification. ``We came here to ask for forgiveness but also to win trust concerning the process of German unification,'' said Ms. Bergmann-Pohl, a physician and political newcomer who became head of East Germany's first freely elected parliament in April. ``There are fears in Israel concerning how the united Germany will act toward Israel, which role it will play in the world,'' added Ms. Suessmuth. In a united Germany, ``relations with Israel will get stronger and that Germany will not shy away from its responsibilities and obligations'' toward the Jewish state, she said. At the Knesset, the two presidents reviewed a 20-member honor guard as the black-red-and-gold flags of their countries _ one with a hammer and sickle and one without _ were raised alongside the Israeli flag. Each laid a wreath at a statue for fallen Israeli soldiers outside the Knesset entrance on a hilltop overlooking Jerusalem. They briefly attended a routine session of the Knesset in which only about 20 of the 120-members, including Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, were present. The parliament rarely has more members in attendance unless an important vote is scheduled. The Polish-born Shamir, who lost his parents in the Holocaust, got up briefly to announce the naming of deputy ministers in his new government but did not acknowledge the presence of the two presidents in the visitors gallery. Another deputy Knesset speaker, Shevach Weiss, said he was very moved by the visit. ``I'm a survivor of the Holocaust,'' Weiss, who spent two years hiding from the Nazis in the basement of a house in the Ukraine, told the visiting German politicians. ``You belong to a new generation ... According to Jewish tradition, guilt should not be transferred from one generation to the next. But I hope that Israel and the free world, including the two Germanys, will work together so we won't forget'' the horrors of the Holocaust, he said. Earlier Monday, Ms. Bergmann-Pohl told reporters at Ben Gurion International Airport that she would seek speedy establishment of relations between her country and Israel. The possibility of ties first arose after last fall's toppling of the ruling East German Communists, who were hostile toward Israel and refused to accept moral responsibility for the Holocaust. The Communists argued that they themselves were persecuted by the Nazis. In April, the East German Parliament issued a resolution apologizing to Jews around the world for the atrocities of the Holocaust and pledging to pay reparations. Preliminary talks on diplomatic relations have been held between East Germany and Israel this year. Foreign Ministry spokesman Motti Amihai said efforts would continue despite the quickening moves toward German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Public Inquest on Pan Am Disaster Set for October 1
DOC.TEXT: A public inquiry into the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 will begin Oct. 1, officials said Monday, but relatives of the victims were not satisfied. All 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 and 11 people in the town of Lockerbie were killed when the aircraft exploded and crashed on Dec. 21, 1988. Lord Fraser, Scotland's chief law officer, said in December he would convene a fatal accident inquiry, but he did not announce the date until Monday. Relatives' groups have been demanding a broader inquiry independent of the government. Dr. Jim Swire, who heads a relatives' group called U.K. Families _ Flight 103, said he doubted the value of a fatal accident inquiry. ``We believe there is a cover-up of U.K. security, and until there is a full independent inquiry we will continue to believe so,'' said Swire, whose daughter Flora, 24, was killed on the plane. Scottish and U.S. officials have said they do not have enough evidence to prosecute anyone for the attack. ``The ordering of the fatal accident inquiry does not in any way signify an end of the hunt for those responsible for the mass murder at Lockerbie,'' said Fraser. ``We remain as committed today as ever to bringing the evil perpetrators to justice,'' he said. Fraser's comments indicated he did not expect a criminal inquiry by Oct. 1. The fatal accident inquiry will be held at Crichton Royal Hospital in Dumfries, about 10 miles west of Lockerbie. Scottish police, who have coordinated an international investigation, have said the bomb was hidden inside a radio-cassette recorder that was probably put aboard the flight in Frankfurt, West Germany. Baggage was shifted to the 747 at Heathrow airport in London, and the bomb exploded as the New York-bound flight was reaching cruising altitude. The fatal accident inquiry will be conducted by Sheriff Principal John Mowatt, the senior sheriff for southwestern Scotland. The sheriff sets the scope for the inquiry. He is charged with finding where and when the deaths occurred, the cause, any ``reasonable precautions'' that might have avoided it, any defects in systems or procedures that contributed to the deaths and any other facts relevant to the circumstances. Fraser's office said a sheriff had the power to compel witnesses to attend or documents to be produced, but this power is confined to the United Kingdom. Sheriffs can issue ``a letter of request'' to overseas authorities for evidence to be made available. The government may claim ``public interest immunity'' over documents, exhibits or evidence, but that claim may be overturned by courts.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says She Saw Barry Smoking Marijuana on Boat
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New grafs 5-7 bgng, Later, another... to UPDATE with later testimony; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A prosecution witness testified today that she saw Mayor Marion Barry smoking marijuana with acquaintances on a boat in 1986, but then conceded she had been at the far end of the vessel and unable to see details. Prosecution witness Jonetta Vincent testified in Barry's drug and perjury trial that she saw Barry smoking and passing a marijuana cigarette in a group that included two government witnesses, convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, and Rasheeda Moore, Barry's female companion on the Virgin Islands outing. That testimony supported Lewis' previous testimony that he and Barry had used marijuana and cocaine together during the trip. But under cross examination from Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy, Vincent then testified that she had been at the far end of the boat and had not actually seen Barry and Lewis and Moore exchanging the marijuana cigarettes. Later, another witness testified that she saw Barry puff on marijuana cigarettes while he was in the Virgin Islands and went into a bathroom out of sight to use crack cocaine. The mayor sat on his hotel room bed and smoked marijuana during a March 1988 trip, according to testimony by Dixie Hedrington, a prosecution witness, whose taped testimony was played in the courtroom. ``I smoked it a little and gave it to the mayor'' who was sitting directly across from her, said Hedrington. ``He smoked it'' and passed the joint to another woman in the hotel room, she said. The testimony came at the start of the second week of testimony in the mayor's trial on three felony charges of perjury, 10 misdemeanor charges of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy to possess cocaine. He has pleaded innocent. The perjury charges allege that Barry lied when he told a grand jury that he was unaware of Lewis' drug involvement, told the panel he had never given Lewis anything of value, and had never given drugs to him or received them from him. In court today, Mundy pressed Vincent on whether she had seen anything to suggest Barry and Lewis had exchanged drugs. ``And you did not see Charles Lewis hand anything to Mayor Barry?'' ``Correct,'' Vincent answered. ``And you did not see Mayor Barry pass anything to Charles Lewis,'' Mundy continued. ``No, sir,'' Vincent responded. Under further questioning by Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin, Vincent said she had been ``confused'' by Mundy's questions about who was passing the marijuana to whom. Vincent also testified that one of Barry's security guards, police Lt. Ronald Harvey, was present when the marijuana was being smoked but did nothing to stop it.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Donates to Iran Earthquake Relief
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Novelist Salman Rushdie, who is under an Iranian death order for alleged blasphemy of Islam, is donating $8,650 to help victims of the Iranian earthquake, a newspaper said Monday. The Independent, which launched an appeal for contributions Saturday, said Rushdie contacted it Monday through a representative to say he was matching the paper's contribution to the fund. ``It's quite clear that at the moment we should be thinking only of the humanitarian issue, which transcends all other discussions,'' editor Andreas Whittam Smith quoted Rushdie as saying in a statement. He further quoted Rushdie as saying: ``I wanted to join The Independent and the hostage families and many other people in their appeal for contributions toward the needs of Iranian earthquake victims.'' Trustees of the fund include the archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie. His envoy, Terry Waite, is missing and believed held by pro-Iranian militants in Lebanon. Waite's brother, David, has written to the Iranian government expressing condolences over Thursday's quake, which killed tens of thousands of people. In front-page notices over the weekend, The Independent told readers that the fund ``will be used for those injured or bereaved in the earthquake or their families or dependents.'' Rushdie, an Indian-born Moslem who became a British citizen, has been in hiding since February 1989, when the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran deemed his novel, ``The Satanic Verses,'' blasphemous to Islam and said he should be killed. Khomeini died a year ago, but Iran has repeatedly said the death sentence stands.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Donnie Wahlberg wasn't seriously hurt when he fell through a stage trapdoor. But the singing star of New Kids on the Block was admitted to the intensive care unit to keep his admiring fans away. More than 100 fans gathered Monday outside Saratoga Hospital where the 20-year-old Wahlberg was listed as stable. He was being held in intensive care for security reasons, said hospital spokeswoman Helen Edelman. Wahlberg suffered bruises to his chest and cuts to his arms and lower lip when he crashed through an unsealed trap door late in Sunday night's concert at the Saratoga Raceway, said Skip Carlson, raceway spokesman. ``I was told the door just gave way and he went down through it,'' he said. Wahlberg is one of five members of the group known for its tightly choreographed shows and rabid teen-age following. Edelman said some of the teen-agers outside the hospital brought binoculars hoping to catch a glimpse of their idol through a window. ``We keep reminding them that this is a hospital,'' she said.

William Warfield just keeps singin' along. The 70-year-old Warfield is back in town to sing ``Old Man River,'' the meandering melody he immortalized in the 1951 movie of the musical ``Showboat.'' Warfield will sing during a fifth anniversary celebration Wednesday for the General Jackson showboat at the Opryland U.S.A. country-music theme park. ``The thought of performing `Old Man River' on a true showboat certainly brings back some fond memories,'' Warfield said.

Author Tom Peters on Monday gave the American Civil Liberties Union $20,000 to protest a proposed state bill that would limit the fine for assaulting a flag burner to $25. ``I don't condone flag burning but this action in Louisiana openly endorses a more profound and dangerous kind of violence. It's pure fascism,'' he told reporters. Peters, a Vietnam veteran decorated for valor and the co-author of two best-selling management books, was in New Orleans to speak to the International Car Wash Association. He said he decided to give the ACLU his speaking fee after reading about the proposal last week. It would create an exception to the state law setting the maximum penalty for battery at a $500 fine and six months in jail. Peters has a syndicated newspaper column. He wrote ``In Search of Excellence'' with Bob Waterman, ``A Passion for Excellence'' with Nancy Austin and ``Thriving on Chaos: Handbook for a Management Revolution.''

The child actor who played Pee Wee in the Oscar-winning 1938 classic ``Boys Town'' returned to the movie's namesake to preside over the dedication of a chapel. The Rev. Bobs Watson was 7 years old when he appeared in the movie with Mickey Rooney as Whitey Marsh and Spencer Tracy playing Father Flanagan. He's now 59 and an ordained United Methodist minister in Montrose, Calif. He gave a sermon Sunday at the dedication of Boys Town's $3 million Chambers Protestant Chapel. Watson said giving the sermon was ``the most privileged thing that's ever happened to me. Here it is 52 years later and Pee Wee has come back.'' Before he became a minister, Watson starred in the 1960s television series ``Hot off the Wire'' with Jim Backus. ``I had the world by the tail, but I was hearing a voice in the back of my mind saying `Isn't there something more than this?''' Watson said he vividly recalls one scene from ``Boys Town,'' when a teary-eyed Pee Wee begs Whitey Marsh not to leave: ``As I watch that scene on screen I can still feel myself looking up at Mickey Rooney on that street, with me crying as though he was really leaving me.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Two state lawmakers aren't very fond of the idea of football player Brian Bosworth crashing into the state Capitol. They've filed a resolution asking state officials to stop movie producers from using the Capitol for filming part of a movie starring the Seattle Seahawks linebacker. Bosworth is filming ``The Brotherhood'' on the Mississippi Gulf Coast and in Louisiana and Alabama. The scene at the capitol in Jackson would have Bosworth land by helicopter on the grounds, climb the outside of the building, crash through a window into the Senate chamber and nab a villain in the rotunda. State economic development agency officials, who are promoting the filming, said one magnolia tree would have to be moved to allow the helicopter to land. Officials said the film company has insurance to cover damage. Lt. Gov. Brad Dye and House Speaker Tim Ford had not yet decided whether to allow the use of Capitol grounds. State Reps. Scott Ross and Bobby Moak said in their resolution that the Capitol is ``too respected a place to be used for a movie scene that the average viewer will not even know is being filmed in Mississippi.'' The resolution goes to the House Rules Committee for consideration.

It's a boy for actress Kelly LeBrock and her actor-husband Steven Seagal. Dominic San Rocco Seagal weighed 7 pounds when he was born Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said Paul Bloch, publicist for the couple. ``Mother and child are in excellent health,'' Bloch said Monday. The couple and their newborn have returned to their home near Santa Barbara, he said. The Seagals also have a 3-year-old daughter, Annaliza. Miss LeBrock may be best known for her role in the movie ``Woman in Red.'' Seagal won acclaim for his role in the film ``Above the Law.'' The couple appeared together in the movie ``Hard to Kill.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Dismantle Pipe Bomb In Downtown Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday safely dismantled a pipe bomb planted near gas tanks at a house in downtown Jerusalem. ``It was a wide pipe blocked with plugs from both sides. It was planted near large gas tanks. ... Thank God that the whole house did not explode,'' Rachamim Edri, a resident who found the bomb, said on Israel army radio. Police detained about 30 Arab suspects, but a spokesman said they were likely to be released soon. Police Minister Roni Milo, speaking on Israel radio, blamed the incident on Palestinians and said he will increase security in Jerusalem. ``Jerusalem has always been an important target for those who want to attack us. There is no doubt we see an upsurge in attacks in Jerusalem and elsewhere,'' Milo said. On Sunday, a pipe bomb, also planted near gas tanks outside a building, exploded in the central Israeli city of Ramle and a similar bomb was safely dismantled nearby. There were no injuries or damage. Police attributed the Ramle bombing to Palestinian nationalists.

DOC.HEAD: Amid The Courtliness, Differences Emerge
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In between the courtesies and the courtliness, there was blunt talk Monday on the South Lawn when President Bush welcomed Nelson Mandela to the White House. They are allies with differences, and neither man was reluctant to speak his mind. The American president said apartheidis an evil and Mandela is a man who ``embodies the hopes of millions.'' Beyond that, Bush added his support for continuing economic sanctions against South Africa. But Bush took a jab at Mandela's embrace of left-wing causes when he said that the mere end of apartheid would be a hollow victory indeed if South Africa opted for Marxism. ``Just as this past year, so many millions of people in Eastern Europe and elsewhere have tasted freedom, so too South Africa's time will come. ... The future belongs not to the dwindling ranks of the world's dictators, but to democracy,'' Bush said. At another point, he stressed that the United States was ``committed to the concept of free market.'' Bush was a gracious host in the presence of a man who is drawing fire from some Republican party figures after his expressions of admiration for Cuba's Fidel Castro, Libya's Moammar Gadhafi and the Palestine Liberation Organization's Yasser Arafat. Mandela was at his courtly best as he responded to Bush's remarks. ``To receive the support of the government of the United States of America, the leader of the West, is something beyond words,'' he said. But almost in the next breath, Mandela departed from the normal decorum of such occasions by challenging Bush on the question of violence. Mandela made clear he was not prepared to accept Bush's appeal for a blanket renunciation of the use of violence. ``The remarks he has made here are due to the fact that he has not as yet got a proper briefing from us,'' Mandela said, speaking extemporaneously. So long as the South African government is committed to peace talks, use of violence is out of the question, he said. But he then added: ``If we are forced to resort to violence, it is because we have no other alternative whatsoever.'' It's not surprising that the two men have differences. Bush has seen democratic capitalism work to advantage. Mandela has seen the horror of a system in which democracy has been limited to a privileged minority. It's easier for Bush to talk about the virtue of restraint than it is for Mandela. Mandela has left some listeners confused about his vision of a post-apartheid South Africa. During his U.S. visit, he has praised effusively the American system. But he also has been effusive about Cuba's system and about what he regards as the positive role of South Africa's Communist Party. On Capitol Hill, where Mandela was expected to receive a warm welcome Tuesday when he becomes the first black private citizen ever to address a joint meeting of Congress, his embrace of Arafat, Gadhafi and Castro were making some supporters nervous _ and raising the ire of opponents. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., a Mandela supporter and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, said in an interview that Mandela's support for Castro, Gadhafi and Arafat ``were not helpful.'' ``I don't think he fully understands how those names resonate within the United States,'' Wolpe said. ``There are few people who are held in lower esteem.'' Despite the controversy, Mandela is sure to be accorded a hero's welcome by much of Congress. Like Bush, they will have differences with the man _ but respect for his experience and his role in the changes in South Africa.
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.
Here are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision Monday saying states may bar the removal of life-sustaining treatment from comatose patients who have not made or cannot make their desires known.
DOC.HEAD: Main Opinion by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist:
DOC.TEXT: ... the majority of states in this country have laws imposing criminal penalties on one who assists another to commit suicide. ... We do not think a State is required to remain neutral in the face of an informed and voluntary decision by a physically-able adult to starve to death. But in the context presented here, a state has more particular interests at stake. The choice between life and death is a deeply personal decision of obvious and overwhelming finality. We believe Missouri may legitimately seek to safeguard the personal element of this choice through the imposition of heightened evidentiary requirements. It cannot be disputed that the Due Process Clause protects an interest in life as well as an interest in refusing life-sustaining medical treatment. Not all incompetent patients will have loved ones available to serve as surrogate decisionmakers. And even where family members are present, ``(t)here will, of course, be some unfortunate situations in which family members will not act to protect a patient.'' ... ...An erroneous decision not to terminate results in a maintenance of the status quo; the possibility of subsequent developments such as advancements in medical science, the discovery of new evidence regarding the patient's intent, changes in the law, or simply the unexpected death of the patient despite the administration of life-sustaining treatment, at least create the potential that a wrong decision will eventually be corrected or its impact mitigated. An erroneous decision to withdraw life-sustaining treatment, however, is not susceptible of correction. In (a previous case) one of the factors which led the Court to require proof by clear and convincing evidence in a proceeding to terminate parental rights was that a decision in such a case was final and irrevocable. ... The same must surely be said of the decision to discontinue hydration and nutrition of a patient such as Nancy Cruzan, which all agree will result in her death. ... No doubt is engendered by anything in this record but that Nancy Cruzan's mother and father are loving and caring parents. Close family members may have a strong feeling _ a feeling not at all ignoble or unworthy, but not entirely disinterested, either that they do not wish to witness the continuation of the life of a loved one which they regard as hopeless, meaningless, and even degrading. But there is no automatic assurance that the view of close family members will necessarily be the same as the patient's would have been had she been confronted with the prospect of her situation while competent. All of the reasons previously discussed for allowing Missouri to require clear and convincing evidence of the patient's wishes lead us to conclude that the State may choose to defer only to those wishes, rather than confide the decision to close family members.
DOC.HEAD: Dissenting Opinion by Justice William J. Brennan:
DOC.TEXT: ...Because I believe that Nancy Cruzan has a fundamental right to be free of unwanted artificial nutrition and hydration, which right is not outweighed by any interests of the State, and because I find that the improperly biased procedural obstacles imposed by the Missouri Supreme Court impermissibly burden that right, I respectfully dissent. Nancy Cruzan is entitled to choose to die with dignity. An erroneous decision to terminate life-support is irrevocable, says the majority, while an erroneous decision not to terminate ``results in a maintenance of the status quo.'' .... But from the point of view of the patient, an erroneous decision in either direction is irrevocable. An erroneous decision to terminate artificial nutrition and hydration, to be sure, will lead to failure of that last remnant of physiological life, the brain stem, and result in complete brain death. An erroneous decision not to terminate life-support, however, robs a patient of the very qualities protected by the right to avoid unwanted medical treatment. His own degraded existence is perpetuated; his family's suffering is protracted; the memory he leaves behind becomes more and more distorted. ... The Missouri court's disdain for Nancy's statements in serious conversations not long before her accident, for the opinions of Nancy's family and friends as to her values, beliefs and certain choice, and even for the opinion of an outside objective factfinder appointed by the State evinces a disdain for Nancy Cruzan's own right to choose. The rules by which an incompetent person's wishes are determined must represent every effort to determine those wishes. The rule that the Missouri court adopted ... transforms human beings into passive subjects of medical technology. The majority justifies its position by arguing that, while close family members may have a strong feeling about the question, ``there is no automatic assurance that the view of close family members will necessarily be the same as the patient's would have been had she been confronted with the prospect of her situation while competent.'' Ibid. I cannot quarrel with this observation. But it leads only to another question: Is there any reason to suppose that a State is more likely to make the choice that the patient would have made than someone who knew the patient intimately? To ask this is to answer it. As the New Jersey Supreme Court observed: ``Family members are best qualified to make substituted judgments for incompetent patients not only because of their peculiar grasp of the patient's approach to life, but also because of their special bonds with him or her.... It is ... they who treat the patient as a person, rather than a symbol of a cause.'' ... The State, in contrast, is a stranger to the patient.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A leading congressional supporter of Nelson Mandela said Monday he wished the black leader had not been so insistent in his praise for supporters such as Cuba, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Mandela was expected to receive a warm welcome on Capitol Hill when he becomes the first black private citizen ever to address a joint meeting of Congress on Tuesday. But his links to controversial figures such as Yasser Arafat, Moammar Gadhafi and Fidel Castro were making some supporters uncomfortable. In public comments last week, Mandela voiced strong support for Gadhafi, Castro and Arafat, saying they ``support our struggle to the hilt'' and that he had no problem with their approach to human rights. He called Arafat a ``comrade in arms'' and said he would not soften his support ``on the basis of the interests of the Jewish community.'' ``Our attitude toward any country is determined by the attitude of that country toward our struggle,'' he said. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, said Monday: ``I wish he (Mandela) had not said those things, very frankly. ``They were not helpful.'' Wolpe was one of the key lawmakers behind the 1986 passage of legislation imposing sanctions on South Africa, and has been among Mandela's strongest supporters in Congress. Another supporter of sanctions, Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., said he would boycott Mandela's speech. ``He comes here and espouses support _ not just casual, offhand support, but significant support _ for people whose methods and backgrounds are terrorists, outlaws or communist dictators,'' Smith said, ``people who practice every day what Nelson Mandela has fought his whole life against.'' ``I wished he would not have been so insistent in his reluctance to be critical of those individuals,'' Wolpe said in an interview. ``I don't think he fully understands how those names resonate within the United States. There are few people who are held in lower esteem.'' Wolpe said he hopes Mandela will at some point address the human rights concerns that Americans have about those the black leader counts among his allies. But he said it would be ``tragic'' if the comments were to overshadow Mandela's visit to Capitol Hill on Tuesday or to diminish U.S. resolve to keep up the economic pressure on South Africa to throw out its racially based government. Wolpe said Mandela and South African President F.W. de Klerk ``are the two keys'' to reform in that country. ``If anything happened to either of them this entire process would unravel in an instant, and the members (of Congress) recognize that,'' he said. One of the more extreme views of Mandela's visit was expressed Monday by archconservative Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., who called it ``a national disgrace'' that the leader of the African National Congress was scheduled to address the U.S. Congress. Dannemeyer cited the ANC's links to violence and Mandela's statements in support of Arafat, Gadhafi and Castro. ``Nelson Mandela is no Martin Luther King. He is more like H. Rap Brown or Willie Horton,'' Dannemeyer said in a floor statement. ``His wife, Winnie, has given a new meaning to the word `necklace'.'' The latter statement was a reference to the practice of ``necklacing,'' torture by placing a gasoline-filled tire around the neck of the victim. Mandela will be the fourth black leader to address a joint meeting of Congress, and the first black who is not a head of state. The others were President William Tolbert of Liberia in 1976, President Paul Magloire of Haiti in 1955 and Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia in 1954. Mandela also is the third private citizen to address such a meeting. The others were Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa last year and the Marquis de Lafayette of France in 1824.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates Flag-Burning Amendment
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Monday debated a constitutional amendment against flag burning that was killed by the House last week but remained alive with political consequence. Flag burning, like pornography, was ``beyond the founding fathers' understanding of freedom,'' said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., calling on the Senate to help send the amendment to the states for ratification. ``If we tamper with the Bill of Rights on the 200th anniversary of our Constitution, then we are ultimately diminishing every flag in America,'' said Sen. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said the Senate was engaged in ``an attempt to enmesh the flag in politics in the November elections'' rather than in an attempt to protect it. The House voted 254-177 in favor of the flag amendment, 34 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed. Two-thirds approval is needed in both houses to send a proposed amendment to the states for ratification. Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., led the opposition, which portrayed the amendment as an attack on the Bill of Rights. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., senior Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said opponents to the amendment ``misinterpreted its application to the right of free speech.'' Behind him, the Senate chamber was decorated with posters of quotations from Supreme Court justices who, disagreeing with the current court, said protecting the flag was not in violation of First Amendment rights. ``The Senate should vote favorably on this proposal and send it back to the House so they may atone for their earlier decision,'' he said. Foley said last week he planned no more House votes on the amendment this year. Since approval by both chambers is required, the proposal is dead until the next session of Congress. Still, Senate proponents led by Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., insisted that their chamber vote on the amendment. The vote was scheduled for Tuesday. Republicans in this fall's election hope to take control the Senate from the Democrats and they are using the flag amendment as a campaign issue. Several incumbent Democrats oppose the flag amendment while their GOP challengers support it. ``The flag protection (amendment)... is dead, but flag politics is just beginning,'' Biden said. The proposed amendment, backed by President Bush, reads: ``The Congress and the states shall have power to prohibit the physical desecration of the flag of the United States.'' If approved, it would be the 27th amendment to the Constitution. The amendment was first proposed a year ago, after the Supreme Court found flag burning to be a form of free speech protected by the First Amendment. In reaction to that decision, Congress passed a new statute against flag burning. The Supreme Court on June 11 ruled 5-4 that the new law also violated the Constitution _ rekindling the political debate. Biden, who led the fight last year for a statute, said he could support a constitutional amendment but not the one before the Senate. The wording of the proposal clearly aimed it against speech offensive to the government, which was ``the core principle'' of free speech. Instead, Biden said he favored an amendment that would protect the physical integrity of the flag without entering the realm of judging the purpose of the flag burning or other attack. Congress should protect the flag, but ``I for one do not want to burn the Constitution in the process,'' he said. Others also planned to offer alternative amendments or statutes, but the Senate appeared in no mood to tinker with the issue and Tuesday's vote was expected to be yes or no on the Republican proposal. It's ``a dead issue in a Congress that should be spending time on other things,'' Biden said.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Chinese Dissident Relieved By Parents' Release
With AM-Fang, Bjt
LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: The son of Chinese dissidents said Monday he's relieved and happy his parents have been allowed to leave their homeland after spending more than a year in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. ``They'll be able to see the sun, to breathe the air, and maybe to see the ocean. That's great for them. They're free,'' Fang Ke said at his Detroit apartment. U.S. officials told him the news in a 4 a.m. telephone call Monday. His parents, Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian, had sought refuge at the embassy after the June 4, 1989, military crackdown on China's pro-democracy movement. ``They are out of Chinese hands, Beijing cannot control them anymore,'' Fang Ke said. Fang Ke, 27, has been a graduate physics student at Wayne State University in Detroit for two years. He hasn't seen his parents since he enrolled at the University of Louisville in 1986. Communist authorities allowed Fang and his wife to leave the country for medical reasons after showing ``signs of repentance,'' according to the official Chinese news service Xinhua. Their release was an effort by China to improve its ties with the West. Fang and his wife, both 54, didn't play an active role in last year's Tienanmen Square demonstrations. But the government accused them of instigating the unrest. The White House said Fang and Li were bound for Britain aboard a U.S. air transport, and would arrive in London early Tuesday. Fang Ke has kept in touch with his parents through letters. He said he had no reason to believe their health was failing. Fang has a second son, Fang Zhe, 22, in Beijing. He was expected to stay at the family's home in China. Since late last year, China has announced the release of more than 800 people jailed for their participation in the democracy movement, but it is believed thousands remain in jail. ``I feel happy for my family and for their release ... but we don't know the exact number of people still in jail,'' Fang Ke said. Fang Ke said he believed his parents probably wouldn't return to China, but he added it is possible if political reform is achieved. ``I bet they'd like to go back, but it depends on Chinese leadership,'' he said. ``If it would be more democratic, then of course they'd go back.

DOC.HEAD: Australia, North Korea, Libya Join in Iran Quake Relief Effort
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran appealed Monday for medical supplies to treat earthquake victims, and countries worldwide answered with tons of foreign relief shipments and millions in cash donations. Iran's U.N. ambassador, Kamal Kharrazi, acknowledged help from the United States and said the disaster ``may create a better atmosphere for relations between Iranian and American peoples.'' A private American relief plane was one of at least 68 that landed in Tehran on Sunday and early Monday, bringing the first overt shipment of U.S. aid to Iran since the 1979 Islamic Revolution. Iran also has accepted $291,000 in U.S. government relief in the form of blankets, tents, water jugs and other supplies. A separate Red Cross charter flight left Washington carrying supplies donated by the U.S. government. Australia, Belgium, Libya and North Korea were among 26 countries announcing or sending aid. Saudi Arabia, which severed relations with Iran in April 1988, said it would send 40 planeloads of supplies in the next few days. Even Iraq, which fought Iran in the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war, offered help. British author Salman Rushdie, who Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered killed for a novel many Moslems considered offensive, pledged $8,650 for quake survivors, the British newspaper The Independent reported. The powerful quake rocked northern Iran on Thursday, killing an estimated 50,000 people and leaving at least 500,000 homeless, the Iranian U.N. mission said Monday. The mission released its latest figures with an urgent appeal for antibiotics, surgical gloves, X-ray equipment and other medical equipment. In Paris, UNESCO on Monday announced the start of a campaign to raise funds to rebuild schools wrecked by the earthquake. The director-general of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Federico Mayor, said about half of those rendered homeless by the quake were children. Communist North Korea announced Monday that it had sent a 58-member medical team and pledged $1 million in aid to victims of the quake. The Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, said part of the aid shipment was sent on the same plane Monday as a medical team from the North Korean Red Cross. The Australian government pledged a $790,000 donation, and Belgium pledged $425,000. Sweden on Monday donated another $2.2 million above the $750,000 it pledged Friday. The money will be handled through the Red Cross, it said. Libya sent a planeload of relief aid to Tehran to help victims, the official Libyan news agency JANA reported Monday. The shipment, which arrived Sunday, contained food, medicine, tents and blankets, said the brief dispatch, monitored in Rome. An AmeriCares' chartered cargo jet carrying 42 tons of U.S. aid _ including bandages, antiseptic burn cream, and tents _ arrived in Tehran on Sunday. Iran and the United States have had no diplomatic ties since the takeover of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran by Islamic militants, who held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days in 1979 and 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Imelda Marcos Knew of `Dirty Money' Investments
LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos knew ``dirty money'' was used for investments that the former Philippine first lady and her husband made in the United States, a prosecutor told a jury in closing arguments Monday. ``She wasn't just an outside observer who had things happening around her that she didn't know about,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella said. ``Imelda Marcos was not in a glass tomb. She was not afraid to venture into the business world,'' LaBella said. ``She was in the thick of things.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, has been on trial since March 20 on charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. The defense presented no witnesses because, Marcos attorney Gerry Spence said, ``there was no case.'' Spence has said Mrs. Marcos was unaware of any wheeling and dealing by her late husband, former Philippines President Ferdinance Marcos, and her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. Defense attorneys are to give their closing arguments Tuesday and Wednesday, and the case is expected to go to the U.S. District Court jury on Thursday. Monday, the prosecutor outlined what he called the circumstantial evidence that proves Mrs. Marcos and Khashoggi violated U.S. laws. ``Now you have the opportunity to put all the pieces together,'' LaBella said. ``You can be sure that Imelda Marcos and Adnan Khashoggi actually participated in the acts ... which are crimes in the United States.'' The government alleges that the Marcoses looted their country's treasury of $222 million during their 20 years in power, investing some of the money in four New York office buildings, jewelry and artworks. Khashoggi, 54, is accused of faking documents to help conceal the Marcoses' ownership of the real estate and paintings. That allegedly occurred after a U.S. court order froze their assets after their ouster from power in February 1986. ``They needed someone to take this hot potato off their hands. Adnan Khashoggi was the credible front they came up with,'' LaBella said. Witnesses at the trial described bribes and kickbacks from projects funded by a Japanese war reparation fund, ``commissions'' that were to go to the government-owned national oil company and fraudulent deals to exchange Philippine pesos to U.S. dollars through the country's central bank. LaBella traced these funds to the purchase of three office buildings and a retail building, the Herald Center, in Manhattan. As an example, he said the war reparation kickbacks were ``part of the dirty money used to purchase the Herald Center.'' LaBella said Mrs. Marcos, in her roles as mayor of Metro Manila and Minister of Human Settlements, had to be aware of the transactions. ``Imelda Marcos was not just the wife of Ferdinand Marcos,'' he said. ``She was a high-ranking government official. Of course she knew that they had to get the money from somewhere.'' The prosecutor also said Mrs. Marcos could be convicted if the jury decided she consciously avoided finding out the source of their wealth. The prosecutor dismissed as ``fiction'' a defense argument that the Marcoses invested in New York real estate in order to hide funds to fight back against a communist takeover of their country. Spence said outside of court that he was more optimistic than he had been earlier about his client's chances for acquittal. ``It's always scary at this stage of the trial, but it looks better than I expected, because they haven't proved a case of direct involvement against her,'' he said. If convicted, Mrs. Marcos would face a maximum of 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Khashoggi faces a sentence of 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted of mail fraud and obstruction of justice.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Says Police Abuse Palestinian Minors
DOC.NOTE: EDS: For Release at 5 p.m. EDT Monday, Time Set by Source. Elinoar in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli police and the Shin Bet security service routinely use violence while interrogating Palestinian minors, an Israeli human rights group said in a report released Monday. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, known as Betselem, also cited other abuses, such as overcrowded cells, a lack of proper medical attention and delays in investigating complaints of police brutality. Police said in response that they were investigating every complaint of brutality. A spokeswoman also acknowledged that prison conditions need to be improved. ``Police treat complaints of brutality by officers with special seriousness ... An investigation has been launched into every complaint submitted to police,'' said Elinoar Mazoz, who deals with public complaints. Her statement was attached to the Betselem report. National police spokesman Adi Gonen said Monday he had nothing to add. The report focused on the treatment of Palestinians aged 12 to 18 from Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem and nearby villages, who were held at police headquarters in downtown Jerusalem. All were detained during the 30-month Palestinian uprising on suspicion of stone-throwing, torching cars and anti-Israeli violence. Betselem said its report was not based on a representative survey, but that the findings indicated a ``widespread phenomenon that should be viewed seriously.'' The report includes affidavits from nine minors. They were not identified by name in keeping with Israeli law. A 12-year-old said he was placed inside a bag by interrogators. ``They put the lights out and I felt it being closed above my head. Then they began to beat me with a stick,'' he said. A 16-year-old said an interrogator ``beat me with the end of a plastic ruler on the arms, the back and all parts of the body ... Then he grabbed a metal bar and hit me on the head. I was handcuffed all the time.'' Another 16-year-old said he was pushed against a hot-water tank and suffered burns when water spilled on his right leg. Betselem said that in most cases, the minors did not file complaints because they do not believe in Israeli justice or fear the consequences. It also said police were not quick enough in investigating and punishing officers engaged in brutality. Ms. Mazoz said police investigated all complaints of brutality. She cited eight cases in which an investigation has either not been completed yet, or there was no response from the prosecutors. The report also described the interrogation methods of the Shin Bet, which deals with those over the age of 16. Betselem said the Shin Bet used a punishment cell, measuring about 4.5-by-4.5 feet. It described it as a ``dark, smelly and suffocating room where prisoners are often kept for days.'' Shin Bet interrogators also handcuff prisoners in distorted poses or place them in the so-called ``grave,'' a small underground cell in which prisoners can only crouch, it said. The Shin Bet has no spokesman. Betselem said the police headquarters, called the Russian Compound, is badly overcrowded. In March, the compound housed 81 Palestinian youths in three cells, including one with 12 beds and 39 prisoners in it, it said. It quoted the detention center's doctor, Andre Weissman, as saying he could not offer proper medical treatment to such a large number of prisoners. Ms. Mazoz acknowledged that the youth ward, designed for 34 beds, usually held some 60 to 80 inmates ``because of an increase in the number of prisoners'' as compared with previous years. She said the prisoners were given medical treatment and cleaned their cells three times a day. Betselem also said that detainees were often forced to sign confessions in Hebrew, a language most of them cannot read.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Experts Say Case Takes Away Choices From Doctors, Family
DOC.TEXT: The right-to-die ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court removes some clinical choices from doctors and family and puts the burden of assuring death with dignity solely on one person: The person who is dying. Though the ruling applies directly only to Missouri, which already has restrictive laws, experts believe medical communities in many states may generally apply the principles expressed in the case decided Monday. The result, some said, is that if there is any question about what a person in a vegetative state would want done, the doctors may choose to keep the patient alive no matter what the family says. There are an estimated 10,000 Americans who are beyond recall from coma. More are added annually with accidents and illnesses, and with the increasing skill of medicine to maintain life. Many people in such a state are allowed to die when doctors say there is no hope of recovery and the families believe the patient would choose such a death. ``I think the whole atmosphere in medicine will shift toward a more conservative ethical position on providing life support,'' said William T. Reich, a professor for bioethics at Georgetown University Hospital. ``This will put a lot of pressure on people to sign a living a will, or to put something in writing to make certain their wishes are known.'' Dr. Terry Walman, a member of the medical ethics committee at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, said the ruling suggested that those who want to make decisions about their terminal care can no longer informally leave it to others. ``They must take some action either in writing or appointing someone to act in their behalf,'' he said. ``If they don't do that, then in states with laws like Missouri they are in danger of not having their wishes followed.'' Dr. David P. Thomasma, the director of the medical humanities program at Loyola University in Chicago, said that in a usual hospital setting, doctors and families talk about what should be done about a patient in an irreversible state of coma. ``We trust family members and guardians unless there is reason to believe they are not trustworthy,'' Thomasma said. Often the family members call on memories of what the patient said and thought before the accident or injury, and try to interpret from these recollections what the patient would want. ``Traditionally, the common law in most states permitted guardians to make such decisions,'' Thomasma said. For patients whose breathing depends on high-tech support, he said, it is universally understood and accepted that the plug can be pulled if there is no sign of life in the brain. But, as in the Missouri case decided Monday, the withholding of food and nutrition is seen as another issue. Nancy Cruzan, now 32, suffered severe brain damage in a 1983 car accident. Her parents authorized the use of a feeding tube in the hope her condition would improve, but later requested that the tube be removed. Ms. Cruzan, who breathes on her own, has been in a coma-like condition for seven years. ``The fluid and nutrition issue is the most difficult for people because a person is not dying of the underlying disease or injury, but death is the result of dehydration or starvation,'' Thomasma said. The ruling left intact the concept that comatose patients can be deprived of food and water unto death, but it now permits states to pass laws that would require a higher level of proof of the patient's wishes. ``This is the first time that the court has said that such clear proof is needed,'' said Walman, an anesthesiologist and lawyer. ``It makes it much harder now for the family to speak for the patients.'' A head injury, stroke or drug reaction could send anyone forever into unconsciousness. But few people actually take formal action ahead of time to make sure their medical wishes are followed. Dr. Joanne Lynn, director of aging studies at George Washington University, said that even if people do write out their wishes ahead of time, it would be unlikely that they could describe precisely the medical circumstance of their final illness. Without a precise description, she said, under the new ruling patients in states with laws such as Missouri would have to be kept alive. ``Under the Missouri ruling, a person who is suffering horribly, but who is incompetent, must be kept alive by the health-care giver, if possible,'' Lynn said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheyenne Brando Has Returned To Tahiti, Won't Testify Against Brother
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's daughter Cheyenne has left the country and will refuse to return and testify against her brother Christian, a prosecutor said Monday. Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop told a judge he will attempt to use a recently enacted law to introduce Miss Brando's statements to police as evidence in a preliminary hearing for the brother, who is charged with murdering Miss Brando's boyfriend. Municipal Court Judge Rosemary Shumsky set Brando's preliminary hearing for July 23 but did not rule on the issue surrounding the new law. The matter was being transferred to another judge. Brando's lawyer, Robert Shapiro, said outside court he was not sure he would challenge Barshop's plan, suggesting that the use of Proposition 115 rules ``would be beneficial to Christian.'' Under the initiative approved by voters in the June 5 election, prosecutors may present hearsay evidence at the hearing in which a judge determines whether there is sufficient evidence to hold a defendant for trial. The measure is intended to spare victims the ordeal of testifying at the preliminary hearing and then having to repeat their stories at trial. Barshop said he would attempt to introduce Miss Brando's statement to police in a June 12 interview as evidence against her brother. He said that Miss Brando, who is eight months pregnant with the child of her dead boyfriend, has gone to Tahiti and refuses to return. Marlon Brando maintains a home there. Miss Brando's boyfriend, Dag Drollet, 26, was shot to death on May 16 at the elder Brando's estate. The actor was home at the time but was in a different part of the house and did not see the slaying. Christian Brando, 32, reportedly told police that Drollet had died during a struggle over a gun. Accounts of the slaying have been confused, and the preliminary hearing is expected to present the first clear picture of what happened.

DOC.HEAD: Fang Lizhi, Biography of a Dissident
With AM-Fang, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a biographical look at Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi, who was allowed to leave Beijing on Monday after a year of hiding in the U.S. Embassy.

BORN: Feb. 12, 1936, in Hangzhou, China. EDUCATED: University of Beijing and Princeton University. MARRIED: Li Shuxian, in 1961. They are the parents of two sons. SCIENTIFIC ACHIEVEMENTS: China's leading astrophysicist, Fang's research into the structure of the universe resulted in the publication of over 170 papers and an international reputation. From 1969 to 1978, while in political disfavor, he had to publish his work under a pseudonym. During the 1980s he explored such topics as structural randomness of the universe, and the role of invisible ``dark matter'' in the formation of large-scale structure in the universe. AWARDS: National Award for Science and Technology, 1978; Chinese Academy of Sciences Award 1982; New York Academy of Sciences Award, 1988. POLITICAL DISSENT: Fang became politically prominent during the pro-democracy student demonstrations of 1986-87. His speeches to students at the University of Science and Technology in Hefei in central China, where he was vice president, helped incite the protests, party hard-liners said. Fang was expelled from the Communist Party in 1957, when he said Marxist theory on physics was obsolete. In 1987, he was fired from his Hefei university posts. In between, in 1966, he was a victim of the Cultural Revolution purges and was sent to a communal farm for ``re-education.'' After the June 4, 1989, military crackdown on the democracy movement, Fang and Li obtained refuge in the U.S. Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says Investments in New Bases Won't Preclude Closure
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Monday that major investments in new military bases and strategic home ports would not preclude a later decision to close the facilities in times of reduced defense spending. ``Obviously we're not oblivious to what's been spent,'' Cheney said at a luncheon with reporters. ``The fact that those are new facilities that we spent money on does not automatically guarantee that they're going to stay open.'' Cheney is expected to ask Congress this week to cancel a significant number of military construction projects at home and abroad in response to expected reductions in the defense budget. The Pentagon estimates the value of the 207 projects under consideration at $1.2 billion. The candidates for cancellation include the controversial home ports in New York, Texas, Alabama and Mississippi. Funds for the projects have been approved already, forcing Cheney to ask Congress to withdraw the money through a process formally known as ``rescission.'' Cheney said Monday that each facility will be decided on a case-by-case basis. But in response to a question as to whether new installations would be affected, the defense secretary said: ``We have no choice.'' Cheney said the Navy of the future is likely to be closer to 450 ships than the 600-ship force that was envisioned during the defense buildup of the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Military's Strength Fell in May
DOC.TEXT: The strength of the armed forces declined by 6,275 in May, according to preliminary figures released Monday by the Pentagon. The announcement said 2,056,625 people wore Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force uniforms as of May 31. The figure includes full-time regulars, reserves on active duty and officer candidates including cadets at the three military academies. The comparable figure on the same date last year was 2,110,615.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Leaves Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy was released Monday from a northern Israeli hospital where he spent 11 days following a minor heart attack. ``I came here exhausted. Apparently I took too much upon myself,'' Levy said on Israel radio after leaving Haemek Hospital in the town of Afula. Doctors described Levy's condition as ``good'' but said he must rest as much as possible and refrain from smoking. Levy, 52, a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc, was a former housing minister and deputy prime minister. He was named foreign minister in Shamir's new conservative government, which took office earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. on Lookout for Mad Cow Disease
DOC.TEXT: Federal and state animal-health authorities are cooperating in a nationwide alert for signs of ``mad cow disease,'' which has stricken Britain's cattle industry, the Agriculture Department said Monday. The disease _ bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE _ was not known to exist in the United States, said James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal Health and Inspection Service. The disease attacks the central nervous system and is fatal to cattle. There has been no scientific evidence that it is a human health hazard, officials said. The agency, Glosser said, has barred the importation of live cattle from Britain since July 1989. ``Also, over 150 federal and state veterinarians constantly conduct field investigations of suspicious diseases and report their findings to us,'' Glosser said. The national surveillance program will include USDA animal health officials, state veterinary diagnostic laboratories and Iowa State University. Initially, he said, laboratories in at least 16 states will be cooperating in the program: California, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia, Washington and Wisconsin. Glosser said other states also have requested to be included, so laboratory specimens may be received from other sources as well. Cattle affected by BSE may suffer changes in temperament, such as nervousness or aggression, thus accounting for it sometimes being called ``mad cow disease.'' Other symptoms include abnormal posture, lack of coordination and difficulty in rising, reduced milk production, loss of body weight despite continued appetite, and eventually death. Confirmation of the disease is possible only through post-mortem examination of the animal's brain. There is no test to detect the disease in a live animal.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says States Can Bar Removal of Life-Sustaining Equipment
DOC.TEXT: Family members can be barred from ending the lives of persistently comatose relatives who have not made their wishes known conclusively, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in its first ``right-to-die'' decision. By a 5-4 vote, the justices gave states broad power to keep such patients on life-support systems. Specifically, the court blocked the parents of a Missouri woman, Nancy Cruzan, from ordering removal of tubes that provide her with food and water. The court, clearing the way to end its term on Wednesday, decided another fundamental and emotional privacy issue by making it significantly more difficult for young girls to obtain legal abortions without first notifying their parents. The court voted 6-3 to uphold an Ohio law that bans abortions for unmarried girls under 18 who are dependent on one or both parents unless one parent is notified. And the court voted 5-4 to allow Minnesota to require notification of both parents as long as girls can avoid telling them by getting a judge's permission instead. Monday's right-to-die ruling encouraged supporters of ``living will'' laws because the court said the Constitution guarantees a competent person _ as opposed to someone in a coma _ a right to refuse medical treatment. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said, ``We assume that the United States Constitution would grant a competent person a constitutionally protected right to refuse lifesaving hydration and nutrition.'' But in Ms. Cruzan's case, he said, such ``clear and convincing'' proof that she would want to die is lacking and it is too risky to leave the decision to anyone else, even loving parents. ``Not all incompetent patients will have loved ones available to serve as surrogate decisionmakers,'' Rehnquist said. ``A state is entitled to guard against potential abuses ... where a guardian seeks to discontinue nutrition and hydration of a person diagnosed to be in a persistent vegetative state.'' He was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin J. Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Doctors have said Ms. Cruzan, 32, could live for 30 more years in her current ``persistent vegetative'' condition. Justice William J. Brennan, in a dissenting opinion, said Missouri officials and the high court are violating Ms. Cruzan's rights. ``Nancy Cruzan is entitled to choose to die with dignity,'' he said. Those denying her that right ``have discarded evidence of her will, ignored her values, and deprived her of the right to a decision as closely approximating her own choice as humanly possible.'' Ms. Cruzan's parents presented evidence she had told friends she would never want to remain alive in a vegetative state. Lower courts said that was not sufficient proof of her intentions. In a separate dissent, Justice John Paul Stevens said, ``The state's unflagging determination to perpetuate Nancy Cruzan's physical existence is comprehensible only as an effort to define life's meaning, not as an attempt to preserve its sanctity.'' Justice Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun also dissented. Ms. Cruzan's father, Joe Cruzan, sheet metal worker, had little to say when he arrived at his two-story frame Carterville, Mo., home with a lunch bucket and can of soda at noon. ``We really don't know what the decision means yet, so it would be pointless to comment,'' he said before closing the door. Dick Kurtenbach of the American Civil Liberties Union that has represented the family said the ruling is unfortunate but not surprising. ``I'm sure the family is going to be extremely disappointed,'' he said. Dr. Nancy Dickey of the American Medical Association said the ruling is ``an intrusion into the doctor-patient relationship and a step toward taking that decision away from the bedside. ... We should not deliver unnecessary care and pay for unnecessary care.'' Groups opposed to mercy killing hailed the decision. ``The high court has affirmed that persons who are unable to speak for themselves can be protected from the death sentence that euthanasia activists seek to force on them,'' said Rita Marker of the International Anti-Euthanasia Task Force. Despite the publicity the Cruzan case has attracted, the ruling's impact may be limited. Courts in nearly every state except Missouri have permitted removal of life-sustaining treatment for the permanently unconscious. And the decision does not bar state courts, or state legislatures, from continuing to allow the removal of such treatment _ even for incompetent persons. Most states, including Missouri, have living-will laws that allow people to authorize the termination of life-sustaining treatment before they undergo medical treatment, but the laws vary in their specifics. Missouri's version, for example, does not allow removal of feeding tubes. In any case, it was not in effect when Ms. Cruzan was injured in a 1983 car crash. It is estimated that as many as 10,000 Americans are receiving life-sustaining care. After Ms. Cruzan suffered severe brain damage, her parents authorized the use of a feeding tube in hopes her condition would improve. But for seven years she has remained in a coma-like condition _ her body rigid, her hands and feet constricted. She can breathe on her own, and at times her eyes are open and move randomly. The Bush administration sided with Missouri officials in urging she be kept alive. Permitting the removal of a feeding tube is a step toward sanctioning mercy killing or suicide, Justice Department lawyers said. The right-to-die issue captured national attention in 1976, when the New Jersey Supreme Court allowed the family of Karen Ann Quinlan to order the removal of a respirator helping her breathe. Ms. Quinlan, in a similar coma-like condition to that of Ms. Cruzan, continued to be fed through a tube and lived nine more years.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Occupy Lumber Office
DOC.TEXT: Nine women dressed as trees, mushrooms, spiders and a banana slug were arrested for investigation of trespassing Monday after they briefly occupied the offices of Pacific Lumber Company, authorities said. The women, who called themselves Urban Earth Women, demanded that Pacific Lumber halt the harvest of ancient redwood trees. They said their protest was in conjunction with ``Redwood Summer'' protests coordinated by the organization Earth First! The women were arrested after Pacific Lumber employees called the Marin County Sheriff's office, said Lt. John Brunslik. ``It was peaceful,'' he said. ``They came to make a statement, and they made their statement, which involved going to jail.'' The women were taken to the county jail for booking, Brunslik said. Thriteen women entered the building, which houses sales offices; four left voluntarily and were not arrested, Brunslik said. Pacific Lumber spokeswoman Mary Bullwinkel said the women asked to speak to a salesman who was not in the office, and then refused to leave after being asked. ``As far as I know, they did not say what they wanted to talk to him about,'' she said. Pacific Lumber has doubled its rate of harvest since being taken over by Maxxam Corp. in 1986, the protesters said in a statement. Although Bullwinkel conceded that the company's total harvest has almost doubled since 1986, she said the rate of old growth harvest has increased by about 25 percent. Protest participants also demanded an end to clearcutting and to meet with Maxxam president Charles Hurwitz.

DOC.HEAD: First U.S. Navy Ships to Visit Poland in 45 Years Due This Week
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. Navy ships to visit Poland in 45 years will make a routine port call at Gdansk this week, the Pentagon announced Monday. The announcement said the guided missile cruiser USS Yarnell, based in Norfolk, Va., and the guided missile frigate USS Kaufman, based in Newport, R.I., would be in the Polish port from Wednesday to Friday.

DOC.HEAD: `Poisoned Sausage' Scare May Lead to Alderman's Censure
DOC.TEXT: A black alderman battling a sausage maker over renaming a street for the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. faces a possible censure for issuing a warning that the company's products were tainted by rat poison. Alderman Michael McGee's warning forced Usinger's Famous Sausage Inc., a century-old family-owned business in Milwaukee, to recall 80,000 pounds of meat from 150 stores. Since then, the company has conducted a preliminary inspection and said it found none of the meats to be tainted. Mayor John O. Norquist and some city council members are threatening to punish McGee for what they say is an unsubstantiated threat. At a weekend news conference, Norquist called McGee ``demented,'' and accused him of fabricating the warning to gain attention. The mayor said McGee's antics were feeding racism and bigotry in the city. McGee, one of three blacks on the 16-member council, recently started a Black Panther Militia group. He said it would stage violent, terrorist strikes beginning in 1995 if inner-city conditions in Milwaukee don't improve.
