McGee has claimed his militia already has about 500 members, including many young street gang members. He has said that possible targets of violence could be motorists driving along highways or fans at sports events. The sausage warning prompted Common Council President Thomas Donegan to say that McGee had ``pushed freedom of speech beyond its limit.'' Donegan said he was planning to strip the alderman of his committee assignments. He also said the council would vote Friday on a censure against McGee. ``I don't want to look like a racist attacking my colleague, but I think if we're provoking fear and anxiety, we have to do something,'' Donegan said Monday. The sausage was recalled after McGee said he received an anonymous phone call that Usinger's products had been injected with rat poison by the Militant African Underground Squared. He identified it as an underground group. The group has no telephone listing and has made no statement regarding the alleged tampering. Norquist and others said they believe McGee's story was fabricated because the alderman brought the warning to news media instead of reporting it immediately to police. ``It's a hoax. It's phony,'' the mayor charged Saturday. ``What he's really doing is scaring the hell out of people, which feeds racism and bigotry.'' ``People in the city ... for the most part know McGee is a fool. They know what he says is not any more than an attempt to feed his own ego.'' McGee has refused interviews with the ``white-owned'' news media in recent months, accusing newspapers of distorting his intentions. He did not return a reporter's phone call to his office Monday seeking comment. A group of black politicians called on Norquist and others Monday to apologize to McGee. The group, which included three state lawmakers and two Milwaukee County Board members, said McGee did nothing wrong and was the target of criticism because he was an ``African-American male.'' Without an apology to McGee, ``I don't think its fair to say we'll have much peace in this city,'' Milwaukee County Supervisor Terrance Pitts told reporters. McGee, flanked by two uniformed members of his militia, attended the news conference and spoke only briefly. ``I'm going to take the pledge of allegiance to Milwaukee. I'm a real Milwaukeean,'' he said curtly, declining other comment. Police said they had received no reports of food tampering and criminal charges were unlikely. Usinger's, however, is proceeding to inspect all the meat it recalled before releasing it for sale, said spokesman Evan N. Zeppos. ``We have no alternative but to take it as a serious situation, whether it is a hoax or not,'' Zeppos said Monday. Zeppos said the company has not determined how much the recall has cost it. Usinger's and other businesses along North 3rd Street have opposed an effort to rename the street in honor of King. Part of the street is already named for the slain civil rights leader, but McGee and others are lobbying for the entire street to be renamed. Merchants have complained that a name change would inconvenience them.

DOC.HEAD: Valve for Columbia Coming from New Shuttle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `NASA plans ...' to CORRECT that Columbia test was conducted after, sted before launch attempt; Endeavour cq
DOC.HEAD: By MARCIA DUNN
AP Aerospace Writer
DOC.TEXT: A fuel valve from the unfinished space shuttle Endeavour will be removed and connected to Columbia, grounded until late summer because of a hydrogen leak, NASA said Monday. Shuttle Director Robert Crippen approved the transfer after engineers at Rockwell International Corp. in Downey, Calif., failed to find a leak in hydrogen lines that had been removed from Columbia's external tank. That confirmed NASA's suspicion the problem was with plumbing on the orbiter side. Columbia's 17-inch-diameter disconnect valve in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen from the external tank to the main engines will be removed and replaced with the one from Endeavour. Endeavour is under construction by Rockwell and is not scheduled to fly until 1992. Only one valve was built for each shuttle. There are no spares. Columbia's bad valve will be shipped to California for testing. Replacing the valve on the orbiter side is going to take the most time, said Lisa Malone, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Nonetheless, the astronomy mission remains targeted for mid-August, she said. Columbia's scheduled May 30 launch with the $150 million Astro observatory was scrubbed six hours before liftoff when the leak was detected during fueling. NASA plans to conduct a tanking test on Atlantis at the launch pad on Thursday, partly filling the shuttle's external tank with super-cold liquid hydrogen to make sure there are no leaks. The same test was conducted with Columbia a week after the scrubbed launch and replicated the leak. Prelaunch tests for leaks normally are conducted with a gaseous helium at room temperature rather than volatile liquid hydrogen chilled to minus 420 degrees. Atlantis is scheduled for a secret military mission in mid-July. The date will be set Friday following a two-day flight readiness review. ``We have no reason to believe we have a generic problem,'' Malone said. ``All leak tests (with helium) have passed. But that was the same for Columbia.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
41 States, D.C. Have `Living Will' Laws
DOC.TEXT: Forty-one states and the District of Columbia have ``living will'' laws that allow individuals to make their wishes about medical treatment known in advance of a crisis that may render them unable to speak. The Supreme Court ruling Monday indirectly supported living wills by saying the Constitution guarantees a competent person a right to refuse medical treatment. Eight states are considering bills that would enact such statutes. Only South Dakota has no statute and no pending legislation, according to the Society for the Right to Die. The eight states considering living will measures are Massachusetts, Michigan, Nebraska, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Explosion Rocks Social Club in Central London
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD background on club and IRA, further quotes. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An explosion tonight ripped through the Conservative Party's social club in central London, trapping and injuring an unknown number of people. The Fire Brigade said 40 firefighters were rushed to the blaze that broke out following the 8:30 p.m. (3:30 p.m. EDT) explosion on the ground floor of the three-story Carlton Club. The Carlton, which is among the famous old institutions known collectively as London's Clubland, is an exclusively male club, but it had to waive that rule in 1979 to admit Margaret Thatcher when she became prime minister. The 158-year-old club, near Trafalgar Square and a few hundred yards from Buckingham Palace, is frequented by Cabinet ministers, lawmakers and other members of Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party. She was in Dublin for a European Community summit. Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe was at a meeting in a nearby building and immediately came to the scene. ``Some people have been hurt ... though I can't say how many or how seriously,'' Howe told reporters. It was not immediately known whether a bomb was involved, but Sky Television News said it had reports ``a second device'' was found nearby. The TV report did not elaborate. Police said they were searching for a car with Irish license plates. The Irish Republican Army has been waging a bombing and shooting campaign against British soldiers in Britain and continental Europe this summer. In 1984 the IRA came close to blowing up Mrs. Thatcher in the seaside town of Brighton. A bomb exploded in the hotel where she was staying for her ruling Conservative Party's convention. Five people died. Mrs. Thatcher was unhurt. The blast smashed windows and sent up clouds of smoke. Ambulances raced to the scene and police cordoned off the area. ``I heard an enormous explosion,'' said Ian Greener, night manager at neighboring Brooks's Club. ``We dashed outside and all the smoke was coming from the building onto the street so it obviously was not a car bomb.'' ``We are still searching the rubble. We are also looking for suspect secondary devices,'' said a policeman on the scene. Last year the Cabinet entertained Mrs. Thatcher to a private dinner party at the Carlton Club to mark her 10 years as prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Meet Budget Negotiators As Talks Flag
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday invited congressional leaders to the White House to discuss flagging budget negotiations as Republicans accused Democrats of being confused about whether the talks should continue. The leaders were to meet with Bush on Tuesday, a day after a budget bargaining session between White House and congressional representatives was canceled. No further meetings were scheduled. The cancellation came four days after the last negotiating session, which ended with Democrats rejecting a Bush administration $51 billion deficit-reduction proposal for next year as inadequate. ``It seems to me the Democrats have not yet decided they even want to proceed,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., after GOP negotiators met with Bush for 90 minutes at the White House. After Thursday's budget session, some Democrats called the White House offer a first step in bargaining, while others insisted the talks should not continue without a better offer. ``We are very perplexed,'' said Domenici. ``We don't understand what the Democrats expect and we don't understand why we are not proceeding with negotiations. We are ready.'' The talks are aimed at finding a way to reduce the deficit for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Unless action is taken, the shortfall could exceed $200 billion. The Gramm-Rudman law will trigger widespread spending cuts unless the budget gap is no more than $74 billion next year.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Execs Want Commercials Exempt from Nutrition Information Requirements
DOC.TEXT: Advertising executives told a Senate panel Monday they want a federal law requiring nutrition information in food labels, but don't believe TV commercials should be required to provide the information. ``Federal intervention is necessary,'' said Peter Rosow, managing director of the advertising firm of D'Arcy, Masius, Benton and Bowles. He said diversity in state laws trying to regulate labeling makes business extraordinarily difficult for nationally distributed products. But ``it's wrong to apply the same guidelines to labeling and advertising,'' Rosow said. You can't get it all in a 30-second commercial, he said. Besides, an advertisement simply introduces the consumer to the product. The label supplies added information when an actual purchase is being considered, said Rosow. Rosow and other executives testifying to the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee acknowledged the power of advertising, but they also said the medium is not designed to tell everything about the product. ``A whole truth is not the same as the whole truth,'' said Richard Manoff of Manoff International Inc., in reference to nutritional claims by a popular powdered fruit drink that is high in vitamin C, though loaded with sugar and of little other nutritional value. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., who chaired the hearing, said the Food and Drug Administration, Federal Trade Commission and the Agriculture Department should coordinate their rules on health claims. The advertising executives agreed. ``The USDA has begun to allow health claims, but its criteria differ somewhat from those in FDA's proposal,'' Lieberman said. ``And the FTC has allowed health claims in advertising, but it has advocated a more flexible standard for evaluating such claims than that proposed by the FDA.'' Lieberman pointed out that at USDA reduced fat means 25 percent less fat, while at FDA it means 50 percent less. Legislation is ready for floor votes in both the House and Senate that would set federal standards on labeling, pre-empting state laws and regulating terms such as ``light,'' ``low'' or ``lean.''

DOC.HEAD: Long Court Battle in Cruzan Case Difficult for Family
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The family of Nancy Cruzan, who has lain in a coma-like condition for seven years, said Monday they will not waver in their desire to let her die with dignity. Joe and Joyce Cruzan released a statement at a news conference in Kansas City following a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that barred them from removing a life-sustaining feeding tube. The Cruzans did not say anything about the ruling, but restated their feelings about their 32-year-old daughter, who was injured in a 1983 auto accident and has neither spoken nor acknowledged their voices since. ``The decision to stop treatment and allow a loved one to die is one of the most difficult decisions a family can face,'' the Cruzans' statement said. ``However, because of our lifelong shared love with Nancy and our understanding of her values, we concluded that we had no choice but to try to set her free from this hopeless condition she is trapped in. Not to do so would be to disregard the very meaning of Nancy's `lived' life. ``Since our initial request in May 1987 to the state hospital to discontinue treatment and allow Nancy the dignity of death, our goal has never wavered, nor does it now.'' The Cruzans, who live in Carterville, did not attend the news conference. They have shunned the spotlight and have talked little to reporters recently. ``We really don't know what the decision means yet, so it would be pointless to comment,'' Joe Cruzan, a sheet metal worker, told a reporter when he arrived at his home for lunch Monday. He had no other comment before going into his two-story white frame house. Dick Moyer, a next-door neighbor in the Ozarks community of about 2,000, was more outspoken. ``I think the Supreme Court's decision would be different if each of those justices walked a mile in Joe and Joyce's shoes,'' he said. ``The Supreme Court goofed. The U.S. justice system is so far behind society's thinking it's pitiful,'' Moyer said. In its first ruling in a right-to-die case, the court in a 5-4 decision said that states may bar the removal of life-sustaining treatment from patients in irreversible coma-like conditions. The justices blocked the parents from ordering the removal of a surgically implanted feeding tube that provides Nancy Cruzan with food and water and keeps her alive at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon, about 30 miles from Carterville and 160 miles south of Kansas City in southwest Missouri. The cost of care _ about $100,000 a year _ is shared by Medicaid and the state. Doctors have said Ms. Cruzan could live for 30 more years in her current ``persistent vegetative'' condition. They have said she has no hope of recovery. For Joe Cruzan, there's no doubt about what his daughter would want. ``She would say, `Pull the plug. Stop it. I don't want to live like this. I have no dignity.' I think that probably would be the key word: no dignity,'' he said in an interview last year. Shortly after the accident, her parents authorized the use of a feeding tube in hopes her condition would improve. But hope never became reality. She has remained in bed, her body rigid, her hands and feet constricted and bent into claw shapes. She can breathe on her own, and at times her eyes are open and move randomly. Doctors say she is incapable of reacting or relating to her environment and can experience no thoughts or emotions.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says Russia Will Restrict its Payments to National Gov't
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian federation, told Soviet television on Monday that his republic would sharply restrict its payments to the national government as it pushes for greater independence. Two weeks ago, the Russian parliament declared itself ``sovereign'' _ though not an independent country _ and said it had the right to overturn Soviet law. The same day, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tried to stave off the challenge to his national government by promising a new Soviet Union of ``sovereign states.'' The suggestion was met with interest by leaders of the 15 republics. Yeltsin's interview indicated one way that Russia would try to realize that sovereignty. He said Russia, largest of the Soviet republics with half its people and three-quarters its land mass, will decide how much money to contribute to each category of the national budget. Yeltsin, a Gorbachev rival who favors radical reform, also said he would cut the size of the republic's bureaucracy in half.

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Jurors Begin Deliberations in Vento Case
DOC.TEXT: A jury began deliberations Monday after a prosecutor said a third defendant is guilty of murder for assembling a white mob that attacked and killed a black teen-ager in the Bensonhurst section. John Vento's defense lawyer countered in his closing argument that his client was neither a killer nor a racist. The attorney said the triggerman acted independently and unexpectedly when he shot Yusuf Hawkins through the heart. Vento, 21, is the third defendant to stand trial for the Aug. 23 attack in the Brooklyn neighborhood. Joseph Fama was convicted of murder and Keith Mondello was acquitted of homicide but convicted of several lesser crimes. Vento is charged with two counts of murder, one count of riot, three counts of unlawful imprisonment, four counts of menacing, four counts of discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon, a baseball bat. If convicted of murder, he faces up to 25 years to life in prison. ``John Vento did not act in concert, did not have the same intent, was not playing the same game as Joseph Fama,'' defense lawyer Gerald DiChiara said, urging jurors to apply common sense in finding Vento innocent. Assistant District Attorney Martin Hershey argued that Vento, when he appeared before a grand jury, acknowledged his role as an organizer of the mob. ``John Vento was one of the ringleaders, one of the generals of this operation,'' Hershey said. ``In this case, we know what was in John Vento's mind because he told us.'' Hawkins, 16, and three friends were accosted when they went to the predominantly white neighborhood to look at a used car for sale. Vento fled New York after the attack, but later agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in exchange for immunity from prosecution. He disappeared again around Christmas. In March, after surrendering to the FBI in Dayton, Ohio, he announced he would no longer cooperate. He was then indicted, charged with murder and other crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Endowment Guidelines Due by July 13
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts opposes federal support for obscenity as ``the antithesis of art'' but its judges' panels base their grant-making decisions primarily on esthetic and artistic quality, the government arts agency's chief lawyer said Monday. The lawyer, Julie Davis, said the arts endowment expects to issue guidelines by July 13 that will interpret controversial legislation that forbids endowment support for ``obscene'' art, to help artists receiving federal grants comply with the law. Ms. Davis said the guidelines generally would embrace the Supreme Court's longstanding obscenity test. That test, outlined in a 1973 decision, says material is obscene if it depicts sexual conduct in a patently offensive manner, appeals to prurient interest and lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. Ms. Davis testified at a daylong hearing of an independent, 12-member commission created by Congress last fall to review the endowment's grant-making procedures and consider whether a different standard should apply to government-subsidized art than to privately financed art. The commission, which will meet again in late July, hopes to report to Congress before the group legally expires on Sept. 30. The panel was appointed by President Bush and the House and Senate leadership and is headed by former White House counsel Leonard Garment and John Brademas, a former Democratic congressman from Indiana who is president of New York University. Congress established the commission at the same time it prohibited the arts endowment from spending federal funds on any artistic works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of sex acts, homoeroticism, sadomasochism or sexual exploitation of children, and which lack any ``serious literary, artistic political or scientific value.'' The ban was imposed as a result of criticism by conservative lawmakers, led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., of an endowment-supported exhibits of sexually explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe and works by artist Andres Serrano that included an image of a crucifix submerged in urine. The furor over obscene art has thrust the arts endowment, an independent federal agency with a $171 million budget, into the biggest crisis of its 25-year history. The House and Senate are bracing for major floor battles over legislation intended to extend the NEA's life and what restrictions might be imposed on artists receiving endowment grants. Ms. Davis said endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer believes that ``obscenity is the antithesis of art'' and has vowed to block NEA financial support from arts projects that might be deemed obscene. She said the NEA panels of outside experts who take preliminary action on grant applications base their decisions primarily on questions of ``artistic merit'' and not on the content of art works. Judgments of whether a grant project might violate the anti-obscenity law are left to Frohnmayer and his senior advisers, she said. About 100 recipients of arts endowment grants this year have signed the NEA's anti-obscenity pledge under protest. Endowment officials say six artists or arts institutions have rejected NEA grants rather than sign the pledge. The endowment has awarded 2,000 grants so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Begins on Use of DNA Evidence
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors and defense lawyers argued in federal court Monday over whether ``genetic fingerprints'' should be used in a weapons trial of three Hell's Angels accused in the slaying of a record store clerk. Lawyers for Steven Yee, Mark Verdi and John Ray Bonds told U.S. Magistrate James Carr that the FBI's DNA testing program is unreliable and should not be used as scientific evidence. Carr will rule on whether DNA tests should be admissible in the case. It is the first time the admissibility of DNA evidence has been argued in the federal court system, and Carr's ruling could establish an important precedent. The hearing, which began Monday, is expected to last more than a month. The three motorcycle gang members face murder and federal weapons charges in the death of David Hartlaub, a Sandusky record store clerk who was shot on Feb. 27, 1988. They are being tried on the weapons offenses before the murder charges. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rae, head of an organized crime task force, argued that the FBI's program is an accurate way of analyzing whether a person was involved in a crime. Rae said genetic scientists and biologists would testify that the FBI's program, and DNA testing in general, is reliable. Genetic fingerprinting involves examining live human tissue such as skin and hair, or body fluid such as blood or saliva to determine a person's genetic code. The pattern is found in DNA _ deoxyribonucleic acid _ which forms the basic material in the chromosome of the cell nucleus. Some scientists say the odds are as high as 30 billion to 1 that any two people outside of identical twins will have the same DNA pattern. Dwight Adams, who works in the FBI's DNA Analysis Unit, told Carr that DNA has been used successfully to determine whether a person has been involved in a crime. But he acknowledged that, unlike fingerprints, they cannot indicate with 100 percent certainty that samples taken from a crime scene came from a suspect. ``All I can do is conclude that an individual is a possible contributor to that stain. But I cannot say he is the sole contributor,'' said Adams, who has a doctorate in biology. Prosecutors said DNA tests conducted by the FBI show that Bonds' blood was found in Hartlaub's van and in Yee's car. They also said Bonds was wounded by shrapnel during the shooting. Peter Neufeld, one of the defendants' lawyers, said scientists are divided over whether absolute matches can be made in criminal cases in which the DNA is extracted from small amounts of tissue. Neufeld and his partner, Barry Scheck, also argued that genetic matching often includes subjective judgments on the part of a technician. Prosecutors said Hartlaub was shot as part of a Hell's Angels initiation for Bonds. They said Bonds mistakenly thought Hartlaub was a member of the Outlaws, a rival motorcycle gang.

DOC.HEAD: Five Decades of Major Earthquakes Worldwide
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The estimated 50,000 dead in the Iran earthquake make it the world's fourth deadliest quake in the past half-century. Here is a list of the major quakes of the past 50 years. The location is followed by the Richter scale magnitude and the number of dead.
Iran, June 21, 1990, 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale, 50,000 dead (estimated). Soviet Armenia, Dec. 7, 1988, 6.9, 25,000. Iran, Sept. 16, 1978, 7.7, 25,000. China, July 28, 1976, 8.2, 200,000 officially, 800,000 unofficially. Guatemala, Feb. 4, 1976, 7.5, 22,778. Peru, May 31, 1970, 7.7, 66,794. Iran, Aug. 31, 1968, 7.4, 12,000. Iran, Sept. 1, 1962, 7.1, 12,230. Morocco, Feb. 29, 1960, 5.8, 12,000. Soviet Turkmenia, Oct. 5, 1948, (no Richter reading available), 110,000.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Central Park Jogger, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0724,0601
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: `They Left Her to Die'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 17th, `Lederer said McCray ...' to UPDATE with defense arguments
DOC.TEXT: The teen-agers accused in the Central Park jogger case gang-raped and beat their victim and ``left her to die'' in a puddle of blood and mud, a prosecutor said Monday. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer described the horrors the investment banker endured during the April 19, 1989, attack by a pack of youths during a night of ``wilding.'' She predicted the three defendants who went on trial Monday would convict themselves with statements they made to police. ``They left her to die, naked and stripped,'' Lederer told the jurors in opening statements in trial-level state Supreme Court. ``Every bone supporting her left eye was broken. She was in shock. She had cuts and bruises covering her body,'' Lederer said, adding that the victim had lost three-quarters of her blood. When police found her, Lederer said, the victim was ``moving and groping and bleeding heavily.'' She was naked except for a bra pushed up near her neck. ``There was a blood-soaked T-shirt around her mouth, obstructing her breathing,'' the prosecutor told jurors. Her pulse had dropped to 40. ``She was cold to the touch,'' Lederer said. The woman, making her nightly jog through the northern section of the park when attacked, miraculously survived but suffered brain damage and ``has no recollection of what happened to her that night,'' Lederer said. Attorneys for the defendants, Antron McCray, 15, and Raymond Santana and Yusef Salaam, both 16, were to present their opening statements later Monday. They are being tried as adults but will be sentenced as juveniles. The defendants are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot. If convicted, they could be sentenced to 10 years in prison. Three other youths will also stand trial. Lederer said the defendants were part of a larger group of 30 to 35 youths who entered Central Park the night of the attack specifically to ``rob, beat and assault people.'' The three were also charged with assaulting two male joggers the same night. Police said the defendants called their action ``wilding.'' The prosecutor told jurors that each of the defendants told police they participated in the attack and said ``photographs show that the victims suffered the very injuries the defendants described having inflicted.'' The prosecutor said McCray told police: ``We charged her. We got her on the ground and everybody was hitting her ... Everybody was stomping and everything ... and we all took turns getting on top of her. I just kicked. There was a whole bunch of us just kicking.'' Lederer said McCray not only described his actions, he demonstrated it; showing police how he repeatedly kicked the young woman. McCray's lawyer, Michael Joseph, said his client initially denied involvement in the attack, and then the police ``added facts'' because he was not telling them what they wanted to hear. Defense lawyers also argued that there was no scientific evidence linking the defendants to the attack, and that without the statements the prosecution case is weak at best. The victim, now 29, spent several months in a New York hospital before being transferred to Connecticut for further rehabilitation. She recently returned to work at Salomon Brothers and was promoted to vice president. Her name has not been used by the media because of the nature of the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers: Cruzan Ruling Likely to Spur More Right-To-Die Debate
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's decision to keep Nancy Cruzan alive should force the Missouri legislature to return to the right-to-die issue, which stalled in this year's session, officials said Monday. ``The court said, `Here you are, states _ you may not want to deal with this but we're going to dump it in your laps _ now deal with it,'' said Senate President Pro Tem James Mathewson. He predicted the issue will come up before the 1991 Legislature, which convenes in January. In its 5-4 ruling, the high court said Missouri may require ``clear and convincing'' proof that a patient in a persistent vegetative state with no hope of recovery _ such as Ms. Cruzan _ wants to die before allowing the withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment. Ms. Cruzan, 32, has remained for seven years in a coma-like condition. Her parents are attempting to get permission to remove her feeding tube. Right-to-die legislation stalled in the Missouri Senate during the 1990 session. Proposals endorsed by Ms. Cruzan's father and state Attorney General William Webster would have allowed removal of food and water if three independent physicians agreed there was no chance of recovery after waiting for three years. Webster said the court's ruling leaves it up to individual states to set statutory guidelines on what defines clear and convincing proof the patient wants to die. ``This decision has impact far beyond the borders of the state of Missouri,'' Webster said. State courts have been waiting for a definitive federal ruling, but ``in this decision today they've essentially said it's up to the states,'' he said. ``We would like to change the law ... so that families with patients like Nancy could receive relief, and yet there would still be safeguards to protect against those that don't have the best interests of the patient at heart,'' Webster said. Missouri already is among the 41 states and the District of Columbia that have ``living will'' laws, which allow individuals to make their wishes about medical treatment known in advance of a crisis that may render them unable to speak. The high court ruled that Ms. Cruzan had not made her wishes known before she entered the vegetative state. Sen. Dennis Smith, who sponsored some of the right-to-die legislation, said the ruling ``gives impetus to those who think the state should address this very delicate and difficult issue. To do nothing is to put in jeopardy people who may be in this situation.'' An opponent of the legislation, Louis DeFeo of the Missouri Catholic Conference, said, ``It seems the court has taken steps to protect the individual, that third parties are not to be making these ultimate personal decisions.'' Webster said the Catholic Conference's opposition was important in defeating this year's legislation, but said he hoped a compromise could be reached in the next session.

DOC.HEAD: As Iranian Quake Aid Pours In, Helicopters Spray Disinfectant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with one-year-old girl found alive in debris of home, number of cities and towns leveled; CORRECTS title of Rushdie book to `Satanic Verses,' sted Verse. Pickup 12th graf pvs, `It's quite...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK1,TOK12,HF1
DOC.TEXT: Aid poured in Monday from dozens of countries, including Iran's bitterest enemies, to help an estimated half-million people left homeless in last week's earthquake. Thousands of people were believed still buried in rubble. Helicopters flew over the stricken area spraying disinfectant because of fears the unburied bodies would cause an outbreak of disease. U.S. health experts said this was unlikely. An Iranian Red Crescent team pulled a one-year-old girl alive from the debris of her home in the mountain village of Kelishom, 30 miles east of here, according to French and Iranian rescue teams operating in the area. The team had been told the infant was dead, but found her on her bed after digging into the bedroom of her house, the Iranian rescuers said. The earthquake Thursday leveled 342 cities, towns and villages across northern Iran and killed 50,000 people, by some estimates. About 200,000 were injured, and countless others were believed lying beneath tons of debris. Tehran University's Geophysics Center reported that 22 aftershocks, some as strong as 5.5 on the Richter Scale, had occurred in the region the last 24 hours. On Sunday, the center reported 360 tremors since Thursday. The aftershocks caused landslides that blocked roads, seriously hampering rescue and relief operations in Gilan and Zanjan provinces. The two provinces were the hardest hit in the earthquake, which registered 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale. Official reports have estimated a half-million people were left homeless. At least 62 aircraft carrying foreign aid from dozens of countries landed at the capital's Mehrabad airport Monday, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Sixty-eight planeloads arrived Sunday, Tehran radio said. One cargo jet from the United States brought in 84,000 pounds of medical, food and other supplies from AmeriCares, a private relief organization. It was the first private U.S. relief effort after 11 years of troubled relations between Washington and Tehran. At the United Nations, Iran's envoy said Monday that Tehran would not accept donations from Israel or South Africa. But it is accepting aid from the United States, which it once condemned as the ``Great Satan.'' ``The Iranian people do not have any problem with the American people,'' said the envoy, Kamal Kharrazi. ``This tragedy may create a better atmosphere for relations between Iranian and American peoples.'' Aid reportedly was also coming from the unlikeliest of sources: author Salman Rushdie, who is living under an Iranian death threat for alleged blasphemy against Islam in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie is donating $8,650 to a relief fund, the British newspaper The Independent reported. ``It's quite clear that at the moment we should be thinking only of the humanitarian issue, which transcends all other discussions,'' Rushdie was quoted as saying by Independent editor Andreas Whittam Smith. Saudi Arabia, which cut ties with Iran in April 1988, said it would send 40 planeloads of supplies. Even Iraq, Iran's foe during eight years of war, offered help. A landslide Monday blocked a 35-mile stretch of road linking the ravaged town of Rudbar with the Caspian Sea coast, a crucial relief supply route. Relief convoys were snarled in traffic jams on other roads that were covered by boulders. But IRNA reported that ``non-stop rescue operations'' continued. Recovery workers aided by police sniffer dogs pulled bodies from the rubble, it said. The aftershocks jolted the Caspian Sea city of Rasht, Gilan's provincial capital and one of the worst hit cities. IRNA said thousands of panic-stricken inhabitants, fearing more buildings would crumble, spent the night outdoors. Tehran radio, monitored in Cyprus, said air force helicopters hovered over inaccessible villages and towns, spraying disinfectant to avert the spread of diseases from decomposing bodies. However, officials at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said the fears were unfounded. They said diseases such as typhoid and cholera do not occur after disasters, even in the absence of vaccinations. IRNA, also monitored in Cyprus, said the stench of death hung over the region. It quoted an unidentified air force commander as saying: ``The tragedy is so grave it cannot be described. I've never seen such a catastrophe before.'' He said that during the 1980-88 war against Iraq, ``we became accustomed to transporting many dead and wounded. But this is different. ``The villages are scattered and barely accessible because helicopters cannot land in the mountain villages. But our pilots are determined to do the impossible.'' He said one of his pilots, Suleiman Keshavarz, lost his mother, sister, brother and nephew. They were killed in the village of Manjil, south of Rasht. As soon as the pilot buried them, he returned to duty to fly relief missions, the commander said. IRNA also reported that a leading religious authority, the Grand Ayatollah Mohammad Reza Golpayegani, ruled that victims ``can be buried in mass graves in circumstances where religious rites are impossible to observe.'' Normally, the body of a Moslem is washed, shrouded and prayed for in a congregation before it is buried in an individual grave. Mass graves are not allowed under Islamic law. IRNA said an exact estimate of the casualties was still ``impossible,'' and that a special relief committee so far has counted 36,907 dead and 35,693 injured. The leading English-language newspaper Tehran Times has reported 50,000 people dead and 200,000 injured.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon, Congress Reach Compromise Over Blackbird Spy Plane
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon and Congress have reached a compromise over a requirement that the department maintain some of the SR-71 Blackbird spy planes for use in a national crisis, according to a letter released Monday. The Air Force and Congress agreed last year to terminate the top secret program, opting instead for satellites that could provide the same intelligence information for less money. But in report language accompanying a $4 billion spending bill President Bush signed last month, lawmakers called on the Pentagon to maintain the aircraft _ by tail numbers _ so that flight operations could begin within 90 days of an emergency. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney criticized the provision, which though non-binding would do serious damage to the relationship between Congress and the Pentagon if the department ignored it. The Air Force and congressional committees negotiated a compromise that Cheney detailed in a June 21 letter to Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee. ``We will place three SR-71A aircraft and six associated reconnaissance sensors and electronic countermeasure suites into long-term storage as a hedge against a protracted conflict some time in the future,'' Cheney said in the letter. ``The time it will take and the cost of restoring these stored aircraft and sensors to a condition that would support safe operations will depend on the length of the storage period.'' The defense secretary also said the Pentagon will make trainer aircraft, two SR-71A aircraft, flight simulator and all associated SR-71 spares and support equipment available for loan or transfer to NASA. The space agency, according to a memorandum from Cheney to Air Force Secretary Donald Rice, would assume the cost for operating and maintaining the aircraft and parts. No estimate was included in the letter. Cheney said reconnaissance operations involving the black, dagger-shaped planes could not resume ``in a safe manner'' on 90-day notice. He also noted that maintenance crews, air crews and other personnel with skills to operate and care for the Blackbird are gone. ``We no longer have an SR-71 flight capability,'' Cheney said. During more than two decades of service, the Blackbird regularly flew missions over heavily defended North Vietnam and provided intelligence in many other regions, including the Middle East, China and the Persian Gulf. The plane can outrun the fastest fighters and has never been shot down. In March, in a flight marking its retirement, a Blackbird set a record for a coast-to-coast flight, flying from Los Angeles to Washington, D.C., in 68 minutes, 17 seconds.

DOC.HEAD: Izvestia Scolds Party Chief for Criticizing Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: The Izvestia newspaper on Monday scolded Byelorussia's conservative Communist Party chief for attacking Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a local party congress last week. In a speech to the Byelorussian Communist Party, Yefrem Sokolov said: ``From our point of view, much of the blame for our ship's loss of its anchors and its crew's sickness lies with those who command the ship and lay out its course,'' Izvestia said. Sokolov did not mention the Soviet president and national Communist Party chief by name, Izvestia said. Izvestia also quoted the reply printed in the Byelorussian newspaper, Banner of Youth. ``One is bursting to ask the rebellious boatswains of the ship: Didn't they feel sick when singing a chorus of hallelujahs to the former captains, senile old men who hung stars on their chests for grounding the ship?'' Hard-line Communists have called for Gorbachev's replacement as head of the national Communist Party at its congress, set to begin July 2. Politburo member Yegor Ligachev has been reported as planning to run against Gorbachev, and many of the congress' delegates are conservatives opposed to Gorbachev's reforms. Also Monday, the Estonian News Service said in an unconfirmed report that the national party congress may be postponed _ effectively putting off the expected challenge to Gorbachev. Estonian television echoed the report, but no other Soviet media reported possibilities of delay. Party officials were still preparing for the congress Monday, and a Soviet Foreign Ministry official said he knew nothing of any such report. The Estonian News Service, which recently replaced the local affiliate of the official Soviet news agency Tass, said, ``Vadim Medvedev, the main ideologist of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, informed the Estonian Central Committee that the 28th party congress might be postponed until September.'' ``The reason for it was said to be `the harvest, that had started in the southern region of the Soviet Union,''' the news service said. Only a handful of farmers are expected at the congress, and the harvest, hardly an unexpected event, is still weeks away in most of the country. The party congress, originally scheduled for 1991, was moved up to autumn of this year, and finally to July, as the need for radical reform grew.

DOC.HEAD: First Amendment Questions Raised by Magazine Probe
DOC.TEXT: These are rough days at High Times magazine, where editors and lawyers are bracing for a possible prosecution that will raise First Amendment issues and bring new controversy to the publication. Editor Steve Hager said Monday that he and two other employees of the magazine with a 250,000 monthly distribution have been subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury in New Orleans on June 29. USA Today reported Monday that federal prosecutors in New Orleans were investigating whether the magazine should be indicted as a drug conspiracy. High Times plans to challenge the subpoena, and Hager said he does not plan to go or to provide the business records and other information that was requested. ``If I do go down, it will be to take the Fifth Amendment. The Bill of Rights is being systematically dismantled in the name of the war on drugs,'' he said. ``I'm not exactly clear what it is they're trying to do. It's basically just a big fishing expedition to try to put us out of business,'' Hager added. John Volz, the U.S. attorney in New Orleans, was in court and could not be immediately reached for comment Monday. Hager said the magazine is outspoken in its support of a movement to legalize marijuana, but advises people to stay away from hard drugs and other damaging substances, including tobacco, heroin and alcohol. ``These are poisonous substances. You could smoke 500 pounds of marijuana and you wouldn't die,'' he said. USA Today said the Drug Enforcement Administration in October searched businesses that advertised garden equipment in High Times and arrested about 400 people for marijuana possession and other offenses. High Times subsequently lost two-thirds of its advertising, said Hager. ``This magazine would be bigger than Playboy if it weren't for government intervention,'' Hager said. The magazine was founded in 1974. ``Basically, the magazine's been through a 16-year period of pretty constant harassment from the government. This is the first time they've started a criminal investigation aimed at trying to create problems for us,'' he said. ``This prosecutor in New Orleans is just trying to get a lot of publicity for himself. He's got a terrible case,'' Hager said. ``We're not going to have any problem surviving. There's at least 20 to 30 million people who use marijuana in our society.''

DOC.HEAD: Slovenia to Start Work on New Constitution Giving it Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: The republic of Slovenia plans to begin work on a constitution that will give it full sovereignty within a new Yugoslav confederation, the state Tanjug news agency reported Monday. Slovenia, whose 2 million inhabitants account for a fraction of Yugoslavia's total population of 23 million, is the most politically liberal and prosperous of the country's six member republics. Slovenia ``should be set up as a sovereign state, with all attributes of factual authority and with full international-legal rights,'' Tanjug said, quoting from a declaration of the Slovenian presidency, the top local ruling body. The Slovenian move was endorsed by Slovenia's president, Milan Kucan, who told a Monday session of the presidency that the new constitution will be the ``constitution of the sovereign state of Slovenia, and not of one of the federal (republics),'' Tanjug said. The proposal is to be discussed by Slovenia's parliament in mid-July, Kucan said. Its approval is viewed as almost certain. Slovenia has been frequently accused by politicians and the media in Yugoslavia's more conservative southern republics, and particularly in the country's largest republic of Serbia, of harboring separatist tendencies and of protecting its own interests at the expense of federal goals. Slovenian authorities claim Serbia is trying to politically and economically dominate the Yugoslav federation by introducing greater federal control and by limiting the autonomy of the republics. More than 70 percent of the residents of the northern republic believe their region might be better off if it were outside the Yugoslav federation, results of a public opinion poll said last March. Only 15 percent of the Slovenes surveyed expressed their wish for Slovenia to remain a republic within Yugoslavia in the present form. Both Slovenia and Croatia, the two Yugoslav republics that held free elections this year, have proclaimed a readiness to turn the Yugoslav federation of six republics and two provinces into a looser confederation of states cooperating voluntarily. Also Monday, Serbia's president Slobodan Milosevic, in a speech to the Serbian parliament, said the new constitution Serbia is preparing is designed to ``offset the transformation of federal Yugoslavia into a confederation.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo: Let's Talk up Florio for President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 5th, ``They ought ...'' to UPDATE with Florio comment
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo said Monday he's going to encourage people to talk about freshman New Jersey Gov. James Florio as a potential presidential candidate. Cuomo, who is considered a potential contender for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination, said he's impressed with the aggressive approach fellow Democrat Florio has taken in dealing with New Jersey's economic problems and on school reform. Among other things, Florio has called for major increases in New Jersey taxes. ``I think Jim Florio has been brilliant. I think he's been bold. He is an instant national hero,'' Cuomo said during the taping of an interview to be broadcast by the state's cable television systems next month. ``They ought to be talking about him for president,'' Cuomo added. ``I suspect they will very shortly. I will encourage that discussion.'' Florio said he was flattered. But he declined to talk about political aspirations, saying he had ``more than enough to keep me busy in New Jersey.'' Cuomo is seeking re-election to a third term as governor. Republicans are attacking him for approving a $1.8 billion tax increase package, the largest in state history.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Leaders Seek to Reassure World About Country's Stability
DOC.TEXT: Canadian leaders sought to reassure foreign governments and investors that the failure of a constitutional accord did not threaten the country with instability, and financial markets reacted calmly Monday. The Canadian dollar held steady against the U.S. dollar on North American markets, prompting relief among Canadian officials who feared the death of the so-called Meech Lake accord might trigger a run on its currency. ``It's a calm response, a steady response, a realistic response,'' said Finance Minister Michael Wilson. ``They feel it's not a time for snap decisions.'' External Affairs Minister Joe Clark and Derek Burney, Canada's ambassador to the United States, were both scheduled to appear on U.S. television programs Monday in an effort to dispel fears that Canada was on the verge of breaking up. The constitutional accord, which would have recognized French-speaking Quebec as a ``distinct society,'' failed to meet a midnight Saturday deadline for obtaining the required ratification by all 10 provincial legislatures. It was effectively torpedoed by Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells and Elijah Harper, a Cree Indian lawmaker in Manitoba, who blocked the legislatures in their provinces from considering the accord before the deadline expired. On Sunday, Wilson appealed to international money markets not to react with alarm to Meech Lake's failure. He issued a statement reminding investors that Canada had enjoyed an ``unparalleled investment boom'' in the past few years. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa, interviewed in Monday's Wall Street Journal, said there were no dangers to his province's economy. Bourassa said he would ``in no way take any decision (adversely) affecting the economic security of Quebecers.'' The Canadian dollar closed Monday at 84.85 U.S. cents in Toronto, unchanged from Friday's close. The Toronto stock market was down moderately in light trading at the close as the TSE composite index dropped 16.56 to 3474.16. Analysts said Bourassa's remarks over the weekend that Quebec would not take any precipitate action had helped calm the situation. There have been fears that Meech Lake's demise would lead to an intensified separatist drive in Quebec. Bourassa declared he would no longer negotiate Quebec's status with the other provincial premiers or return to the constitutional bargaining table. But he said Quebec officials would make no decisions on the province's future course until the fall. But some Quebecers were not prepared to bide their time. In Montreal, several thousand people celebrating the province's national holiday, St. John the Baptist Day, marched through downtown streets Sunday, shouting separatist slogans. About 500 nationalist supporters broke into Olympic Stadium, disrupting the Montreal-Pittsburgh baseball game for about 10 minutes. ``Our country is Quebec and our problem is Canada,'' one demonstrator, Robert Paradis, 50, shouted as security staff led him away from the ballpark. In English Canada, some newspapers greeted the demise of Meech Lake with relief, while others appealed for a cooling-off period and national unity. The Toronto Sun wrote: ``Whatever the case, it was past time for Meech to die. It was an unacceptable deal. It divided the country.'' Ontario's London Free Press commented: ``In the aftermath of the Meech Lake disaster, politicians who care about the survival of Canada should stop blaming one another for the dangerous divisions brought on by this debacle and concentrate instead on healing the nation's wounds.'' Prime Minister Brian Mulroney appeared to be the biggest loser from Meech Lake's demise. Mulroney, whose approval rating stood at about 16 percent in the polls before the weekend, had hoped the accord would reverse his political misfortunes. ``Brian Mulroney wanted to be in the history books as the man who unified Canada,'' wrote the Ottawa Citizen. ``His desperation to achieve that distinction led him to dubious tactics.'' The Meech Lake accord, named after the resort outside Ottawa where it was drawn up three years ago, was the culmination of a long effort to win Quebec's signature on the 1982 Canadian constitution. Its purpose was to draw the ever-wary Quebecers into the Canadian family, unifying a country frequently beset by problems of regionalism. The accord recognized Quebec's status as a distinct society within Canada, but its opponents feared it would give the French-speaking province special privileges. The Telegraphy-Journal in Saint John, New Brunswick, noted wryly that the Meech Lake furor had changed Canada's image as a boring nation. ``The image of Canadian stability has been shattered,'' the newspaper wrote. ``We were seen as a bland, even unexciting country which would never do anything to rock the boat. Now we are perceived in the U.S. media as a nation on the verge of breakup.''

DOC.HEAD: David Duke's Affirmative Action Bill Stymied by Senate Committee
DOC.TEXT: A former Ku Klux Klan member's effort to end all programs that give minorities an advantage in hiring was blocked Monday by a state Senate committee. The Senate Finance Committee voted 6-2 to sit on Rep. David Duke's bill, thus apparently killing it for the session, which ends July 9. The House overwhelmingly approved the bill earlier this month. ``I'll try to get the Senate to force the committee to report the bill to the floor,'' Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, said later. Duke, a Republican from Metairie and a candidate for the U.S. Senate, said his bill ``merely prohibits discrimination in favor or against anyone on the basis of race.'' ``Members of the Black Caucus in the House referred to my bill as racist. That word is an epithet people use to silence opposition. I don't believe we should run for cover when that word is used. ``If discrimination is wrong when exercised against a minority, it's wrong when exercised against a white majority.'' Democratic Sen. J.E. Jumonville said the bill does nothing because no state law can supercede federal laws that allow programs that compensate for past discrimination. ``I know you are a candidate for the U.S. Senate and this makes good political hay,'' said Jumonville. ``But are we really doing anything? I think it's window dressing.'' Duke told reporters after the hearing that opponents ``pulled a dirty political trick by sending my bill to the Finance Committee. There are no Republicans on this committee.'' Of the 39 senators, five are Republicans. Duke is running for the Senate as a maverick member of the party. The GOP chose state Sen. Ben Bagert of New Orleans as its nominee to oppose incumbent U.S. Sen. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat who has held the post since 1972.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Calls Iran's Relief Effort Efficient, Impressive
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At the headquarters of the Red Crescent Society, Iran's equivalent of the Red Cross, the sidewalk and lobby are stacked high with donated blankets, clothes, food, stoves and medicine. Dozens of volunteers sort through the piles, boxing them for shipment to the northwest, where a half-million people have been made homeless as a result of Thursday's killer earthquake. ``Many people come here to donate goods for the earthquake victims, but then stay for the day to help out,'' Javad Afshar, director of Public Cooperation for the Red Crescent, said Monday. Iran's internal relief effort following the quake has been speedy and thorough, a team from the Geneva-based United Nations Disaster Relief Organization said. The earthquake leveled cities and towns across northern Iran and killed 50,000 people, according to official Iranian estimates. About 200,000 were injured, and countless others were believed beneath tons of debris. The response ``was large-scale, rapid and efficient,'' the mission said in a report Monday. ``The numbers of relief personnel, ambulances and heavy equipment appeared to be more than adequate for the task.'' It said it was ``most impressed by the relief response.'' Iranian relief officials credited the speed of the relief effort to equipment and experience left over from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, and to strong suppport from the Iranian people. At the Red Crescent, Afshar's voice was hoarse Monday after what he said were 72 hours of directing volunteers and working three telephones and a walkie-talkie without any sleep. ``But I'm not tired,'' he said. ``There's an Iranian proverb that says that all people come from one body. If one part is in pain, then the other parts also feel it.'' At the Baghi Allah-Ala'zam military hospital, 144 of the 400 beds were occupied by earthquake victims, most of them evacuated by army helicopter. ``During the Iran-Iraq war we regularly received injured patients by helicopter from the front,'' said Jamshid Narenjkar, director of the hospital, one of about 15 military medical centers in the Tehran area. ``Because of the war, doctors and nurses were ready to help,'' he said. Narenjkar said about 4,000 victims were hospitalized in Tehran and many others elsewhere. Meanwhile, international humanitarian aid, from both allies and past enemies, continued to pour into Tehran's Mehrabad airport, where more than a dozen aircraft from West Germany, Algeria, Cuba, Bangladesh and Pakistan waited to be unloaded. The Iranian air force was airlifting the aid to the earthquake zone, where road traffic was badly clogged by heavy construction machinery and buses carrying thousands of relief workers. Ground crews worked in the heat of the tarmac of the airport's military section as they transfered hundreds of tons of cargo to waiting C-130 Hercules transport planes to fly the supplies to the disaster zone. Air force officers said their pilots were averaging six to eight flights a day to the mountainous region about 170 miles northwest of the capital. ``Once we reach the area, the supplies are transferred to the helicopters which fly them out to villages so remote they are almost inaccessible by any other means,'' said Lt. Col. Fridoon Zadeh, an air force pilot. John Tomblin, a U.N. Disaster Relief Organization director, said more than two dozen nations have provided quake aid to Iran. The Islamic Republic News Agency said 26 countries have contributed to the relief operations. More than 40 German military personnel and medical volunteers waited with their gear Monday for their flight to Rudbar, one of the hardest hit towns on the border between the devastated Zanjan and Gilan provinces. The German volunteers were to set up a field hospital in the town. On Sunday, a U.S. cargo plane carrying 84,000 pounds of supplies from AmeriCares, a private U.S. relief organization, unloaded at Mehrabad airport, then flew back. It was the first American aid to Iran since the rift that followed the rise of Islamic fundamentalists to power 11 years ago. Iranian officials Monday stressed that they were not rejecting outside help, but did not need large amounts of foreign relief personnel. ``We haven't asked other countries for help because our people and our government were ready,'' the Red Crescent's Afshar said. ``But if other countries and Red Cross societies offer to help, we will accept it with thanks.''

DOC.NOTE: EDs: With AM-Fang Bjt and AM-US-Fang
DOC.TEXT:
Here is the full text of the statement written by Chinese dissidents Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian immediately before the Chinese government permitted them to leave their homeland. The text was distributed by the State Department.
1. I am opposed to the four cardinal principles which are contained in the preamble to the Chinese constitution, because their purpose is to uphold a political system of ``class struggle.'' I take note that the above political view violates the preamble of the constitution. 2. In order to visit relatives and friends abroad and to obtain necessary medical treatment, I apply to leave the country and travel abroad. I hope that the Chinese government will give this humanitarian consideration. 3. The purpose in going aborad is focused on scholarly exchange and research. We will appreciate and welcome all activities which accord with the progressive interests of Chinese society, and moreover refuse to participate in all contrary activities whose motive lies in opposing China.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic City Anxiously Watching Trump Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's casino workers are offering him pieces of their paychecks. His betting patrons wish him well. But city officials are nervously watching what's doing with the man who means 14,500 jobs. As a midnight Tuesday deadline neared for Trump to make an overdue $43 million bond payment on his Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay, bankers apparently were scrambling to win approval from two foreign banks balking at a rescue package for the developer. City and industry officials were trying to gauge the effect of Trump's troubles on the already clouded image of this stagnating casino town. The consensus Monday seemed to be that Trump would slide to safety without bankruptcy, but perhaps at the cost of selling one of his three casinos. Trump officials have said none of the properties is for sale. ``The Trump Organization and Donald Trump himself are shrewd enough to work themselves out of it,'' said Michael DeRogatis, head of the Greater Atlantic City Chamber of Commerce. ``You would have to say that if somebody needs money and has these properties, it makes sense to sell one of them.'' Roy Silbert, president of Local 54 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Union, agreed and said Trump's workers are loyal. The union represents about 4,500 of Trump's roughly 14,500 employees, and 16,000 of the industry's 50,000. Laura McNichol, a manager in the game room for teen-agers at Trump Castle, said she'd donate a day's pay if it would ease her boss' burden. She declined to say how much she earns. ``I think the man is a business genius,'' said Ms. McNichol, who took the job four months ago. ``Does he really need help? I don't know. But I'd do it if he does.'' She said about six other workers discussed the prospect of helping Trump. Trump Castle spokesman Bob Arrow said he hadn't heard of such a movement. ``Mr. Trump is going to solve his problems,'' Arrow said. Trump also is flush with fans outside his work force. ``I think that anybody who has worked at something deserves to keep it,'' said Madeline Spinello of Smithtown, N.Y. She and her husband lost $500 in their latest foray into Trump Castle, where players scoffed at the superstition that says it's bad luck to gamble at a troubled casino. ``I don't know why people are jealous,'' said Thomas Weber of Allentown, Pa. ``They had the same opportunities he had.'' Barry Durman, executive director of the Atlantic City Rescue Mission, said Trump has been a good corporate neighbor. Trump Plaza donated $10,000 at Christmas when the 250-bed mission faced financial troubles of its own. And Trump Castle donates 250-300 meals a day. Trump's massive Taj Mahal Casino Resort, which opened April 2, is expected to bring Atlantic City $51.6 million in spending by convention-goers in its first year, said Blair Learn of the Convention & Visitors Bureau. His name alone brings this city a lot of attention, Learn said. But Mayor-elect Jim Whelan said he doesn't know what Atlantic City could do in return if Trump needs help. ``I'm not sure there's anything we can do,'' Whelan said. ``It's not like we can lend him money. ... Ultimately, Donald is going to have to sell some properties.'' Casino Association President Thomas Carver said Trump's woes illustrate the high cost of doing business here _ whatever your name _ and of chasing a market that won't grow unless the state loosens industry regulations. ``If these three casinos were operated by other people, it wouldn't make any difference in the (flat) growth of the industry,'' Carver said.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Marks War Anniversary, Schoolchildren Vow Revenge
LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: North Korean schoolchildren marked the 40th anniversary of the start of the Korean War on Monday by vowing to avenge ``murders'' by U.S. troops, North Korea's official media reported. In the capital of Pyongyang, 200,000 people gathered to express their ``surging indignation and hatred'' at ``the U.S. imperialists and their stooges who inflicted immeasurable disasters and sufferings upon our people during the past Korean War and are now running amok to provoke a nuclear war in Korea,'' the Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, reported. North Korea invaded South Korea on June 25, 1950. United Nations forces led by the United States fought to defend South Korea. Chinese troops joined North Korean forces in the war, which ended three years later in an armistice. More than 54,000 American troops died during the war. North Korean accounts say the United States ignited the war. The North Korean agency said schoolchildren rallied in Sinchon County, the site of a ``brutal massacre comitted by U.S. aggressors.'' The agency claimed Americans killed more than 35,000 people, a quarter of the county's population, during the war. The agency quoted schoolchildren as saying at the rally: ``The U.S. imperialist aggressors are the most heinous human butchers and an inveterate enemy of our people.'' It said they vowed to avenge ``the imperialist murders a thousand fold.'' The report did not say how many schoolchildren attended the rally. Rodong Sinmun, official newspaper of North Korea's ruling Workers Party, said that although 40 years had past since the war began, ``it is the invariable ambition of the U.S. imperialists to establish domination over our republic and the rest of Asia.'' ``The atrocities committed by the U.S. imperialists ... have hardened our people's will to fight against imperialism down through the generations,'' it said in an editorial. The Rodong Sinmun editorial also called for the United States to withdraw the 43,000 troops based in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. The North Korean agency quoted Choe Mun Son, chief secretary of the ruling party's Pyongyang municipal committee, as declaring at the rally: ``There can be no ground for the United States to stay in South Korea with a hue and cry over the fictitious `threat from the North' still now when we call for a drastic cutback of armed forces and when the withdrawal of foreign troops has become a worldwide trend.''

DOC.HEAD: Flags Lowered to Mark Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: President Bush marked the 40th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean war Monday by ordering that flags be lowered to half staff on federal buildings. In a proclamation, Bush noted that 54,246 U.S. soldiers were killed and 103,000 wounded. ``Looking back at the Korean conflict, we recognize that our defense of freedom in this early struggle of the Cold War helped lay the foundation for the march of democracy we see today around the world,'' Bush said. On June 25, 1950, North Korean troops invaded South Korea, and the United States, aided by other nations under the auspices of the United Nations, came to the aid of the South Korean government. An armistice was signed in July 1953.
