DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Murder of Two Officers
DOC.TEXT: An inmate was convicted Monday of murdering two detectives by shooting them as they drove him to jail. ``This was more than murder _ it was an execution,'' District Attorney John J. Santucci said after the verdict. He said he would seek the maximum term, 63 years to life in prison for Jay ``Stoney'' Harrison. The state jury deliberated for less than an hour to reach its verdict. Detectives Richard Guerzon, 46, and Keith Williams, 34, were slain Nov. 13 while transporting Harrison from Queens Borough Hall after he met with lawyers on another murder charge, for which he has yet to be tried. Harrison, 25, had been handcuffed by one hand to a pipe on a table in the squad room. While briefly unguarded, he apparently managed to reach into a police locker that had a broken lock and remove a gun. In the back seat of the officers' car, with his hands handcuffed in front of him, he drew the gun and shot the detectives as they drove back to Rikers Island jail, prosecutors said. Authorities later said the prisoner should not have been unguarded in the squad room and should have had his hands cuffed behind his back in the car. Harrison originally was arrested on charges of killing his ex-girlfriend in 1988 and conspiring to kill an accomplice to the murder. Harrison had been brought to Borough Hall to discuss a plea bargain on those charges. In addition to murder, he was convicted Monday of escape, grand larceny and weapons possession. He is to be sentenced by July 25.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Aid No Reason to Expect Improved Relations, White House Says
With AM-Iran-Quake a0747 and AM-Iran-Quake Aid a0686
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has provided $291,000 in emergency relief supplies and transportation to aid earthquake victims in Iran but has no reason to expect the donation in itself will improve frayed U.S.-Iranian relations, the White House said Monday. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the aid includes blankets, tents, water jugs and search and rescue equipment. The supplies were airlifted from Pisa, Italy where they had been stored for emergencies to Iran by a Swiss aircraft under charter to the American Red Cross. They were given to the Iranian Red Crescent Society for distribution. Fitzwater said the United States would try to be responsive if other Iranian relif needs are identified. ``This in our judgment is a humanitarian gesture, a response to the tragedy of the earthquake,'' Fitzwater said. ``But we don't anticpate that it has any larger political consequences,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Zaire Bishops Denounce Campus Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Zaire's Roman Catholic bishops have condemned last month's massacre of students at a university in southern Zaire, and asked their government to investigate the incident, a Belgian newspaper reported Monday. Dozens of students reportedly died in the May 12 clash with security forces at the University of Lubumbashi. The incident has led to another breakdown in relations between Belgium and its former Central African colony over alleged human rights abuses. The daily Het Volk said Zaire's bishops issued a declaration earlier this month that demanded ``total clarification of the tragic events of Lubumbashi.'' They also accused Zaire's president, Mobutu Sese Seko, of paying lip service to the process of democratization he announced April 24. Het Volk said it had obtained a copy of the six-page statement in which the bishops condemned ``the militarization of university campuses.'' ``We forcefully condemn the general use of security forces,'' according to the bishops' statement, which was published by Het Volk. The bishops added that security forces were being used for ``the suppression of and interference with the lives of peaceful citizens. ``In particular, we condemn strongly and without reservation the massacres which in all likelihood were carried out against students on the campus of (the University of) Lubumbashi,'' the bishops said. Belgian media have reported that dozens of students died in clashes on the campus with a special unit of Mobutu's personal guard. The dispute broke out over charges that some university students were spies for Mobutu. On May 25, Belgium froze its relations with Zaire and called for an independent inquiry into the event. Zairean officials have rejected this. Belgium has stuck to its call for an impartial probe that led Mobutu last Friday to reduce diplomatic and other ties with Belgium. He suspended Belgian-Zairean development accords, expelled some 700 Belgian development workers, closed down three of the four Belgian consulates, and reduced the number of weekly flights between Brussels and Kinshasa by Sabena, the Belgian national airline. On Sunday, Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank ``have no intention of granting more aid to Zaire if it breaks relations with Belgium.'' He said Belgium wanted to maintain good relations with Zaire and again rejected the notion that the Belgian government's reaction represented interference in Zaire's internal affairs. ``In human rights matters, there is no foreign interference,'' Eyskens said on Belgian television. The new Belgian-Zairean dispute erupted less than three months after the two countries reconciled a previous breakdown in relations. It comes one week before observances marking the 30th anniversary of Zaire's independence. Belgium has not been invited to attend the ceremonies. Mobuto has ruled Zaire, a nation of 25 million, since 1965 when he took power in a coup.

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Statement Wins U.S. Praise
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 12th graf: ``Maguid is,'' with one graf bgng: ``Maguid will,'' to note meeting scheduled for Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: The State Department resumed its pursuit of Mideast peace talks Monday and praised Israeli Housing Minister Ariel Sharon for declaring that Soviet immigrants would not be sent to the West Bank and Gaza. Spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Sharon's statement was a ``step in the right direction'' even though it was not clear whether Sharon was barring the refugees from the territories or simply saying they would not be settled there at Israeli government expense. ``We have seen various reports and we don't yet have a detailed analysis,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. Meanwhile, Osama al-Baz, the principal foreign policy adviser to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, called at the State Department without advance notice. He met with Dennis Ross, director of the department's policy planning staff, and John H. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for the Near East. Ross and Kelly are the principal advisers on the Middle East to Secretary of State James A. Baker III. A U.S. official, declining to be identified, said Middle East peace efforts and Egypt's economic plight were discussed. Egypt is the principal U.S. channel to the Arab world in trying to open negotiations between Israel and Palestinians. The process halted in March when the Israeli government collapsed over a plan by Baker that would have required negotiating with Palestinians deported from the West Bank. The formation of a new government in Jerusalem _ and its declared interest in a settlement _ inspired the Bush administration to begin again. On Saturday, President Bush spoke on the telephone with Mubarak. The Egyptian leader then sent al-Baz and Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel Meguid to Washington. Meguid will meet with Bush on Tuesday. Among the U.S. objectives is halting Jewish settlement of the West Bank and Gaza, which the Arabs lost in the 1967 Mideast War and hope to recover, as well as in East Jerusalem, which is part of Israel's capital. Sharon, in an important gesture, said Sunday: ``We do not divert and we do not send any Russian immigrants or any Jew who comes from Russia to Samaria, to Judea, to Gaza because we understand the seriousness of the situation.'' He added: ``Our efforts in resettling immigrants are directed to this side of the Green Line.'' Sharon is one of Israel's strongest advocates of Jewish settlement on the land he referred to by their Biblical names. But the United States, the Soviet Union and the Arabs are opposed even though very few Russian Jews have gone to the territories. ``Mr. Sharon's statement is a hopeful development as it responds to international concerns, including our own,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. However, the Bush administration isn't ready to unfreeze a $400 million loan guarantee to help Israel build badly needed homes for the historic tide of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union. Ms. Tutwiler said the administration was still seeking assurances from Jerusalem, but declined to say what they were or whether they had to be in writing. Baker last week made a gesture of his own to Israel while holding talks in Europe on Germany's future. He said Palestinians would talk to Israel only with the acquiescence of the Palestine Liberation Organization. But Baker said the Bush administration was not trying to steer Israel into talks with the PLO itself. Israel regards the PLO as a terrorist organization. The PLO is committed in its covenant to dismantling the Jewish state. Last Wednesday, the Bush administration broke off talks with the PLO over an attempted raid against Israel three weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of Former Prague Communist Party Boss Opens
LaserPhoto PRA1
DOC.TEXT: The former Prague Communist Party chief went on trial Monday on charges of abusing his official powers by ordering police to break up anti-government demonstrations. Miroslav Stepan, 44, is the first senior Communist Party official to be put on trial since last fall's peaceful revolution ended more than 40 years of one-party Communist rule. If convicted, he faces up to 10 years in prison. Stepan, a former Communist Party Politburo member, was accused of ordering former Prague Police Chief Bohumil Carda to use water cannon and tear gas against 5,000 demonstrators in Prague's Wenceslas Square on Oct. 28, 1988. The rally had been called by independent groups to mark the 70th anniversary of Czechoslovak independence with demands for reforms and greater freedom. At the time, Stepan was head of the Prague Defense Council, which, as a state organ, is competent only in matters related to the defense of the state. ``Thus, as a public official, he (Stepan) overstepped his competence with the intent to cause harm to others,'' said prosecutor Ladislav Cepl, reading the indictment. Stepan was also charged with ordering police to transport 195 demonstrators, without their personal documents, 18 to 30 miles outside Prague on Jan. 15-17, 1989. The demonstrators had refused to disperse during an unauthorized rally in downtown Prague. Stepan has been under arrest since December, pending investigation for his role in the Nov. 17 crackdown on student demonstrators in Prague. The brutal police action triggered mass demonstrations that led to the ouster of the hard-line Communist regime. Stepan's trial was not open to the public, because it may deal with classified information related to the Prague Defense Council. The verdict was expected to be handed down early next month.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Deferred Sentence, Orders Trial In Booby Trap Death
DOC.TEXT: A judge rejected a plea agreement Monday and ordered trial for a warehouse owner who rigged a shotgun booby trap that killed a teen-age intruder. ``What's next, punji sticks, Claymore mines, bouncing betties?'' Denver District Judge Richard Spriggs said. Tossing out the suspended sentence agreed upon by a prosecutor, Spriggs ordered Philip Connaghan, 46, of Arvada to stand trial for reckless manslaughter and a misdemeanor charge of violating the state's booby trap law. Spriggs said the loss of 19-year-old Michael McComb's life ``is non-justifiable, and to me deferred judgment does not seem warranted.'' A booby trap ``is a deadly device without mercy or distinction, brutally savage and inhumane,'' the judge said. District Attorney Norm Early and Connaghan's attorney, Bob Ransome, had reached an agreement whereby Connaghan would plead guilty to the two charges. In exchange, he would have served no jail time and his record was to have been wiped clean. Early and Ransome argued that Connaghan had been burglarized repeatedly and had tried other means of thwarting burglars before setting the trap. After McComb's death, Connaghan was remorseful, they said. But Spriggs ordered Early and Ransome to prepare motions by Aug. 21 and said Connaghan will face trial no later than Dec. 24. The manslaughter conviction would carry a penalty of up to eight years in prison, while the misdemeanor count is punishable by a fine up to $5,000 and one year in jail. The booby trap set at Connaghan's warehouse near downtown Denver killed McComb during a break-in the night of April 14, when McComb entered the warehouse with three friends. McComb, whom authorities said had burglarized the warehouse at least once previously, died of a single blast to the chest from the 12-gauge shotgun. The three juveniles were not injured and face possible burglary charges. Spriggs said that while McComb was breaking the law when he entered Connaghan's warehouse, that was not sufficient reason for him to die. ``It's also been suggested that the victim in the case (McComb) subscribed to a belief all of us find reprehensible,'' Spriggs said, referring to reports that McComb was a skinhead who subscribed to racist beliefs. Connaghan' warehouse, where he kept various personal effects, had been burglarized several times before the April 14 incident. He once lost about $7,000 worth of tools. Connaghan set two shotgun booby traps in the warehouse after it was burglarized in January. During another burglary in March, one of the booby traps was tripped, but malfunctioned. He dismantled one of the traps, but told authorities he forgot to disarm the second one. Early said Connaghan had taken other measures to protect his property before setting the booby trap, including blocking the entrance with parked vehicles and placing bars on the windows. Connaghan even had leased a pit bull, but it either was stolen or escaped, Early said. ``He didn't want to injure anyone. In fact, he had intended to disarm the gun,'' Early said. But Connaghan had promised police he would disarm the booby trap, Spriggs said. ``The fact remains he didn't take it down,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: House, Senate Approve Amtrak Bill Without Anti-Takeover Provision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 2 grafs new with Senate action sending bill to president.
DOC.TEXT: Congress on Monday approved and sent to the White House new Amtrak legislation devoid of the railroad anti-takeover provision that drew a veto from President Bush. The bill was approved by a voice vote first in the House and then in the Senate. The legislation caps federal subsidies for the government-owned passenger railroad at $684 million in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and at $712 million in fiscal 1992. In vetoing an earlier version, Bush said he accepted the spending figures but objected to a plan which would have required Interstate Commerce Commission approval of railroad takeovers by non-railroad companies. The House voted to override Bush's veto, but the Senate narrowly failed to get the needed two-thirds majority to enact the bill over his objections. ``Because the president's concerns have been addressed ... the current version of the bill is acceptable to the administration,'' the White House said in a statement Monday. Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio, chairman of the House subcommittee on transportation, said the bill authorizes enough money for Amtrak to replace and upgrade its passenger cars. However, while the bill caps the Amtrak allocation, the actual amount will be determined later in a separate spending bill. In addition to Amtrak service, the bill would clear legal impediments to the start of new commuter rail service between northern Virginia and the District of Columbia.

DOC.HEAD: Poe's Mysterious Birthday Visitor Captured on Film
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT year of Poe's death to 1849 sted 1848
DOC.TEXT: The dark figure who visits Edgar Allan Poe's grave every year was captured on film by a photographer who used surveillance equipment to snap the only known picture of the annual rite. But the identity of the man remains a mystery worthy of Poe, the patriarch of American mystery writers. The photographer did not approach the shadowy figure or try to spoil his secret. Every Jan. 19 since at least 1949, on the anniversary of Poe's birthday, someone has left three roses and a bottle of cognac on the writer's grave. Poe died in Baltimore in 1849. Life magazine, in the July issue that hit newsstands Monday, includes a picture of the figure during his early-morning visit. Bill Ballenberg, a free-lance photographer in New York, spent $17,000 from Life to rent infra-red, night-vision equipment, which he set up facing Poe's original grave and the monument he rests beneath. When the darkly clad visitor appeared at the grave at 3 a.m., Ballenberg took the picture by a remote radio signal from inside Westminster Hall, the Presbyterian church that overlooks the graveyard. ``We had about 30 seconds. It was really fast. It was like 12 hours of boredom punctuated by 30 seconds of terror,'' Ballenberg said in a telephone interview Monday. Jeff Jerome, curator of the Edgar Allen Poe House, allowed the photographer and a magazine writer to wait with him for the visitor last Jan. 19, the 181st anniversary of the writer's birth. The two agreed not to try to nab, identify, talk to or otherwise disturb the visitor. The picture shows the back of a man kneeling at the grave where Poe was buried for 26 years. Because the photo was taken with a nightscope, which intensified the available light 35,000 times, the somewhat fuzzy photo shows only the visitor and the grave within a circle of light. ``I could see his body. I never could see his face. No one could see his face. He had a hat and a scarf pulled up well around his face, securing his face,'' Ballenberg said. Poe died at the age of 40 after being discovered in a delirium on a Baltimore street in 1848. He had stepped off a steamer and was en route to New York after visiting his childhood sweetheart in Richmond, Va. The circumstances of his death remain unclear. Some researchers of Poe attributed his state to a fever; others pointed to the late stages of alcoholism and a deteriorating mind. For 26 years, Poe's remains lay under a medium-sized stone in the graveyard. A larger monument was erected in front of the downtown burial ground and he was reinterred in 1875. Jerome, who became curator in 1979 and began the overnight vigils, has been accused of orchestrating the visits, which he denies. But he said he uses the publicity and annual birthday celebrations to draw attention to the works of the writer. Witnesses' accounts indicate that several different men have brought the cognac and roses in the 40 years since the offerings were spotted by the church curator. No one else will be allowed to photograph the mysterious visitor, Jerome said. ``This was a once in a lifetime chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Crewmen Killed, One Missing in British Oil Tanker Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with two killed and one missing, fire under control, no oil spills reported, amount of oil on ship, CORRECTS number of crew members to 42 sted 52. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A British oil tanker caught fire off Norway's southwest coast Monday after an explosion in a pump room, killing at least two crewmen with another missing and presumed dead, officials said. The blaze was brought under control and there were no reports of any oil spills, said Einar Knutsen of Shell's Norwegian division. The tanker Rapana, operated by Shell Tankers Ltd. in London, caught fire 26 miles off Norway, with 500,000 barrels of crude oil aboard, said Anders Bang-Andersen of the Sola Rescue Central. Knutsen said two crewmen were killed and a third was missing and feared dead. He did not give their identities or nationality. The accident took place in the North Sea's Egersund Basin. ``The fire is under control and the ship is sailing for Scotland under its own power,'' said Bang-Andersen. Bang-Andersen, speaking in a telephone interview, said 23 of the 42 crewmen aboard were flown to Stavanger, Norway, about 175 miles southwest of Oslo. One crewman was seriously injured, he said. Rescuers earlier said they believed 52 crew were on board. ``The others remained aboard voluntarily to fight the fire,'' he said. The ship's officers are British, and most of its crew from the Philippines, he said. The tanker was bound for Liverpool, England, from the Swedish port of Brofjorden, when it started broadcasting distress signals Monday afternoon after a series of pump room explosions rocked the ship. ``There were two big explosions followed by two smaller ones,'' Bang-Andersen said. Six firefighters and equipment were flown out on two helicopters from Stavanger to help fight the blaze, he said. The Norwegian news agency NTB said the 227,400-ton ship was registered in the Isle of Man.

DOC.HEAD: HHS Secretary Denounces Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis Sullivan said Monday he was outraged that ``un-American'' protesters prevented him from being heard at an AIDS conference, but the incident would not reduce his commitment to fight the disease. Sullivan said the demonstrators who shouted, whistled and threw wads of paper at him as he spoke Sunday in San Francisco ``stepped over the line'' of legitimate protest and were ``un-American,'' and he will have nothing to do with their organizers any more. The secretary, in an interview Monday evening, said he had been aware that his speech to the closing session of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS in San Franci target of protesters, but he said he had not expected to be drowned out for more than 20 minutes. ``I've been heckled before but I've never had the intesco would be thensity that I heard there, where the clear intent was not for the protesters to simply make a point, but their intent was to prevent me from making a point. ``And that is un-American, that is clearly antithetical to the basic principle we have in this country of free speech. That is what I object to and what I take personal and professional exception to,'' he said. DOC.HEAD: China Hopes Fang Release Will Bring Big Dividends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2-3 `Astrophysicist Fang' to UPDATE with arrival in Britain. Picks up 4th pvs, `China has...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Fang, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: China has ended the yearlong isolation of dissident Fang Lizhi in hopes of ending its own estrangement from the United States and other Western nations. Astrophysicist Fang and his wife Li Shuxian, a physicist, arrived in Upper Heyford, a U.S. base 60 miles west of London, late Monday on a U.S. Air Force jet after the government allowed them to leave the U.S. Embassy, where they had been living since June 1989. Beijing cited ``leniency'' in allowing the couple, wanted by police as counterrevolutionary criminals, to leave Monday. But the decision was based more on diplomatic than humanitarian concerns. It was the latest, and most important, gesture aimed at returning to the good graces of the West. China has been stunned by Western condemnation of the military suppression of the pro-democracy movement last June that forced Fang and his wife, China's leading advocates of democratic reform, to seek refuge in the U.S. Embassy. Western nations suspended high-level contacts, invited Chinese studying in their countries to stay, and blocked governmental and World Bank loans to China. Government spokesman Yuan Mu, in an interview last week with Japanese reporters, acknowledged that restrictions on development loans had hurt. He said China cannot put its trust in ``impractical self-wishes'' for better relations with the West. China has made several diplomatic gestures this year directed at ending its ostracism. It lifted martial law in Beijing in January, and ended more than a year of martial law in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa on May 1. Since December, nearly 900 people arrested in connection with the pro-democracy protests last spring have been released. The government has stressed that Chinese students, both in China and abroad, will not be prosecuted merely for joining pro-democracy protests. Fang's release removes a major impediment to improved U.S.-China relations, which seriously deterioriated after the military crackdown. ``Relations have hit the bottom,'' a Foreign Ministry official said Monday. ``They have no place to go but up.'' He added, however, that China is ``puzzled'' by the tendency in the West to discount China's goodwill gestures as ``cosmetic.'' Western critics say China in reality has done little to improve its human rights record. They note that although martial law ended in Beijing, thousands of troops remain in the city to crush any attempt at political protest. And although Fang was allowed to leave the country, many well-known figures _ among them student leader Wang Dan, political scientist Liu Xiaobo, senior party official Bao Tong, and political activist Ren Wanding _ face long prison terms as alleged counterrevolutionaries. Thousands who joined in the protests last year are still in jail without having been charged or tried. Fang's release was timed to coincide with debate in the U.S. Congress on giving China most-favored-nation trading status. Many members of Congress, citing China's human rights record, have opposed President Bush's decision to extend the trade status, which gives China low tariffs on exports to the United States. Resolution of the Fang case also comes just before the Western nations hold their annual summit in Houston. One question at the July summit will be whether to continue opposing loans to China by international financial organizations such as the World Bank. Even before the decision to release Fang, cracks were appearing in Western sanctions on China. The Bush administration has approved World Bank loans on a ``human need'' basis, and the bank has pushed ahead with $590 million in credit to China. Japanese Foreign Ministry officials indicated Monday that Fang's release would create a ``favorable environment'' for reopening talks on a $5.2 billion five-year loan package to China. As Fang left for Britain, a high-ranking member of the West German or parliament held talks with Premier Li Peng. A Communist Party Politburo member, Li Tieying, was preparing for a visit to Japan, and a senior British official is scheduled to visit Beijing next month for talks on Hong Kong. Rapid improvement in U.S.-China relations is unlikely, although White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater praised Fang's release as a ``far-sighted, significant step that will improve the atmosphere for progress in our bilateral relations.'' One country where Fang's release will go largely unnoticed is China. The tightly controlled official press has rarely reported on Fang, except to condemn him. His departure from China received only short mention in the middle of the national evening news, after reports on a meeting on agriculture policy and a discourse on state financial affairs.
Jim Abrams is Beijing bureau chief for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Conable Tells Bush Protectionism Hits Third World
DOC.TEXT: Protectionism against imports costs Third World countries twice as much as they get in foreign aid, World Bank President Barber Conable wrote to President Bush. ``Nobody will benefit from fragmentation of the world trading system,'' Conable wrote. ``The world's poor stand to lose the most.'' In 1988, the last year for which complete figures are available, aid reached $48 billion. The United States is the largest single contributor though it ranks close to the bottom when its own wealth is taken into account. The World Bank, owned by 152 governments, is the biggest source of aid, lending over $20 billion a year. If the industrial countries dismantled their barriers to imports, the Third World could raise its income by 3 percent, Conable figured. The barriers take the form of import duties, quotas that limit the size of imports, and subsidies that the governments of industrial countries give to their own farms and industry. Conable's letter, dated June 18, was made available Monday. ``The next few months of 1990 may well be as crucial for freer trade as the last few months of 1989 were for freer peoples,'' he wrote. He said the leaders of seven governments, whom Bush will host July 9 in Houston, should break the deadlock in four years of worldwide trade talks. This ``Uruguay round'' has been stalled by a clash between the United States and the 12 governments of the European Economic Community over subsidies to farm products. The Bush administration wants exporting countries to end the subsidies they give to foreign sales. The Europeans want all kinds of farm subsidies reduced. Reducing subsidies given by the governments of industrial countries would help the Third World sell its own products. Subsidies to farming are estimated to cost hundreds of billions of dollars a year to taxpayers and consumers of the industrial countries. ``It is imperative that the interests of developing countries are fully represented in any agreement breaking the deadlock,'' Conable said. ``Agreement embracing all parties would benefit developing country exporters and importers, especially in agriculture and in textiles and clothing.''

DOC.HEAD: Reform Rabbis Accept Homosexual Colleagues
LaserPhoto SE1
DOC.TEXT: The organization of Reform rabbis broke with 4,000 years of Jewish tradition Monday and endorsed homosexual rabbis as qualified leaders of congregations in the United States and Canada. The Central Conference of American Rabbis, meeting for its 101st annual convention, overwhelmingly approved a resolution urging that ``all rabbis, regardless of sexual orientation, be accorded the opportunity to fulfill the sacred vocation which they have chosen.'' The conference is the organization of 1,550 rabbis in the Reform movement, which has 1.3 million congregational members in the United States. ``It's an exciting day,'' said Rabbi Denise Eger, the lesbian leader of Beth Chayim Chadashim, a primarily homosexual congregation in Los Angeles. Some estimates have said as many as 10 percent of U.S. Reform rabbis are homosexual. The resolution was put forth by a 17-member committee that adopted it unanimously after four years of study and debate. The final resolution stated the committee's majority position in affirming that homosexual unions are not on a par with ``heterosexual, monogamous, procreative'' marriages, which were specified as the Jewish ideal. But a minority of the committee was able to insert a statement ``affirming the equal possibility of covenantal fulfillment'' in both homosexual and heterosexual relationships. Creating a traditional Jewish home is considered a religious duty. ``To the extent that sexual orientation is a matter of choice,'' the majority of the committee affirmed in the resolution, heterosexuality is the only appropriate choice. In an interview before the vote, Rabbi Samuel Karff of Houston, conference president and a committee member, said the committee's unanimity in supporting homosexual rabbis had been contingent on emphasizing that distinction. ``What emerges on the one hand is a desire to affirm support for our colleagues who are gay and lesbian ... and on the other hand we feel it essential to maintain our link to basic Jewish norms,'' he said. Jewish law, embodied in the Torah and other texts, condemns homosexuality as an abomination. But ``out of concern for human dignity one is permitted to violate the prohibitions of Torah,'' Karff said. About 500 conference members are attending the four-day convention, which ends Wednesday. The conference originated in the United States but now includes Reform rabbis worldwide. A two-thirds vote was needed to pass the resolution, which stated it was an attempt to address the issue only in the United States and Canada. A 45-minute debate preceded the voice vote, with most rabbis expressing support and some calling for an even stronger statement. Others worried the resolution pushes the limits of Judaism too far. ``It will be an angle for enemies of Reform Judaism and those who are neutral to use this as yet another weapon as a challenge to our authenticity,'' said Rabbi Clifford Librach of Congregation Moses Montefiore in Bloomington, Ill. Reform Judaism is the largest and most liberal of the three main branches of Judaism. In 1972, it became the first branch to ordain a woman rabbi. The Conservative Jewish movement has had women rabbis since 1985 but it does not openly accept homosexual rabbis. Orthodox Jews, the third major branch, oppose ordination of women or homosexuals as forbidden by Jewish law. Rabbi Daniel Syme, national vice president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said, ``I view this resolution as an important baseline document that will serve as a basis for change in the Jewish community as a whole.'' The union, which last fall overwhelmingly approved a similar document, represents the 1.3 million members of U.S. Reform congregations. There are another 100,000 to 200,000 Reform Jews worldwide. The Central Conference, which places rabbis with congregations, warned gay and lesbian rabbis that their jobs could be endangered if they make their sexual orientation known, and called for ``education and dialogue'' to encourage acceptance.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Disturbance Leaves One Guard Hurt
DOC.TEXT: About 400 inmates rioted at the state's minimum security prison Monday, looting and setting two buildings ablaze and ripping doors off hinges. A guard was injured by a thrown rock, authorities said. The disturbance at the Carl Robinson Correctional Institution started about 7:15 a.m. when the inmates refused to return to their dormitories after breakfast to protest the food and low wages for their prison jobs, said Correction Department spokesman William Wheeler. The inmates threw rocks, broke windows and broke into the two buildings, which housed mess halls, a commissary and a gymnasium, Wheeler said. The inmates looted the commissary and torched both buildings, which were reduced to rubble. Wheeler estimated the damage at $2.7 million. About 250 correction officers, including scores brought in from other state prisons, used tear gas to quell the riot. Most of the inmates were returned to their dormitories by 12:30 p.m., and Warden George Bronson said preliminary checks showed all 1,356 inmates accounted for. ``The perimeter security was maintained throughout the entire incident,'' Bronson said. ``The correction officers were in control. The inmates were in the yard.'' He said the riot instigators would be charged. A guard suffered a broken ankle from a rock thrown by an inmate, Wheeler said, and a number of inmates complained of injuries like smoke inhalation and cuts and bruises. About 100 state troopers equipped with riot gear and police dogs were brought in but remained on standby about a quarter mile away, Wheeler said. Wheeler said prison officials did not have advance warning of the riot, but later received a flyer inmates had circulated calling for a strike Monday. Several news organizations reported getting anonymous calls Sunday and Monday about a planned strike. A woman who identified herself only as an inmate's wife telephoned the Journal Inquirer newspaper in Manchester Monday morning and said the prisoners were undertaking a ``food strike.'' Reading from an inmate letter, she said food quality was substandard, the mess hall unsanitary and the diet lacking in fruit. ``We realize we're not at the Holiday Inn, but we are human beings. It's been proven that individuals treated as animals will return to society as animals,'' she read. The prison's population has nearly doubled in the last three months and tensions have mounted. Bronson said additional guards have been hired, but acknowledged the 250-member staff had not doubled. The prison, opened in 1987, was designed to accommodate 1,360. The prison was plagued by escapes last year, prompting authorities to spend $1 million on an electronic fence topped with razor wire. Still, three inmates escaped earlier this month; two remain at large.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Forces Stage Military Exercises, Tlass Warns Israel
DOC.TEXT: Syria's defense minister warned Monday that Israel would ``pay dearly'' for any attack against Arab states, the official Syrian news agency SANA said. Defense Minister Gen. Mustafa Tlass, who was overseeing joint air force and army maneuvers, told the soldiers they should be prepared to thwart the ``grave dangers'' posed by Israel, according to the news agency. The news agency said the soldiers successfully performed their tasks in ``circumstances that were as close as possible to a real battlefield.'' The news agency did not specify where the training exercises were held or how many soldiers took part. ``At the end of the maneuvers, Gen. Tlass complimented the participants and stressed that the present circumstances are exposing the Arab nation to grave dangers that are threatening its existence and future,'' SANA said. ``This dictates upon our armed forces to double their alertness, fighting capabilities and prepardness to fight the battle of liberation,'' it quoted Tlass as saying. Tlass added that ``Israeli threats and provocations are counterproductive and if Israel waged any aggression, it will pay dearly,'' SANA reported. ``President Hafez Assad's orders are that the armed forces should carry out their national and pan-Arab responsibility in confronting such aggression with all the available means,'' he added, according to SANA. Tensions in the Middle East have heightened in recent weeks following the slaying of seven Arab laborers by an Israeli civilian. The slayings gave a new impetus to the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The United States suspended its ongoing dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization after a failed seaborne raid on Tel Aviv by a militant Palestinian faction. Arab officials have called the new conservative Israeli Cabinet led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir ``a war government.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Die from Gas Poisoning Near South Pacific Volcano
DOC.TEXT: Six people have died from gas poisoning at a volcano in Rabaul Harbour, the main port of Papua New Guinea's northern islands, police said Tuesday. A man and two children suffocated Sunday while hunting wild-fowl eggs near Tavurvur volcano, police said. The other three, two adults and a child, went looking for the missing trio Monday ahead of an official search party and died trying to retrieve the bodies. All six were believed to have died in a pocket of naturally occurring carbon dioxide.

DOC.HEAD: Quints' Parents Seek Extra Money to Care for Nieces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, ``We can...; to CLARIFY that parents of nieces are unemployed
DOC.TEXT: Parents of the country's first in-vitro quintuplets said Monday that without more state money they might have to turn out their three nieces. ``We can take care of our own,'' Michele L'Esperance said of her 2{-year-old quints and two other children. But she said the family needs more than the $295 they receive monthly to care for the nieces, who moved in several months ago. The nieces' parents are unemployed and homeless. Michele L'Esperance said it costs $350 a week to feed her brood. The L'Esperances want their nieces designated as foster children, which would allow the family to receive about $800 per month for each of the three children. Frank Millard, a lawyer for the nieces, told Oakland County Probate Court Judge Robert Martin on Monday that the state Department of Social Service is expected to rule soon on the couple's request for a license to run a foster home. Martin then adjourned the hearing until July 3. The department has denied previous requests because the family already has seven children. The L'Esperances are seeking a waiver of that rule. Raymond L'Esperance is a corrections officer at the Macomb County Jail, earning about $26,000 a year, and has a second full-time job. His wife works part-time at a shelter for battered women. Alexandria, Danielle, Erica, Veronica and Raymond Jr., born Jan. 11, 1988, were the first quints in the nation conceived in vitro to survive to birth. Michele L'Esperance said outside of the courtroom Monday that weekend reports of her family's tight finances were embarrassing. She also said the family doesn't want public contributions. ``We're fine,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Progress Reported in Mexico on Salvadoran Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to clarify, minor editing thereafter. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: After six days of peace talks, Salvadoran government and guerrilla negotiators have made progress but no concrete advances in talks on the military's future role, a U.N. mediator announced Monday. Alvaro DeSoto, a representative of U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, told journalists the negotiators have moved on to the second item on their seven-point agenda _ human rights _ before concluding their round of dialogue at this resort 40 miles south of Mexico City. DeSoto said movement to the next subject meant ``that for the moment, possibility for concrete advance on the first item, the armed forces, was exhausted.'' He said negotiators would return to the subject of armed forces in future sessions. ``Both sides are conscious of the difficulty of the subjects of negotiation, especially the first subject. Accords have not yet been achieved. But ... there has been movement in that direction that has no precedence in the history of contact between the government and the FMLN,'' said the U.N. communique. The initials stand for the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the leftist insurgent army that has waged civil war against a succession of U.S.-backed governments. The civil war has left about 72,000 people, most of them civilians, dead. The talks were the second round in a dialogue begun last month in Caracas, Venezuela. The military retains a strong degree of power in El Salvador's government and international rights organizations have blamed the armed forces for the torture and murder of thousands of suspected opponents. No military officer has ever been convicted, or even tried, for rights violations. Salvadoran Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria, chief of the government delegation, told The Associated Press the session was ``successful,'' but like DeSoto, declined to elaborate. Miguel Saenz, a member of the guerrilla delegation, said, ``In general, we're encouraged by the results.'' Guerrilla negotiator Salvador Samayoa said: ``It is the old question of whether the glass is half-empty or half-full. I prefer to see it half-full _ and not because of mere optimism, but because conditions favor movement toward peace.'' The seven topics to be discussed in the accords are: the role of the armed forces, human rights, judicial and electoral reform, constitutional revision, socioeconomic problems and international verification of compliance with the agreements. The two sides agreed to meet again July 20. The communique did not say where, but participants said it would be in Costa Rica. Four rounds of dialogue from 1984 to 1989 failed to produce progress and talks broke down over mutual charges of intransigence.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Decision `Farsighted Step' in Improving Relations
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 9-11: ``Richard Solomon,'' with report of heart attack
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Fang, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: China's decision to permit dissident astrophysicist Fang Lizhi to leave his country after a year behind the sheltering walls of the U.S. Embassy is a ``farsighted, significant step'' to improved U.S.-Chinese relations, the White House said Monday. ``We think it's one step, an encouraging step, in the process,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``It would hopefully indicate a desire for better relations with the West.'' Fitzwater acknowledged that as part of the process that led to his release, Fang ``did make a commitment not to oppose the policies'' of China's communist rulers. However, the spokesman said, President Bush made ``no commitment ... granted no quid pro quo of any kind'' in exchange for the Chinese scholar's freedom. The United State remains ``strongly critical'' of continuing human rights abuses by the Chinese government, Fitzwater said. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, left China for Britain late Sunday after Communist authorities allowed them to end their sojourn in the U.S. Embassy. He has accepted a position at Cambridge University. ``The United States government welcomes the People's Republic of China's decision to facilitate the departure of Dr. Fang and his wife,'' Fitzwater said in a formal statement, which he said was issued with the knowledge of the Chinese foreign ministry. ``This humanitarian action is a farsighted, significant step that will improve the atmosphere for progress in our bilateral relations,'' the statement said. Richard Solomon, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, was quoted by Hearst News Service as saying a heart attack Fang suffered last month was the ``face saver'' that permitted the Chinese government to cite ``humanitarian concerns'' in permitting him to leave. A specialist, flown to the embassy, treated Fang after concluded that he would be arrested if he went to a Beijing hospital, Solomon said. Solomon said both governments had agreed to refrain from direct reference to the heart attack, saying only that Fang needed medical treatment. Fang was a symbol of the crisis in relations between Washington and Beijing in the aftermath of the Chinese violent crackdown on pro democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square last June. The official Chinese news agency Xinhua said Fang and his wife were allowed to leave the country for medical reasons after showing ``signs of repentance.'' But Fitzwater said he believed Fang's statement merely ``paralleled many of his public statements in the past.'' China had previously said that to be released, Fang and Li would have to confess ``guilt,'' and promise not to carry out any anti-government activities. President Bush has agreed to extend preferential trade and tariff status for China, pending approval by Congress. Fitzwater said Chinese Embassy officials here are clearly aware of widespread reluctance on Capitol Hill to approve continued Most Favored Nation trade status for China.

DOC.HEAD: Conferees Delete AIDS Provision from Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, bgng: But sponsors xxx to UPDATE with Kennedy statement.
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate conferees on Monday deleted from a civil rights bill language that would have allowed employers to move AIDS sufferers away from food-handling jobs. The action came as representatives of each chamber discussed changes made on the respective floors in the landmark civil rights legislation aimed at ensuring the rights of some 43 million disabled. Earlier this month, the Senate had accepted a House-added provision placing the limitation on work assignments of AIDS sufferers _ a move that was seen at the time as a major victory for Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. But sponsors of the legislation, including Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn.; Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and Thomas Harkin, D-Iowa, argued that no such restrictive language was necessary. They said it could not be justified in view of existing scientific evidence indicating that the AIDS virus is not transmitted through such casual means as the preparation and handling of food. Kennedy said in a statement later that he was happy the conferees turned back the food-handlers amendment. ``This amendment flies in the face of all scientific and medical evidence and is a step backwards in our public understanding of and compassion for this nation's AIDS crisis,'' he said. The Senate, by voice vote on June 6, had approved a non-binding motion by Helms to have the Americans with Disabilities Act include an exemption that would allow employers to reassign infected workers from food-handling jobs. Helms' motion instructed Senate negotiators to accept a House-adopted exemption when they worked out a final version of the bill. But the so-called Chapman amendment, named for Rep. James Chapman, D-Texas, was deleted from the bill during Monday's conference committee work. Harkin had said earlier that the amendment would ``codify ignorance'' about AIDS and how it is transmitted. The House had approved the exemption 199-187 last month before it finally passed the entire act 403-20. The Senate passed the bill 76-8 last September. The conference report is expected to go first to theSenate, possibly as early as Wednesday, and then to the House, and sponsors said they expected final congressional passage before a Fourth of July recess. The House had adopted the amendment even though Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan said it was unnecessary. The White House had not spoken out against the amendment, however, although it specifically endorsed another, unrelated change. It was endorsed by the restaurant and food-service industry as well as by the National Federation of Independent Business, a chief critic of the entire disabilities bill.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Legislature Convenes Special Session on Subsistence Hunting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to CLARIFY that state constitution, not laws, being changed, UPDATE with November soonest date for a vote, CLARIFY that all fisheries controlled by state; picks up 10th graf pvs, `The takeover...
DOC.TEXT: The governor warned lawmakers Monday they will have to change the state constitution to give rural residents the first crack at game and fish if they want to avoid federal control of the state's wildlife. The Legislature was convened in special session at Gov. Steve Cowper's request to consider a constitutional amendment to bring the state back into compliance with federal subsistence law. The Alaska Supreme Court in December declared part of a state law giving rural Alaskans preferential rights to subsistence hunting and fishing unconstitutional, saying it discriminated against urban hunters and fishermen. Because of that ruling, which put state and federal laws at odds, the federal government plans to assume responsibility for game management Sunday in the two-thirds of the state it owns. To regain state control, an amendment must pass both houses of the Legislature by a two-thirds margin and be put to the voters. The soonest date for a vote is the Nov. 6 general election. Cowper, a Democrat, and U.S. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, both support the amendment. ``There are sound reasons based on our history as a territory and as a state for us to do whatever is necessary to maintain the opportunity for rural Alaskan residents to live off the land, and to keep the power to manage our fish and wildlife for ourselves,'' Cowper said. An estimated 110,000 Alaskans venture into the wild to hunt, fish and gather plants for food. Five federal land agencies plan to assume game management of Alaska's federal land to protect the rural subsistence right, which is grounded in a 1980 federal law. Management of fisheries will remain under state control. The takeover is expected to produce confusion among hunters faced with differing regulations on Alaska's patchwork of public lands. Stevens said Alaskans' control over their future will be lost if the federal takeover is allowed to become permanent. ``The proposed federal subsistence regulations are bad for Alaska, and they will inevitably get worse,'' Stevens said. ``Anti-hunting groups are a strong force in Washington, D.C., and they will continuously lobby federal agencies to reduce hunting opportunities in Alaska.'' Said Cowper, ``Go to an animal-rights meeting on the East Coast and see if you identify with the views expressed there.''

DOC.HEAD: High Court Accepts Parental-Notification Abortion Law
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 23rd graf: ``A jubilant,'' to CORRECT ``impute'' to ``input.''
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court made it significantly more difficult Monday for girls to obtain legal abortions without first notifying their parents. The court voted 6-3 to uphold an Ohio law that bans abortions for unmarried girls under 18 who are dependent on one or both parents unless a parent is notified or a judge's approval is obtained. And the court voted 5-4 to allow Minnesota to require notification of both parents as long as girls can avoid telling either parent by getting a judge's permission instead. By a separate 5-4 vote, the justices struck down a provision in the same Minnesota law that would have required two-parent notification with no judicial bypass option. Abortion rights advocates and anti-abortion forces agreed that the two decisions heightened the possibility the high court soon would reverse its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. But nothing in the two decisions _ which featured nine separate opinions and shifting coalitions among the justices _ affected directly adult women's right to abortion. The decisions' practical potential impact is enormous. Of the 1.5 million legal abortions performed annually in the United States since 1973, about 12 percent _ some 180,000 a year _ have been for minors. The two decisions offer these guidelines for such parental-notification laws: _States may require that both parents be notified only if a judicial bypass option is included. _Even requiring notice to one parent must be accompanied by an alternative that allows a girl to avoid telling her parent if she can prove to a judge it would be against her best interest. _The girl may be required to prove by ``clear and convincing'' evidence, not by just a ``preponderance'' of the evidence, that she is mature enough to make the decision on her own. _Doctors personally may be required to notify the parents. _States may require that parental notice occur at least 48 hours before an abortion is performed. ``These decisions bode ill for the future of reproductive choice in America,'' said Melanne Verveer of People for the American Way, a pro-abortion rights group. ``With Justice Sandra Day O'Connor creating the anti-choice majority today, we now have a Supreme Court ready and willing to give the green light to states weighing curbs on choice.'' O'Connor provided the key fifth vote for upholding that version of the Minnesota law featuring a judicial bypass option. The court last July gave states greater power to regulate abortions. Four members then appeared ready to reverse Roe vs. Wade and allow states to ban virtually all abortions. O'Connor refused to go that far, but again Monday indicated she would be willing to uphold any abortion regulations that do not present ``an undue burden'' on women. Since joining the court in 1981, O'Connor has only found one such regulation to be an undue burden _ the Minnesota provision requiring two-parent notification without a judicial bypass option. ``These decisions, coupled with (last July's ruling), are very chilling,'' said Faye Wattleton, president of Planned Parenthood. ``Today's decisions are a defeat for young women and ultimately for all women.'' Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, called the decisions ``quite alarming.'' ``As if allowing states to treat teens like criminals were not enough, Justice O'Connor ... once again signaled her willingness to overturn Roe vs. Wade,'' she said. Praising the decisions, Ann-Louise Lohr of Americans United for Life called them ``big victories for parents' rights and for the rights of minors to have their parents involved in personal decisions.'' A jubilant Beverly LaHaye, president of Concerned Women for America, added, ``Minor daughters should not be excluded from receiving the input of their parents in this critical, life-changing experience,'' she said. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said, ``The two decisions indicate clearly the court holds to its view there is a degree of flexibility states can utilize in regulating abortion but that there are still constitutional limits the court tends to observe and impose.'' The justices previously had allowed limits on the availability of abortions for minors. For example, the court in 1979 said states may require a pregnant, unmarried minor to obtain parental consent to an abortion so long as a judicial bypass option is provided. Twenty-two states have enacted such parental-consent laws. Ten states have enacted parental-notification laws similar to those ruled on Monday. Voting to uphold the Ohio law were O'Connor, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices John Paul Stevens, Byron R. White, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices William J. Brennan, Harry A. Blackmun and Thurgood Marshall dissented. Voting to uphold the Minnesota provision that includes the judicial bypass option were O'Connor, Rehnquist, White, Scalia and Kennedy. Dissenting were Stevens, Brennan, Marshall and Blackmun. Voting to strike down the Minnesota provision that would have excluded the judicial bypass were O'Connor, Stevens, Brennan, Blackmun and Marshall. Dissenting were Rehnquist, White, Scalia and Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: Record Lows in the South, Record Highs in Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with hottest day ever in Phoenix; picks up 2nd graf pvs, `Two Georgia...
DOC.TEXT: Monday brought unseasonably cool weather to parts of the South and California, and another broiling day to much of the Plains and desert Southwest. Phoenix had its all-time hottest day at 120 degrees. The city's previous record of 118 degrees was recorded on four dates, most recently July 4, 1989. Tucson broke its record for the date with 113 degrees. The extreme heat was caused by a combination of warm air from a high pressure system and heating caused by the sun's high angle during the summer, said Craig Ellis, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Phoenix office. ``The pressure system is centered along the New Mexico and Arizona border, and when it gets this strong at this time of the year, it means hot, hot weather,'' Ellis said. Two Georgia cities set or tied record low temperatures Monday morning, less than a week after record, triple-digit highs. Augusta, Ga., dropped to 57 degrees, tying the record for the date set in 1974. And the mercury in Macon fell to 59 degrees, breaking the 1975 record of 62. The low temperature for the nation Monday morning was 33 degrees at Tahoe Valley, Calif. Meanwhile, temperatures neared 100 degrees before noon in western Texas and eastern New Mexico, and 100- to 108-degree temperatures were reported in other portions of the Southwest. On Sunday, Amarillo, Texas, reached 108 degrees _ breaking the record for the day and marking Amarillo's ninth day this month with a temperature of 100 degrees or above. Flooding elsewhere in the state notwithstanding, June has been a dry month across western Texas. Rainfall is down 2} inches below normal at Amarillo, by 2\ inches at Lubbock, and by 1{ inches at San Angelo. Early afternoon rainshowers and thunderstorms extended from southeast Kansas across southwest Missouri, northern and eastern Arkansas, northwest Mississippi, northern and western Louisiana and the upper Texas Gulf Coast. Showers and storms also reached over the southern half of the Florida Peninsula and from New England across eastern New York state. Rainshowers were widely scattered over central and north-central Texas, northwestern South Dakota and northeast Montana. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included an inch and a third at Tampa, Fla., and a half-inch at Beaumont and Port Arthur, Texas. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 59 degrees at Arcata, Crescent City and Vero Beach, Calif., to 113 degrees at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Phoenix Hits All-Time High of 120 Degrees
LaserPhoto PN1
DOC.TEXT: On Phoenix's hottest day ever Monday, the question was whether to suffer in a stifling car or turn on the air-conditioning and risk getting stranded on a roadside with the temperature at 120 degrees. Phoenix's previous record of 118 degrees was hit most recently last July 4. The Arizona Automobile Association's Phoenix office took at least 1,500 calls, easily a third more than normal, said Frank Kuczora of the road service department. He said the extras were mostly overheatings and dead batteries. People apparently fared better than their cars: The Fire Department reported just ``a few more heat-related calls.'' The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus arrived and promptly set up 55-gallon water barrels so its elephants could hose down. Despite the heat, utility spokesmen weren't expecting new records in electricity usage. The humidity was low, so many customers probably were trying to get by with evaporative coolers, which eat less power than air conditioners, said Jeff Eldot, a Salt River Project spokesman. The extreme heat came from a combination of a high pressure system's warm air and the sun's high summer angle, said Craig Ellis, a National Weather Service metereologist.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bomb at Conservative Party Social Club in London Injures Nine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with nine injured, Lady Kaberry quotes, changes time of blast. Pick up graf 18 pvs, `St. Thomas's Hospital...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Monday evening in a Conservative Party social club in downtown London, injuring nine people, including one seriously, authorities said. The victims of the blast at the Carlton Club included an 82-year-old member of the House of Lords, the lawmaker's wife said. Two American tourists also suffered minor cuts from flying glass. The bomb, containing 10 to 15 pounds of high explosives, was planted just inside the door of the 158-year-old club, said George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad. The club has long been considered one of the most venerable symbols of British establishment. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army, which has been waging a new terror campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. ``It brings a new dimension to the campaign, and I must warn the public in general that these people are determined to cause injury and maim,'' said Churchill-Coleman, clearly alluding to the IRA. ``Everyone must be on their guard.'' The bombers struck at one of the most popular meeting places for Cabinet ministers, lawmakers and other members of the governing Conservative Party. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the only female member of the men's club, called the attack ``one more outrage in a catalog of terrorist inhumanity.'' ``Whoever is responsible stands condemned of total and callous disregard for human life, both within the club and among passers-by,'' she said in Dublin, Ireland, where she was attending a European Community summit. ``These people are prepared to bomb and maim others indiscriminately for their own perverted satisfaction.'' It was the worst attack on a Conservative Party target since 1984, when an IRA bomb narrowly missed Mrs. Thatcher in the hotel in the seaside resort of Brighton where she was staying for a party convention. Five people died in the blast. The explosion occurred at 8:40 p.m. (3:40 p.m. EDT) on the ground floor of the three-story club, which is near Trafalgar Square and a few hundred yards from Buckingham Palace. It was not known how many people were inside at the time of the blast. The Fire Brigade said it rescued 24 people from the building. ``I heard an enormous explosion,'' said Ian Greener, night manager at neighboring Brooks's Club. ``We dashed outside and all the smoke was coming from the building onto the street, so it obviously was not a car bomb.'' Police said one person was seriously wounded _ Scotland Yard identified him as a porter working near the club's entrance. Eight other people suffered lesser injuries. Authorities identified none of the casualties, but Lady Kaberry said her husband, Lord Kaberry, was injured. His condition was not known. Kaberry is a former vice chairman of the Conservative Party. ``This is terribly shocking. These people who do these things are taking shots in the dark,'' Lady Kaberry said. ``It is everyone who has to live in fear now. Not only the army, but civilians and politicians.'' Also injured were two other staff members, an unidentified man, and two policemen who were treated for smoke inhalation. St. Thomas's Hospital said it discharged two Americans, Jane Kahan, 49, and Jacob Boal-Tefhuva, 61, both of New York, after treating them for cuts from flying glass. Kahan said she was coming out of Christie's auction house when she heard ``a terrible crash and looked up and saw a window had blown out of the building nearby. ``Some of the fragments of glass hit me. I was in no doubt that it was a bomb.'' The area is in a crowded tourist site. ``I am horrified. This is the mecca of the Conservative Party. That is why the terrorists have chosen to attack it,'' said Sir John Stokes, a Conservative lawmaker. Chauffeur Tim Parrington, 30, was waiting in a Rolls-Royce on the street outside the Carlton when ``there was a deafening bang, and then the shock waves hit the car and it started rocking. ``I went outside to see and there was smoke billowing from the windows and the curtains were blowing about. The people seemed to be walking out quite orderly.'' Other witnesses said they saw two waiters stumble outside in a daze, their aprons blackened. Two art dealers who were at a reception near the club said that just after the explosion, they saw four men carrying athletic bags jump into a car, make a U-turn and drive away. The men appeared nervous, the witnesses said. The Carlton, nestled among the establishment watering holes known collectively as Clubland, is a favorite haunt of Conservative Party lawmakers and therefore a likely target for the IRA in its campaign to drive Britain out of Northern Ireland. Founded in 1832, it is an exclusively male club, but it had to waive that rule in 1979 to admit Mrs. Thatcher when she became prime minister. It moved into its present building after its original home was bombed in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: China's Best-Known Dissident Leaves Embassy, Flies to London
LaserPhotos BEJ1, NY17; LaserColor BEJ2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 6th graf `The official' to ADD report that Fang suffered mild heart attack. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `The Public...'
DOC.TEXT: Fang Lizhi, China's best-known dissident, ended his yearlong refuge in the U.S. Embassy on Monday and flew to Britain after the government freed him in an effort to improve ties with the West. The White House hailed Beijing's move as a ``humanitarian action'' that will improve U.S.-Chinese relations. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, also a well-known dissident, flew from Beijing to London aboard a U.S. Air Force transport jet. They landed at Upper Heyford, a U.S. Air Force base 60 miles west of London, at 8:30 p.m. EDT. The couple had sought refuge in the embassy after the June 4, 1989, military crackdown on China's pro-democracy movement. The official Xinhua news agency said they were given permission to leave the country for medical reasons after showing ``signs of repentance.'' It said the move was ``in line with China's policy of leniency toward those who participated in the disturbances'' of last June. The U.S. and Chinese governments refused comment on Fang's health condition. But Richard Solomon, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, was quoted by Hearst News Service as saying a heart attack Fang suffered last month was the ``face-saver'' that permitted the Chinese government to cite ``humanitarian concerns'' in permitting him to leave. A specialist, flown to the embassy, treated Fang because he feared he would be arrested if he went to a Beijing hospital, Solomon said. The Public Security Ministry said the couple was given lenient treatment after they admitted in a writing to having violated the constitution by opposing socialist principles and the leadership of the Communist Party. In Washington, the State Department issued a statement by Fang and Li in which the two said they remain opposed to four cardinal principles of the Chinese constitution ``because their purpose is to uphold a political system of `class struggle.''' The two dissidents also said their purpose in going abroad ``is focused on scholarly exchange and research. ``We will appreciate and welcome all activities which accord with the progressive interests of Chinese society,'' they said. ``And moreover refuse to participate in all contrary activities whose motive lies in opposing China.'' China's decision to allow the couple to leave eliminated a major obstacle to bettering China-U.S. relations. They deteriorated badly after the violent crackdown on pro-democracy protesters and their supporters, which left hundreds and perhaps thousands dead. The move clearly was intended to bolster China's international standing at a critical time. The U.S. Congress is debating President Bush's decision to extend China's most-favored-nation trade status, which gives China lower tariffs on goods sold in the United States. Some members of Congress have said China should lose the status because of its human rights record _ including the Fang case. Also, the seven industrialized nations are to hold their annual summit in July to discuss policies that include withholding government loans to China. Japan's Vice Foreign Minister Takakazu Kuriyama said the release created a ``favorable environment'' for reopening talks on the loan program. Japan had pledged a $5.2 billion five-year loan program to China, but the plan was frozen after the bloody suppression of pro-democracy protesters. On Capitol Hill Monday, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., used Fang's release to claim victory for Bush's much-criticized China policy. ``It is a small but significant step toward the path that we want China to take _ the path of reason and the path of reform,'' Dole said. ``It is also one bit of tangible evidence that President Bush is on the right track in the way he is managing U.S.-Chinese relations.'' China has made several gestures recently toward repairing its image abroad. Since December, the government has released nearly 900 people arrested for taking part in the pro-democracy movement, and it lifted martial law in Beijing and in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa. Fang, a 54-year-old astrophysicist, has been China's most vocal and eloquent dissident since late 1986, when he supported student pro-democracy protests that winter. The government, claiming his speeches incited students to protest, expelled Fang from the Communist Party and fired him from his post as vice president of a major university. But Fang, protected in part by his growing international renown, continued to openly criticize the government and the socialist system. Until he and his wife fled to the U.S. Embassy, Fang spoke publicly both here and abroad about the necessity of political reform in China. He pointedly avoided playing an active role in last year's seven-week movement. Even so, the government accused Fang and his wife, a physicist, of instigating the unrest. They were charged with ``counterrevolutionary'' activities and placed on China's most-wanted list. Fang's flight to the U.S. Embassy hurt his popularity among many Chinese, who said he and others who fled were unwilling to endure the crackdown with their countrymen. In London on Monday, the Foreign Office said Fang and Li had been granted standard six-month tourist visas but declined to explain why the couple was going to Britain rather than the U.S. The Foreign Office spokesman said Fang had received an invitation from the Royal Society, Britain's oldest and most prestigious scientific organization. Fitzwater said Fang had accepted a job as a professor at Cambridge University. Fang is famous for his research in cosmology and black-hole physics. He pioneered laser research in China.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Defends Violence, Asks Bush to Continue Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 19-21: ``At a,'' Mandela at Senate dinner
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela defended the use of violence to free South Africa from white-minority rule but told President Bush on Monday that force would not be used as long as Pretoria's government negotiates in good faith with the black majority. ``If we are forced to resort to violence,'' Mandela said, ``it is because we had no other alternative whatsoever.'' Bush assured the black revolutionary leader he was not about to lift U.S. sanctions against the South African government but said all sides in the struggle should renounce violence, armed struggle and repression. ``In the words of the great Martin Luther King Jr., `Let us not seek to satisfy our thirst for freedom by drinking from the cup of bitterness and hatred,''' Bush said. The president welcomed Mandela at a sun-splashed ceremony on the South Lawn amid applause and cheers from a crowd of several hundred. As Mandela waved, his wife Winnie gave a clenched-fist salute. Bush and Mandela met for three hours. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said afterward Mandela had pledged to suspend hostilities if the white government in Pretoria clears the way for negotiations. ``The president encouraged him to go beyond that, to renounce the armed struggle,'' Cohen said. Mandela, deputy president of the once-banned African National Congress, did not make a commitment but said he would consider that step, the official said. Mandela, at a news conference, said he had told Bush the ANC had scaled down its military operations in 1986 in order to promote negotiations. ``We made it clear that once the government removed all the obstacles to negotiation, we would consider the cessation of hostilities,'' Mandela said. ``When we explained our position on this point, President Bush appeared to understand our position.'' He said that to get negotiations going, the South African government must release 1,000 political prisoners, return 20,000 political exiles, eventually repeal ``repressive'' legislation and lift the state of emergency in the Natal province. ``We are hopeful that in our next meeting these obstacles will be completely removed'' with the exception of the legislation repeal, Mandela said. Welcoming Mandela to the White House, Bush saluted the tide of democracy in Eastern Europe and said, ``So, too, South Africa's time will come.'' After tumultuous receptions for Mandela earlier in New York and Boston, the White House meeting was the beginning of two days of bargaining with political leaders to keep the pressure on South Africa to abolish apartheid, the system under which 5 million whites subjugate 28 million blacks. Mandela met later Monday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, and as he arrived at the State Department he was greeted by cheers from about 1,000 people. There were also boos and jeers from a small group of people protesting violence by Mandela's group in South Africa. The protesters were organized by a conservative group, the National Center for Public Policy Research. ``Our complaint is that the ANC is using violence,'' said Amy Moritz, president of the center. Leaving the department, Mandela praised Bush as a man with ``a head and a heart, and I exploited that.'' He said he thought his gap with Bush ``had been narrowed considerably and I think we more or less see the problems from the same angle.'' At AFL-CIO headquarters, where he was met by scores of employes packed into the lobby, Mandela said violence was ``no longer really an issue.'' Mandela said he was honored to be greeted by people ``with an established record of committment to the struggle'' against apartheid, and called on American unions to help by sharing their expertise with black trade unionists in South Africa. AFL-CIO president Lane Kirkland said blacks in South Africa ``can continue to count on our unwavering support'' until apartheid is ended. At a dinner for Mandela in the ornate Caucus Room of the Russell Senate Office Building attended by about 40 of the 100 senators as well as prominent black figures in the Washington area, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, told Mandela ``we will heed you call'' to keep sanctions in effect until apartheid is demolished.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: is demolished.
DOC.TEXT: ``I am so deeply touched by what has been said here that I find it difficult to express my gratidude to the senators,'' Mandela said. In a post-apartheid South Africa, he said, the African National Congress wanted ``economic equality for all'' but would not necessarily follow a strict socialist model. Mandela will address a joint session of Congress on Tuesday. Mandela listened impassively as Bush praised South African President F.W. de Klerk for reforms ``to expand the rights and freedoms of all South Africans.'' Bush said, ``All parties must seize the opportunity to move ahead in a spirit of compromise and tolerance, flexibility and patience, and from all parties, we look for a clear and unequivocal commitment to negotiations leading to peaceful change.'' Politely differing with the president, Mandela said Bush ``has not as yet got a proper briefing from us.'' Bush smiled at the comment. Mandela left the White House saying he was ``very much encouraged'' by support from Bush. He said they discussed a variety of issues and ``reached broad agreement on almost all of them.'' He said that in areas where they had disagreed, they had ``narrowed the gaps.'' Bush and Mandela agreed to disagree on U.S. aid to noncommunist guerrillas in Angola, as well as Mandela's support for Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and for Cuba's Fidel Castro, Cohen said. Mandela asked for money for the African National Congress but Bush said no funds would go directly to any political organization, Cohen said. He said the ANC would benefit indirectly from funds channeled through a quasi-government organization, the Fund for Democracy. On Capitol Hill, a leading congressional supporter of Mandela lamented that he has been so insistent in praising leaders of Cuba, Libya and the PLO. ``I wish he had not said those things, very frankly,'' said Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. ``They were not helpful.'' Another supporter of sanctions, Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., said he would boycott Tuesday's speech. And Republican Rep. William Dannemeyer of California said that because of Mandela's violent past it was ``a national disgrace'' that he was invited to address Congress. In his opening statement Monday, Mandela said that as long as South Africa's government is prepared to talk, ``there can be no question of violence whatsoever. ``But when a government decides to ban political organizations of the oppressed, intensifies oppression and does not allow any free political activity, no matter how peaceful and nonviolent, then the people have no alternative but to resort to violence,'' Mandela said. Mandela, jailed for 27 years until his release Feb. 11, said his African National Congress has a ``total commitment to peace. If we are forced to resort to violence, it is because we have no other alternative whatsoever.'' He said he would ask Bush to keep sanctions in place ``because it is of sanctions that such enormous progress has been made in the attempt to address the problems of our country.''
