DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ He's no ordinary man of the cloth. His brother is hardly a typical businessman. One is a Roman Catholic priest, the other a reputed mob boss. Here are two brothers, sons of Italian immigrants, both of whom have attracted a lot of attention in New York City.

To his admiring flock, the Rev. Louis Gigante is the priest who saved his ravaged parish. He's the builder who stopped the urban death march in his South Bronx neighborhood, built new homes, fought crack and crime. To federal investigators, he's the brother of Vincent ``The Chin'' Gigante, 62, the bathrobe-clad reputed boss of the Genovese crime family, which has for years maintained its grip on New York's building industry. To the family of a Harlem teen-ager accused in the gang-rape of a jogger in Central Park, Louis Gigante is the ``angel'' who posted $25,000 bail from his own funds so the youth could be released from jail. To tabloid readers, he's the priest who sat in jail for a week in 1979 because he wouldn't tell a grand jury about his prison conversations with reputed gangster James Napoli, a man he described as ``an old, dear friend.'' To one and all, the 57-year-old pastor is no ordinary man of the cloth. Iris Gonzalez, a member of Gigante's parish who has known him for nearly three decades, won't discuss how a man she so admires could have a sibling so infamous. ``The fingers of the same hand are not the same,'' she says. There were five Gigante children. Their parents immigrated from Naples, Italy, and settled in a cold-water flat in Greenwich Village. The boys were athletic _ Louis, the youngest, was an all-star high school basketball player, while Vincent scored in the boxing ring. Louis graduated from Georgetown University on an athletic scholarship. He attended St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers, was ordained a priest in 1959 and sent to Puerto Rico for two years. In 1962, he was assigned to St. Athanasius Church on Tiffany Street in the South Bronx. By the late '60s, the neighborhood was in rapid decline and fires were wiping out the housing stock. Burned-out buildings were bulldozed, leaving entire blocks leveled. Gigante turned to politics to fight the destruction, running unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for Congress in 1970. The next year, he founded his own Bruckner Democratic Club; in 1973, he was elected to a four-year term on the City Council. During his years as a councilman, the priest-politician persuaded the government to allocate millions of tax dollars to rehabilitate the South Bronx. The money was funneled through the South East Bronx Community Organization (SEBCO), a not-for-profit housing developer. The president and chairman of SEBCO is Louis Gigante. The Rev. Gigante brought a ``second spring'' to the Hunt's Point section of the South Bronx, says New York's Cardinal John J. O'Connor, who calls him the Roman Catholic Church's ``master builder.'' ``He helped people. There is more housing, less drugs, people get together, they make a community,'' says Victoria Serra, who came to Mass on a recent Sunday with her mother, Rosa. ``Before, drugs were all around us. He led a march from door to door, and we posted signs against drugs. It's a much better place now.'' Four years ago, Mrs. Gonzalez moved into a SEBCO-built apartment. ``Before, you'd be afraid of being here. But now, the neighborhood is changed 100 percent. He helped people who had problems with drugs and alcohol, people who were unemployed,'' she says. ``He's turned the neighborhood around,'' says Alberto Negron, 28, glancing at the prefabricated wooden houses standing alongside crumbling brownstones. St. Athanasius Church is ringed by one- and two-family, cream-colored homes with driveways, iron security fences and gardens. In contrast, the area is surrounded by garbage-strewn lots with torched cars next to gutted houses _ the dismal South Bronx that writer Tom Wolfe used as the setting for his novel ``The Bonfire of the Vanities.'' ``It was a ghost town before Father G. built this and got parishioner support,'' adds Negron, who was baptized in the church. ``This neighborhood was terrible, the houses were down, everything was bad, there was nothing,'' says Rsa Serra. ``Father G. is good, I know him for 20 years. The neighborhood is good now, and he did it, through faith.'' Nonetheless, last year, a Manhattan grand jury began investigating whether the Hunt's Point housing revolution may have included inflated bids and kickbacks to organized crime. It subpoenaed SEBCO's financial records for the past three years, court sources said. SEBCO's offices are near the church rectory, where the priest lived for years. Now, he reportedly commutes in a Cadillac, or another of his six cars, to several apartments in Manhattan and an upstate country home. Sometimes he flies to a condominium in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NEW YORK: Puerto Rico.
DOC.TEXT: Tax records show he personally owns SEBCO Management, the company that oversees SEBCO-built real estate. It's only one of at least a half dozen companies with varying addresses and different names _ all sharing the ``SEBCO'' root _ that are listed in the Bronx telephone directory. The priest-politician vehemently denies ever being directly investigated, and authorities have never officially linked him with any organized crime family. But SEBCO, according to a report in the Village Voice last year, has steered about $50 million in government-financed construction to companies with alleged ties to the Genovese crime family. Louis Gigante, through a SEBCO spokeswoman, refused to be interviewed. Gigante has said he's tired of reporters' references to his brother and crime. The priest reportedly says the Mafia doesn't exist. But authorities say Vincent ``The Chin'' Gigante is every bit as ruthless as the better-known John Gotti, his organized crime archrival as the reputed head of the Gambino family. Though some say he is mentally deranged, and he wears a bathrobe, pajamas and slippers as he rambles through the streets of Greenwich Village, Jules J. Bonavolonta, the FBI's mob and narcotics chief, says Gigante is ``crazy like a fox.'' ``As far as we're concerned, he's still the boss of the family,'' Bonavolonta said. While his brother turned to the priesthood, ``The Chin'' chose a life among criminals. In his teens, he became a protege of mobster Vito Genovese. He was arrested seven times between the ages of 17 and 25, though most of the charges were dismissed. Eventually, Vincent Gigante came to be regarded as an enforcer of Genovese orders. He was charged with attempted murder after a botched hit on crime boss Frank Costello. He got off when Costello refused to testify against him. He was jailed in 1959 for five years on a narcotics conspiracy charge. Eleven years later, he was charged with trying to bribe the police force of Old Tappan, N.J., but avoided prosecution by pleading mental incompetence. Now, federal prosecutors believe they've finally nailed The Chin. He is among 15 members of four mob families charged with monopolizing the installation of windows in city housing projects since 1978, accompanied by kickbacks to organized crime. But Gigante's lawyer, Barry Slotnick, says, ``His mental state is such that he couldn't be the boss of a candy store.'' Earlier this year, Louis Gigante and the Gigante family filed legal papers to have Vincent declared incompetent, and his finances placed in their hands. Later, they dropped their application, decrying the attention it had drawn. Two other Gigante brothers, Mario and Ralph, also are said to be Genovese soldiers. But Louis Gigante has not distanced himself from his wayward kin. Last year, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., conceded the Rev. Gigante had appealed to him on behalf of Mario, who was serving an eight-year prison sentence on loan-sharking charges. Louis Gigante reportedly argued that his brother's prison sentence was too long. D'Amato said he spoke to then-U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani in 1984 and 1985 on behalf of the Gigantes. He was passing on his ``concern'' for a priest to the prosecutor's office, D'Amato said. At the altar of the 80-year-old Gothic-style church where he has celebrated Mass for 28 years, Gigante blesses kneeling parishioners while ceiling fans stir the air. Thick gold bracelets hang from the priest's wrists. As far as his parishioners are concerned, Gigante can do little wrong. And he has ridden out storms that would have sent other priests scurrying to a monastery. Last year he created a media blitz by posting $25,000 of his own money to bail out Kevin Richardson, a teen-ager charged in the April 1989 gang-rape of a jogger in Central Park. ``An angel came to us,'' said Howard Diller, the lawyer for Richardson, whose Baptist family in Harlem couldn't afford the money. ``Rich people and gangsters shouldn't be the only ones who are freed on high cash bail.'' ``These are 14-year-olds. I don't want them to rape again,'' Gigante told his congregation. Jail is not a good place to rehabilitate delinquent youths, he explained to his flock. After the morning Mass, the priest hugged and kissed parishioners, smiling at them as they left through the church door that overlooks a new square. Its surface is brick-laid and swept clean, thanks to him.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ She was truly an innocent abroad, a New York City girl with little command of the French language and even less skilled in home repair. That nothwithstanding, she and a friend bought a 180-year-old house in rural France. When she set out to try to make it livable the do-it-yourself way, she found herself in a heap of trouble, even running afoul of the law.

First, there was a bag hanging from our doorknob with lettuce so fresh from the ground a snail was still crawling through its leaves. Then a white-haired country woman in her faded print smock and heavy shoes showed up in person to offer a ``promenade'' through the village to her vegetable garden. As we made our way down the rutted, dirt road, she tried to teach a city girl from Manhattan the names in French of the trees and flowers that I couldn't even identify in English. I also picked up that day the misdirections that got me arrested by three gendarmes and hauled before the mayor for illegal dumping. And so it went for the next two weeks: Me and my adopted home coming to grips with each other, what one might call the gentrification of a tiny village in southwestern France and the frenchification of me. An English friend and I had bought the house together in the spring of 1989. We did it on an impulse, a whim. For one thing, it was cheap. The 180-year-old, four-story, stucco and stone house with its red tile roof and electricity and proper plumbing cost little more than, say, an American minivan. And taxes are only several hundred dollars a year. So here I was a year later, coming to claim my new home: a New York City apartment dweller who can't find the start button on her own vacuum cleaner, thinking all I needed to do for a house beautiful was find a flea market and proceed to buy French country antiques. I was armed with a long-ago D in college French and a blue plastic tool kit shaped like a briefcase that I ordered from an upscale catalog _ the screwdrivers and pliers all had coordinated yellow handles. And I had my 81-year-old mother in tow to help me select the antiques. The village has 500 residents, a church, a post office, a city hall, an elementary school, a tiny grocery, a gold statue of the Virgin and a World War I monument topped by a gold chicken, or some manner of bird. The monument sits at the top of a tiny dirt square dominated by trees and large wooden geometic shapes that are either art or a children's jungle gym. The hub of the village is a big, open, sun-drenched space that for some reason makes me think of Gary Cooper and ``High Noon.'' Nothing happens there much except a couple of times a day when a merchant comes through to peddle olives or fish or shoes from his truck. The houses, crammed in close and facing each other on narrow, crooked streets, create a perpetual shade. There is no restaurant, no filling station. The boulangerie is open only a few hours in the morning for fresh bread and croissants. If you don't get there early, everything is sold, or reserved. There's also the wine cooperative, the raison d'etre for this village and all the others scattered through this area that cups around the western shore of the Mediterranean, from the low-land deltas south to the Spanish border and from the foothills and craggy rock cliffs north to Marseille. Each village cooperative has its own wine label. Bar owners and local residents alike come in with any sort of container, large or small, and get filled up from a hose attached to one of the huge stainless steel vats. The area was settled by the Romans and the mentality of living in something of a circle, behind walls, still prevails. Outside the walls, the families of Ceyras each own their own plot among the tilled and blooming gardens cascading down the side of a hill that drops off into the Herault River. Their vineyards are generally beyond the village, if they still till them. The old vintners are dying off, price supports for wine have dropped and the young sons and grandsons all seem to want Paris. So the English and other Europeans from unsunny climes have discovered that these old farmers' vacant and often neglected homes offer rare bargains in an otherwise outrageously expensive France. Never a farmer's daughter, I had nonetheless come home. And it was a rough two weeks: The culture shock had as much to do with unaccustomed labor, broken fingernails and plaster dust that coated my hair like a lacquer as it had to do with rural living in a language I couldn't speak.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
CEYRAS, France: couldn't speak.
DOC.TEXT: I fell asleep each night, often in my dirty work clothes, in a panic that my brain was going to explode rather than accept one more new word or sensation. Trying to buy paint remover is a major project: You can't tell the salesperson what you want because you don't know the word, so you wander around searching for something that looks likely, then you get out the dictionary and start trying to read all the labels. It took several days to get settled in with the proper gaskets for the generic wine bottles I finally located in a junk store. I proudly took them to the winery carrying them in a wire rack such as milkmen used for home deliveries during the days when they did that sort of thing, only to be shown, not told, that the loosely attached ceramic corks would leak unless I had a washer. The amused attendant at the cooperative told me the French word, rondelle, but it took two trips to the hardware store to get the right size. I learned to distinguish the slight difference between the French words for stove and hot water heater. And I learned for the first time in any language the difference between plaster and plasterboard _ the plaster was what was in my hair. Things got better for my hair after I finally figured out how to ask Monsieur Boisseau, my across-the-street neighbor, if he knew someone I could hire to strip wallpaper and knock plaster off old beams. It was that plaster that got me arrested. My wonderful worker, Jean Claude, was knocking it off lickety-split and we were ankle deep in the powdery stuff. As I'd fret about what to do with it, he'd repeat we needed a ``petite camion,'' which I took to be a pickup. He assumed I didn't understand, but actually I had no idea how to go about getting one. Finally, with the help of Madame Rieufregier, the garden lady, we decided to scoop the broken plaster into heavy-duty fertilizer bags she saves and haul it in my spanking clean rented car. Mrs. Rieufregier told us where ``riverains'' (residents) could dump, and I thought she said at the west edge of the village. But at Jean Claude's direction, we landed up on the east. The gendarmes got there right after we did. If you think American cops are bad, chasing after speeders and illegal parkers when they should be arresting drug pushers and other manner of crooks, just remember this story of three gendarmes wasting more than two hours with me in their van being grilled about my broken plaster. They checked me through their computer to see if the car was stolen. They asked me how much I paid the worker, how long I'd known him, then something else about pay. When I said ``yes,'' thinking they were asking if I would pay his fine, I really got a grilling. We went around that two or three times, and they kept using the word ``fiche,'' which normally is some sort of a bill, when all the sudden my head went ``whoa.'' It hit me that I might have an illegal immigrant on my hands, or maybe I was supposed to be paying payroll taxes. Finally, I just put my hands out in front of me, wrists close together. Who knows the word for handcuffs, but it's a universal gesture. They laughed and took me to the mayor. Not before, I might add, one of them asked me in a most acerbic tone: ``Il n'ya pas d'ecologie en Amerique?'' You didn't have to speak much French to catch the sarcasm and pointed intent that ``there's no ecology in America?'' meant flibbertigibbet foreigners bent on running around despoiling the French countryside were in for a hassle. Despite all my pratfalls, the signs were encouraging. The mayor laughed and shook my hand when I apologized for my legal transgressions. The cops got a good laugh when I told his honor I was ``enchanted to make your acquaintance,'' a stilted phrase straight out of French 1A. Several local men hanging out in a garage gossiping and smoking cigarettes teased me as I passed by about how I seemed to relish the local wine. The caretaker at the cooperative gave me a bottle of champagne on my last day, apparently in appreciation of what a good customer I'd been. It all came, I suspect, from that promenade through the village with Madame Rieufregier. All the old ladies were sticking their heads out their windows, or making it a point to pass by and say ``bonjour.'' Madame Rieufregier told me she ``had 70 years'' and that she had been born in this village. One couldn't ask for a better sponsor than that.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Cape Cod, that storied Massachusetts retreat by the sea, is still not without its charm. But it's a paradise threatened by the bulldozer and concrete mixer and local residents have begun to fight back.

You can still drive to the corner of Irving and Scudder avenues in Hyannis Port and peek down at the white-shingled Kennedy compound, nestled on rolling green lawns overlooking the broad expanse of Lewis Bay. The neighborhood of large, stately summer homes, which includes a tiny red post office and a weathered dock at the end of the street, looks almost exactly as it did the summer before John F. Kennedy was elected president 30 years ago. But less than two miles away in downtown Hyannis, the landscape has changed dramatically _ and not necessarily for the better. As a result, Cape Cod residents have approved a sweeping new measure that they hope will curb helter-skelter growth and restore some of the area's rural charm. ``It's a pigpen here,'' says Alexander Theroux, a Yale professor and writer who has lived in West Barnstable since 1974. ``When I moved here, it was a lovely place.'' Route 132, once a pastoral road linking Hyannis with the rest of Cape Cod, is now a dizzying strip of fast-food restaurants, billboards and shopping malls. Construction is almost complete on the enormous, and controversial, Christmas Tree Plaza. Traffic is often backed up for miles. Elsewhere on the Cape, a flat, sandy peninsula attached to mainland Massachusetts by two bridges spanning the Cape Cod Canal, signs of trouble are everywhere: Contaminated shellfish beds. Ponds tainted by acid rain. Overflowing dumps. Ground water pollution. The intersection at one corner in Harwich is called the ``Dust Bowl'' by locals because of the swirling dust kicked up by a 24-acre construction site for an office and shopping center that has been stripped bare for two years. ``I miss the tranquillity and independence that used to be out here,'' says Jack Smith, 65, the owner of Jack's Outback restaurant in Yarmouth and a 50-year resident of the Cape. ``I miss dirt roads and I miss pulling out onto Main Street knowing there wouldn't be anyone coming in either direction.'' The population on the Cape, a 67-mile strip that runs from near Plymouth out to Provincetown, has swollen in the last two decades. In 1960, the oldest town on the Cape, Sandwich, had 2,000 residents; now it numbers 16,000 and is still growing. Many Cape Cod residents, weary of the mini-golf outlets and Kandy Korner shops that have sprung up to accommodate the influx of tourists, have decided it's time to take action. In March, they approved the Cape Cod Commission Act, which resulted in the formation of a county commission to regulate development on a regional basis. Up until now, the 15 towns that comprise the Cape have overseen development on an individual basis. The 19-member land use and planning commission is designed to control developments that will affect the region and protect critical natural and man-made resources. The commission is not unlike other regional and statewide planning agencies around the country. The Adirondacks State Park in New York, Lake Tahoe, Pine Barrens, N.J., and Martha's Vineyard island off Cape Cod are areas with similar policies. The California Coastal Commission regulates coastal development along the coast. The Cape Cod Commission also borrowed heavily from Florida's statewide land-use policy. Proponents hope that the roughly 70,000 acres of developable land left on Cape Cod will be more stringently monitored. ``People said we're sick of growth and development and we're sick of the dismantling of Cape Cod,'' says Susan Nickerson, executive director of the Association for the Preservation of Cape Cod, formed in 1968 when residents became alarmed over a proposal to cut a waterway into Nauset Marsh for oil tankers. Some of the statistics compiled by the group: _The Cape Cod population growth is 10 times the state average. _The number of housing units on the Cape has doubled in the past 20 years. _More open space was lost on the Cape during the 1980s than any other region in the state. _The average home price on the Cape has tripled just in the past decade. _About 6,000 acres of shellfish beds remain closed, an eightfold increase in just eight years. Most of those statistic apply to the so-called ``upper Cape,'' the communities around Hyannis and to the west. The lower Cape, which is the farthest from the mainland and includes more rural areas such as Truro and the art colony of Provincetown, has escaped what one environmental activist called the ``schlock'' of the upper Cape. ``It's a special place,'' says Nickerson, a lifelong Cape Cod resident. ``It shouldn't be turned into Long Island.'' But real estate developers disagree. They contend the Cape Cod Commission will drive up prices for single-family homes and hamper the right of landowners to develop their properties. ``The Cape thrives on the building business,'' says Nick Franco, a Cape Cod developer for 17 years who has projects in Hyannis and Marstons Mills. ``The sad part is that there is a very little supply of land. When you take that supply away from developers, there will be a lot fewer homes and they'll be a lot more expensive. A lot of the working people will have to leave Cape Cod.'' But Franco says it's a ``misconception'' that all developers opposed the commission. He voted for the commission, he says, because he knew he would profit from the sudden crackdown on development. ``Land is becoming dearer because of this,'' Franco says. ``The day after the vote, every one of my lots became worth 15 percent more.'' Environmentalists, including former U.S. Sen. Paul Tsongas, who has a home on the Cape, dismisses claims that housing will become too expensive, saying the real mission is to preserve the quality of life on the Cape. ``Left unchecked Cape Cod would lose its character,'' says Tsongas, who chaired a committee that recommended a moratorium on building on the Cape. ``It's one of the few places in the country that really have a separate identity. The concern was that Cape Cod was beginning to look like everything else.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ No other spot in Japan has quite the cachet of the Ginza in Tokyo. It's a paradise for hedonists, an elegant shopping center, a place where dinner can cost $800 a plate. It's also a place where Oriental traditions persist, where businessmen stay in touch with their local gods.

Thumping drums, wooden clappers and eerie flute music draw the people of the neighborhood out to watch as shopkeepers parade a golden shrine through the streets, oblivious to the honking horns of backed-up traffic. Each year the Ginza's busy shopkeepers put aside their work for a few hours to celebrate their local gods, seeking protection from calamity for the world's most expensive neighborhood. The Ginza is Japan's Fifth Avenue, Bond Street, Champs Elysees all wrapped into one. Its deluxe department stores cater to Japanese matrons and a steady stream of tourists. Its bars and restaurants offer any type of cuisine in practically any imaginable setting. It also is home to 3,615 people who keep their traditions alive on land costing as much as $23,700 a square foot. By day, the Ginza's urban landscape is brightened only by luxurious window displays and weeping willows and maples along quiet side streets. By night, the neon lights of hundreds of pubs, restaurants and ``hostess bars'' transform the district into a glittering paradise of female companionship, good food and drink for men with deep pockets or hefty expense accounts. No other spot in Japan has quite the cachet of the Ginza. Since the turn of the century this tiny district squeezed between the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Bay has been THE place to be. Hundreds of optimistic shopping streets throughout Japan bear the name ``Ginza,'' but none match its opulence or prestige. Four hundred years ago, the Ginza was under Tokyo Bay. In 1603, one of Japan's most powerful shoguns, Tokugawa Ieyasu, moved to Tokyo, then known as Edo. He ordered part of the bay filled in. Under a later shogun, a silver mint, or ``ginza'' in Japanese, bequeathed the district its prophetic name. At the time, it was an earthy market and entertainment district. After fires destroyed posh shops and villas slightly to the north, shopkeepers moved into the Ginza. Some have been there ever since. The Ginza itself has risen, phoenix-like, from ashes several times, each time becoming more modern and Western. A fire in 1869, shortly after rulers in the modernizing Meiji era declared that Japan would learn from the West, cleared the way for tree-lined avenues of London-style brick buildings. Just a few feet of those brick walls remain intact. The Western-style shops crumbled and burned in 1923 when a powerful earthquake leveled most of Tokyo. All but a few of the buildings constructed after that disaster were destroyed by U.S. firebombing during World War II. Today, only a few prewar buildings remain, and most of the buildings thrown up just after the war have been torn down to make way for modern structures. Most conform to an eight-story limit imposed to reduce earthquake and fire hazards and to give everyone at least a glimpse of sunshine. Ginza's night life, its department stores and small shops all have an air of cosmopolitan elegance. There are shoe stores with names like Washington and America, London-style tailors, Parisian brasseries and cafes, and some 250 art galleries crowded into an area only about 1,100 yards by 650 yards. Beneath the veneer of Western commerce, however, the Ginza is as Japanese as its kabuki theaters. In the morning, shopkeepers fastidiously sweep in front of their stores, wipe windows and splash the sidewalks to keep the dust down. When department stores open to waiting crowds in the morning, uniform-clad clerks bow deeply and say, ``Irrashaimase'' _ Welcome. Well-established department stores, with names like Wako, Mitsukoshi, Matsuzakaya and Matsuya, sell designer dresses and caviar, but they also sell tofu, sushi and dried fish and have tiny shrines or temples on their roofs to consecrate their businesses. Naohisa Nagai, 42, is the eighth generation in his family to run the Echigoya kimono shop, which has been in the Ginza since 1800. ``People have worn kimono for ages. Now, they only wear them for special purposes, such as ceremonies or in certain professions. But even if the number of customers falls, the number of shops like ours is also falling, so we can stay in business,'' Nagai says. On weekend afternoons, when Ginza Dori, the main street, is closed to traffic, families and dating couples crowd the sidewalks and shops, continuing a tradition of ``ginbura,'' or strolling on the Ginza. In the evenings, sidewalk vendors, left over from the times when night markets filled the streets, still sell noodles and grilled rice cakes, wind chimes, flowers, candy and toys. Palmists and fortunetellers wait serenely for customers. Beefy sumo wrestlers in robes and wooden sandals stride among suit-clad businessmen and women in fancy dresses or kimono, all headed for bars where a single drink could cost $127 or more. In east Ginza, powerful businessmen and politicians gather in exclusive, traditional restaurants, called ``ryotei,'' that charge $800 a person or more for a single meal. Rickshaws carry geisha girls, many aged but still elegant masters of traditional dance and music, between the secretive, tan stucco buildings, with their miniature gardens at the entrances. In recent years the Ginza's less expensive wine bars and restaurants have drawn growing crowds of young Japanese. ``This is the best it's ever been,'' says Yuji Ishimaru, who has run the Ginza Street Association of local merchants for 31 years. ``The young people really love the old atmosphere, and the older men don't seem to mind being crowded out. They want new generations to follow them.'' The Ginza's population, mostly concentrated in its less glamorous eastern half, has fallen from 8,344 in 1970 to 3,615 this year as inheritance taxes and high land costs forced shop owners to sell out, leaving only a few die-hards, tiny shops sandwiched between modern buildings, to fight land developers. In his office, Ishimaru, 53, proudly displays photographs of a local festival and a neighborhood visit to the nearby Imperial Palace to pay respects to the emperor. ``We are all children of our local diety and of the emperor,'' he says. ``That remains very important to me.''

DOC.TEXT: Rick Dees, the Los Angeles radio personality who is taking his wacky style of comedy into the late-night TV wars, says he won't be a copycat. ``Into the Night Starring Rick Dees'' debuts Monday, July 16, and will be seen every weekday night on ABC at 12 midnight after ``Nightline.'' That makes Dees the latest entrant into the late-night battle for audiences with Johnny Carson on NBC's ``The Tonight Show,'' NBC's ``Late Night With David Letterman'' and ``Arsenio,'' the syndicated show starring Arsenio Hall. The latest in a long list of casualties was Pat Sajak, whose CBS show was canceled after little more than a year. Dees was voted the nation's No. 1 radio personality for six years by Billboard magazine. His morning show on Los Angeles radio station KIIS-FM is first in the Arbitron radio ratings. He's also the nation's highest-paid radio personality. Dees, like his predecessors, says he's not in competition with the established shows. In fact, he says he would like Carson, Letterman and Hall to be guests on his show. ``I think the approach we're taking is not to copy what's gone before,'' Dees says. ``I'd describe our show as one that's primarily comedy with regular features. We'll have the hottest music, and we'll endeavor to have the hottest guests we can get, but the show will not be guest-driven. We're going to give away money for guessing such things as the mystery oldie song. ``I want to represent things that are good. If I can make people feel better at that time of the night we'll be successful. We're going to have four senior citizens picked from around the country sitting on lawn chairs and voicing their opinions.'' Dees is host of a morning radio show on KIIS and the nationally syndicated ``Rick Dees Weekly Top 40.'' His record ``Disco Duck'' sold more than 4 million copies in 1976. Since then he's had four hit comedy albums. He's the voice of Rock Dees on ``The Flintstones'' and of Rocket Rick in the upcoming ``The Jetsons: The Movie.'' He had a small role in the movie ``La Bamba.'' ``My favorite voice was Mel Blanc,'' he says. ``He did some voices for me, and that tape is one of my most prized possessions.'' Dees grew up in Greensboro, N.C., and started in radio in Birmingham, Ala., and Memphis before coming to Los Angeles in 1980. ``After a year my station went to a country format and I was out of work,'' he says. ``Hollywood let me know real fast you have to pay your dues first. I couldn't get a job for a year. I called KIIS and told the station manager I'd do anything for a chance to do a show. He said, `Thanks for your interest, but why don't you go back where you came from.' ``I couldn't understand that kind of attitude. Funny is funny. It doesn't matter where you are or where you're from.'' Three months later, the station had a new manager and Dees eventually got his chance. His show, beginning in 1984, broke all Arbitron ratings. ``Into the Night'' will feature announcer Lisa Canning, Billy Vera and the Beaters band and two repertory comedy players, Greg Binkley and Bob Perlow. It will be taped every night before an audience at the ABC studios for its late-night showing. This represents a new venture for ABC, which has not had a regular late-night show, other than the news show ``Nightline,'' since 1975. Dick Cavett and Jimmy Breslin alternated as hosts of late-night talk shows. In 1980-82, ABC had ``Fridays'' on one night a week. Cavett also had a talk show in the 1970s, followed by ``The ABC Wide World of Entertainment.'' ABC tested three other concepts over a period of three years before deciding to go ahead with Dees' show. ``They told me we were starting from zero,'' he says. ``They said I had seven viewers and would have to build on that. People ask me what audience I'm going after. I turn that around and say I'm going after as wide an audience as possible. Then, after I've been on a while, you tell me what my audience is.'' Dees says he compares his comedy style to Ernie Kovacs, a television pioneer whose original and zany comedy probably influenced many performers and writers. His wife, Julie Dees, has created much of the material for the new show. ``Boy, if I could get as lucky as Ernie Kovacs did with Edie Adams, wouldn't that be great,'' he says.

DOC.TEXT: In the world of set and costume design, Santo Loquasto is one of Broadway's big guns. He has taken home a Tony Award two years in a row to prove it. Last year, his atmospheric re-creation of an old theatrical hangout on New York's Lower East Side for ``Cafe Crown'' was named Broadway's best set design. So realistic was the setting that it now sits in storage in New Jersey while plans are made to use its dark wooden bar, tables and chairs in a real-life restaurant. This year, Loquasto's stylish 1920s wardrobe for the employees and guests of the musical ``Grand Hotel'' picked up the best-costume award. No word on whether the bellhop outfits are wanted by Hilton or Hyatt. And the man can talk with feeling about the profession that has been his life for some 30 years. Ask him, for example, about what makes a good costume, and the shaggy, bearded Loquasto speaks with authority. ``It's all about telling stories,'' he said the other day during an interview at Barbara Matera Ltd., the shop which made the costumes for ``Grand Hotel.'' ``A good costume tells us an appropriate amount of information about the character, but not necessarily everything,'' the designer says. ``You might not want too much revealed. For example, you might not want the villain to be twirling a mustache and cane.'' The 45-year-old designer doesn't work just in the theater. He has also made a name for himself in dance, collaborating with choreographers such as Jerome Robbins and Twyla Tharp, and in the movies, where directors such as Woody Allen depend on his sharp eye. Good costumes, he adds, take in practical considerations, too _ like movement and comfort. For dance or for musical theater, he says, you want to reveal or expand upon a performer's movement, not obscure it. ``Revealing it in the purest sense would be wearing as little as possible,'' Loquasto says. ``Or revealing as clean a line as possible by adding a shirt or a skirt or whatever which has the right weight or movement to it so that the costume will float or swing or cling.'' Loquasto's design career began at age 15, when the stage-struck youth got a job doing sets and costumes for a summer theater in the Poconos. He was born in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and later raised in Easton and Bethlehem. Mom ran a beauty shop; dad was a salesman. The only show-business connection was a great aunt who had worked in silent-film Keystone Kops comedies. Loquasto hasn't stopped working in the theater since those summer stock days. After graduation from King's College in Wilkes-Barre, there were journeys to the Yale School of Drama to study design and an apprenticeship at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts as well as a lot of work in regional theaters such as Hartford Stage and Long Wharf, both in Connecticut. Broadway first saw his designs in the 1970s. Among his successes were ``That Championship Season'' and ``American Buffalo.'' He won his first Tony Award for costumes in 1977 for the Lincoln Center production of ``The Cherry Orchard.'' Besides Loquasto, ``Grand Hotel'' has two experienced production designers _Tony Walton who did the massive, two-tiered unit set of reflective pillars and Jules Fisher, who handled the lighting. Loquasto joined the musical last summer after director Tommy Tune began a workshop production. In the workshop, the actors wore their own clothes, augmented by hats and overcoats. At the time, the script for the show, which is set in 1928 Berlin, still was evolving, and Tune didn't want the designer to rely on it. ``All I had to go on was a cast breakdown,'' Loquasto recalls. ``Tommy and I went through it at a meeting. He said what he thought about the characters and what he thought was important to know about them. ``There also were certain images that Tommy and Tony had already hit upon and that they thought were wonderful _ pictures of bellhops and certain books on Berlin,'' the designer says. ``So I just sort of collected all this stuff and started working.'' Because ``Grand Hotel'' is a relatively spartan unit, a one-set production, it is the livery in the hotel which gives the audience a sense of architectural detail in many ways, according to Loquasto. ``The form of the lobby was punctuated by the arrangement of bellhops and other hotel staff members,'' he says. The designer used the same color _ many shades of brown extending almost to a rusty red _ to suggest to theatergoers the flavor of a luxury hotel. ``It's not something that hits you over the head, but it does fill out the space and expand on it,'' he says. ``In `Grand Hotel,' we also did not want to have masses of clothing,'' Loquasto adds. ``People don't really change their costumes a lot. It's not like a huge show. It's less than 50 costumes. What they have are spats and shoes and hats and gloves and cuff links and overcoats. It's a big overcoat production. ``The hardest costumes in `Grand Hotel' were the secretaries','' he says. ``Historically, those uniforms were not very attractive, and I wanted the girls to look terrific and be very individual. We did it in the subtleties of the fit and the fabric so that the dresses moved quite well even though they looked like rather dowdy uniforms.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: An Attorney's Fashion
LaserPhoto NY700
DOC.TEXT: Gloria Allred's wardrobe could be jam-packed with Chanel and Armani, but the polished-looking attorney emphatically declines to pack it that way. After all, she doesn't need a $1,000 sweater when she could spend the same money helping a woman become governor or to further AIDS research. A fashion fantasy is still a dream for this feminist. That would be comfortable, attractive, practical and lower-priced clothes. ``If women knew how to have a revolution on the price issue alone, they would,'' says Allred, who characteristically sniffs out sales. Many agree with Allred that clothing choice for women is limited by finances, figure flaws, and fashion designers who may not always heed the call of the consumer. Even devout fashion mavens can't toss away last season's outfits simply at the whim of designers who dictate the look of the moment. Ask Allred what she wears and she'll glibly tell you, ``It's whatever's back from the dry cleaners,'' a response that belies her deliberately calculated approach to dressing. Press the subject, and she'll offer, ``I always view fashion as a political statement,'' a not surprising response from this Los Angeles lawyer, known for battling for sex equality. Time Magazine called her ``one of the nation's most effective advocates of family rights and feminist causes,'' and Lear's deemed her ``Lady Civil Liberty....a combination of Rocky and the Rockettes.'' Indeed, Allred is widely considered one of the most accomplished and prominent attorneys in the country. She founded and currently serves as president of the Women's Equal Rights Legal Defense and Education Fund. She also offers weekly political commentary on KABC News in Southern California. Surely you wouldn't expect her to hold forth on the beauty of frilly little floral prints and Peter Pan collars. And don't expect her to discuss techniques for building and updating one's wardrobe. She'd sooner zero in on the consumer's plight and just what's wrong with the nation's fashion and beauty industry. ``I often ask myself who's designing for the American working woman,'' says Allred. ``There's no democracy in the world of fashion. Designers switch styles every season to sell their goods. Prices are completely unrealistic for the consumer. It's a planned obsolescence. They're designing to meet their own needs, not the needs of the public.'' Allred has developed her own style for an answer to the dilemma. She chooses suits that have timeless appeal. St. John knits occupy a portion of her closet because of their practicality. ``I can wear them for years. They're high quality, look nice throughout the day and pack well,'' she says. With her jet-black hair and porcelain complexion, she creates a powerful, commanding image in her knit suits. Her name, in fact, says it all: The favorite color of this fiercely flamboyant advocate is red. Women still lack fashion freedom and independence, she insists. ``As much as we talk about equality in the workplace, women to this day are required to comply with an unwritten dress code that they must wear dresses or skirts on the job. We're forced to wear the costume of our sex. It's a gender uniform. Women wear skirts, and men wear slacks.'' Allred nonetheless does not wear pants to court since ``it would make my clothes an issue for the judge and jury.'' Instead, she wears a suit with a skirt just below the knee. Her business clothes are sensible and shaped, but not form-fitting. ``I don't think many men would put up with being restricted in a tight skirt,'' she says. There are political overtones to practically everything in a woman's closet, in Allred's view. Take shoes, for example: ``My theory is that if your shoes don't allow you to run away quickly from a rapist, you shouldn't be wearing them.'' Allred once was raped at gunpoint and nearly died after a subsequent illegal abortion. She wears shoes with a medium to low heel, partly for comfort, and partly because she thinks a jury wants to see an attorney in a business-like image. Sexy high heels would be inappropriate. ``One of the most interesting issues for a jury to discuss among themselves is what the lawyer is wearing, and I always want to do whatever is appropriate to win the case.'' Then there's her view on pantyhose: ``They're the ultimate example of lack of practicality. Think about spending $4 to $5 for something that is not made to last _ men would never put up with such a consumer ripoff.'' And handbags: ``The two most liberating acts a woman can perform are to buy comfortable shoes and a big handbag.'' Allred thinks that makeup and cosmetics need greater regulation by the Food and Drug Administration. Nail polish, for example, contains formaldehyde, a carcinogen, and ``women have no idea what they're putting on their bodies.'' Its a complicated enterprise for any woman to get herself together, she says. ``I have great admiration for the American working woman, when I think about how she survives each day. She has to think about what she'll wear, makeup, shoes, underwear, stockings. ``We women have problems men don't even think about.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Britain's Bloc Chic
LaserPhotos NY701, NY702
DOC.TEXT: After the revolution, Eastern Europe is suddenly chic. Polish restaurants are favored by London's trendy set, Czechoslovak films play on prime-time TV and three of Britain's hottest designers are chips off the old bloc. Edina Ronay, Tomasz Starzewski and Linda Cierach have taken inspiration from their Hungarian and Polish roots _ peasant braiding, fur-trimmed waistcoats and street styles from the Cold War years _ to create collections that fuse an eastern sensibility with English swing. Although each designer has a distinctive style, all are doing booming business among London's young and well-heeled. ``Eastern Europe has been so submerged, so hidden since the war that few people realize the depth of the design traditions,'' said Mrs. Ronay, the daughter of a Budapest family of restaurateurs who still makes regular forays home to shop and see friends. ``Hungarian embroidery is extraordinary, the sequins and the waistcoats and the aprons are all so beautiful,'' she said, sitting on a cushion on the dark wood floor of her intimate King's Road store. Patterns from an old book on embroidery discovered in a Budapest antique store inspired the beading on evening jackets, capri pants and skirts in red and black that are part of her collection for next winter. Pictures in a family album of her great-great-uncle Otto in a brocade and fur-trimmed waistcoat inspired the trim on winter evening wear, she said. The 40-year-old former actress started designing clothes just five years ago. Now, she is one of Britain's best known designers with a reputation for combining the folkloric with the aristocratic. Her clients include actresses Lauren Bacall and Charlotte Rampling, and the Duchess of York, formerly Sarah Ferguson. Ronay hopes to open a shop someday in Budapest. Starzewski dreams of making clothes in Poland, where his mother was born. The darling of the daughters of the titled rich, Starzewski's specialty is kicky party clothes and his signature is the horizontal pleat. Born and raised in England, the 28-year-old designer speaks fluent Polish learned in a Polish school and from his parents, who fled Poland in the Second World War. ``My culture is from my family, books, music and art. Without doubt it's a romanticized picture and some of that feeling comes out in my clothes,'' said Starzewski, peering through stylish horn-rimmed glasses and a thoroughly European cloud of cigarette smoke. ``The Polish are very much like the French. They depend more on emotion than logic,'' he said. ``My themes are never based on history or culture, but rather on mood. I do clothes that are sensual with a bit of fun.'' His clothes this season have a slightly 1950s feel, off the shoulder and glamorous. For evening he mixes black lace with fuchsia satin, and trims a short fitted dress of horizontal pleats in khaki wool crepe with black feathers at the neck. Starzewski is building a new shop and atelier and is enjoying enormous success built on his reputation for good design and quality. The quality of his clothes he credits to his mother, Maria, who spent the war years in a military school after fleeing Poland. ``Because of her military training she is good at organizing, and she runs the shop,'' he said. ``She is also a brilliant technician. I'm competing with people 30 years older, but because of her skill our clothes are just as well made, just as well cut.'' Miss Cierach, whose Polish father served time in a Siberian labor camp, is famous for having designed the Duchess of York's sumptuous satin wedding dress. Her made-to-order evening clothes hang heavy with braid, beads and brocade. Her client list is laden with duchesses. ``I have a tremendous sense of texture and color, an affinity for anything ornate,'' she said in a telephone interview from Dallas, where she was fitting her ball gowns to the cream of Texas society. ``One of my earliest memories is of my parents' wedding photo. The bridesmaids wore the most exquisite dresses, beaded all over. It was enchanting.'' The 37-year-old designer's father recently visited Poland to tour factories where some of the collection could be made. ``The Polish are good with their hands. They are hard working. There are opportunities now to work there,'' she said. ``With all I have gained from the Polish culture, I would like to put something back.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: France
LaserPhotos NY703, NY704, NY705
DOC.TEXT: Inspiration from the bedroom, the ski slopes and the hunt ball is sparking the French fashion scene for next fall. It's also a nostalgic look back to the 1960s, with reams of beautiful folklore prints from the likes of Yves Saint Laurent and Ungaro. What was shown on the Paris runways is not necessarily what will appear on the racks of your friendly local store, even if you're in the thick of Manhattan or ranging around Malibu Beach. But smart shoppers keep in mind the novelties they've seen as inspiration from this fashion capital. Sports are currently playing big in the fashion field, as designers like Gianfranco Ferre of Dior look to the hot colors of race-course jockeys' silks. Karl Lagerfeld is current and past master of the fitted long jacket or redingote shortie coat over coltish long legs _ both for Chanel and under his own label. Ferre, too, likes these sleek redingote coats, often giving them an Edwardian dash of elegance for Dior with top hats and organza bows at the neck. But the main sports inspirations are coming from the ski slopes and Tour de France bicycle race, with drawstring parkas and skin-tight shiny cycling shorts. Shown for next winter, the shiny stretch biking gear is already a big hit on Paris streets this summer, usually worn by the under-25 set. Older Frenchwomen, even though in top form, usually have the good sense to dress rather more conservatively than their daughters and granddaughters, even though they do aim to be elegant and sexy. The current active sporting look adapted to street wear for the young comes out in short tights with long pantyhose, or long stirrup stretch pants. And jackets are all-important. They may be on the puffy taffeta side, as shown by ready-to-wear designers like Jean-Charles de Castelbajac, or versions of hooded, drawstring windbreakers, seen throughout all French collections these days. At Chanel, designer Karl Lagerfeld likes to mix up the ski-slope wear and very rich fabrics and details. His tiny minis and simply legs (alone) encased in tights with their hot-colored, important toppers make for a youthful winter line. Chanel-lovers, however, are also looking to the new cruise line shown for next winter here: it is very abbreviated, but full of excellent details, like beautifully cut short jackets, round Chanel-logo buttons matching the outfits, pearl chokers with beads larger than cherries and chain-circled button-pearl earrings bigger than the ear itself. And of course, the tight shorts, or currently fashionable pedal pushers, are given the Chanel fillip of big buttons up the side. From the bedroom come some of the late-day ideas for next fall and winter. Touches of satin and lace give discreet sexy touches to luxury ready-to-wear. Hanae Mori, the most Parisian of Japanese designers, even brought out a line of dance-hall merry widow styles, gay enough for a Toulouse-Lautrec poster. Another influence for next winter is the enthusiastic embrace of folklore, especially by leading designers like Ungaro, Saint Laurent and Christian Lacroix. The creative Lacroix never left the folklore camp: he always shows a group of prints and silks inspired by his colorful Provence home country and rich fabrics from Byzantine and Far Eastern origin. Paris is now unveiling clothes year-round, even between the big group shows. Recent out-of-season showings included a quiet comeback from the house of Rochas, which had kept a very low profile, with perfume and accessories only, after the death of Marcel Rochas in 1955. They hired an Irishman named Peter O'Brien, who worked with Marc Bohan at Dior and at Chloe, to refurbish the house image and bring out clothes with personality. His clothes for next winter are an exercise in subtility, in the high-priced category. Details are haute-couture style in the full and fitted gored long skirts, satin, lace and soft cashmere fabrics. ''This is definitely understated chic,'' says O'Brien, who believes in autumnal colors to match the ladylike styles: deep slate gray, mustard, burgundy, pine or brick and autumn-leaf red. Long and easy pants and very full skirts as shown for Rochas may be beacons for what's to come in the next generation of fashion. As Paris has come through the sharp, tailored looks, the sexy minx styles and the return to 1960s minis, it still seems floundering in what's due for the 1990s. Will the next decade of fashion be kinder and gentler to women? As more styles, fabrics and colors are being shown every season in the rush to be commercially successful, it seems that women are freer than ever to choose gentle or tough chic.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Italy
LaserPhotos NY706, NY707, NY708)
By DANIELA PETROFF
DOC.TEXT: The Italian challenge is to get into shape for a ruthless winter _ at least where fashion is concerned. Next winter's Italian hemline is so short that its average length plays around the thigh, leaving no room for such weaknesses as plump legs or _ perish the thought _ chubby knees. Most fashion followers agree that the latest Gianni Versace microskirt, whose hemline grazes the hip bone, is just too short, but at the same time his is the clearest statement that short skirts have definitely arrived. The abbreviated hemline even creeps into fashionable night life with many elegant and sequined gowns anything but floor-length. As if ultra short skirts weren't demanding enough, the winter fashion 1990-1991 Italian style also is filled with sporty shorts and bermudas as well as body-clinging rib knit jump suits, all of which sorely tax those with anything but the perfect female figure. The new winter bermudas and shorts are loose and sporty, usually in corduroy or light wool jersey, worn with dark or printed stockings and comfortable walking shoes. On the whole, the fall-winter ready-to-wear ``moda Milanese'' presented during the week-long showings in Milan, which previewed what will soon appear in fashionable boutiques around the world, is pert rather than sexy, with a heavy accent on sportswear. Gone are the tailored city suits and classic coats of past winters, replaced by sweatsuits, sport jackets, parkas, down and duffel coats and loads of knitwear, from cozy cardigans, pullovers and sweater dresses to the brand new all-knit jumpsuit. To enoble its sporty thrust, this year's winter fashion uses lots of gold detailing both for day and night. The new shape is the A-line, which appears in dresses and jackets alike. In general, shoulders are narrower, although there is no need to throw away your shoulder pads. Jackets tend to be long and loose, often ending where the skirt begins, another danger signal for anyone but the well-proportioned models who adorn the glossy pages of fashion magazines. There are plenty of trousers in the winter collections, with the 1950s pencil pants in light fabric or wool jersey the favorite style. In the passementerie department there is abundant use of silk cording, wool braiding, frines and lace trimming. Fake fur, usually cozy plush dyed and printed to resemble the real thing, is used for both trimming and lining. The designers also indulge in a variety of fake fur jackets and coats, which are a must for anyone contemplating a fashionable ski vacation. The favorite fabric for this winter is velour for both day and night. Although they have not given them up entirely, the Milan designers have looked beyond the drab browns, grays and blacks of their industrial home town to draw inspiration for their color schemes from the bright shades of a New England fall landscape or the icy pastel shades of an early winter morning. Christmas red is the newest color. However, in their efforts to create fast-track fashion for the young, sporty and beautiful, the Italian designers seem to have forgotten the working woman, offering almost no clothes she could wear to the office. Even such staid labels as Genny and Basile opted for the short hemlines and sporty parka, leaving their career woman clients in a bind. Only Giorgio Armani and Gianfranco Ferre snubbed the miniskirt, keeping their hemlines a discreet several inches above the knee. But alas, only executive level women can afford their price tags. Following in alphabetical order are a few tips of where to look for what: Armani -- exquisite daytime suits and the most feminine evening wear in delicate porcelain prints and beautiful embroidered velvet. Byblos -- cozy Irish knit sweaters with gold and floral embroidery. Ferre -- the best in the gold look from sumptuous evening wear to one-of-a-kind shimmering parkas. Genny -- suits where the jacket and the hemline of the skirt meet midway up the thigh. Krizia -- lots of cozy sweater dresses and sporty shorts. Missoni -- the best in reversible quilted duffel coats with multi-colored knit prints inspired by Russian folklore. Mario Valentino -- bright tri-colored shearling car coats. Versace -- the shortest skirt on sale and the best in the A-line style.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Fur Wars
LaserPhoto NY709
DOC.TEXT: To wear fur or not to wear fur? That is the question many New Yorkers faced this last winter as animal-rights activists mounted a major assault against the fur industry. Even as fur prices plunged and several retailers declared bankruptcy, the battered furriers fought back. Round one has ended and both sides are claiming victory. ``No question the animal rights groups have had a great deal to do with that decline,'' declares George Cave, a national director for Animal Rights Mobilization, an animal-rights group based in Williamsport, Pa. ``Their tactic is to keep sales high, but they're driving prices way down to keep sales volume at the same level,'' Cave adds. ``The movement has forced the issue to be in the media, but it hasn't changed anybody's mind,'' counters Lili Glassman, a spokeswoman for Saga Furs, an international fur marketing and trade association. ``In fact, the American fur industry has projected 1989 retail sales at $1.9 billion _ up from $1.86 billion for last season,'' Glassman says. The fur industry has been in trouble, but officials blame it on a worldwide glut of furs and warm winters in the United States and Japan, the two largest consumers of mink. ``Up until 1986 the fur business grew rapidly _ sales tripled in dollar volume,'' according to Glassman. ``By 1987 farmers were overproducing and at the same time we had a stock market crash and the fur market slowed _ it was a natural correction,'' Glassman explains. Nevertheless, the battle has been fierce. Anti-fur demonstrations were held across the nation, especially on Nov. 25, a date designated by the animal-rights movement as Fur Free Friday. That day, Bob Barker, host of the game show ``The Price is Right,'' led 2,500 protestors in a march down Fifth Avenue. Barker, a longtime animal-rights activist, resigned as host of the Miss USA pageant over its award of a fur to the winner. Four fur shops were vandalized in Miami and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Dozens of other cities were hit with protests, including Beverly Hills' ritzy shopping district. The issue even went prime-time when the television series ``L.A. Law'' aired a show that presented Canadian trappers as brutes and showed animals being mangled in traps. Activists also adopted confrontational tactics. There were reports of fur wearers being jeered at, sprayed with ketchup or red paint, and even having their coats slashed. ARM, formerly known as Trans-Species Unlimited, says it doesn't condone violence. ``It was a couple of isolated incidents,'' Cave says. ``We don't advocate any kind of illegal activity.'' The fur industry used the vandalism incidents for propaganda purposes and character assassination, according to Cave, who says he believes the strategy backfired. The fur industry also downplays the attacks on fur wearers. ``There might have been a few incidents of spray painting _ more a scare tactic to make people think they might do it,'' says Glassman. All this has changed the industry's promotional strategy to emphasize a fur wearers' freedom of choice and the humane aspects of the industry. When Barker called the nation's fur farms ``animal concentration camps,'' fur farmers responded by saying that American fur farms receive the highest standards of care of any farm animals in the world. ``An animal's coat is a clear signal of well-being,'' Glassman said. ``The animals must be taken care of very well in order to produce quality fur.'' The industry also has attacked the animals rights activists as extremists who don't believe in using animals for anything, including clothing, meat, entertainment, and even AIDS research. ``The fur industry is a matter of freedom of choice, and these people want to take away their freedom of choice and their right to wear fur without intimidation,'' says Glassman. Round two is about to begin.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Parisian Furs
DOC.TEXT: Fur real? Or just fur fun? Everything from sable to fake lamb is part of Paris style. No matter that winters have been warm for several seasons, driving some furriers out of business. The top furriers and couturiers are doing well with the real thing and with fakes. The French take a sanguine view of furs, and they don't throw stones at wearers of mink or fox on the street here, although the use of endangered species does raise some ecological eyebrows. Real furs have never looked more appealing, particularly at Yves Saint Laurent, whose collection was designed by Robert Merloz. Thinking mink means designers are giving it new fillips, relegating more conventional styles to grandma's closet. Merloz made a hit at the Saint Laurent winter show by shaping trapeze styles and shortie trench coats in watered silk, poplin or taffeta, then lining them with lamb or mink. He also put fun into furs by draping sable, mink or chinchilla coats with ribbons - decorative though not particularly useful in a snowstorm. Dior's top designer, Gianfranco Ferre, also sees new ways to use fur, often featuring a pyramid-shaped coat, whether in chinchilla or blackgama mink combined with lace to make dressy reversible coats. Ferre's way-out look for Persian lamb was to dye it pink and gray in flower patterns. Endangering no species at all, Ferre also came out with spotted-cat furs made from dyed lamb. And his most amusing use of astrakhan was to pattern it like chevron tweed for sharp blazers. Former Dior fur designer Frederic Castet opened up a new shop in the fashion district on Rue Pierre Charron this year and came out with an opulent collection of sportswear starring leather and furs. Though a past master of dying and patterning minks and sables, this time Castet outdid himself in a stunning finale: long minks dyed with homages to various countries - a Statue of Liberty for America, and an Eiffel Tower for France. But Castet's real coup was a soft and silky new fake fur he calls ``Castiss,'' invented, he said, to show his concern for ecological matters. This usually looked appealingly soft and white and came out in everything from duffel coats to sweeping longer fitted numbers. Another furrier whose original ideas are attracting attention is Georges Constant, whose grandfather started the family firm of Alexandre. ``I'm doing quite well overall,'' he said, ``even in just natural ranch mink jackets and coats.'' But he also loves to play around. Some women found his painted mink-tail long reversible jackets irresistible. One one side are the black mink tails in chevron patterns, on the other a flowery pattern using both the tails as outlines and painted details on the leather exterior. He not only uses all the conventional furs, including lamb, chinchilla, sable and beaver, but he's elated over a new soft fur from a new hybrid animal called an orylag. As Constant describes it, the orylag is a kind of super-rabbit, ``which I'm responsible for helping breeders create and on which I have a patent for the first years of production.'' The fur is light, soft, dyeable and looks a lot like nutria, a far more expensive fur. Constant makes terrific little evening shrugs as well as longer dressy jackets out of orylag. In many big-name couture and ready-to-wear houses fakes are taking the upper hand of the fur scene. Jean-Charles Castelbajac has always been known for his ecological approach to clothes design, and says ``I wouldn't dream of using real furs, having been revolted by what I saw at a fox farm once.'' But he adores using plush-type fakes for his duffel coats, cuddly teddy-bear sweaters and jackets. And he recently brought out a line of warm clothes with furry linings made just like French concierges' slippers. Jean-Louis Scherrer is perennially crazy about wild-animal skin themes, but he usually puts them on silk fabrics and has hardly ever used the real thing. ``I love fake furs, too, and don't believe in using genuine fur,'' says Erik Mortensen, the couture designer for the house of Balmain. His sleek spotted coats and fake fur trim look so real they could set off ecological protests. But while the sane and sound fashionable fakes are indeed less expensive than, sable or fox, they are hardly bargain-basement stuff. ``My coats indeed cost several thousand dollars,'' said Castelbajac. ``I want to make quality, and even though the furs are not real I want them to evoke luxury and a dream. Good fashion is always something out of the ordinary.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: American Campaign
LaserPhotos NY710, NY711
DOC.TEXT: A campaign to encourage consumers to buy American-made clothes has begun to pay off, according to an industry group formed to offset the impact of imports on the fashion industry. ``This is more than just `pocketbook patriotism.' It reflects American consumers' preference for U.S.-made clothing's quality, style and fit _ a preference that is also evident in many foreign cultures,'' says Robert E. Swift, executive director of the Crafted with Pride in U.S.A. Council, a nonprofit industry marketing group formed six years ago. Swift points to a study made by the Good Housekeeping Institute, which showed that 80 percent of the women interviewed rated American-made clothing as the best quality on the market. Another study by a market research firm, R. H. Bruskin Associates, showed similar approval, with 87 percent of its sampling, and Time Magazine-CNN research shows an 82 percent rating. A survey by Cambridge Reports indicates that the number of U.S. consumers who say they have not purchased a specific product because it was foreign-made has nearly doubled in the last four years. When the council coordinated ``Made in the U.S.A.'' promotions with retailers like Belk's in Charlotte, the Jones Store in Kansas City, several Dillard's locations in the Southwest, the May Company in Cleveland and Los Angeles, and Thalhimer's in Richmond, sales increases ranged up to 18 percent, according to Swift. He estimates that 350,000 jobs in the U.S. apparel industry have been lost in the past decade due to imports, and he says studies which indicate a turnaround are good news to textile and apparel makers. Dr. Michelle Morganosky of the University of Illinois School of Human Resources and Family Studies says a study she conducted shows that stores promoting U.S.-made merchandise are perceived by consumers as being higher quality than those associated with imported merchandise. ``America is rebuilding its reputation for producing quality merchandise like never before,'' says Virginia Wages-Plotkin, co-owner of Down Home America, a boutique sportwear merchandiser. ``We've re-tooled our thinking about quality, design, productivity and most important _ culture.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Denims to Wash
DOC.TEXT: American consumers buy denim jeans at an estimated 13 pairs per second, and these ubiquitous blues have become a major international fashion category, spotlighted on the runways and in the boutiques of New York, Paris, Rome, London, and Tokyo. And unlike so much other high fashion wear, this fabric _ first made in the Middle Ages at the French textile town of Nimes (``de Nimes'') _ should be washed, not dry-cleaned, say most fabric manufacturers. Denim is one of the strongest fabrics around and will not tear or show signs of wear after many washings. Real denim is 100 percent cotton with indigo blue dye that definitely will fade. Most denims today are relatively shrink-proof with Sanforizing for Sanfor-set, or by blending the cotton with polyester. Laundering techniques to get the special look you want for your jeans are outlined by specialists at the Maytag Company: _ For brand new blue denim, wash with soap or detergent in warm water and tumble dry, both on the regular fabric cycle. Dry at moderate temperature setting, and don't over-dry, since that can cause wrinkles to ``set'' or encourage shrinkage. The indigo dyes will fade during laundering, so extremely dark denim should be washed separately or washed with other deeply dyed items. _ To fade deep blue denims, use one cup of liquid chlorine bleach in the laundry water, taking care to dilute it with four parts of water to be added to the washer after agitation has started. The liquid bleach dispenser on your washing machine also can be used for this purpose. Repeat this process until you get the fade you like. _ To care for acid- or stone-washed denim, wash in warm water with soap or detergent, using the gentle machine setting and tumble dry on moderate heat. The only exception to the no-dry-cleaning rule is when the jeans are trimmed with certain kinds of appliques, sequins, leather or other decorations that can't be laundered. Each denim item you buy for your wardrobe will have a care label sewn in, since by law these labels must be attached to all clothing sold in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Denims to Watch
DOC.TEXT: Some of the season's new denim trends: _ The new ``anti-fit'' denims _ loosely structured and comfortable _ are interpreted for Guess? by Georges Marciano, to create slouch pants, wide-leg jeans and the Nathalie jeans. A gaucho version features black denim and can be paired with a suede ``rifle'' jacket. Cutoff shorts in bleached denim, worn with an embroidered western-style shirt, also have the loose, casual fit. _ A denim shirtdress with corduroy yoke, from Liz Claiborne dresses, comes in petite sizes. Its short hem is shown with high, western-flavor boots. Claiborne's version of the jeans jacket has a velvet collar over the indigo sand-washed and bleached cotton denim. Five-pocket classic jeans in black also are included in Claiborne's collection for men. _ A bit of Upper East Side chic, country division, will soon become available nationally as Down Home America, a trendy New York unisex boutique, expands across the country next year. Meanwhile, visitors to New York will find the flagship store on East 78th Street full of classic denim-western jeans and jackets, which can be paired with bright tropical and African print shirts. For eclectic tastes, there are white Edwin jeans.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Denim Facts
DOC.TEXT: Denim has a long history. Here are some highlights, culled by Levi Strauss & Co.: _ This tightly woven fabric was first made during the Middle Ages in the French textile town of Nimes. It first was called ``Serge de Nimes,'' later shortened to ``de Nimes'' and finally to ``denim.'' _ Early sailors from Genoa, Italy, characteristically wore pants made of denim, and these became known as ``genes,'' later adapted to ``jeans.'' _ The sailors from Dhunga, India, also wore denim pants. Theirs were called ``dhungarees,'' now ``dungarees.'' _ Denim was used for the sails of the Nina, Pinta and Santa Maria when Columbus' fleet sailed to the New World. _ American jeans became popular during the California Gold Rush, when a young immigrant, Levi Strauss, arrived too late for the gold. He decided to make heavy-duty pants for the miners, who complained they couldn't find clothing to withstand the rigors of their work.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Custom Cuts for Men
DOC.BYLINE: (A version of this story appeared on the financial wire.) ^By MARYBETH NIBLEY
DOC.TEXT: Wealthy and discriminating male shoppers have known the Zegna name for decades. Members of European royal families and affluent Asian businessmen have Zegna suits in their wardrobes. The Italian clothier hopes to capitalize on its cachet by opening its first American store on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. It will join a half dozen other Zegna stores located at the right ritzy addresses in foreign fashion capitals. By venturing into U.S. retailing, Zegna wants to drum up more interest in its label. The goal is to boost business for Zegna merchandise sold around the country at upscale department stores, such as Neiman-Marcus, and tony boutiques, including Ultimo in Chicago and San Francisco's Wilkes Bashford. Zegna, pronounced to rhyme with Kenya, will be following the examples of classy lines like Burberry's, Chanel, Hermes, Louis Vuitton and others that increased American consumer awareness of their goods by opening stores here. ``We like to think of ourselves in the same ilk as those companies,'' says Richard Cohen, president of Ermenegildo Zegna USA, the Italian group's American arm. The timing isn't perfect to launch into retailing. Middle-of-the road retailers have fallen by the wayside as specialty merchants have made inroads into their business. Still, Cohen is confident. High quality goods, he says, have what it takes to attract customers even in tough times. ``You continue to do well in bad economic times because you're offering value for money.'' Luxury retailers aren't immune to problems if increasing numbers of consumers convert to more conservative buying habits. But luxury really never goes out of style among people with loads of money who view every purchase _ even a new suit _ as an investment, notes John Mincarelli, a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. ``What's happened is we're finding custom tailoring is becoming a status symbol again,'' says Mincarelli. ``It always was but now it's more prevalent.'' Men's fashion guru Alan Flusser, an author, designer and store owner, believes a revival has begun in made-to-measure suits. ``As prices of men's clothes have risen precipitously, the difference between a good ready-made suit and a good custom-made suit has narrowed,'' Flusser says. ``The custom-made suit has had a rennaissance in this country.'' Indicating that a trend has developed, more retailers and manufacturers with retail outlets are upgrading their tailoring services. Some bring their fabrics and samples to offices for customers too busy for in-store shopping. The ranks of these haberdashers who make house calls has expanded recently and include such mainstream quality clothing makers as HartMarx. Zegna will offer roving tailors, too. The fitters will visit offices and elsewhere to accomodate customers needing to be measured for alterations on ready-made clothing or for custom-made suits. The store will schedule private appointments for after-hours customers. At the top of the scale, a made-to-measure suit will retail at an average price of around $1,500. A customer's measurements will be faxed to Italy where all the work will be done. Delivery is promised in four weeks. The Zegna store will stock off-the-rack suits ranging from $900 to $1,500 with free alterations done on the premises. If that's too pricey for someone keen to buy into the Zegna image, there will be casual shirts for $60 to $65 and casual slacks for $225 to $250. Ties go for about $85. Ermenegildo Zegna, named for his grandfather who built the business and known simply as Gildo, says much of what makes the company special is that it is still run by the founding family. The company, based in Trivero, Italy, oversees the production of the wool and other raw materials that Zegna weaves into fabrics that become clothing.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Menswear
LaserPhoto NY712
DOC.TEXT: Here's good news for all you hunks _ or is it hulks? _ out there. A new collection of men's clothing has been designed to accommodate the bulging biceps, fearsome forearms and wasp waists common to men who work out. ``The Gladiator collection of fashionable tailored clothing has been thoroughly thought out and designed to address this new body of men,'' says Mitchel Nichnowitz, president of Botany 500, which distributes the line. Suit jackets have 8-and 10-inch drops and feature fuller chests and shoulders to define and fit broad shoulders and backs. The sleeves are wide and the armholes are cut to fit large biceps. Trousers are fuller at the thigh and seat, though waists are smaller and have a lower rise to balance the silhouette. Conventional suits have 6-inch drops, which means a 6-inch difference between the measurement of the shoulders and that of the waist _ a size 40 jacket would be paired with trousers with a 34-inch waist. The Gladiator line pairs 42-inch jackets with 32-or 34-inch waist trousers. Popular executive-style suits, sports jackets and slacks are included in the collection. _ The country trend continues to grow, and men will find serious-casual jackets, sweaters and pants in rich soft fabrics with napped and suede finishes, in rich autumn colors, in the menswear lines at J.C. Penney stores. ``Men are ready for a break from the fast-lane, city-slick kind of look,'' says Joe Sapienza, vice president and fashion director at the chain. ``It's a whole focus on the ex-urban thing _ guys wanting to look like they're going to the country for the weekend.'' Country looks in the store's collections include soft cottons and flannels that are napped, stone-washed, sand-washed, or brushed. Denim is a big item, though, he says, not necessarily in obvious cowboy styles.
