And there is lots of leather and suede. ``The demand for suede and leather from the customer is phenomenal,'' says Sapienza. Shetland wool sweaters and jackets feature suede and leather trims for shoulder and elbow patches. Traditional patterning in sweaters remains popular, with Indian, kilim carpet, blanket, Nordic and Fair Isle predominating. Jackets are done with plaids and country checks, but not limited to the usual tans and grays; they also can be found in rich royal, pumpkin, plum, teal, green and brown tones. _ More urban but still casual is the style for men from Claiborne, featuring easy-fitting trenchcoats, blazers, bomber jackets, cuffed trousers and twill shirts. Traditional paisleys, foulards, florals and medallion prints are found in the neckwear line, and fancy shirts have rich cream backgrounds striped with navy, charcoal, antique red and willow. _

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Kidswear
LaserPhotos NY713, NY714
DOC.TEXT: Denims, bright colors and graphics continue to characterize everyday clothes for children. Like their elders, youngsters can wear status stone-washed jeans and jackets with a country-western flavor. For example, Guess? Kids is offering green denim jackets, to be worn with corduroy pants or skirts or slub blue jeans. A pair of cowboy boots from Justin Boot Company can add an authentic western touch to these outfits. _ Comfortable hooded sweatshirts, drawstring pants and over-sized sweaters for children also mimic adult wear, except that many of them have cartoon and happy face lace tips (from Brookside Enterprises) to keep the drawstrings from slipping into the casings. Called Lace Faces, they also can be added to the tips of shoelaces. _ A slight contrast to the bright colors and graphics typical of children's playwear today is Le Roi's Folk Song lines, which feature traditional ethnic patterns, including cotton wallpaper florals and paisleys, touched with gold. The company's distinctive rounded silhouettes are featured for infants in full-legged playsuits and for toddlers in jumpsuits and two-piecers. The traditional motifs are carried through on the sleepwear lines, decorated with teddy bears, bunnies and clouds in pastel shades. These are made of flame-resistant polyester in generous, roomy cuts featuring colored snaps and covered feet. _ Marika Kids' Fitness Apparel checks in with another collection of brilliant shades and bold graphics on its T-shirts, shimmels, sweatpants, shorts, leotards, tights, and tank suits. The Baryshnikov for Kids line features ballet themes, including the Cinderella story and an arabesque abstract. _

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Accessories
LaserPhoto NY715
DOC.TEXT: Because its research shows that working women have the discretionary income and desire to buy gold jewelry for themselves, Fortunoff is marketing its ORO 1990 Italian jewelry directly to them. The collection includes one-of-a-kind works of about 20 Italian jewelry designers and companies and are meant to be worn both at work and in the evening. The company says that women are buying real gold jewelry for its long-term quality and value. ``The savvy woman of today is ready to purchase fine jewelry herself, knowing that it is an important fashion investment as well as image enhancing,'' says Helene Fortunoff. _ Precious wildlife jewelry is enjoying revived popularity, according to the Diamond Information Center, which has organized a diamond animal jewelry exhibit currently touring the country to raise money for local zoos and wildlife organizations. The menagerie has 30 unusual pieces, including a slithering snake necklace, wild horses galloping across a gold cuff, a striped tiger, a gorilla bearing a 2{-carat diamond in his hand, a mother and baby rhinoceros covered in diamonds, and panther earrings. ``Wearing animal jewelry expresses a strong concern for wildlife,'' says Mia Fonssagrives-Solow, an avant-garde jewelry designer and sculptor whose work is included in the show. ``These creatures are so rare, so precious and so few.'' The pieces come from a number of retailers, manufacturers and designers. _ Goldpfeil, the West German luxury leather goods firm, has launched several new collections for American buyers that include handbags inspired by Civil War uniforms, a group of sueded-nubuck handbags and belts in autumn shades, a line of structured handbags in dual shades of black and brown, and a collection of business and personal accessories for men in tobacco nubuck with brushed brass fittings. It also is offering its traditional line of luggage, business cases and personal accessories that re-create designs first made popular by the company 70 years ago, but newly interpreted in bright primary colors and hunter green. _ The charm bracelet _ de rigueur in the l950s _ reappears this year dressed up as fashion jewelry. Swarovski, under its Savvy label, offers a version with caged and dropped pearls with twisted rope chains. Matching earrings also are available. _ Light, understated versions of traditional eyeglass frames are new from Giorgio Armani Occhiali's Soft Focus line. The collection features slightly larger, slightly rounder frames designed to be light, comfortable, and well balanced, says Claudio Del Vecchio of the Luxottica Group, the eyewear manufacturer which distributes the line. _ Scruffles is a new type of ruffled fabric hair ornament, mounted on interlocking combs, that can be used on both long and short hair. Lloyd and Pat Hehlo, who own Headlines, the company that makes the ornaments, say the design is versatile. ``Because the Scruffle ruffles, which are available separately, are interchangeable, a woman can have a variety of styles,'' says Lloyd Hehlo. ``In addition, the removeable ruffles are hand washable.'' _ Liz Claiborne has branched out into fashion jewelry, with a collection of earrings, bracelets, necklaces, pendants and pins that match the character of the designer's clothing lines. Most pieces are bold sculptural shapes in silver- and gold-burnished metals mixed with colors, including amber-colored beads. The company says the new line is a targeted for both career and weekend wear. _

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Outerwear
LaserPhoto NY716
DOC.TEXT: The rugged motif for fall may look good on the outside, but how does it feel on the inside? Manufacturers are seeking ways to blend the ``rough and ready'' with the comfortable in parkas, field jackets and carcoats. Man-made fiberfill insulations can provide the wearer with warmth and comfort from the inside out, says Don Ziesel, Du Pont marketing manager, who sees coats with a ``rugged attitude'' among the most popular looks this fall. He says the synthetic insulations ``not only drape well for the designer, but they help keep the wearer warm and dry.'' Some activewear from Helly-Hansen is lined with Hydrofil nylon mesh, which draws moisture away from the body to prevent wet cling, according to its manufacturer, Allied Fibers. ``Recently fabric and fiber technology has come a long way,'' says Du Pont's Ziesel. ``Man-made insulations such as Thermoloft and Thermolite aid designers in creating innovative jackets and coats that consumers will find more exciting then ever before.'' Fall colors for outerwear, he says, are ``woodsy,'' ranging from earth tones of olive and brown to shades of berry, mustard and mango.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Perils
DOC.TEXT: The old saw about suffering in the name of fashion has real significance with today's styles, says Dr. Leonard W. Morgan, assistant professor of family medicine at the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center. Waist-cinching belts, tight-fitting jeans and tight shirt collars can cause or aggravate health problems, he says. By far the worst offenders are shoes. ``People buy shoes for style, not for comfort. Frequently the shoes are too narrow, have inadequate cushioning in the soles, or are ill-fitting. This can lead to everything from tired feet, corns and calluses to serious foot problems that require surgery.'' Close-fitting garments also cause problems. ``Tight clothes interfere with blood circulation to the skin. Too-tight shirt collars and ties can interfere somewhat with blood flow to the brain. For people who already have arteriosclerosis, which is impeded blood flow to the brain, tight collars and ties can increase their risk of problems,'' says Morgan. Similarly, knee-high hose or tight socks can contribute to development of varicose veins, he adds. Summer or winter, people should try to protect themselves from the sun. ``There is no such thing as a `healthy' tan. The rays of the sun are quite damaging, as the rising incidence of skin cancer proves,'' he says. He thinks most people make their worst clothing mistakes in the summer; dark, close-fitting clothing traps warmth and can contribute to heat stroke. He advises people to choose light colors in loose-fitting styles to allow airflow next to the skin.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Fashion: Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The psychedelic pop art era is popping out again, inspiring fashions from Paris and Milan to New York, says Elle Magazine. ``Look for a modern interpretation of the colorful sixties spirit,'' says Jane Hsiang, the magazine's fashion director. She cites designs with short miniskirts, A-line and chemise silhouettes _ putting pressure on the fashion-conscious to shape up. Hot pants, which made a brief appearance in the early l970s, are back, along with form-fitting one-piece unitards (once called body suits) in lacy fabrics, bold colors and graphic prints. These will be interpreted in bright psychedelic day-glo colors and cubist shapes. ``It's legs, legs, legs for Fall 1990,'' says Hsiang. _ The skin-hugging, psychedelic look was definitely in evidence at a fashion show staged by budding designers at New York's Fashion Institute of Technology in cooperation with Pepperidge Farm, which is promoting its new line of diet desserts. Slick metallic fabrics and brilliant colors, with layers and zippered sections to peel away for multi-use, were shown in designs for activewear. A pair of trousers became a pair of shorts by zipping off the lower sections, for example. Or a ski outfit pared down to become a swimsuit. That fashion show fixture, the bridal ensemble, was even revved up, featuring a motorcycle pair with skin-hugging leotard styles decorated with lace and veil for her and bib and tie for him. That design, by Sheila Gutekanst of Winnetka, Ill., won top honors in the show. Other winners Wiveca Oest and Mirjam Wolff of Sweden, Angeles Rivera of Puerto Rico, Georges Antoniou of Astoria, N.Y., Diana Hang of Kew Gardens, N.Y., and Michelle Biondolillo of St. Petersburg, Fla. _ Midwest college students say they wear jeans from 90 to 99 percent of the time, according to the latest Levi's 501 Report conducted by the Roper Organization, sampling 1,024 students from 100 colleges across the country. That beats the national average of 56 percent. The marketing poll also shows that students most prefer their jeans to be stone-washed (67 percent) or worn and faded (62 percent). Levi's says it was surprised to find the third most preferred are dark blues (40 percent); acid-washed jeans are fourth (34 percent). Other preferences indicated in the poll _the sixth annual survey conducted by Roper for Levi Strauss & Co. _ are loose-fitting jeans, (61 percent), tight-fitting jeans (33 percent) and baggy-fitting jeans (28 percent). The new ``anti-fit'' jeans are favored by only 8 percent of the poll group. The poll, looking beyond jeans, found campus preferences for the clean-cut, athletic look (87 percent), oversized baggy clothing (73 percent), bicycle shorts and other spandex clothing (67 percent), multiple earrings in the same ear (61 percent) and little black dresses (57 percent). _

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Mobile Home Battle Pits Morals Against Mores
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a mobile home park for retirees who frowns on unmarried couples living together has launched a legal battle he hopes will turn the clock back 100 years. ``This case could lead to the re-emergence of an extremely old and valuable principle _ the family,'' said Peter Hooper, lawyer for Romany Mobile Home Park. The case could affect all the fair-housing laws in Florida, said Gloria Williams, president of the Florida Association of Community Relations Professionals. Hooper represents William Watson, a quiet man in his early 60s who refers inquiries to his attorney. ``I don't mean to be discourteous, but talk to my lawyer. I don't want to put my foot in my mouth.'' He's asking the courts if an 1868 state law against ``lewd and lascivious'' cohabitation is grounds to evict unmarried old couples who stay together in the same trailer. Hooper said ``lewd and lascivious'' is a general legal term that does not necessarily mean depravity and could apply to common sexual activity. Watson also wants a Pinellas County judge to decide whether the state law renders unconstitutional local fair-housing laws forbidding discrimination based on marital status. Hooper, who is negotiating the case with the city and county, believes officials have no choice but to stand behind state law until it is removed or altered. The dispute, meanwhile, has caused a stir in the sleepy 96-site park where residents 55 and older pedal around the well-kept grounds on tricycles. More than half spend winters here, returning to cooler climes to escape the summer. ``I believe it's immoral for people not married to live together,'' said Bernice Ulrey, a native of Indianapolis who has lived at the park since 1964. ``It doesn't matter to me,'' said a balding white-haired man from Pontiac, Mich., who wouldn't give his name. Tenants are told the rules mean no overnight stays for unmarrieds, he said, adding: ``What can you do at night that you can't do during the day?'' Hooper calls the situation a Catch 22. On one hand state law bans cohabitation, but city and county law bans discrimination based on marital status. The problem isn't unique to this central Gulf Coast community, Hooper said. ``Most states have the same conflicts in laws. They differ in degree and detail. It's a clash of new thoughts with old principles,'' he said. Some think the key to the case is in the interpretation of lewd and lascivious conduct. ``That is really something you wouldn't know unless you looked through the windows,'' said James Yates, director of human relations for the city. Hooper disagrees. He thinks the terms could apply to an unmarried couple living together. The city ordinance contains an exemption allowing a landlord to refuse to rent to an unmarried couple, Yates said. This was added at the behest of ministers. But the county has no such exemption. ``It's the county's stand in this day and time we don't consider cohabitation between two consenting adults to be lewd and lascivious behavior,'' said Robert Reece of the Pinellas County Office of Human Rights. Robert Herman, a 65-year-old retiree who shared a mobile home with his wife until she died three years ago, is among the residents upset with the lawsuit. ``He is passing moral judgment on me,'' Herman said recently before heading back to summer in New Jersey. Herman said he was told by Watson's son he must sell his home, lease it or marry his girlfriend. ``He's assuming that things are happening here,'' said Herman. ``My client isn't shooting at any individual,'' Hooper said. ``He's sued the city and the county because they deserve it. They passed those ordinances that muddied the water.'' There are others who endorse Watson's effort. ``We're behind the manager 100 percent,'' said Oscar Bray, a retiree from the Ann Arbor, Mich., area. An assistant Pinellas County Attorney Bill Falker said Watson assumes that people who are unrelated and living together are committing lewd and lascivious acts. ``I don't know if we can make that assumption. It certainly doesn't seem so to me.'' According to the Florida State Archives, the 122-year-old law states that ``if any man and woman, not being married to each other, lewdly and lasciviously associate and cohabit together ... they shall be guilty.'' The Legislature amended the law in 1971 and changed the maximum penalty from up to three years in prison to one year in prison and a $500 fine. Hooper sued on March 11. The parties have been involved in negotiations that Hooper hopes will lead to a settlement without trial. He won't disclose contents of the talks. Watson's 43-year-old son, Jerry, who helps manage the park, shares his father's feelings and is proud of what he is doing. ``It's the way we were brought up. It's the right way to act,'' he said. ``He's standing up for his beliefs.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Congress Examining Services for Older Americans
DOC.TEXT: The Older Americans Act marks its 25th anniversary next year and already is being used to call attention to a law that underpins the growing network of social services for the nation's elderly. On Capitol Hill, where the act is widely viewed as a success story that has enhanced the independence and dignity of older Americans, Congress is preparing to do some fine tuning for the law's 1991 reauthorization. But some supporters of improved aid to senior citizens say they are concerned that President Bush has yet to call the 1991 White House Conference on Aging, regarded as a once-in-a-decade spur to improving the nation's care network for the elderly. In a letter to Bush late last year, members of the Senate Select Committee on Aging urged him to call the conference and focus it on long-term care for vulnerable people of all ages. Since then, Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., the committee chairman, and Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., have introduced a resolution calling on the president to move on the issue. ``I am perplexed and disturbed at the president's delay in calling this important conference,'' Pryor said. The first White House Conference on Aging, held in 1961, is credited for laying the groundwork for the Medicaid program, adopted four years later. Conferences have been held every decade since with the aim of providing a look forward at the needs of the aging population. Congress last took a comprehensive look at the problems of the elderly in 1987 when it overwhelmingly approved a four-year, $6.8 billion reauthorization of the Older Americans Act. The act provides funds for senior centers, meals on wheels, transportation for the elderly, legal assistance, health programs, adult day care, counseling, employment opportunities and programs for the frail elderly at home, and for older Americans in nursing homes. ``Of the act's many achievements, none is greater than the establishment of an aging network of committed federal, state and local agencies, as well as service providers, dedicated to providing desperately needed social services to our nation's elderly,'' Pryor said. Pryor's committee has begun a series of workshops examining issues and options as work begins on the reauthorization of the basic law. Two leading issues under discussion include: _ The possibility of voluntary cost-sharing for the recipients of such services as meals on wheels who can afford it. Some worry this might lead to the establishment of a means test or to distorting basic services, with those able to pay receiving a higher quality of service than those who are not. _ Information and referral: creating a system to link people in need with existing services. Pror will hold workshops next week to explore the possibility of improvements in legal services for the elderly and in the existing system of ombudsmen who field complaints from senior citizens about the quality of services they receive. Representatives from state and local ombudsmen's programs will examine such questions as whether the program should be expanded, how to recruit competent personnel, and what barriers exist to doing an effective job. The program was added to the act by Congress in 1978 to help resolve the complaints of residents in nursing homes and other care facilities. Pryor's committee also plans to examine the effectiveness of the U.S. Commission on the Aging, the prime coordinating group for government services for the elderly. ``I intend to make concrete proposals designed to improve and strengthen a number of services funded by the Older Americans Act,'' Pryor said. ``These include transportation, information and referral, ombudsmen, legal services and nutrition programs.'' As the time approaches for making changes in the Older Americans Act, suggestions also are coming from representatives of the private organizations with interest in the elderly and their problems. The National Association of Area Agencies on Aging says it is coordinating a campaign to increase federal programs, complaining that a decline in spending over the decade has led to a gradual reduction of services and longer waiting lists. The National Council on Aging is urging Congress to earmark at least $20 million to expand nutrition and exercise classes, information on the safe use of medication, and meals featuring low-fat, high-fiber foods. Daniel Thursz, the council's president, told a House Human Services subcommittee earlier this year that effective and widespread health promotion services would reduce the growth of funds being spent for treatment of health problems. He complained that the $5 million authorized for such services when the Older Americans Act was renewed in 1987 has not yet been spent. ``What is tragic is that thousands of centers are offering useful but thin preventive health services to the nation's most at-risk population,'' he said. But even before formal consideration of amendments to the Older Americans Act, Pryor is working to make some changes. For example, a Pryor amendment to the National Affordable Housing Act is aimed at providing services for elderly tenants in federally assisted housing. ``With modest forms of support services, such as hot meals and help with basic home care needs, including bathing, dressing and grooming, these people can continue to live in the setting they consider home,'' Pryor said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Elderly Topics Range from Serious to Lighthearted
DOC.TEXT: Author Alex Haley told stories of his days growing up in Tennessee, doctors warned about Alzheimer's disease and prescription drugs, and former congresswoman Shirley Chisholm expressed ``hope for George Bush.'' Speakers touched on a range of issues at the biennial convention of the American Association of Retired Persons earlier this month. Ms. Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress (in 1968), said Bush is ``not as doctrinaire and inflexible as Ronald Reagan was. But he's just a little too cautious on some things. .. . He watches to see which way the political winds blow. He needs to be a little more brave.'' Some of the 15,000 delegates attending the sessions in Orlando heard one doctor assure senior citizens that the mind-deteriorating Alzheimer's disease was not inevitable. Another physician warned the ``greatest preventable health problem'' is caused by prescription drugs. And Haley, author of the novel ``Roots,'' spoke movingly and humorously about growing up in a small Tennessee town, where he recalled his grandmother and her five sisters sitting and rocking, dipping into their tobacco and ``taking practice shots'' off the front porch. ``Aunt Liz was the champion,'' Haley said of their spitting contests. ``When she was in good form, Aunt Liz could drop a lightning bug at four yards.'' Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, warned the elderly that they could seriously harm or kill themselves unless they pay careful attention to the prescription drugs they're taking. ``All drugs have side effects. You need to be aware of them,'' especially if taking several medications at the same time or if getting prescriptions from more than one physician, he said. Wolfe, whose research and lobbying group was founded by consumer activist Ralph Nader in 1971, criticized the AARP for not setting up a system to advise members about the quality of the different drugs it sells. ``The AARP sells $150 million worth of drugs a year. ... It should recommend some and steer people away from some that are dangerous or no good,'' Wolfe said. The organization sells its members prescription and non-prescription drugs at a discount by mail. Dr. Robert N. Butler, who heads the department of geriatrics at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, told a large seminar audience that he was concerned that the medical profession had overly worried the elderly about Alzheimer's disease. ``It is awful. It is tragic. It kills many people. ... But in our zealousness, we've scared a lot of people,'' Butler said. ``But that's also happened with cancer and other major diseases.'' He said much research was under way and much more was needed in investigating a disease caused by a number of factors _ including heredity, the body's chemical makeup and immune systems, environmental toxins and others. Eventually, Butler predicted, medical research will find ways to control or prevent the disabling brain disease. Meanwhile, he said, the government should create a new Medicare category for patients needing long-term care. ``Individuals can enjoy a certain quality of life at different levels of Alzheimer's disease,'' he said. ``There is real hope for the introduction of new therapies within our lifetimes.'' AARP is a non-profit organization open to anyone age 50 or older, working or retired. Of its 32 million members, an estimated one-third are ``older workers,'' officials said. Based in Washington, D.C., it provides programs for members and is an active lobbying force in Congress. It devotes much of its resources to campaigns involving affordable health care, protecting the rights of the elderly in the work force and minority and women's affairs.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Alice Faye's Memories of a Bygone Era
DOC.TEXT: There was a time when Alice Faye was queen of the 20th Century Fox musicals. ``It was great, it was glamorous, it was wonderful. I don't spend too much time thinking about it, but when I do, it was lovely. I had so many nice friends, people who were good to me. I didn't have too many beefs, many complaints,'' she said. ``I have great memories _ of the working people. Wonderful stars like Don Ameche, John Payne, Tyrone Power, Jack Oakie, Jack Haley, on and on. We had so much fun, we really did. They don't seem to have that kind of fun today.'' Now she has produced a book, ``Growing Old, Staying Young'' (E.P. Dutton, $18.95), written with Dick Kleiner. Still a striking blonde at 75, she also has been spokeswoman for Pfizer Pharmaceuticals. ``I go out every month, almost,'' she says. ``I travel a day, I rest a day, then I work two days and I come home. It works out real nice. It's kind of fun; it keeps me active, keeps me involved and keeps me off the street.'' Her book contains the message Faye imparts to her audiences, whom she calls ``young elders.'' The Faye method: ``1. Staying active and involved. ``2. Eating a well-balanced diet. ``3. No smoking, which is tough for a lot of people. ``4. Exercising; that's a key: walking, swimming, stretching. ``5. Seeing your doctor and talking to him about your problems. ``I throw in 6. Please God, have a sense of humor, because it helps.'' She enjoys meeting fans who recall her films of the '30s and '40s. ``All of them have a story to tell you _ they had a baby at the time I did this movie or I sang that song,'' she said. Faye was born Alice Jeanne Leppert, daughter of a New York police officer. A teen-age beauty who danced in the Capitol Theater chorus at 14, she eventually made her way to Hollywood. For 10 years she starred in a string of popular musicals: ``Sing Baby Sing,'' ``Stowaway'' (with Shirley Temple) ``On the Avenue,'' ``Alexander's Ragtime Band,'' ``Sally, Irene and Mary,'' ``Rose of Washington Square,'' ``Lillian Russell,'' ``Weekend in Havana'' and more. Faye seldom watches her old movies on television (``I was never a fan of me''). But she saw one recently that she remembered fondly, the wonderfully slapstick ``Hollywood Cavalcade'' (1939). ``I really enjoyed seeing that one again,'' she said. ``I had forgotten how funny (Buster) Keaton was. He was a genius who never got his due in Hollywood.'' She has less pleasant memories of her relations with studio boss Darryl Zanuck. ``I wanted to do something more mature, but Zanuck didn't see it that way,'' she said. ``They were making lots of money with pictures that Betty Grable and myself were doing, all those musicals. Always it was the same story. We changed costumes and leading men, and off we'd go and make another one.'' ``The only chance I had (for a dramatic role) was `Fallen Angel' (1945). That was a good, meaty part. But when I finally saw it on the screen, I was on the cutting room floor.'' Faye was a victim of the big-studio era, when stars were pigeon-holed. Her musicals were a studio staple, so Zanuck refused to change the formula until ``Fallen Angel,'' a box-office failure. Because of Zanuck's cuts, no one will ever know whether Faye could have succeeded in drama. And Faye left. She never went back. She and her husband starred for a decade on their top-rated radio program, ``The Alice Faye-Phil Harris Show.'' She was a frequent guest on television and returned to Fox for the 1962 musical version of ``State Fair,'' with a score by Rodgers and Hammerstein. In more recent times, she toured in ``Good News,'' first with John Payne and then with Don Ameche. For many years Faye and her husband have lived in Rancho Mirage, Calif. Harris, 85, often travels to golf tournaments.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Abuse of Older People a Growing Problem
DOC.TEXT: Contrary to expectations, the abuser of an older person tends to be dependent on that person for money or housing, said a social worker who is trying to increase awareness of the problem. ``We have a long way to go educating police, attorneys and doctors,'' said Kathleen Skoglund, a supervisor in the Sioux Falls Office of Adult Services and Aging. She spoke at a workshop last month on protective services for older people as part of the 11th annual Gerontology Forum in Sioux Falls. Stella Bergin, education director of the Sioux Falls Senior Citizens Services office for 14 years, said the forum was started in part because South Dakota is among the nation's leaders in the percentage of older people in its population. U.S. Census figures for 1988 ranked South Dakota as the seventh-oldest state, with 14 percent of its population over 65. Florida was the oldest, 17.8 percent; followed by Iowa and Pennsylvania, both 14.9; then Rhode Island, Arkansas and West Virginia. A congressional report issued last month said an estimated 1.5 million older Americans, or 5 percent of all elderly, are abused each year, up from 1 million in 1980. Only one in eight cases is reported, according to estimates. South Dakota has about 120,000 older residents, Skoglund said, and last year, fewer than 300 cases of abuse were reported; 168 were substantiated, she said. Abuse can be physical, psychological, passive neglect, self-neglect, exploitation and abuse of power by professional caregivers, Skoglund said. Studies show elderly abuse primarily is inflicted by a relative, most commonly spouses, followed by sons and daughters. Skoglund said studies she has seen, most of them done from 1982 to 1988, also show that what has been thought to be the main cause of abuse _ caregiver stress _ really isn't. Most abuse has been found to be inflicted by people who depend on the older person. ``One study showed that two-thirds of the perpetrators were financially dependent on the victim,'' she said. ``Fifty-five percent were dependent on them for housing.'' Studies also have shown that those inflicting abuse usually have a drug or alcohol problem, have a history of arrests, are disabled or cognitively impaired or have suffered a recent loss of some kind, Skoglund said. ``So you have a case where a vulnerable, needy person is abusing a more vulnerable, needy person,'' she said. South Dakota has had five laws on elderly abuse on its books since 1986, and two more take effect July 1. By 1987, all states had laws governing abuse of older people, and several states require reporting, including Florida, Skoglund said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Centuries-old Crops Flourish in Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Tohono O'odham I'itoi's _ named after a deity _ are tiny, multiplier onions cultivated in the arid Southwest for centuries. No one seems sure where they originated. But they grow easily in desert gardens with a minimum of water and can remain in the ground for harvesting year after year. The flavor, something like a shallot, is a delight in salads or cooked foods. Do such heirloom crops have a future role in a water-short era? Native Seeds@SEARCH, a non-profit, seed conservation group incorporated in 1983, is sure of it. Its seed bank at the Tucson Botanical Garden includes more than 1,000 varieties of grains, beans, melons, spices, squash and other crops. Supplies of many are now sufficient to offer for sale in a 1990 catalog, which says, ``We invite you to join us in maintaining these crops.'' The genetic erosion in Southwest crops began around 1920, with the emergence of mechaniclal irrigation methods. ``Increased water supplies temporarily lessened the need for drought-hardy, locally adapted varieties,'' Gary Paul Nabhan, assistant director of Phoenix's Desert Botanical Garden and president of Native Seed's board of directors, said in a talk to an ethnobotany symposium. ``Since the region's water problems have again deepened, interest has been renewed in using remaining native crops directly or as a plant breeding material.'' Preserving the seed genes selected by generations of desert farmers led to formation of Native Seeds@SEARCH. SEARCH is an acronym for Southwestern Endangered Arid-land Resource Clearing House. As of January, there were almost 2,500 members. The usual reason given for preserving genes of plants is they someday may be needed to make cultivated crops pest- or disease-resistant. The Irish potato famine after crop failures often is cited. To such concerns, Native Seeds adds ecological considerations such as drought and heat tolerance and suggests certain crops may help in control of some nutritional diseases. Nabhan, now on sabbatical from the Desert Botanical Garden, is reasearching native food plants with gummy fibers and mucilages that may be useful in control of diabetes. Diabetes has increased greatly among Sothwest Indians in recent years, and some scientists blame a diet change from traditional foods. So the reasons people join Native Seeds@SEARCH can be varied. But the seed catalog must be high on the list. Interested in trying to grow Hopi Blue corn? It's available. So is the Chiapas wild tomato, with sweet and flavorful, cherry-size fruit. And, of course, the Tohono O'odham I'itoi's, which are best planted in the fall in the low desert and in the spring in cooler regions. The latest catalog calls them an early introduction by the Spanish, who once ruled this area. It was more romantic when I bought my first ones in 1984. I'itoi, a deity of the Tohono O'odham tribe, is said to live in the Baboquivari Mountains of southern Arizona. Indian families harvested the multiplier onion only in the wild for years, according to the original story, before growing it around their desert homes. The multiplier is definitely different from the common desert onion (Allium macropetalum), or any onions or shallots available from the conventional sources. Plant the bulbs 1 inch deep and 12 inches apart. They multiply into clumps. After the tops die back in the summer, the clumps are harvested and stored in a cool place. Or they can be left in the ground to continue multiplying. In that case, harvest as desired. Just be sure to save enough for future crops. The catalog is available for $1 from Native Seeds@SEARCH, 2509 North Campbell Ave., No. 325, Tucson, Ariz., 85719. Seed packets are $1.25, plus shipping.
James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, June 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Survey: Elderly Feel Younger Than Their Years
DOC.TEXT: Contrary to many perceptions, most of America's older citizens feel good about themselves, with more than half saying they are excited about the future, according to a survey commissioned by Marriott Corp. In fact, most older Americans say they feel a dozen years younger than their ages, expect to live to at least 86 and are basically happy, the survey shows. More than 10 percent say they believe they will live to be 100. The survey was conducted among 1,004 men and women over 65. Marriott said its interest stems from the fact that Marriott Senior Living Services owns or operates 10 retirement communities and plans to build an additional 150 communities for the elderly by the middle of the 1990s.
DOC.HEAD: Elderly Warned To Take Precautions in Summer Heat
DOC.TEXT: The federal Office of Consumer Affairs cautions that elderly people are more vulnerable to the extremes of summer heat because they do not adjust well to sudden increases in outdoor temperature. Such changes can strain the heart and blood vessels, leading to heat exhaustion, heart failure and strokes, the agency says. The danger signals: dizziness, rapid heartbeat, diarrhea, nausea, cramps, throbbing headache, dry skin, chest pain, emotional changes, breathing problems, or vomiting. Any or all should prompt an immediate call to a doctor. The agency's advice is to spend as much time as possible in air-conditioned surroundings, use fans to cool and circulate air at home, wear loose-fitting and light-colored clothing. Also, curtail physical activity, avoid hot foods and heavy meals, reduce the use of salt and avoid alcohol.
DOC.HEAD: Group Supports Plan To Create Independent Social Security Agency
DOC.TEXT: The National Council on the Aging is supporting legislation by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., that would create an independent Social Security Administration and take surplus Social Security trust funds out of the calculation of the federal budget deficit. Daniel Thursz, council president, said the legislation provides ``decisive steps to continue to secure the integrity of the Social Security system over the coming decades.'' The Rostenkowski bill would establish a three-person bipartisan board to run the independent Social Security agency. Thursz said these officials would be responsible for advocating Social Security improvements and would defend their recommendations before congressional committees.

Philip Morris Cos. said it would acquire Swiss coffee and candy conglomerate Jacobs Suchard AG in a $3.8 billion deal creating the third-largest food company in Europe. The combined company, linking Suchard with Philip Morris's Kraft General Foods International unit, would have annual revenue of $6.7 billion and a broad reach across the growing European consumer market. Only Nestle SA and Unilever NV would be larger. The deal, announced Friday, could also produce an insider trading investigation, Swiss officials said.

President Bush said he wants to double spending to pursue savings and loan fraud, but Democrats said the proposal was too little too late. Bush's proposal Friday also would establish ``rapid response teams'' and name a Justice Department official to direct the effort. Democrats said they found little new in the plan and called it an admission that past anti-fraud efforts had failed. The program would double spending for Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service investigators and prosecutors to $100 million in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1.

The two Germanys, for 40 years the most visible symbol of the Cold War divide, took their biggest step toward unification by reaching final agreement on economic merger. In East Berlin on Friday, representatives of the World War II victors and vanquished gathered to discuss German unity, and one of the most notorious markers of East-West conflict _ Checkpoint Charlie _ was removed from the Berlin Wall.

Personal spending was flat in May, the government said in a report indicating growing caution among consumers who have been a major source of strength for the economy during seven years of growth. The Commerce Department said Friday consumer spending remained unchanged at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.66 trillion after seven straight months of gains, including 0.5 percent in April and 0.3 percent in March.

Orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods jumped 3.9 percent in May, the government reported. Analysts said it was further evidence the economy's sluggish manufacturing sector may be bouncing back. The Commerce Department said Friday orders for durable goods _ items such as automobiles and appliances expected to last at least three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $128.2 billion after falling 4.2 percent in April.

Lisa Jones, a teen-age runaway who became a $100,000-a-year trading assistant at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was sentenced to 10 months in prison for lying to a grand jury investigating Wall Street fraud. U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand on Friday reduced his original 18-month sentence after an appeals court threw out the term on grounds it was longer than mandated by federal sentencing guidelines. Jones, now 27, was convicted last year of seven counts of perjury and obstruction of justice for lying in January 1988 to a federal grand jury investigating trading activities at Drexel.

Soviet oil exports dropped nearly 10 percent last year, according to figures provided by the CIA, raising concerns about domestic oil shortages and cuts in supply to Eastern Europe. The export drop reflected a decline in oil production caused by aging wells, labor unrest and bureaucratic chaos, U.S. officials said Friday. The Soviet Union exported 3.69 million barrels of oil a day in 1989, down from 4.08 million in 1988, according to the newly compiled CIA figures.

Coniston Partners, one of the most prominent takeover strategists of the 1980s, is closing up shop in response to the shrinking market for mergers and acquisitions. Coniston's biggest targets included Gillette Co., Allegis Corp. and TW Services Inc. Coniston said Friday it was disbanding the $700 million investment pool it used to fund its takeover bids and proxy fights because of the scarcity of financing and suitable target companies. Most of the money will be returned to Coniston's investors.

Computer-program selling overpowered an attempt to rally the stock market Friday, The Dow Jones industrial average fell 44.55 to 2,857.18. The dollar was mixed against most major currencies. Government bond prices rose marginally. Pork belly futures fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound; energy futures rose; grains and soybeans were lower; orange juice advanced; and precious metals retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell sharply today in reaction to the Japanese yen's weakness against the dollar, which rose for the fourth consecutive trading day. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average plunged 570.38 points, or 1.80 percent, closing at 31,124.19 points. On Friday, it lost 392.70 points. Volume on the first section today was estimated at 300 million shares. ``There are three worries _ higher interest rates, the dollar is higher at 155 yen, and inflation in Germany because of the merger of West and East Germany _ making institutional investors nervous,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities. Institutional investors are also worried about Japanese inflation heating up, he said. The dollar closed at 155.62 yen, up 0.87 yen from Friday's finish of 154.75 yen. It opened at 155.53 yen and ranged between 155.42 yen and 155.75 yen. In the last four trading days, the dollar has gained a total of 1.90 yen. Market players were actively buying dollars in the morning to cover short positions and stop losses, said Junichi Kodama, head of corporate traders at Chemical Bank. Purchases by insurance companies sent the dollar up to 155.70 by mid-morning. ``There was a rumor that the Bank of Japan might have intervened. The rumor came from Singapore. I don't know if the rumor was true, but it was true that there was strong selling at the 155.70 level,'' he added. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell slightly to 86.91 points as of 5 p.m. from its 87.18-point finish Friday. The yield rose to 7.205 percent from 7.145 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Siebe to Acquire Foxboro For $656 Million
DOC.TEXT: Siebe PLC, a British security systems engineering group, has agreed to acquire Foxboro Co., a U.S.-based manufacturing equipment maker, for $656 million, the companies said Monday. Siebe is offering $52 a share for Foxboro's 12.62 million outstanding shares, the companies said. Foxboro stock soared on the news, rising $12.75 to $50.87\ a share in early New York Stock Exchange trading. Foxboro, which makes equipment that automatically controls industrial processes, will remain headquartered in Foxboro, Mass., and will operate as an independent subsidiary, said Barrie Stephens, vice-chairman and chief executive of Siebe. ``We will benefit from combined technologies, products and distribution capabilities, allowing us to increase our activities in various segments of the controls business,'' Stephens said. Siebe also said it is considering selling part of its U.S. subsidiary, Siebe Inc., to the public. The joint announcement by the companies said Foxboro had been seeking to establish a strategic alliance. Gary Willis, Foxboro's chairman, president and chief executive officer, said Siebe was an ideal partner. The two companies said they expect the acquisition to strengthen their worldwide distribution network.

DOC.HEAD: National Rig Jumps by 22 Over Last Week
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States jumped by 22 this week to 1,021, Baker Hughes Inc. announced Monday. Last week, the rig count had risen by eight to total 999. A year ago this week, the count was 810. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The Houston-based oil toolmaker company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Louisiana showed the biggest gain for the week, adding 16 rigs, followed by Texas, which added 10 rigs. Other states posting gains for the week include Ohio, up four; Pennsylvania, up three; Wyoming and Michigan, both up by two; and Kansas, up one. Among states losing rigs for the week were California, which dropped 11 rigs, and Oklahoma, which lost five rigs. Rig counts for Colorado, New Mexico and North Dakota remained unchanged for the week.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 458.28 down 1.05 from the previous day's close.

Stocks were mixed this morning, failing to rebound substantially from last week's losses. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 78.71 points last week, climbed 10.39 points to 2867.57 in the first hour of trading. But most broader market indicators were down. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about a 6-to-5 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, with 670 down, 542 up and 519 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 42.44 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Stocks sold off sharply late Friday in computer-program selling by professional traders engaged in multiple strategies involving stock-index options and futures. Although buyers re-entered the market this morning, brokers said they failed to generate much enthusiasm for a rally. The news background provided little to alleviate investors' recent worries about prospects for corporate profits and the chances for further declines in interest rates. Rates moved moderately higher in the credit markets today, partly because of a large number of new debt issues to result from a wave of Treasury auctions this week. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds edged up to the 8.50 percent-8.54 percent range. Foxboro Co. jumped 12} to 50~. The British company Siebe PLC agreed to acquire the company for $52 a share. Philip Morris, which announced plans late last week to acquire Jacobs Suchard of Switzerland, rose 1] to 46[. Caterpillar, a leading manufacturer and exporter, dropped 3{ to 60 after saying earnings would likely fall this year. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.06 to 194.18. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .09 at 359.19.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rules Against Royal Crown in Merger Expenses Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate a $1.4 million lawyer fees award Royal Crown Cola won and then lost for its 1986 challenges to two proposed mergers of soft drink companies. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that Royal Crown is not entitled to be reimbursed for the lawyer fees it incurred in fighting the later-aborted mergers. In early 1986, Pepsico Inc. announced its plan to acquire the Seven-Up Co. from Philip Morris Inc. for $380 million. The Coca-Cola Co. then announced its intent to acquire Dr. Pepper Co. for $470 million. Believing its existence threatened, Royal Crown in June 1986 sued in a federal court in Georgia to block the mergers. Four days later, the Federal Trade Commission asked a federal court in the District of Columbia to block Coca-Cola's takeover of Dr. Pepper. The commission did not challenge the Seven-Up acquisition by Pepsico because efforts to complete that transaction already had been abandoned. U.S. District Judge J. Robert Elliott in Columbus, Ga., awarded Royal Crown Coal $1.4 million in lawyer fees under a federal antitrust law provision for such awards to a ``prevailing party.'' The Atlanta-based 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the award last Nov. 13. ``Royal Crown filed a precautionary lawsuit and started the litigation wheels moving after much of the desired information had already been produced to the FTC,'' the appeals court said. ``Such action is neither swift nor decisive and it is not enough to confer upon Royal Crown the status of a prevailing party.'' The case is Royal Crown Cola vs. Coca-Cola Co., 89-1756.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mixed After Lower Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were strongly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting a mixed bag of crop weather and signs of smaller-than-expected supplies of soybean oil and meal. The crop markets opened mostly lower following a weekend of favorable growing and planting conditions in the Midwest and the Great Plains. Prices quickly rallied, though, after the Census Bureau released a monthly report showing smaller-than-expected U.S. stocks of soybean oil and meal. The Census Bureau reported soybean meal stocks at 252,555 short tons and soybean oil stocks at about 1.5 billion pounds at the end of May. Further support stemmed from forecasts for extremely hot weather to move from the Southwest into the western Corn Belt later this week, analysts said. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.34{ a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 4\ cents higher with July at $2.85 a bushel; oats were 4 cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $1.38 a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 7 cents higher with July at $6.04 a bushel. Livestock futures were narrowly mixed while pork bellies were sharply lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .12 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 73.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .33 cent lower to .03 cent higher with August at 84.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent lower to .52 cent higher with August at 58.47 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .42 cent to 2 cents lower with July at 57.40 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly lower on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Lets Stand $8 Million Antitrust Award Against Kansas Blue Cross
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact an $8 million antitrust award against Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas. The justices, without comment, rejected arguments that the medical insurance company was trying only to cut costs, not interfere with competition, when it ended a contract with the largest hospital in Wichita. Blue Cross said the award should be overturned in light of a May 14 high court ruling that said price-cutting schemes that hurt a competitor's business do not necessarilly violate federal antitrust laws. The May ruling said that only when price-cutting can be proved to be predatory _ when prices are set below cost _ does it violate the Sherman Antitrust Act. In the case acted on today, the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last March upheld the $8 million judgment against Blue Cross. The company was sued by Wesley Medical Center, the largest hospital in Wichita; Health Care Plus Inc., Wichita's major health maintenance organization; and New Century Life Insurance Co. Blue Cross ended its contract with Wesley in 1986, and agreed instead to purchase hospital services in Wichita from St. Francis Regional Medical Center and St. Joseph's Medical Center. The suit against Blue Cross alleged that the termination was due to Wesley's acquisition by Hospital Corporation of America (HCA), which is based in Nashville. Wesley officials said Blue Cross, alarmed over HCA's growing importance, was sending a message to other hospitals that they would suffer a loss of business if they were acquired by the corporation or did business with Blue Cross's competitors. Blue Cross said it signed up with the other two hospitals in return for a 20 percent reduction in hospital prices. The 10th Circuit court said the jury believed those suing Blue Cross who said the insurer tried to restrict consumers' access to, and benefits from, rival health care financing arrangements. The case is Blue Cross vs. Reazin, 89-1839.

The stock market extended last week's losses in midday trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 78.71 points last week, was down another 4.21 points to 2,852.97 at noon on Wall Street. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 844 down, 472 up and 511 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 66.02 million shares, compared with 69.24 million shares at the same time on Friday. Stocks sold off sharply late Friday in computer-program selling by professional traders engaged in multiple strategies involving stock-index options and futures. Buyers re-entered the market this morning, pusing the Dow Jones average up more than 10 points in early trading, but little enthusiasm for a rally was generated and stocks pulled back. The news background provided little to alleviate investors' recent worries about prospects for corporate profits and the chances for further declines in interest rates. Rates moved moderately higher in the credit markets today, partly because of a large number of new debt issues to result from a wave of Treasury auctions this week. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds edged up to around 8.50 percent around midday. Among most active stocks, Foxboro Co. jumped 12} to 50~. The British company Siebe PLC agreed to acquire the company for $52 a share. Philip Morris, which announced plans late last week to acquire Jacobs Suchard of Switzerland, rose 1] to 46[. Caterpillar, a leading manufacturer and exporter, dropped 4] to 59[ after saying earnings would likely fall this year. Among other issues, UAL dropped 2~ to 152{ and J.C. Penney fell 1| to 61[ The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.95 to 193.29. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 0.84 at 358.44.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices ended higher on London's Stock Exchange Monday, boosted by a healthy start on Wall Street. Nervousness over Wall Street's Friday slump depressed London prices in early trading. But when the New York market opened strongly, London investors breathed a sigh of relief and propelled the Britimpared with 497.8 million shares Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Announces Its Profits to Drop Substantially
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. today announced its 1990 earnings will be far below last year, due mainly to a dramatic decline in the performance of its Brazilian operations. ``We have a serious, short-term negative problem in Brazil,'' said Richard E. Stober, Caterpillar spokesman. The Peoria-based construction equipment manufacturer earned $497 million in 1989, down 19 percent from 1988's $616 million. Last year's profits lagged despite revenue of $11.1 billion. Stober said Caterpillar expects its sales and revenue to match the 1989 record although sales volume will be lower. Higher prices will compensate for the drop in product sales, Stober said. According to Caterpillar's projections, the company's six-month earnings will be less than $148 million and on pace for a sharp drop from 1989. ``More than half of the revision is due to Brazil,'' Stober said. ``Our sales there have continued relatively strong .... (but) the government has frozen all the prices and it appears we will be selling at a loss for the year in Brazil.'' Caterpillar employs 5,100 of its 60,000-member worldwide workforce at two plants in Brazil. Workers there build gas, diesel and marine engines, generator sets, winches, as well as an assortment of wheel loaders, tractor scrapers, bull dozers, rippers, motor graders and track-type tractors. Caterpillar's Latin American territory, which includes Mexico, Central America and South America, bought $447 million of equipment manufactured at the company's U.S. factories. In addition, Caterpillar sold $382 million in equipment made in Latin America. Other factors contributing to Caterpillar's slide include tight U.S. monetary policies and higher inflation, Stober said. Also, a plant modernization program is taking longer than expected and is costing more than projected, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Examining Whether Takeover Deal Was Leaked
DOC.TEXT: Swiss authorities have begun a preliminary investigation to determine whether news of the $3.8 billion takeover of the Swiss chocolate and coffee group Jacobs Suchard by Philip Morris Cos. Inc. may have been leaked. Zurich District Attorney Rudolf Unterrassner said Monday ``intensive clarification'' is under way to see whether media reports hinting at possible insider trading of Jacobs Suchard shares can be corroborated. Insider trading became a criminal offense in Switzerland two years ago. Unterrassner said the Zurich Stock Exchange has been asked to supply records allowing investigators to analyze the share price movements. Urs Bruegger, chief legal officer of the Zurich Exchange, said there were ``certain unclear elements'' but that there was no concrete evidence of a violation. Jacobs Suchard had ordered an internal probe already on Friday after details of the deal were published in newspapers on the eve of its announcement. Rumors of a possible takeoever of Jacobs Suchard had been circulating for weeks. The Zurich financial newspaper Finanz und Wirtschaft noted in its Saturday edition that the volume of trade in Jacobs Suchard shares quadrupled from May 15 to May 18, well before the rumors were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Tire Maker to Eliminate 2,260 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Michelin, the world's largest tire company, said Monday it plans to cut 2,260 jobs from its work force in an effort to hold down costs and meet foreign competition. The plan, presented to employee representatives Monday, eliminates jobs at five plants in Clermont-Ferrand, where Michelin's total work force is about 20,500, and at various distribution centers across France. Job cuts had been anticipated as a result of aggressive pricing policies by leading tire makers and the consequent need to boost productivity and reduce expenses. Michelin will attempt to reduce the work force through early retirement programs, part-time employment, transfers and other options, instead of outright firings. Executives reportedly told shareholders at Friday's annual meeting that they anticipate several difficult years and that financial losses were possible. Michelin had consolidated net profit of about $420 million in 1989 on revenue of about $9.4 billion. It recently acquired the U.S. tire firm Uniroyal, following the acquisition of Firestone by Japan's Bridgestone. Michelin shares on the Paris stock exchange reacted sharply to Monday's news, falling by 8.3 percent in heavy trading.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Store Chain Being Bought for $330 Million
DOC.TEXT: Melville Corp. plans to buy Peoples Drug Stores Inc. for about $330 million in cash, creating one of the biggest drug retailers in the country, it was announced Monday. The acquisition from Canada's Imasco Ltd. will strengthen Melville's already prominent position on the East Coast in drug retailing. Through its CVS chain, Melville has established a major presence in the drug, health and beauty aids businesses. CVS operates 811 stores in 14 states, primarily in the Northeast. The chain's sales last year amounted to $1.95 billion. Peoples, which operates 490 stores in the mid-Atlantic states, is expected to keep its name and become a separate entity within CVS. Last year, Peoples' sales totaled $1.02 billion. Peoples has been owned by Imasco, a big Montreal-based consumer products company, since 1984. ``CVS and Peoples make an ideal geographic and strategic fit,'' said Stanley P. Goldstein, Melville chairman and chief executive officer. ``CVS has been an outstanding performer, and we are pleased to strengthen our commitment to an industry that we know well and where we have a demonstrated record of success.'' The combination of CVS and Peoples will create the fifth largest chain of drug stores in the United States, based on annual sales, Melville said in a news release. Melville said it will tap into its operating cash flow and existing credit lines to finance the Peoples purchase. The transaction will not dilute earnings, the company said. From its headquarters in Rye, N.Y., Melville oversees a vast collection of specialty retailers ranging from the off-price apparel chain Marshalls to Thom McAn shoe shops, Linens 'n Things and This End Up furniture stores. Companywide sales in 1989 totaled $7.5 billion. Completion of the deal with Imasco depends on the execution of an acquisition agreement. The transaction, expected to close in August, must be approved by government regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Stay Sought in Microprocessor Patent Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. announced Monday they will jointly seek a stay of an order by a U.S. District Court in Texas that barred both companies from manufacturing and selling certain microprocessors. The companies also announced they have reached an agreement in principle that will end their dispute. Suburban Chicago-based Motorola and Tokyo-based Hitachi have been embroiled in an 18-month legal battle over trade secrets that centers on some of their most popular computer microprocessors. On June 18, U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton, sitting in Midland, Texas, barred Motorola from marketing its 68030 microprocessor. He also barred Hitachi from marketing its similar chip. On June 19, the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington granted Motorola's motion to delay Bunton's order. A spokeswoman for Motorola said the stay of Bunton's ruling will be sought from the Washington court.

DOC.HEAD: Toblerone Takeover Leaves Bitter Taste in Sweet-Tooth Switzerland
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The American invasion of Switzerland's chocolate industry has left a bitter taste among some Swiss, pioneers of the confection and statistically its biggest eaters. Comments have been ranging from sadness to indignation in the wake of Philip Morris Companies Inc.'s announced $3.8 billion acquisition of Jacobs Suchard, makers of the two top Swiss brand names, Toblerone and Milka. Throughout this century, Toblerone, with its typical triangular shape, and violet-wrapped Milka have been synonyms of ``Schokoladenschweiz,'' chocolate Switzerland. ``It is almost as if a Swiss entrepreneur would buy Ford,'' the weekly Zurich Sonntagszeitung editorialized after Philip Morris, the world's biggest consumer products conglomerate, announced it would buy the world's third biggest chocolate and coffee group. ``Milka cow is grazing on Marlboro Ranch,'' headlined the Basler Zeitung, in reference to one of Philip Morris' cigarette brands. And at Toblerone's hometown of Bern, the Bund newspaper predicted ``popular indignation at the loss of this `piece of Switzerland' will be great.'' ``Although Toblerone and Milka continue to be made in Switzerland, they will be part of an anonymous conglomerate with controls in the United States,'' it stated. Even the staid Zurich financial newspaper, Finanz und Wirtschaft, said the takeover would stir strong emotions. Emotions are not cooled by the fact that Suchard's owner, Klaus Jacobs, is a native of Germany. Polls consistently show that Germans are Switzerland's least loved neighbors. Jacobs was the first foreigner to move into the Swiss chocolate industry, which is one of the world's leading chocolate exporters. Sales last year totaled about 40,000 tons to more than 130 countries, with another 60,000 tons consumed domestically. The Swiss reputation in the field _ chocolate rivals watches, cheese and bank secrecy as the country's chief image makers _ dates to the early 19th century. Francois-Louis Cailler and Philippe Suchard began the world's industrial production of chocolate. Another breakthrough came in the 1870s when Daniel Peter invented the milk chocolate bar and Rodolphe Lindt refined the product so that it melted on the tongue. Dario Kuster, Director of Chocosuisse, the Union of Swiss Chocolate Manufacturers, said in an interview Monday that the Swiss also were the first to push exports. ``At the turn of the century, they had an enormous lead,'' he said. ``Up to 70 percent of the Swiss production was sold abroad while foreign manufacturers focused on their domestic markets.'' Before World War I, when other countries increasingly set up import barriers, many Swiss subsidiaries sprang up abroad. ``An early awareness of what we now call marketing was a second important factor,'' Kuster said. ``Posters and ads were widely used already in the 19th century.'' Toblerone became a pacesetter in 1908. It registered with the Federal Intellectual Property Office and remains the only Swiss chocolate that is patented. ``It has become a special hit,'' Kuster said. ``Perhaps because the shape brings to mind the Matterhorn, or perhaps a whole range of untouched mountains.'' Swiss chocolate seems a must buy of even the most diet-conscious tourists visiting Switzerland. They often claim that chocolate made in Switzerland tastes better than the same brand made by a subsidiary abroad. ``There is a good part of imagination involved,'' said Kuster. ``But it's true that the mix of cocoa beans, the choice of milk, and of course the Swiss pride in quality are also factors.'' Switzerland supposedly is the biggest consumer, at 25 pounds per capita annually. But the figure may be misleading because it includes purchases by tourists in Switzerland. Swiss sales abroad are in the ``quality range'', he said, naming Belgium as the country's leading competitor. In value, Exports last year totaled $200 million, with West Germany, France, Britain, Austria and the United States the leading buyers, respectively.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Trade Negotiators Begin Final Round Of ``Structural'' Talks
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the United States disagreed Monday over specific plans for structural reforms of the Japanese economy, but a senior U.S. official said progress was made and the talks were ``friendly and cooperative.'' Monday's meetings began a final round of trade talks dubbed the Structural Impediments Initiative. Officials said they focused on Japan's plans for changing policies and business practices that are thought to impede imports and foreign investment. The two sides remained apart on the issue of public works spending, said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition he not be further identified. Japan has agreed, at U.S. urging, to spend more on parks, roads, sewers and other public infrastructure, both to stimulate more imports and to reduce the imbalance between savings and investment in this thrifty nation. But the two sides disagree over the amount needed to significantly affect the trade imbalance. U.S. officials said earlier they were hoping for a 500 trillion yen, or $3.22 trillion, public works package for the next 10 years. They also said they would like Japan to promise to spend a certain percentage of its gross national product on such projects. Japanese officials, however, have indicated they favor spending between 400 trillion and 415 trillion yen, or $2.58 trillion to $2.68 trillion, in the next decade on public works. So far, they have rejected the request to specify what portion of GNP they will spend on public works, saying this would limit their ability to adapt public spending to changing economic conditions. The U.S. official, who attended Monday's talks, declined to specify the figures being considered. But, he said, ``We noted the current figure under discussion would not represent a significant increase relative to the size of the Japanese economy.'' Japan also has pledged to ease rules on opening retail stores, speed up processing of patent applications, crack down on allegedly unfair business practices by corporate groups and revise its land use policies. The changes are aimed at making the Japanese economy more open to trade and foreign investment. Senior Japanese officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the talks were ``relatively constructive.'' ``I think the Americans were satisfied about some things, and dissatisfied about others,'' one of the officials said. On Tuesday, the talks will focus on U.S. plans to do more to cut the federal budget deficit, encourage savings, curb excessive consumption and improve worker training and education _ changes aimed at boosting U.S. export competitiveness. Washington has ``filled in the gaps and increased the specificity'' of pledges it made in an interim report on the talks in April, the U.S. official said. He declined to explain specific measures taken. The official said Washington expects reforms initiated during the talks to have a noticeable impact on trade imbalances in the ``medium term ... about two or three years.'' But he said the impact was likely to be more apparent in the two nations' overall trade imbalances than in their bilateral trade accounts. Japan's trade surplus with the United States last year was $49 billion, according to the U.S. Commerce Department. Its global trade surplus was $76.92 billion. The United States posted a total trade deficit of $109 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Mining Industry Not Exempt from Hazardous Waste Rules, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court Monday decided against exempting the mining industry from some federal environmental rules for treating, storing and disposing of hazardous waste. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by the American Mining Congress and a mining company, Solite Corp. The two challenged a 1987 decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to apply the hazardous waste regulations to the mining industry. The industry said it should be exempt under a 1980 law called the Bevill Amendment, which temporarily excluded some solid wastes from EPA rules until the agency could complete a study. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last year the EPA did not exceed its power in enforcing the regulations for the mining industry. The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court to reject the industry appeal. Justice Department lawyers noted that waste generated from mining, including ash and sludge, was believed to pose less of a hazard to the environment than other forms of toxic waste. But, the government said, chemicals and compounds are released from the mining wastes ``that are known to have adverse effects on humans or other life forms.'' The government said it therefore was appropriate for the EPA to apply stringent rules to the mining wastes. The case is American Mining Congress vs. Environmental Protection Agency, 89-1511. In other action Monday, the court: _ Agreed to decide whether the secretary of labor or a safety and health review board has the last word on what federal regulations require for on-the-job safety. The court's decision, expected sometime next year, will determine whether CF&I Steel Corp. of Pueblo, Colo., must pay a $10,000 fine for not making sure the respirators given to coke oven workers fit them properly. The case is Dole vs. Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission, 89-1541. _ Refused to free Communications Satellite Corp. from having to refund $38.8 million to its customers. The court, without comment, rejected arguments by Comsat that the Federal Communications Commission exceeded its authority in ordering the refunds. The case is Communications Satellite Corp. vs. FCC, 89-1687. _ Refused to reinstate a $1.4 million lawyer fees award Royal Crown Cola won and then lost for its 1986 challenges to two proposed mergers of soft drink companies. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that Royal Crown is not entitled to be reimbursed for the lawyer fees it incurred in fighting the later-aborted mergers. The case is Royal Crown Cola vs. Coca-Cola Co., 89-1756. _ Refused to revive a 14-year-old lawsuit by a Texas oil refinery's black employees who say they are victims of racial discrimination. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that dismissed the suit against a union and Gulf Oil Corp. The case is Bernard vs. Gulf Oil, 89-1617. _ Left intact an $8 million antitrust award against Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas. The justices, without comment, rejected arguments that the medical insurance company was trying only to cut costs, not interfere with competition, when it ended a contract with the largest hospital in Wichita. The case is Blue Cross vs. Reazin, 89-1839.

DOC.HEAD: USX Held Talks on Disposing of Some Steel Operations
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. has talked with foreign investors about disposing of some of its steel operations, a spokesman for the steel and energy giant said Monday. Representatives of one of the companies, British Steel PLC, met with USX about two weeks ago, said the spokesman, William E. Keslar. He declined to identify other parties interested in the company's steel assets. Keslar said British Steel made no bids, and no further talks were scheduled. He declined to elaborate on the nature of the talks but characterized them as highly exploratory. ``There are no sales pending. No offers are on the table,'' he said. Keslar said the talks were not prompted by takeover strategist Carl C. Icahn's proposal to spin off at least 80 percent of the company's steel division. The proposal was defeated at the company's May 7 annual shareholders' meeting following a heated proxy battle. ``Throughout the last half dozen or more years we periodically have discussions with other companies about mutually advantageous business opportunities,'' he said. ``Some of those have led to sales of assets or joint ventures.''
