DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 12.13 points to 2,845.05. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,017 down, 484 up and 494 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 133.1 million shares, against 172.57 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index fell 1.64 to 192.60. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index declined 1.89 to 357.39.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices slipped Monday in lackluster trading, while gasoline futures showed strength. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 8 cents to settle at $17.38 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It had gained 52 cents Friday. Other contract months also lost ground. Andrew Lebow, senior broker and analyst at E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc., said news that production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries did not fall this month, contrary to earlier reports, may have accounted in part for the softening in prices. Among refined products traded on the exchange, the July contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline rose .90 cents to settle at 62.27 cents a gallon, after rising 1.14 cents Friday. Other contract months also rose. Lebow said gasoline ``continues to show surprising strength.'' He said gasoline futures prices were boosted by gains in the cash market for gasoline. Premium unleaded gasoline has been in short supply, he said, and dealers may be stocking up for the Fourth of July holiday. The market ignored the news Monday that Exxon Corp. partially restarted a New Jersey refinery that had been closed for four months. Wholesale home heating oil for July delivery rose .26 cent to settle at 48.92 cents a gallon, after gaining 0.75 cent Friday. Other near-term contract months saw smaller gains, while prices in later months declined. Lebow said heating oil refiners could be building stocks in advance of winter, accounting for the rise in near-month prices. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.516 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.522 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned in a mixed performance Monday as dealers directed their attention to trading other major currencies. Gold prices gained on domestic and overseas markets. Much of the movement in the dollar came as a byproduct of trades involving the West German mark against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc. Renewed buying of Canadian dollars after a recent slide was another feature of foreign exchange trading. The absence of significant economic reports being released this week and the onset of month-end investment maneuvers were expected to mute activity in the currency markets, dealers said. The start of the European holiday season also was expected to restrain currency trading. Continuing uncertainty over the economic consequences of German unification put pressure on the mark. Concerns have resurfaced as the day of German monetary union approaches on July 2. The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo by rising to 155.62 Japanese yen at the close from 154.75 yen Friday. Later, in London, it was quoted at 155.35 yen. The dollar traded at 155.40 yen late in New York, up from 154.90 yen Friday. The British pound fell in London to $1.7300 from $1.7330 late Friday. A pound fetched $1.7305 late in New York, weaker than late Friday's level of $1.7330. Selected late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6775 West German marks, up from 1.6740; 1.4100 Swiss francs, down from 1.4110; 5.6315 French francs, up from 5.6215; 1,225.25 Italian lire, down from 1,226.75; and 1.17705 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17855. The Canadian dollar rebounded modestly from a selloff sparked by the failure of the Meech Lake accord, a plan designed to preserve the country's unity by recognizing French-speaking Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels were: 1.6775 West German marks, up from 1.6737; 1.4110 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085; 5.6335 French francs, up from 5.6220; 1.8830 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8835; 1,228.50 Italian lire, up from 1,227.25; and 1.1792 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1816. Gold and silver prices rose in precious metals trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for June delivery rose $3.40 to $353.80 a troy ounce. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted a troy ounce of gold bullion at $352.80 as of 4 p.m. EDT, $3.30 higher than Friday's late bid. In London, gold rose to a late bid price of $353.50 a troy ounce from Friday's late bid of $348.75. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $353.50 from $349.40 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 59 cents to close at a bid of $352.87. In New York silver trading, silver for June delivery closed at $4.816 a troy ounce on the Comex, compared to $4.81 on Friday. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce from $4.83 late Friday.

Leading the decline was Caterpillar Inc.'s report of sharply lower earnings projections for the second quarter. That raised fears that broader corporate earnings prospects overall might be weaker than anticipated. Caterpillar plunged 5 to 58{. Meanwhile, interest rates on the Treasury's 30-year bond climbed above 8.50 percent during a market sell-off triggered by oversupply concerns as a wave of government auctions began. J.C. Penney said its sales for June were off last year's pace and an investment bank downgraded the company's earnings estimates for 1991 and 1992, indicating weakness in the retail economy. J.C. Penney was off 2~ to 59~, Woolworth fell ~ to 32~ and K mart was off ] to 35. Peter Canelo, chief portfolio strategist at Bear, Stearns & Co., said ``there's clearly apprehension and it relates primarily to interest rates.'' ``The consumer economy is somewhat sluggish and there is some concern that will spread to the industrial companies,'' he said. Higher interest rates tend to stifle economic growth and raise the costs of doing business. Stocks sold off sharply late Friday in computer-program selling by traders engaged in multiple strategies involving stock-index options and futures. Some buyers re-entered the market early Monday, pushing the Dow Jones average up more than 10 points in early trading. But little enthusiasm for a rally was generated and stocks pulled back. Analysts said trading was extremely light Monday. They also said some program sell orders contributed to the decline. Buyers were scarce, they said. Among actively traded issues, Philip Morris gained 1} to 46]. The company on Friday announced it was acquiring 80 percent of the Swiss coffee and chocolate maker Jacobs Suchard. Foxboro jumped 12~ to 51. The British company Siebe PLC agreed to acquire the company for $52 a share. Wellman tumbled 3\ to 28\ after DuPont, a competitor in the polyester fiber business, cut the price of some dacron fiver products by 6 percent to 8 percent. Some analysts said the drop in Caterpillar may have been an overreaction since the agricultural equipment company said more than half its second-quarter earnings drop was due to problems in Brazil. Still, Tenneco, a competitor, fell 1{ to 65|. Honeywell rose 1} to 98\. A federal court announced appointment of a special master to handle Honeywell's longstanding patent-infringement case against Minolta. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market declined $27.51 billion, or 0.81 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.64 to 192.60. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.47 to 413.63, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 3.12 to 352.31. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market declined 3.69 to 455.64. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 357.39, down 1.89.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Talk Boosts Corn, Bean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Forecasts for a Midwestern heat wave helped push corn and soybean futures prices up sharply Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid fears that an extended dry spell could harm tender young sprouts. Wheat futures closed narrowly mixed, reflecting perceptions that hot, dry weather would benefit the maturing winter wheat crop. On other commodity markets, precious metals advanced; copper fell; energy futures were mixed; livestock futures were mixed; and pork bellies declined the daily limit for the third straight day. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures settled 3 cents lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.33{ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 8 cents higher with July at $2.87 a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 12 cents to 19 cents higher with July at $6.12} a bushel. A high pressure sytem featuring temperatures in the 90s is expected to edge into the western Corn Belt from the Southwest by Wednesday. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said a heat wave of three to five days would benefit crops flooded by last week's rains in Iowa, Missouri and Illinois. Dry weather also would allow Midwestern farmers to finish their soybean planting, which was 89 percent complete as of Sunday compared with a five-year average of 93 percent, according to the Agriculture Department's weekly crop-progress report. But if the expected heat lasts beyond five days, young plants could be damaged, and traders will ``start pushing the panic button,'' Karlin said. ``It's not uncommon for these high-pressure systems to become entrenched in an area for a fairly long while, eight to 10 days,'' he said. ``At that point, you would have dried out the topsoil to an undesirable degree.'' A six-to-10-day National Weather Service outlook released after the close did not threaten an extended heat wave, though. It predicted normal temperatures and above-average precipitation for the Midwest during the period July 1-July 5. The USDA crop progress report also showed slight deterioration last week in the conditions of the soybean and winter wheat crops while the corn crop improved slightly. Gold futures posted their strongest gains in five weeks on New York's Commodity Exchange, climbing more than $3 an ounce on indications of buying interest by Japanese investors and several central banks. Gold settled $3.40 to $3.50 higher with June at $353.80 a troy ounce; silver was 0.2 cent to 0.4 cent higher with July at $4.822 a troy ounce. Copper futures fell moderately on the Commodity Exchange, reflecting ideas that supplies are likely to grow as demand slows during the summer months. Copper settled 1.6 cents to 2.85 cents lower with June at $1.095 a pound. Crude oil futures slipped in lackluster trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gasoline futures showed strength, though, boosted by gains in the cash market and strong dealer demand ahead of the Fourth of July holiday. West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 4 cents to 13 cents lower with August at $17.38 a barrel; heating oil was .17 cent lower to .26 cent higher with July at 48.92 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .15 cents to 1.06 cents higher with July at 62.27 cents a gallon. Near-term pork belly futures fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for the third straight day, mostly in reaction to a government report Friday that showed a larger-than-expected supply of bellies in the nation's commercial freezers. Cattle futures also finished mostly lower, reflecting slack packer demand for animals and weaker retailer demand for beef products. Live cattle settled unchanged to .17 cent lower with August at 73.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .28 cent lower with August at 84.47 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .75 cent higher with August at 58.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to .45 cent higher with July at 57.40 cents a pound.

Wheat futures closed narrowly mixed, reflecting perceptions that hot, dry weather would benefit the maturing winter wheat crop. A high pressure system featuring temperatures in the 90s is expected to edge into the western Corn Belt from the Southwest by Wednesday. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said a heat wave of three to five days would benefit crops flooded by last week's rains in Iowa, Missouri and Illinois and allow Midwestern farmers to finish their soybean planting. But if the expected heat lasts beyond five days, young plants could be damaged, and traders will ``start pushing the panic button,'' Karlin said. At the close, wheat futures were 4\ cents lower to \ cent higher with July at $3.33\ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 8 cents higher with July at $2.86} a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 12 cents to 17} cents higher with July at $6.12 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Armco to Record $70 Million Second Quarter Charge
DOC.TEXT: Armco Inc. announced Monday it would record about $70 million in second-quarter charges against earnings because of costs from a breach-of-contract suit and federal tax assessment against the steelmaker. A charge against earnings is an accounting practice used by companies to reflect unusual expenses. A $20 million charge relates to a 1986 lawsuit filed against Armco in Houston. The case ended May 11 when a jury awarded the plaintiffs $46.8 million. That judgment was later reduced by $26 million, Armco said in a statement. AWH-1 Ltd. and MBank filed the lawsuit after Armco decided not to occupy an office building that was built for it. Shortly after the filing, MBank was seized by federal banking regulators and acquired by Bank One Texas, company spokesman James Herzog said. The steelmaker also paid $15 million to settle federal taxes and interest for the tax years between 1978 and 1982. The charges also include an estimated $30 million for Armco Financial Services Group companies, subsidiaries that the parent is liquidating. As a result of the charges, Armco said it expected to report unspecified losses for the second-quarter and first half of 1990. The charges also prevent Armco from paying common stock dividends, the statement said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS model name in 7th graf, Sony is, to DTC-75ES; picks up 8th graf, Digital audio
DOC.HEAD: Empty Shelves, Waiting Lists After Weekend Debut of DAT
DOC.TEXT: Booming business greeted the weekend debut of Sony Corp.'s digital audio tape deck, and by Monday many stores were sold out of the biggest item to hit the recording industry since compact discs. Nationwide sales figures had not been compiled Monday, but company officials and store owners were pleased. ``I don't think people stormed the doors, but it was generally very successful,'' said Shari Haber, spokeswoman for Sony in Park Ridge, N.J. All 18 units stocked by the nine United Audio Centers stores in the Chicago area sold out Saturday, said Bob Goldsmith, manager of a Chicago outlet. ``It's a very exciting product. I wish we had more of them,'' Goldsmith said. ``I think we could have sold six or seven more of them easily. I've got a waiting list with a few people on it now.'' United Audio is the only Chicago-area dealer carrying the high-end unit, the DTC-75ES, released Friday. Sony could only supply two units to each store in time for weekend sales, but Goldsmith said another shipment is due this week. Sony is the only electronics company selling popular priced DAT machines in the United States. Its DTC-75ES lists for $950. Another model, the DTC-700, will go on sale this week for $50 less, Ms. Haber said. Digital audio tapes are about half the size of conventional cassettes and about twice as expensive. Sony offers 60-minute, 90-minute and 120-minute tapes for $12, $15 and $18 respectively, Ms. Haber said. Digital audio tape, or DAT, decks offer the sound fidelity of compact discs. Their introduction to the U.S. market had been held up by record companies, who feared DAT's ability to make near-perfect recordings of compact discs will encourage pirating and cut into disc sales. That issue was for the most part resolved last summer, however, when an agreement was reached on new technology that would allow digital copies of compact discs, but not copies of the resulting tapes. The accord had seemed to resolve the threat that U.S. record companies would sue manufacturers if their DAT machines did not have some type of anti-copying technology. But George Scarlett, product manager for Tower Records in Sacramento, Calif., noted that for every new technology, there grows a cottage industry intent on cracking it. ``I am sure there are hobbyists at home that will find their way around the circuitry on these things,'' Scarlett said. Felix Loo, who manages Disc-O-Rama Music World in New York, said he has been selling ``gray market'' DAT machines imported directly from Japan, at an average price of $1,200, for more than a year. ``We've sold a lot of units,'' said Loo, who declined to give specific figures. Salesman David Moseley of Sony ES-By Grove Audio Video in Houston would not say how many units the store was carrying. None will be sold until Saturday when the store carries in ad in local newspaper business sections. ``Consumers are interested. They are cautious. They are confused with all the different formats, but I think that most consumers understand that this will eventually replace the cassette as we know it today,'' Moseley said. ``What will happen is the way the LP and the cassette coexisted happily, we'll have the CD and DAT coexist happily,'' Moseley said. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., the Japan firm that produces the Panasonic, Technics and Quasar brands, hopes to introduce a DAT recorder in the U.S. market some time this year. Matsushita's unit will cost about $1,300, the company said at the Consumer Electronics Show here earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Agrees to New Labels for Little People Toys
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price has agreed to place warnings on packages cautioning consumers that its Little People figures present a choking hazard to children, the state attorney general said Monday. The toy, sold separately and as part of various Fisher-Price play sets, have been linked to the choking deaths of at least five children nationwide and left one child severely brain damaged, Attorney General Robert Abrams said. The company also agreed to pay the state a $25,000 penalty, Abrams said. The toy firm, based in East Aurora, N.Y., agreed to place labels on all packages beginning next month and print warnings directly onto packages by next year. Fisher-Price spokeswoman Carol Blackley said the company's packages already bear a warning that the product is not intended for children who still put objects in their mouths. She said the new labels will warn consumers about the potential choking hazard. The toy manufacturer, a division of the Chicago-based Quaker Oats company, says it has sold 670 million Little People toys. The figures, hollow and often less than one inch in diameter, are marketed for children ages 2 to 6. The toys meet federal safety guidelines. But Abrams said the company's present packaging does not adequately disclose the potential choking hazard, in violation of New York's general business law prohibiting deceptive trade practices. Abrams had asked the Consumer Product Safety Commission in 1987 to change federal regulations governing the size of toys that can be sold to children under age three, but his request was denied. Edward Barbini, a spokesman for the attorney general, said Abrams would continue pressing for changes on the federal level.

DOC.HEAD: Plaintiffs Add Two Charges to Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for 912 West Virginians suing Ashland Oil Inc. over alleged health and property damage added charges of fraud and obstruction of justice to their lawsuit Monday. The complaint filed in Kanawha County Circuit Court asks for $110 million in damages, boosting the amount sought in the suit to $2.91 billion. The residents allege emissions from Ashland Oil's refinery complex in nearby Catlettsburg, Ky., have hurt their health and property. Ashland Oil has denied the claims and has said no link has been made between its emissions and any alleged health problems. Ashland Oil has been hit by a $10.3 million judgment in the first of several jury trials expected to stem from the lawsuit. Four plaintiffs will share in that award if it withstands appeal; the rest involved in the suit will bring their claims to trial in groups of five. The amended lawsuit said the fraud charge stemmed from a February 1988 letter Ashland Oil Chairman John Hall wrote to Kenova-area residents. Hall's letter said emissions from the refinery were a ``nuisance'' but were harmless, when they in fact contained toxic calcium oxide, the suit said. In addition, before and during the initial jury trial, Ashland Oil allegedly ``expended large amounts of corporate funds in and around Kanawha County'' to promote the company, the new complaint said. At the same time, plaintiffs, witnesses and some news reporters covering the matter were threatened and harassed, the suit said. Ashland Oil spokesman Roger Schrum said Monday ``the allegations of fraud and obstruction of justice are false and ridiculous.''

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Says Profits to Drop Substantially In Second Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. forecast a sharp drop in its second-quarter and 1990 earnings Monday, largely blaming the business impact of Brazil's economic austerity program for hurting its results. Caterpillar projected its annual profits will be ``substantially lower than in 1989,'' when it earned $497 million. The 1989 results represented a 19 percent drop from the previous year's record profit of $616 million. Revenue is expected to remain flat this year, matching the record $11.1 billion of 1989. The Peoria-based maker of farm and industrial equipment said its results would be affected adversely by the Brazilian government's efforts to slow inflation and increase competition. ``We knew the government's plans to restore Brazil's financial viability would be severe and would cause us some short-term problems. But we support the government's actions,'' said company spokesman Richard E. Stober. Stober said sales volumes would be lower, but higher prices would compensate for the drop. Second-quarter results, due out July 20, will be more than 50 percent below the $99 million profit in the first quarter, Stober said. In the second quarter last year, Caterpillar earned $141 million on sales of $2.9 billion. The first quarter earnings were down 30 percent from the $141 million earned during the same period a year earlier, although sales improved 10 percent to $2.86 billion. Stober said sales in Brazil have been relatively strong, but ``without any price relief. The government has frozen all the prices, and it appears we will be selling at a loss for the year in Brazil.'' Caterpillar employs 5,100 of its 60,000-member worldwide workforce at two plants in Brazil. Workers there build gas, diesel and marine engines, generator sets, winches, as well as an assortment of wheel loaders, tractor scrapers, bull dozers, rippers, motor graders and track-type tractors. In 1989, Caterpillar's Latin American territory, including Mexico, Central America and South America, bought $447 million of equipment manufactured at the company's U.S. factories. In addition, Caterpillar sold $382 million worth of products made in Latin America. Other factors contributing to Caterpillar's profit decline include tight U.S. monetary policies and higher inflation, Stober said. Also, a costly plant modernization program is taking longer than expected and costing more than projected. Caterpillar says that with no further deterioration in the world economy and a more stable economy in Brazil, its profits are expected to improve in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Agree To Settle Microprocessor Patent Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. said Monday they have agreed to settle an 18-month legal battle over powerful computer chips that form the brains for several popular computer lines. The two companies also will jointly seek a stay of a court order barring them from manufacturing and selling the products, Motorola said in a statement. Motorola, based in Schamburg outside Chicago, charged in a 1989 lawsuit that Hitachi of Japan had infringed on several of its patents and engaged in unfair competition in the sale of computer microprocessors. U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton, in Midland, Texas, on June 18 barred Motorola from marketing its M68030 microprocessor. He also barred Hitachi from marketing its similar, but far less widely used, H8532 chip. A day later the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington granted Motorola's motion to delay Bunton's order. Motorola said Monday the two companies jointly will seek a stay from the appeals court, pending appeal of the case. Providing the court issues the stay, both companies will continue to supply their customers with the products while they work to finalize their agreement to settle the case, Motorola said. A Motorola spokeswoman declined to elaborate on the statement, which said officials of the two companies ``have reached an agreement in principle that will serve as a framework'' for ending the dispute. Motorola shipped 500,000 of its M68030 chips last year, yielding what analysts estimated to be $100 million in revenue. The chip is used in the more advanced lines of computers produced by such companies as Apple Computer Inc., Hewlett Packard Corp. and Sun Microsystems Inc. Hitachi's similar H8532 microprocessor was distributed only to about 200 customers in Japan and to none in the United States, Hitachi has said. A microprocessor is a digital electronic device that performs the control and arithmetic functions of a computer.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Trade Negotiators Begin Final Round Of ``Structural'' Talks
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the United States disagreed Monday over specific plans for structural reforms of the Japanese economy, but a senior U.S. official said progress was made and the talks were ``friendly and cooperative.'' Monday's meetings began a final round of trade talks dubbed the Structural Impediments Initiative. Officials said they focused on Japan's plans for changing policies and business practices that are thought to impede imports and foreign investment. The two sides remained apart on the issue of public works spending, said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition he not be further identified. Japan has agreed, at U.S. urging, to spend more on parks, roads, sewers and other public infrastructure, both to stimulate more imports and to reduce the imbalance between savings and investment in this thrifty nation. But the two sides disagree over the amount needed to significantly affect the trade imbalance. U.S. officials said earlier they were hoping for a 500 trillion yen, or $3.22 trillion, public works package for the next 10 years. They also said they would like Japan to promise to spend a certain percentage of its gross national product on such projects. Japanese officials, however, have indicated they favor spending between 400 trillion and 415 trillion yen, or $2.58 trillion to $2.68 trillion, in the next decade on public works. So far, they have rejected the request to specify what portion of GNP they will spend on public works, saying this would limit their ability to adapt public spending to changing economic conditions. The U.S. official, who attended Monday's talks, declined to specify the figures being considered. But, he said, ``We noted the current figure under discussion would not represent a significant increase relative to the size of the Japanese economy.'' Japan also has pledged to ease rules on opening retail stores, speed up processing of patent applications, crack down on allegedly unfair business practices by corporate groups and revise its land use policies. The changes are aimed at making the Japanese economy more open to trade and foreign investment. Senior Japanese officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the talks were ``relatively constructive.'' ``I think the Americans were satisfied about some things, and dissatisfied about others,'' one of the officials said. On Tuesday, the talks will focus on U.S. plans to do more to cut the federal budget deficit, encourage savings, curb excessive consumption and improve worker training and education _ changes aimed at boosting U.S. export competitiveness. Washington has ``filled in the gaps and increased the specificity'' of pledges it made in an interim report on the talks in April, the U.S. official said. He declined to explain specific measures taken. The official said Washington expects reforms initiated during the talks to have a noticeable impact on trade imbalances in the ``medium term ... about two or three years.'' But he said the impact was likely to be more apparent in the two nations' overall trade imbalances than in their bilateral trade accounts. Meanwhile in Washington, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills raised the possibility that the July deadline for reaching agreement on a final report in the structural barriers negotiations may not be met. Hills said it may be necessary to hold another round of talks if all of the issues are not resolved at this week's bargaining session. ``We will continue to talk until the job is done. If there needs to be another meeting, so be it,'' Hills said during a speech to a trade conference sponsored by the Institute for International Economics. Failure to reach agreement by the original deadline of early July opens the threat that U.S.-Japan trade problems would cast a pall over the July 9-11 Houston summit of the world's seven richest industrial countries. In her speech, Hills raised the spectre of a backlash against Japanese imports in the United States if the current talks fail to expand foreign business opportunities in Japan. ``We simply must have Japan open up faster,'' she said. ``Japan isn't open and until we get that parity of opportunity we will have an enormous buildup of antagonism that creates a backdrop for very bad public policy.'' Japan's trade surplus with the United States last year was $49 billion, according to the U.S. Commerce Department. Its global trade surplus was $76.92 billion. The United States posted a total trade deficit of $109 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Won't Intervene in Company Sale
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided not to intervene in a takeover offer for Norton Co. by a British company after reviewing the deal from a national security standpoint, it was announced Monday. An economist in the Treasury Department's investment office, speaking on condition he not be further identified, acknowleged that a takeover by Britain's BTR PLC is no longer likely, although BTR's offer is ``still on the table.'' Norton has agreed to be acquired instead by Compagnie de Saint Gobain, a French concern. The official did not say whether the government would investigate the French company. Norton announced the $1.8 billion Saint Gobain offer late last month. Norton, of Worcester, Mass., manufactures abrasive products and engineering materials and is a leader in development of advanced ceramics and diamond films. A 1988 law authorizes the president to investigate and, if necessary, to suspend or prohibit the purchase of an American business by a foreign company on national security grounds. Norton does have contracts with the Defense Department.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Co., Gulf States Reach Settlement in Power Sales Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Southern Co. said Monday it has reached a tentative agreement worth $300 million to settle a dispute over an energy sales contract with Gulf States Utilities Co. The agreement, which is subject to federal regulatory approval, would end all litigation between Atlanta-based Southern and Gulf States, which is based in Beaumont, Texas. The dispute stemmed from a 1982 deal by four Southern utility subsidiaries to sell $1 billion worth of electricity to Gulf States from 1984 through 1992. But in 1985, Gulf States asked Southern to suspend or end the sales, saying its customers' energy needs had fallen below expected levels. Southern said Gulf States discontinued most payments in 1986. Southern subsequently stopped all transactions with the company. Southern contended that Gulf States was required to continue accepting, and paying for, the electric power. But Gulf States argued the contract required good faith negotiations whenever changes in purchases were requested. The case went before Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and the U.S. Supreme Court. A separate suit is still pending in the U.S. District Court in Texas. Under the proposed settlement, Southern will receive $75 million in cash, 6 million new shares of Gulf States common stock with ``very limited'' voting rights and a $160 million promissory note payable on Jan. 1, 1993. The settlement says that if the highest price of Gulf States common stock does not average $18.25 a share for five consecutive days through Jan. 1, 1993, Southern will get a cash payment for the difference between the average price and $18.25 a share. The agreement has a net present value of about $300 million, Southern said. Gulf States is putting its Lewis Creek power plant near Willis, Texas, up as collateral for future payments under the settlement. ``We're pleased that we've been able to resolve this contract dispute in out-of-court negotiations and come to terms that protect the long-term interests of our companies,'' said Southern President Ed Addison. Addison said it was too early to say what effect the settlement would have on Southern's earnings. Gulf States Chairman Linn Draper said the settlement avoids the possibility that litigation over the dispute would drag on for years. ``This dark cloud has in many ways hampered our ability to look to the future,'' Draper said. ``GSU management believes that removing this cloud at this time and in this manner is in the best interests of the company, its shareholders and its customers.'' Draper said Gulf States' cash outlay for the settlement through 1999 could be as little as $167 million. The Southern Co. is the corporate parent of Alabama Power Co., Georgia Power Co., Mississippi Power Co., Gulf Power Co. and Savannah Electric Co. At the time of the contract with Gulf States, Savannah Electric was not part of Southern. Gulf States does business primarily in Texas and Louisiana.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The company ...' to CLARIFY that figure is income before taxes.
DOC.HEAD: Foxboro Company Makes Deal for Takeover by Britain's Siebe
DOC.TEXT: Foxboro Co., a leading international maker of manufacturing control systems, has agreed to a $656.4 million marriage for cash with the British firm Siebe PLC, provided Siebe stockholders consent, the companies said Monday. Under terms of the deal, the Windsor, England, company would buy Foxboro's 12.6 million outstanding shares for $52 a share, in a cash tender offer to begin Friday. Siebe shareholders will be asked to vote on the offer by July 27, Siebe said in a statement. Siebe PLC is a leading manufacturer of industrial and environmental controls, compressed-air products, specialized engineering products and life-support products. In the year ended March 31, Siebe had record sales of $2.35 billion. Pre-tax profits rose 19 percent to $310 million. Foxboro systems are used to record and control manufacturing processes such as temperature, pressure, humidity and liquid levels. Most of its customers, which include Exxon Corp. and Dow Chemical Co., are in the chemical and petroleum industries. An 82-year-old company with an old and loyal customer base and 7,000 employees, Foxboro recently emerged from a restructuring. It has a new product line that enables Foxboro systems to be integrated with those of other companies. But bugs in the new product had to be worked out and for the past four years the company has been borrowing money to pay for its operations. The company reported 1989 net sales of $598 million and income before taxes of $1.5 million. Foxboro stock also has been flat. Earlier this month, before rumors of a possible sale, stock sold for $24 a share. Last year it traded as low as $18.62. The stock soared Monday after the possible merger was announced, closing at $51 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up $12.87{ from Friday's closing price. Barrie Stephens, Siebe vice president and chief executive officer, said Foxboro Co. would operate as an independent subsidiary and maintain its current headquarters. ``We will benefit from combined technologies, products and distribution capabilities allowing us to increase our activities in various segments of the controls business,'' Stephens said in a prepared statement. Gary Willis, Foxboro chairman, president and chief executive officer, called Siebe an ideal merger partner for his company. The British buyer's strategy, he said, ``is to create a geographically diversified single source controls company.'' John C. Fuller, a member of the Foxboro board and vice president for investor relations, said Siebe was among several new partners the company considered. The British company, which dates back to the early 19th century, was the higher bidder, and also promised to suit Foxboro's need to expand in an increasingly competitive marketplace, he said. ``As we've gone through our long-term strategic planning, looking at the '90s, we see much larger and broader-based competition facing us,'' Fuller said. ``We felt that Foxboro, as a single, control-based company, needed a larger technological base and an ability to provide more capability to our customers.'' About two weeks ago Foxboro satisfied takeover rumors by disclosing it was seeking a possible purchase. ``One has to be very happy for shareholders, it's a premium of near-record magnitude,'' said analyst John W. Adams of Adams Harkness & Hill in Boston, noting more typically such offers come in at 30 or 40 percent above what a stock regularly commands. Adams said the company ``was undervalued, if you assumed it was going to be well-managed.'' ``Neverthless, one has to mourn the passing of yet another independent New England company,'' Adams said, referring to such recent international change of hands as the takeover of Norton Co. Norton, a Worcester-based maker of abrasives, is awaiting government approval to merge with the French Compagnie de Saint Gobain, after fighting off a hostile takeover bid by Britain's BTR PLC. Robert Sullivan, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc. in New York, called the price for Foxboro fair. He saw no obstacles to the merger. ``I am told the financing's lined up. I don't see any anti-trust fears. So I see it happening,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Concern Buys Jetliner Leasing Outfit
DOC.TEXT: International Lease Finance Corp., a major aircraft leaser, agreed Monday to be acquired by American International Group Inc. for $1.3 billion to gain the financial backing of the insurance giant. AIG, the largest U.S. underwriter of commercial and industrial insurance, also will provide ILFC with $125 million in financing as part of the deal. Analysts and spokesmen said the deal gives ILFC financial muscle at a time when the leasing outfit must borrow heavily to complete an ambitious expansion. ``They've found someone with lots of cash, low cost of funds, and willing to take some greater risk in return for greater rewards,'' said Daniel A. Hersch, a securities analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles. ILFC, one of the world's biggest aircraft leasing companies, owns 98 jetliners worth more than $3 billion and averaging only three years of age. It has placed $10 billion worth of firm orders for planes to be delivered over 10 years, and has another $4 billion in options. That means ILFC, which already has had to borrow heavily and occasionally issue new stock to finance its deals, will need much more capital at a time when it is harder to come by. ``I think that having a strategic alliance with a backer of the stature and credit-worthiness of AIG should instill a greater confidence in the financial markets,'' Jay Jacobsen, a spokesman for ILFC, said in a telephone interview from New York. ILFC will continue to borrow in the markets to raise capital, Jacobsen said. AIG's triple-A debt rating, the highest ranking possible, will enable ILFC to borrow funds more cheaply. The deal also helps AIG further its goal of increasing its financial services business, such as leasing, said Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based insurer. The company had operating income of about $150 million in financial services other than insurance last year out of total operating income of nearly $2 billion, Greenberg said. The company hopes to boost that figure to close to $500 million in the next couple of years, he said. The buyout price of $32.50 a share is about 15 or 16 times expected earnings for this year, at the top of the recent trading range for ILFC stock, Hersch said. The stock closed at $26.87{ in over-the-counter trading Monday. It had sunk as low as $19.37{ in the past year. Jacobsen said the stock had been undervalued because of investor worries over debt, despite the fact that ILFC's purchase agreements for Boeing and other planes are at extremely good prices. ``The asset values were substantially above the stock price,'' he said. ILFC's management will be unchanged and the company will continue to be based in Beverly Hills, operating as a wholly owned AIG subsidiary. It is 53 percent owned by three men, all of whom have approved the merger: Leslie L. Gonda, the board chairman; Steven F. Udvar-Hazy, president and chief executive; and Louis L. Gonda, executive vice president. The definitive agreement has been approved by AIG's executive committee, by ILFC's directors, and by a special committee of ILFC's independent directors, the companies said in a joint news statement. Under the deal, ILFC shareholders can receive $32.50 a share in cash or 50 cents a share plus 0.3 shares of AIG common stock. The amount of AIG stock to be exchanged can be adjusted depending on AIG's share price at the time the deal closes. ILFC's three controlling owners have agreed to accept AIG stock for their holdings, Jacobsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson Announces Layoffs of 850 Marshall Field's Employees
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Department Store Co. announced plans Monday to lay off more than half of Marshall Field & Co.'s 1,550 employees at its Chicago headquarters. The 850 layoffs will occur over the next six months, Dayton Hudson said. They will not affect the more than 13,000 employees at Marshall Field's stores and warehouses. On Friday, the Federal Trade Commission cleared the way for Dayton Hudson to acquire Chicago-based Marshall Field's for about $1.05 billion. Gary Witkin, Marshall Field's former executive vice president of stores, has been named president of the Field's unit. Field's Chairman Philip B. Miller and President Burnett W. Donoho announced their resignations April 20, the day after Dayton Hudson announced it would consolidate Field's administrative and buying operations at Dayton Hudson's Minneapolis headquarters. Sue Sorensen, a Dayton Hudson spokeswoman, said the layoffs would include management, buyers and financial and advertising executives. Dayton Hudson will honor the existing Marshall Field's severance policy for all employees being laid off, the company said. It also has hired a placement company to assist laid-off employees find new jobs. The department store division of Dayton Hudson Corp. had 1989 revenues were $1.8 billion and operating profit of $179 million. The division now includes 17 Dayton's stores, based in Minneapolis; 20 Hudson's stores, based in Detroit, and 24 Field's stores, based in Chicago. The division now employs about 31,000 people. Marshall Field's, sold by BAT Industries PLC as part of a restructuring, had revenue of about $1.1 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: PPG Plans Joint Venture with Japan's Itoh
DOC.TEXT: PPG Industries Inc. plans to form a joint venture with C. Itoh & Co. Ltd. to sell and distribute flat glass in Japan. PPG, the world's largest maker of flat glass products, said Monday it would own 51 percent of the new company, PPG-CI Co. Ltd. The joint venture would sell only PPG products. Art Marino, a spokesman for PPG, said the glass is sought by the automotive and construction industries in Japan. The vice president of PPG's flat glass products division, Joseph Cafaro, said the venture will be well positioned because of ``C. Itoh's reputation in and knowledge of the Japanese marketplace.'' C. Itoh & Co. is an independent Japanese trading company. PPG has a long-standing joint venture with Asahi Chemical Industry Co. Ltd., a Japanese chemical manufacturer, Marino said. PPG has been looking to expand further internationally, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Natural Gas Co. Agrees to Pay $300 Million for ARCO Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Southern Natural Gas Co. has agreed to pay ARCO Oil and Gas Co. more than $300 million for damages that resulted from an explosion on an ARCO drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico last year. The March 19, 1989, blast and resulting fire killed seven people, injured 23 and destroyed the platform. The blast occurred while workers for Southern Natural Gas were attempting to make repairs on the platform. Representatives agreed on the settlement Monday during a recess in a civil trial that began June 11 in State District Court in Madison County. They presented the agreement to Judge Bill McAdams while he was holding court in neighboring Grimes County. ``We feel we've been adequately compensated for our losses,'' said Don Riddle, lead counsel for ARCO. ``Aside from Pennzoil, it's the largest settlement around as far as anybody knows,'' Riddle told the Bryan-College Station Eagle. Pennzoil Co. in 1984 won a $10.3 billion judgment against Texaco Inc. after claiming that Texaco had broken up its deal to buy Getty Oil Co. Texaco agreed to settle the case for $3 billion in 1988. Houston attorney Randy Wilson, one of about 20 attorneys representing Southern Natural Gas, declined to comment on the settlement. According to the settlement, Southern Natural Gas made no admission of guilt but agreed to pay ARCO $300.5 million by Aug. 6, and to pay a total of $500,000 to three ARCO employees injured in the explosion. ARCO was a party to several lawsuits pending against Southern Natural Gas in federal court in Louisiana. The settlement will end those suits, Riddle said. The settlement will be paid by the gas company's insurance carriers, primarily Lloyd's of London, Riddle said. ARCO had asked for between $250 million and $325 million in actual damages and $5 billion in exemplary damages resulting from the explosion on a drilling platform about five miles south of the mouth of the Mississippi River. In addition to damage to the platform itself, ARCO claimed it lost about $200 million in profits from oil and natural gas sales because the destroyed platform was crucial to a seven-platform oil field. Southern Natural Gas bought natural gas from ARCO and transported it to shore by means of pipeline running from the platform. The explosion occurred when subcontractors hired by the gas company cut into the pipeline while trying to make repairs.
